PROCTEXT.PARA: The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Douglas McClelland) took the chair at 10 a.m., and read prayers.

TALK.START.PARA: —Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:

PETITION.TITLE: Australian Capital Territory: Self-Government
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That in November 1978 more than sixty two per cent of the voters of the Australian Capital territory in a Referendum rejected the introduction of Territorial Government or Local Government in the Australian Capital Territory;

That until the Government's decision on the Commonwealth grants Commission Inquiry into Australian Capital Territory finances have been made public and there has been a Referendum of the Australian Capital Territory as to their attitude to Territorial or Local Government;
Your petitioners most humbly pray that the Government take no further action or legislation in respect of Territorial or Local Government in the Australian Capital territory.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Taxation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:
Introduction of any additional capital gains taxes, wealth taxes or death duties is opposed on the grounds that:
they adversely affect the small and medium size businesses in Australia, destroying incentive and discouraging investment in this important area of the economy;
the Australian economy, and employment in particular, is heavily reliant on growth in small businesses;

any capital gains that might result when owners of small businesses finally sell the business are not ``windfall gains'' but the result of many hard years of work and sacrifice, with very little being taken out of the business by way of salaries so that the maximum amount of money can be ploughed back into the business to create growth and jobs;
Your petitioners request that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, will protect the rights of private enterprise and reject any inequitable additional taxes.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Nursing Home Benefits
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled; the humble petition of the undersigned citizens of South Australia respectfully showeth that:

Without any warning and at the worst possible moment, the Federal Government has abandoned the pensioner patients in South Australia's Nursing Homes. These people are suffering undeserving hardships and trauma as a result of the Federal Government's decision to freeze the nursing home benefit levels in South Australia.

The pensioner patients and those on fixed incomes now cannot expect any relief from recent significant fee increases approved by the Department of Community Services and which have coincided with the decision to freeze benefits.

80-85 per cent of nursing home patients are pensioners and the majority are now required to pay in excess of their pension for their nursing care for the very first time. Some are paying over $5 per day on top of their pension. Many are looking for cheaper nursing care that doesn't exist.
We request that the Federal Government:

1. alleviate the distress of South Australia's nursing home patients and their families by effective restoration of the principle that pensioner patients should not have to pay more than their pension for nursing home care
2. restore the review of the benefit rates in November 1985
3. resolve its concerns over health care costs with the South Australian Government rather than inflicting unnecessary suffering on nursing home patients.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Bill of Rights: Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That the Australian Bill of Rights will do nothing to advance the rights of Australians, because it is dangerously ambiguous and will cause confusion within the legal system; it endangers our Federal system; and, it is to be administered in an authoritarian manner inconsistent with the present legal rights of all Australians.
Your petitioners therefore pray:
That the Senate rejects the Australian Bill of Rights Bill and all cognate Bills.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Bill of Rights: Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned shows:
That the Bill of Rights and the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Bill
1. Offer nothing more than is already available under Common Law,
2. Deny some Human Rights and do not include others,
3. Give dangerously wide powers to an unelected body, and
4. Could cause far more damage than they could possibly cure.
Your petitioners request that the Senate should:
Completely reject both the Bill of Rights and the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Bill.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Bill of Rights Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:
The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia, respectfully showeth:

That the proposed Australian Bill of Rights 1985 will endanger the Federal system in Australia, the State and federal criminal justice systems, the State and Federal Police Force, the State and Federal education systems, the independence of the churches and religious associations, marriage and the family, children, the unborn, the handicapped, the aged and the infirm, employer and employee relationships and Australian society generally.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray:

That your Honourable House defer debate on the Bill for twelve months and circulate the Bill for twelve months for the widest possible debate, scrutiny and discussion, and your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Peter Baume (from 40 citizens), Brownhill (from 143 citizens) and Robertson (from 151 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Bill of Rights Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That the Australian Bill of Rights Bill is a harmful, dangerous and divisive proposal, the provisions of which are authoritarian and anti-democratic.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Senate rejects this Bill.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Sir John Carrick (from 92 citizens), Messner (from 64 citizens), Reid (from 42 citizens) and Robertson (from four citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Bill of Rights Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and the members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That the Australian Bill of Rights Bill is un-Australian and is designed to destroy the Federal System.
Your petitioners pray: That the Senate rejects this Bill.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senator Sir John Carrick (from 43 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Bill of Rights Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. In this session of Parliament the proposed Bill of Rights will come before the Senate to be debated.
We, the undersigned, would like to voice our protest at the proposed Bill.

1. Because of the haste and secrecy with which this legislation was passed through the House of Representatives despite the fact that it will adversely affect areas of immense importance to liberty and freedom and is contrary to the spirit of the Australian Constitution.

2. The Bill is based upon the United Nations International Covenant of Civil and Political Rights which has been rejected both by the United States of America and Great Britain but accepted by the Warsaw Pact countries. We therefore believe there is a potential threat to our national security through making treaties of this kind with foreign nations, many of whom do not practise the principles that they have covenanted to uphold.

3. Because our Australian Constitution states that ``whereas we the people'' give you the government these rights, the Constitution limits the rights and power of government. The proposed Bill of Rights reverses this totally and states that ``we the government give you the people these rights''. This totally reverses the nature of government in this country.
4. Our rights and the principles of freedom are now protected by current legislation, Common law and the present Constitution.
5. Because it transfers the powers of interpretation of legislation from the Parliament of Australia (the democratically elected institution) to the Courts (unelected body of people).

6. Because the Bill of Rights will be administrated by the Human Rights Commission which is an unelected body of people with powers which are outside and not subject to the normal processes of law-no appeal, closed hearings, no legal representation.

7. That the implementation of the legislation through a process of new educational initiatives will result in the centralised control of education and this will inevitably lead to the destruction of States' rights and just as inevitably the centralised control, by government, on human behaviour.
We therefore request that you vote to reject this proposed Bill of Rights in any shape or form being introduced in Australia.
Yours humbly

PETITION.TITLE: Bill of Rights Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That we oppose utterly and completely the proposed Bill of Rights 1985 Bill because it will:
Threaten our rights by making them subject to the will of the present and future Government
Give unjustifiable power to a commission not elected by the people namely the Human Rights Commission
Give no protection for the family, for private property for private trade and enterprise for the churches and freedom of worship or for the maintenance of the present judicial system.

As there has been no groundswell for a Bill of Rights from the greater part of the Australian community, it is our will that you take immediate action to prevent the Bill of Rights being passed by the Senate. And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Bill of Rights Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Tasmania showeth that: Your petitioners pray that Your Honourable House will reject the proposed Australian Bill of Rights Bill 1985 for the following reasons:

1. We believe as a matter of faith and judgment that the proposed legislation is anti-God and its implementation will result in attacks on the Christian church and the promotion of a State religion based on secular humanism;
2. That there is no need for legislation of this kind since the principles of freedom are already enshrined in Common Law and that it will cause more problems than it seeks to solve;

3. That there is a potential threat to our national security through making treaties of this kind with foreign nations, many of which do not share a common heritage and do not practise many of the principles that they have covenanted to uphold;

4. The methods being used to introduce this legislation are secretive and a blatant misuse of the external affairs powers under Section 51 of the Australian Constitution and that furthermore are contrary to the spirit of the Constitution;

5. That the implementation of the legislation through a process of new educational initiatives will result in the centralised control of education and this will inevitably lead to the destruction of States' rights. And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

DEBATE.TITLE: TRADE UNION TRAINING AUTHORITY AMENDMENT BILL 1986

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill received from the House of Representatives.
Ordered that the Bill may be taken through all its stages without delay.
Bill (on motion by Senator Gareth Evans) read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-

The Bill relates to the participation of officers and employees of the Trade Union Training Authority in the election of staff representatives to the regional councils for trade union training established in each State under the Trade Union Training Authority Act 1975. These regional councils have the role of advising the Australian Council for Union Training and ensuring that the training policies formulated by the Australian Council are implemented in their States by the local trade union training centres.

These elected positions were first provided for by amendments made to the Act by the Statute Law (Miscellaneous Provisions) Act (No. 1) 1985, which dealt with a number of matters relating to the structure and administration of the Trade Union Training Authority.

It was provided that there be a new position of staff representative on each regional council and it was intended that the holder of the position would be elected by and from those officers and employees of TUTA who performed their duties in the State for which the council was established. The officers and employees in TUTA establishments which are located in a State but which function at the national rather than the State level were to be precluded from participating in those elections because the regional councils are only concerned with the work of TUTA at the State level.

The national bodies to which I refer are the office of the National Director, the National Office and the Australian Trade Union Training College. Of course, persons employed at those establishments are eligible under the Act to participate in the election of the staff representative on the Australian Council for Union Training which has national responsibility for the formulation of TUTA's policy.

When the necessary election regulations were being prepared, however, it became apparent that the intended exclusion of national and college staff could not be given effect to under the 1985 provisions. Accordingly, the amendments contained in this Bill are designed to remove that difficulty and to give full effect to the intention of the 1985 amendments.
The Bill seeks to achieve that objective in the following manner.

Proposed paragraph 20 (1) (e) provides that a regional council is to include a representative of TUTA staff in that State elected by and from those staff and appointed to the council by the Minister. When read in conjunction with proposed sub-section 20 (5), this provision also limits the persons who may participate in the election to officers and employees of TUTA who are employed in relation to the State in which the regional council is located.

Proposed sub-section 20 (5) sets out the criteria for determining whether an officer or employee is to be regarded as employed in relation to a State for the purposes of the election pursuant to proposed paragraph 20 (1) (e).

As I have mentioned, officers and employees engaged in national functions are to be excluded from these elections and therefore the `non-regional offices' under the regulations will be the national director's office in Sydney and the national office in Wodonga. It was considered preferable to enable this to be done by regulation rather than to specify the offices concerned in the Act because of the possibility of changes in the future to their location.
Financial impact

The Proposed legislation has no significant financial impact. The costs of conducting the elections for staff representatives are expected to be small in view of the limited number of TUTA staff involved.

Mr President, the measures contained in recent amendments of the Act, including this Bill, will assist in the further development of an efficient, progressive and well-led trade union movement which is of crucial importance to all Australians.
The education of leaders and potential leaders of trade unions in developing and improving their skills and industrial knowledge is clearly a national responsibility.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.
Debate (on motion by Senator Lewis) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Referral to Standing Committee
Debate resumed from 11 February, on motion by Senator Durack:
That the Trade Practices Amendment Bill 1985 be referred to the Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —When the Senate was last considering the Trade Practices Amendment Bill 1985, I had moved a motion on behalf of the Opposition that the Bill, having been read a second time, should be referred to the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional And Legal Affairs for its detailed consideration of clauses of the Bill, instead of our now proceeding, as would normally be the case, to consider it in a Committee of the whole. I had commenced to state the Opposition's reasons why we thought that was the preferable course. I had emphasised that the Bill deals with many important and also very technical questions. The range of amendments to be moved to the Trade Practices Act is very great. The Opposition, the Government and the Australian Democrats wish to pursue a number of amendments and it would take up a great deal of the time of the Senate to consider such a great range of amendments. I suggest that that is not a suitable course, the amendments being of such a technical character, even though some are of enormous significance. Because they concern a very technical subject I propose that it would be better for them to be considered by the Constitutional and Legal Affairs Committee, which could have more time to devote to them than would the Senate. Indeed, it would be a great waste of most senators' time for there to be prolonged technical discussions in the Committee of the whole.

SPEECH.PARA: The other consideration which I wish to advance in support of the Opposition's case is that the amendments to the Act proposed by the Government have created a great deal of interest on the part of various organisations in the community which represent both sides of the debate. The Opposition has received representations from numerous groups and people. It really would be far more satisfactory if the people who have made representations came before the Committee and stated their cases. These could be fully examined by a body which represents all parties in this chamber. This would be preferable to a situation where we, in the course of a Committee debate in this place, would have to pick and choose between representations that have been made without as a whole having the advantage of directly hearing the views of organisations of high standing and importance in the community which are concerned with this matter. I believe that the people representing those organisations would be of great assistance to the Senate committee and, ultimately, to the Senate. The Committee, and ultimately the Senate as a whole, would be directly informed of their views. The Committee would also be able to question them in detail about their views and thereby senators would be in a better position to make a judgment about whether their proposals should be adopted.

The Opposition has opposed the second reading of the Bill. We still maintain our view that it is a bad Bill. It is highly regulatory; it will increase regulation in a very significant way. We believe that the appropriate course would be to defeat the Bill. Nevertheless, the Senate has taken a different view. We simply wish to pursue amendments to some clauses and oppose certain other clauses. Our amendments are by no means exhaustive and do not affect all clauses of the Bill. I think the Australian Democrats have taken a similar approach.

We do not believe that the Senate Committee should take a great deal of time to consider the Bill. Obviously, since we started to debate this question several weeks ago, major interest has been expressed in relation to one part of the Bill, namely, the proposal to remove the power of the Trade Practices Commission to investigate the acquisition of a monopoly. That matter should be resolved quickly by the Parliament. Therefore, we would not want to see the Committee delay in any way the ultimate resolution of this whole question by the Senate.

The Opposition is concerned to see that nothing we do in this Parliament should affect in any way the existing rights of either of the parties to the takeover offer for the Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd. However, the Opposition does not believe that the Government's amendment should be amended any further. It has been our policy from the beginning that, if we failed to defeat the Bill, we would want it examined by a committee. We believe that course should still be followed. At the same time we do not want to see the final decision on this matter by Parliament delayed. Clearly, the Trade Practices Commission has taken action which indicates that it wants to have the Parliament's view on this without further delay. It was expecting the matter to be resolved apparently before it took legal action.

No doubt highly relevant to what the Trade Practices Commission decides to do in the end is what this Parliament does about that section. Nevertheless, it is a matter for the Trade Practices Commission to decide, on the state of the law as it was at the time, what action it should take. We do not want to suggest to the Trade Practices Commission what it should do, but it is entitled to know what the Parliament proposes to do about this section for future cases and because of its great relevance to the case that it is having to deal with. I do not see the Committee consideration, therefore, as unduly delaying this matter. It is certainly not the Opposition's intention that it should do so, because we believe that the sooner this whole question can be resolved the better for all concerned.

I do not know that there is anything further I need say in support of our motion that the Bill as a whole be referred to the Senate Committee. As I say, if we do not take that step we will be spending a good deal of time in what will be an unsatisfactory debate in the Committee of the Whole whereas the matter will be dealt with, we believe, in a much more satisfactory way in the atmosphere of the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs. I commend that approach to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: — The Government opposes the motion to refer the matter to a Senate committee. I believe that we will have time in this place to deal effectively with those amendments which need proper consideration. Although the task is a big one, it is nothing like as big as the task we seem to have embarked upon with the Bill of Rights and I do not believe it need take us anything like as long as that. Let me explain why it need not take as long.
—I think there are more senators interested in the Bill of Rights though, don't you?

—I think there might be one or two interested in this legislation too. Let me explain why it should not take long. First of all, as to the consumer protection provisions, the majority of those amendments--
—I'm sorry, what did you say should not take long?

—I said that there are some amendments which are going to take us a deal of time, clearly, because there is a degree of interest in them, but the great bulk of the amendments should not delay us long, certainly not as long as another Bill presently before this place. First of all, the consumer protection amendments have been widely exposed; they are essentially of a non-controversial nature and have not attracted any criticism. They are, however, urgently required to close loop- holes in the Act and to remedy deficiencies in the coverage of the Act. Many of the amendments to Division 1 of Part V and related provisions are part of a uniform consumer protection legislation exercise with the States. State mirror legislation, which will confer benefits on consumers and businessmen alike, will be delayed further, or the States may, even worse, decide to implement non-uniform legislation instead.

SPEECH.PARA: Again I say in respect of the consumer protection provisions that passage of the product safety and information provisions in Division 1A to commence on 1 July 1986 is required now to allow suppliers time to prepare for the provisions coming into effect. As to the restrictive trade practices amendments, they again have been widely exposed and, in some cases, have been substantially modified to take into account our concerns and criticisms made in submissions on the Green Paper of February 1984. The major amendment in Part IV to strengthen section 46 is needed now to protect small business against anti-competitive price discrimination and refusal to supply. In addition, an effective section 46 is needed to prevent any potential abuse of market power which has been derived from recent acquisitions or mergers.

The amendments to section 50 primarily close loopholes and anomalies. It is important to proceed quickly with these amendments to prevent exploitation of the loopholes now that the legislative intention is clear. I am referring in particular to the possibility, not in the context of any takeover at current moment but more generally, of natural person takeovers or joint venture takeovers to circumvent the Act. These possibilities are of particular concern and need to be addressed urgently. It also hardly needs to be spelt out in relation to section 50 that one particular amendment to section 50 is a matter of very great moment indeed in the public domain at the moment and that any further delay in resolving the question of what the applicable law is in relation to section 50 as it applies to bare transfers and monopoly power will not serve anybody's interests.

The suggestion made by Senator Durack that this matter be delayed by reference to a Senate committee is, I would suggest, the worst of all possible worlds. There would be delay, which is clearly something which involves taking sides in this matter because delay clearly serves the interests of one particular party in the issue, but at the same time there would be no public inquiry proceeding as to the merits of the issue, which is what the Australian Democrats, for example, have indicated is their primary concern. So there would be delay without any compensating advantage to the public interest. As Senator Durack said in his contribution to the debate, the Trade Practices Commission has indicated publicly that it wants this matter clearly resolved by the Parliament as soon as possible. Indeed, I detected a certain half-hearted quality in Senator Durack's commitment to his motion at this stage by comparison with the fervour with which he advanced the cause when we were first dealing with this matter back in February.

Just to complete the record, though, might I say something about the record of consultation which has already occurred on the Trade Practices Amendment Bill, because I think that again lends very strong weight to the argument in favour of getting on with the business of resolving the outstanding issues in this chamber and not further delaying the Bill by reference to a committee. Leaving aside the new product recall provisions, the majority of the amendments were exposed to public comment in a Green Paper issued, as I said, back in February 1984. Following evaluation of the public comments received further consultations were held with industry groups, business groups, representatives of small business, consumer groups and the Law Council of Australia. Proposals for product recall provisions were discussed in a White Paper issued in June 1985-now nine months ago. This White Paper was the culmination in turn of discussion with industry and consumer groups on the subject since 1980. The views of the various groups were well established and the public comment received on the White Paper, the majority of which supported the Government's preferred option, did not raise any new points. It was therefore feasible to draft the necessary legislation quickly.

Since the introduction of the Bill on 9 October, now six months ago, further discussions have been held with the Law Council and the Metal Trades Industry Association of Australia. The Government strenuously denies any suggestion that, given the short time between the closing date for public comments on the product recall White Paper and the introduction of the legislation, inadequate consideration was given to the public comments. As I have already said, consultations on product recall had been held since 1980 with interested groups and their views were well established, and the majority of public comments favoured the Government's preferred position. I think it bears mention that the actual provisions were developed in conjunction with the Administrative Review Council to ensure that the rights of suppliers were safeguarded by an adequate review procedure.

So the current Government amendments and the Government amendments in the House of Representatives demonstrate the Government's willingness to discuss, and where appropriate to amend, the Bill to ensure that it does not have any unintended effects. For all those reasons it is fair to say that, although the debate in this place will not be very short, for obvious reasons, the matters in issue are important. This is important for a number of reasons to resolve them quickly, not least because of the consumer protection side of things. I urge the Senate accordingly to get on with the debate and to reject Senator Durack's motion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise very briefly to support Senator Durack's motion to refer the Trade Practices Amendment Bill 1985 to the Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs. I speak as a member of that Committee in the belief that reference to it of this legislation will allow the exposure of a number of issues that would be best dealt with by one of the Senate standing committees, rather than by the Committee of the Whole procedure. I would instance only the following issues without attempting to say anything about the merits of each of them, which nevertheless would be worth examination in the committee procedure.

SPEECH.PARA: If one looks at clause 5 (b) of the legislation one sees that there will be a substantial increase in penalties and I think that is a matter worth considering. The proposed amendments to section 45C seek a change in the definition of `a market' in terms of the substitution of the term `any market' for the term `a market'. We have already drawn attention to the potential problems that will arise if the Australian Capital Territory is to be defined as a market because of the way in which reference to territories has been included in the legislation for the first time. Similarly there are precedents arising from the Cool and O'Brien case in terms of the definition of the Wagga area, a small geographic area, as a market. There are also problems arising from clause 46 to which I drew attention in my speech during the second reading debate on the question of the interpretation of purpose in that clause. In clause 46, proposed sub-clause 7 one sees what might be called `the inferential purposes clause' which allows a determination to be made if that purpose, in the words of the legislation, is ascertainable only by inference from the conduct of the corporation. There is also the problem of the whole of clause 50 to which the Minister for Resources and Energy, Senator Evans, has just referred. I will return to that in a moment, but clearly it is an area of current controversy and clearly an area which would benefit from some greater exposure and investigation.

We also need to look at the proposals for section 52A of the principal Act in terms of unconscionable conduct, the whole of the proposed Part V, the whole proposed clause 65F on compulsory recall and the whole question of proposed clause 74 in terms of warranties and liabilities as they affect the provision of professional services. In that respect I must just mention that we have received representations from the Law Council of Australia and from bodies as diverse as the Australian Veterinary Association and the Australian Council of Professions drawing our attention to the difficulties which they believe will arise for them if the legislation proceeds in that particular form, particularly in dealing with the question of professional liability. These representations clearly indicate that the consultation about which Senator Evans has spoken, at least in regard to the clause 74 proposals, cannot be said to have been as widely canvassed or to have reached a point of as much unanimity in the matter as Senator Evans would have us believe. Indeed, that may well be the case in some of the matters arising from the Green Paper or from the previous exposure report dealing with product safety.

The other comment I wish to make is in relation to Senator Evans's remarks about delay as it affects clause 50, sub-clause 2 in particular. Senator Evans put the proposition that delay serves one particular side in the current controversy over the Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd takeover. Unfortunately it can also be said that to proceed with the legislation in its current form will equally serve one side of the argument. Frankly, there is no way in which it can be established that delay is inherently wrong because it favours one side of a controversy, if proceeding equally has the effect of favouring the other side, as it were. Therefore, to that extent I think that is not a relevant matter to be brought to bear.

I take the opportunity to remind my colleagues in the Australian Democrats of their own commitment in this matter. Under the heading of `Policy Items-Legislation' the Australian Democrats' own policy document in relation to legislation states--

TALK.START.PARA: —Pay as much attention to yours and we will get on a lot better.

—I am attempting only to follow the lead of the distinguished leader of Senator Haines's party in insisting that we keep them honest. I have been chastised for using the honourable senator's distinguished leader's exact words--
—By whom?
—By Senator Colston when he was in the chair. I am not prepared to risk the same from Senator Hamer. Nevertheless, the commitment which the Democrats have reads as follows:

SPEECH.PARA: While a Bill is before Parliament it will be scrutinised, clause by clause, including any delegations of power, by the relevant Standing Committee.

In fact, all that is being sought by this reference is an examination clause by clause, including any delegations of power, by the relevant standing committee. I have drawn attention to a whole series of items which I believe would be assisted by consultation and by exposure of some of those representations which we have received through the work of the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs. It is for those reasons that I believe that Senator Durack's motion for the reference of this Bill should be supported.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Haines Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I find it rather extraordinary to hear Senator Puplick lecturing us about our particular policy items and then in the same breath supporting Senator Durack's reference of the entire Trade Practices Amendment Bill to a committee when this piece of legislation, which has been floating around for the last six months and is a direct result of inquiries which have taken some two years, aims to increase protection not only to individual consumers in this country but also to small business organisations-the very group of people which Senator Puplick's Liberal Party is always talking about the need to preserve and protect because of the contribution it makes to the country's economy and the number of people it employs. I ask Senator Puplick not to talk to me about our policy until he is prepared to stand up and be counted on his own.

SPEECH.PARA: The fact of the matter is that the Trade Practices Amendment Bill which is before us at the moment covers a wide range of consumer protection measures from misleading conduct to false representation, corrects an anomaly in the, at the moment, rather embattled section 50 concerning off-shore mergers, looks at extensions of the warranties provision, provides additional protection in the area of mandatory recall and, in addition, looks of course at tidying up section 50 with regard to the issue of bare transfer of monopoly power. It is for that reason-that is, the scope of the Bill itself-that the Australian Democrats are not in favour of referring this piece of legislation to the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs.

As far as the other provisions in the Bill are concerned, a reference to a committee would simply hold them up. In fact, it would defer the implementation of some significantly beneficial consumer legislation. At the very most what it would do with regard to section 50 and the current Broken Hill Proprietary Co Ltd-Holmes a Court battle is to delay the introduction of that section for so long that Holmes a Court would do a John Elliott and indeed do what he has done himself in the past-withdraw from his bid and wait it out. So it would at very best postpone whatever was likely to happen in that area and at the same time have the quite undesirable effect of delaying things like a mandatory recall of unsafe products legislation. People in the community who are aware of things such as the Tibaldi salami case and others will be aware that there are some problems in this area that need to be attended to. While I do not think it is going too far to suggest that it is quite possible that, in the months the Bill would be before the Committee, some fatality could occur for which this place would be blamed, honourable senators in this chamber do have to take into account that that is a possibility.

On the question of proposed section 50 (2C), of course, comes the concern that a great many people have expressed about the need for a national interest inquiry to be able to be undertaken in the event of the bare transfer of a monopoly power and, in particular the transfer of a monopoly power from a company which is, to all intents and purposes, a public company into the hands of one man. Regardless of whether people are or are not impressed with the methods used by Robert Holmes a Court to revitalise companies in the process of making himself a lot of money, the fact remains that we have at risk an extremely large company in this country which plays a very important part in the country's economy and which employs large numbers of people in a variety of States. To jeopardise the existence of that company is, I think, something that this Parliament ought not to be a party to.

So the Australian Democrats are not going to support the reference by Senator Durack of the entire Bill to a committee. We certainly would not have any difficulty if section 50 itself was referred to the Constitutional and Legal Affairs Committee, although why they should come up with any different arguments about it than the Green Paper I cannot understand. However, if somebody wants to send that off to a committee, we are not going to argue. What we would certainly prefer to do is, in the first instance, move an amendment to the Trade Practices Amendment Bill giving the Trade Practices Commission power to conduct public interest inquiries into takeovers of all sorts. Currently, under section 50 as it stands the Trade Practices Commission does have power of inquiry but it can only inquire in the public interest, as I understand it, if the mover of the bid seeks authorisation from the Trade Practices Commission. In the past the TPC's quite natural policy has been to inquire only if the control or dominance in the market was being increased by the merger or takeover rather than simply in the case of the bare transfer of monopoly power.

TALK.START.PARA: —When are we going to see the terms of your amendment to that effect?
—In good time.
—You are all heart.

—I know-what is not good looks is all heart. The honourable senator will certainly be given the terms of that amendment in time for him to consult colleagues, even if it means reordering the discussion in the Committee stage so that we can allow the Liberals to indulge in their extended debate on the section 74 changes about which they are currently hysterical. In the event of our not receiving support for the amendment of the Bill to include a public interest inquiry section, we will move to oppose the clause, and in doing so, excise proposed new section 50 (2C) from the Bill. I suggest that the Opposition look fairly carefully at this. The Opposition has indicated that it is its intention to oppose the Bill as a whole.
—It is not our intention. We have done that.

—I know the Opposition has already attempted to do it, quite unsuccessfully. Unlike the Opposition, we are concerned, as I said earlier, about the other elements contained in the legislation that relate to increased protection for small businesses and for the consumer generally. There is certainly no way that we will be prepared to block an entire Bill for some whimsical reason of the Opposition. I am saying to Senator Durack and his colleagues that if they are prepared to block the entire piece of legislation, which of course includes proposed section 50 (2C), they might just as well, for the purposes of this exercise, support us when it comes to the debate on that proposed section and eliminate it, at least for the moment, at least until the issue of the acquisition by Bell Resources of a significant number of BHP shares is dealt with. At that stage the Government can, through the Statute Law (Miscellaneous Provisions) Bill, or in any other way, come back to look at proposed section 50 and the amendments it wants to make to clarify what has always been the accepted practice, if not the actual law, contained within that section. If we do not get support for the excision of proposed section 50 (2C), we have decided to support the Liberals' motion at the third reading to vote against the Trade Practices Amendment Bill in its present form and at the same time--
—There is no Liberal motion at the third reading.

—Just wait a minute, Senator, before you get your knickers thoroughly in a twist. At the same time we would immediately introduce another Bill identical to the current Bill, but without proposed section 50 (2C), which the Government, if it has any commitment at all to consumer protection legislation, will be forced to support. It is about the only way we can see at the moment of having our cake and eating it too. We hope that some sort of reason will prevail in this place.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me say at the outset that we do not support allegations that have been wandering around in the community that the Labor Government has introduced the proposed new section 50 (2C) in the middle of the game, so to speak. It is quite fortuitous that the Senate is dealing with this Bill now. It was before the Senate last year, but other business got in its way and we rose for the Christmas break before we had dealt with the Trade Practices Amendment Bill. Had we dealt with it at the time, section 50 (2C) would be firmly implanted in the legislation.

All we are saying at the moment is: Take out proposed section 50 (2C) for the time being; use the procedures in this place and the procedures the Government has available to it somewhere down the track to reintroduce it either in another Trade Practices Act amending Bill or through the Statute Law (Miscellaneous Provisions) Bill and allow some sort of inquiry to take place to take into account what effect the takeover by Bell Resources of BHP is likely to have. It would be preferable, of course, if our amendment with regard to the need for a public interest criterion to be introduced were to operate also, but certainly the excision of proposed section 50 (2C) will go a long way to allowing the community, the corporations and individuals concerned to clarify exactly what is happening in the market-place with the proposed takeover. We will not be supporting the Liberal Party's motion for reference to a committee at this stage.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want briefly also to support Senator Durack's comments on behalf of the Opposition in requesting that the Trade Practices Amendment Bill be referred to the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs. I have listened carefully to the arguments of Senator Haines for the Australian Democrats and of Senator Gareth Evans and, to me, both statements sound singularly unconvincing. The argument that the Bill has to be rushed through in the next couple of days, for whatever reason, seems to me to be a quite spurious argument. The Opposition is not proposing that the reference to the Constitutional and Legal Affairs Committee be without a time limit. We agree with the Democrats and the Government that the matter does need to be resolved fairly quickly but that there should be a delay of a shortish period for reference and consideration by that Committee.
—That would take four or five months.

—It is not necessary for it to take four or five months. It could be given to the Committee as a matter of priority. I understand that the Committee would respond to that, so that the matter could be back in this place in four or five weeks, not four or five months.
—There are 74 clauses.

—Yes, but not all of them are in great contention. The argument by Senator Haines that we voted against the entire Bill also is a very arguable proposition. Certainly we voted against the second reading of the Bill in the House of Representatives, but the reason why we did that was that several of the key amendments that we feel are very important were not supported and, therefore, we had problems with the Bill as a whole.

SPEECH.PARA: We have received very important representations on these matters, as have the Government and the Democrats, and not just from a particular section of either the business or wider community, but from a wide cross-section of the community. There is a degree of concern on an issue which is not just a technical issue. It relates to a piece of legislation which is becoming increasingly important in this country in terms of determining the course of the development of our business and private enterprise sector. If the representations received on this Bill are to be given serious credence and consideration, I believe that all of us owe it to our constituency to be absolutely sure, when we take the final decisions as legislators on this very important piece of legislation, that we have done the necessary homework to take the right decisions. This matter affects the whole spectrum of business; it certainly affects large business, and, as the Democrats point out very rightly, it has fundamental implications for small business in this country. The importance of small business in the context of the total private sector environment is such that I believe that some of the provisions which will have an effect on small business need to be looked at more carefully.

In my view a number of amendments have not been looked at properly. The Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills reported to this place two days ago on a couple of major issues. It disagreed with the Government on matters which we have not yet fully considered and that is another reason why the Bill should be given further consideration. I understand the Democrats' point of view, and I agree that we do not want to hold this matter up or have an interminable delay. To have a referral to the Constitutional and Legal Affairs Committee does not automatically do that. We can give that Committee a time limit. I believe that it is essential to have that reference if we are going to make decisions at the end of the day which are of fundamental importance to the business community in this country and, therefore, to economic development and growth. We should give ourselves the opportunity of closer scrutiny. If we do not, I do not believe that we can honestly say that we are doing our jobs as legislators.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chipp Sen The Hon D.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support Senator Haines's remarks rather than to add anything to them or differ from them in any way. I want to mention one specific aspect of the Trade Practices Amendment Bill only. I will choose my words very carefully because it is a complex matter. As I understand it, the situation is that the Trade Practices Commission, for which I have an unbounded respect, has for one of the few times in its history, or I might be correct in saying for the only time in history, showed an interest in a takeover of a monopoly. I put it no stronger than that. The Trade Practices Commission indicated that it had an interest in a monopoly. This is not just some ordinary monopoly company that makes matchboxes, matchsticks or whatever; it is the biggest monopoly in the country, the operations of which affect every living human being in this country. If the price of steel is varied it affects virtually every job in the country, whether it is at the lathe, at the bench or in the office. That is the importance of what is at stake in the interest shown by the Trade Practices Commission.

SPEECH.PARA: Without any intent by the Government, as Senator Haines properly said, proposed section 50 (2C), as I understand it, will deny the Commission's showing an interest in the present take-over of Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd by Mr Robert Holmes a Court's group. That was not the intention of the Government because, as Senator Haines said, this particular amendment was introduced last year long before Mr Holmes a Court's intentions for BHP became apparent. He might have been thinking about it but certainly his intentions were not apparent. All we are asking the Government and the Liberal Party of Australia to do at this stage, if they believe there is merit in the content of section 50 (2C), is to debate it another time. Let us not debate it while in the middle of one of the biggest ball games in Australian commercial history, while the greatest Australian company is in the process of being taken over.

TALK.START.PARA: —Not the greatest, the biggest.
—I will change that.
—The most inefficient and incompetent bunch that has ever been in control of shareholders' funds.

—I acknowledge that interjection so that it can be included in Hansard. It at least adds a little colour to my speech. Of course, I reject the interjection totally and make my own commendation of the management and expertise of BHP and the people who run it.
—I would not have Brian Loton running my bank account.

—I acknowledge that interjection also so that it can be included in Hansard. That sort of interjection is uncalled for because that particular gentleman has no opportunity to reply in the same circumstances as those in which the allegation has been made. All I ask for of the Labor Party and the Liberal Party-we will be pushing them to vote on all these matters-is to pass the trade practices legislation, the first class legislation that is before us on consumer protection, restrictive trade amendments and whatever, but let us leave aside this extraordinarily contentious issue of the takeover of monopolies and particularly the current takeover bid of BHP by Robert Holmes a Court.

SPEECH.PARA: One thing that bothers me about the whole question and the attitudes of both major parties is why they are so intractable about it. Why are they intractable? Why do they not do the simple thing of letting the Commission-I believe everybody in this chamber has a great respect and admiration not only for its constitution but also for the job it has done and is doing-look into this matter and tell this Parliament whether Mr Holmes a Court's takeover of BHP would be a good thing in the national interest? Are the allegations of my friend from Western Australia, Senator Crichton-Browne, accurate?

TALK.START.PARA: —I have spoken on the steel industry a number of times, as has been demonstrated.

—Let them be heard before the proper tribunal and not intruded into a debate in this place where we do not have the opportunity of hearing BHP's side. Why not let the properly appointed tribunal, the tribunal created by this Parliament for the very purpose of determining whether that is in the public interest, have a look at his particular matter? If we pass this Bill, which the Labor Party and the Liberal Party will collude to pass, it will deny the Commission the opportunity to look at this particular transaction in the public interest. I hope that in the course of the debate when this motion has been defeated-and the reason we will vote against it has been aptly stated by Senator Haines, because we believe that the provisions are urgently required-there is still room for negotiation, particularly with the Liberal Party, which I would have thought championed companies like BHP, which have shown a remarkable record of growth and contribution-
—Speak for yourself. Speak for your Party, not for the Liberal Party.

—I am speaking for myself. I would never presume to speak for the Liberal Party and have not done so for many years, as the honourable senator would well know. Even though I have a fair bit of confidence in my own ability, one thing I could never do is to speak for the Liberal Party in this country.
—Especially when you were a member of it.

—Even then I had some doubts about whether I could, yes. I plead with the Liberal Party in particular to contemplate whether an inquiry into this takeover is desirable in the national interest, because that is the question that must be considered.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support Senator Durack's motion that this matter be referred to the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs. Because of the suggestion that the matter may be delayed in the Committee, I want to place on the record the fact that, if it is so referred, as a member of the Committee I would certainly act to have the matter dealt with expeditiously. The long delays that have been mentioned by others in the debate would seem to me to be quite unnecessary.

SPEECH.PARA: I believe that the matter should be so referred because of the unsatisfactory state of the current debate. We have before us a wad of amendments. A large number of amendments have been proposed by those on this side of the House and another large number of amendments by the Australian Democrats. Again, the Government is seeking to amend its own amendments, which seems to be becoming an unsatisfactory practice of this Government. Today we have before us a couple of extra amendments that were distributed only a few minutes ago. One has been proposed by Senator Vigor and there are some further--

TALK.START.PARA: —What is that about?

—The Government has not seen the one from Senator Vigor yet? The Minister might have to address himself to that one. Further amendments have been put before us by the Australian Democrats today. Senator Haines a few minutes ago said that yet another amendment is envisaged in due course which we are yet to see. I would have thought that anybody, acting reasonably and objectively, would regard it as a very unsatisfactory state of affairs for the Committee of the Whole to continue the debate on that basis.

SPEECH.PARA: It is not only the amendments that have been proposed by honourable senators that should cause concern. The Law Council of Australia, an objective and unbiased body, I would suggest, proposes amendments to almost half the clauses of the Trade Practices Amendment Bill. I would have thought that that in itself would lead the Government to have some grave reservations about the quality of the Bill that has been presented to the Senate. It would suggest to me that the best course of action would be for it to be considered by a bipartisan committee which, in the quiet of day, could look at these matters. I will list a few that come to my mind as requiring further, careful and balanced consideration. Clause 34, in the consumer part of the Bill, provides for a non-reviewable decision and has received criticism from the Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills. The solutions that have been suggested in the Senate to date are unsatisfactory. It is deserving of further consideration.

There are amendments to section 46 of the Act that are intended to lower the threshold. I would have thought that that required further consideration. It seems to me to be worrying that the direction this country is taking under this legislation is contrary, for example, to that of the United States, which feels that larger companies will be necessary in the years ahead to compete in the international environment. We are finding so much of our business subjected to that area. However, under this Government we seem to be taking the opposite trend. Is that the best course of action for us to adopt? I suggest that the bipartisan Senate committee system is an excellent way in which that question can be examined.

Proposed new sub-section (7) of section 46 requires further consideration. It provides that matters can be determined on the basis of inference. I would have thought that that would probably be so as a matter of law in any event. One questions why it has been introduced. The argument of some is that when it gets to the stage of interpretation it will amount to a reversal of the onus of proof. I am not too sure whether that is correct, but that is the sort of question that can be examined by the Senate Committee. The Senate Committee can take evidence and reach a conclusion which no doubt would be helpful to the Committee of the Whole and that would be the objective. Recently further consideration has been given to the question of section 74. Senator Puplick mentioned the concern that is now being expressed by veterinarians. When we look at the warranty provisions as they relate to services, particularly as they relate to services within the biological science area, there do seem to me to be very real questions that need to be carefully addressed as to whether we are applying a standard upon these professions that it is impossible for them to comply with.

I suggest that the Bill requires further consideration in an environment which is more satisfactory for that careful consideration than this chamber. We are certainly not suggesting that there are not worthwhile reforms in this Bill, which we would like to see introduced and we would want to see introduced as soon as is practicably possible. That objective can be achieved by a proper usage of the Senate committee system. Senator Puplick and I, as two members of that Committee, have undertaken to use our best endeavours to ensure that such consideration is expedited so that a report can be brought back to the Senate as quickly as possible in order that the Senate might better fulfil its obligations to the Parliament and the nation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Siddons Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to comment on the performance of the Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd. Some rather astounding interjections were made by Senator Crichton-Browne. Senator Hill made it very clear that the Opposition does not support the existing legislation-the Trades Practices Amendment Bill. If that is so, presumably the Opposition will vote against this piece of legislation. As I understand it, Mr Howard has indicated publicly for some time that that would be the case. I believe the allegations about BHP must be answered. The first point I make is this: It is difficult to overestimate the importance of BHP to the Australian economy. It represents 2 per cent of our gross domestic product. It accounts for 8 per cent--
—Order! Senator Siddons, we are discussing a proposal to refer the Bill to a committee. These remarks may be more appropriate when we are actually considering that clause of the Bill.

—I take the point, Mr Deputy President. I will confine my remarks to the importance of getting this matter sorted out as quickly as possible. Referring this legislation to a committee would simply delay the whole process. It would not alter the position of the two major parties in this chamber and the shareholders of BHP, Mr Holmes a Court and the management of BHP would be in a state of indecision for some months. They would not know what was going to happen. An important industry very largely would be paralysed because the executives' attention would be sidetracked to what was happening in the Parliament instead of getting on with their business.

SPEECH.PARA: If we thought that there was any merit in looking at the trade practices legislation we would support this matter being referred to a committee. We have looked at the trade practices legislation and we are anxious for it to be passed as quickly as possible. We think it is an important piece of legislation. Our only concern is clause 50 (2C) which would have the effect of neutralising the power of the Trade Practices Commission to proceed with legal action which it has already initiated. For the very first time in its history the Trade Practices Commission has seen fit to take action in respect of the takeover of a company which is in a clear monopoly position. This is the first time the Trade Practices Commission has initiated such action. However, that action is stalled at the moment pending a decision of this Parliament. Surely we have a responsibility to the Trade Practices Commission, the executives of BHP and Mr Holmes a Court to get on with the business and to let them know what is going to happen. All we are suggesting is that the legal action which is already in process should continue under the existing legislation.

As Senator Chipp pointed out, we are about to change the rules mid way through the most important takeover that has ever occurred. On a later occasion I will outline the importance of BHP to the community. To delay a decision on what is going to happen and to keep everybody in suspense is certainly against the public interest. I support my colleagues who have made it very clear that to put this matter to a committee at this late stage is the worst possible course of action.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am concerned that the Australian Democrats are seeking to single out, in effect, one element of the Trade Practices Amendment Bill 1985 when there are so many elements that must receive the sort of scrutiny that Senator Durack's motion requires. As Senator Hill pointed out, the enormous volume of amendments to the Bill in this place is a clear indication of the half baked, ill-considered--
—I have another one.
—Senator Hill says that he has just been given another one. It is a clear indication of the half baked, ill-considered nature of this whole legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: Because it happens to suit the Australian Democrats' particular desperate search for issues so that they can stay alive as a party, by pandering to individual groups, the intrusion of this proposal into the proper examination of a Bill which is of significance to a large number of Australian people is, to my mind, elevating political expediency to an art form. This is what I would expect from the Australian Democrats. They are not concerned at all about the consequences of this legislation. They are concerned about one minor element of it on which they hope to make the sort of vulgar political capital which is their stock in trade.

There are many reasons why this matter should be referred to a committee for some proper examination. Certainly the Government itself needs to examine the consequences of many of its own amendments because the manner in which they have been presented indicates a great lack of intellectual confidence about their content. I would suggest that this range of concerns clearly merits attention. I pointed to many of those concerns in my speech during the second reading debate. However, I do not want to go over that. For interest's sake, I had a good look at the comments that Senator Haines made in her speech during the second reading debate. I must say that, having looked at how incredibly misdirected her comments were, it would seem to me that the Australian Democrats would get a great deal of benefit if someone gave them the opportunity of at last understanding what this Bill is all about. Perhaps referring this Bill to a committee would provide them with that opportunity.

Apart from all these issues, the clear fact is that the Government has totally ignored and failed to respond to many of the issues raised by, for example, the Australian Law Council. It failed to respond in debate in this chamber to very sound points that merit a response. This indicates to me with some vigour that it is most appropriate to refer this matter to a committee for proper examination. On top of all of those objections and on top of all the points that have been made in this chamber, I refer the Senate to the third report of the Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills. The report is dated yesterday, 12 March. I would point out that Senator Haines is a member of that Committee. I regret that she did not participate in the detailed examination of this element at the Committee's meeting on Wednesday. I also am a member of that Committee and I draw the Senate's attention to some elements of that report. The report states:

The Committee commented on this Bill in its seventeenth report but it indicated at that time that it was examining submissions which had been made to Senators in relation to the Bill by the Business Council of Australia and the Law Council of Australia and that it might make a further Report to the Senate on the Bill.

I ask the Senate to pardon me for taking some time over this. However, I think it is absolutely vital that this Scrutiny of Bills Committee report, which expresses such concerns over elements of this Bill, be dealt with at some length.

Following its consideration of those submissions the Committee, in its first report of 1986, drew the attention of the Senate to two further clauses of the Bill. The report of the Committee dated 12 March states:
The Committee has now received a response from the Attorney-General to those additional comments the relevant parts of which are reproduced . . .

I must say that I found the letter from the Attorney-General to be the most incredible nonsense that I have had the misfortune to read since I have been in this place. I commend a reading of that letter to honourable senators. I would like to incorporate the essence of the Committee's response which, of course, relates to the basic question of the burden of proof. This is something that I thought might have interested the Australian Democrats, but obviously this is not the case. They want to rush through the whole Bill except for the part that relates to their one bit of political expediency. I encourage the Australian Democrats to study this part of the report that obviously does not interest them. The report stated:

While the Committee recognises that it is always open to a court to draw inferences from conduct it suggests that new sub-section 46 (7) goes beyond this accepted principle in permitting inferences to be drawn from the effects of the corporation's conduct. Indeed, the Green Paper, the Trade Practices Act: Proposals for change, suggests that this is the intention underlying the proposed amendment.
In order to establish a contravention of section 46, as proposed to be amended, the plaintiff is required to prove:
(i) that a corporation has a substantial degree of power in a market;
(ii) that it has taken advantage of that power; and
(iii) that in doing so it had one of the purposes set out in paragraphs 46 (1) (a), (b) and (c), for example the purpose of preventing the entry of a person into the relevant market.

Sub-section 46 (7) would enable the court to draw an inference as to the third point, the purpose of a corporation, from the conduct of the corporation, the conduct of any other person-for example the person prevented from entering the relevant market-or from other relevant circumstances. The Attorney-General suggests in his reponse that below average cost pricing would not, of itself, be sufficient to enable an inference as to the purpose to be drawn. However, the Explanatory Memorandum states that-

where a corporation with the requisite market power is, in the absence of countervailing evidence that its pricing was not aimed at destroying actual potential competition, selling at below average cost there may be grounds for inferring that it is taking advantage of its power for a prescribed purpose.
Really that seems to me to be clearly a reversing of the onus. To continue:
The Committee's point is that the burden will probably be cast upon the corporation concerned to provide the `countervailing evidence' referred to above.

Either the Democrats believe in reverse onuses of proof or they do not. I do not think they believe in anything apart from how to appeal to individual group's special interests in order to desperately win a vote. Here we have a major principle, a reverse onus, and the Democrats of course wish to exclude that from any--

TALK.START.PARA: —Why do you talk about us so much?

—Because the Democrats are the people who are trying to make politics out of this issue. That is their typical style. They have been challenging us on our bona fides in respect of this matter but they cannot take a response in kind because their lack of principle on this matter is so overwhelming. The Scrutiny of Bills Committee, on which I remind Senator Chipp his Party is supposed to be represented, concedes that there have been difficulties in establishing that corporations have had the anti-competitive purposes--
—Why do you talk about us so much?
—Because you are such a pain in the neck, if you would like to know, senator. To continue:

SPEECH.PARA: The Committee concedes that there have been difficulties in establishing that corporations have had the anti-competitive purposes required under section 46 and that this time may be an appropriate place for the imposition of an evidentiary burden on the defendant corporation. In this connection the Committee notes that the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs in its report referred to above was prepared to see an evidential burden imposed on the defendant in criminal proceedings-
Where the prosecution faces extreme difficulty in circumstances where the defendant is presumed to have peculiar knowledge of the facts in issue. (Recommendation 6.13) (b) (i).)
I continue to quote:

Nevertheless the Committee feels that some doubt remains whether this is an appropriate case for imposing an evidential burden on the defendant and whether, if it is, the corporation should face the task not merely of rebutting inferences drawn from its own conduct but also of adducing evidence to counter inferences drawn from the conduct of others.

Accordingly the Committee continues to draw clause 16 to the attention of the Senate in the hope of promoting a fuller consideration of the issues involved at the Committee stage of debate on the Bill.

Here we have a clear indication that there are matters of concern which should properly be referred for detailed examination by the Senate. The effect of an amendment to omit proposed new sub-section 46 (7) also attracts the attention of the Scrutiny of Bills Committee. It notes:
In his response the Attorney-General also argued that to amend clause 16 at this stage to omit proposed new sub-section 46 (7) might have-

particularly serious consequences, since an amendment to remove from the Bill provisions already introduced into Parliament would almost certainly lead courts to the construction that the omissions were deliberately designed to negate what they would have provided for. The courts would, because of this, hold that `corporate purpose' could not be inferred and could only be proved by direct unequivocal evidence emanating from the highest level of management. This would make section 46 unworkable for all practical purposes . . .

I have heard some legal gobbledegook and nonsense from the Attorney-General's Department, but this probably takes the cake. This is the absolute apex of nonsense. The Committee responded to that in this way:

On one level, the Attorney-General's initial proposition is a simple truism. If the Government were, for example, to introduce a Bill containing a clause stating `Thou shalt not murder' and the Bill were to be amended in the course of its passage to omit the clause, it would be appropriate for a court to conclude that the Parliament did not wish murder to be made the subject of a penal sanction. However in the present case the mere omission of new sub-section 46 (7) should leave the common law, and the power of the courts to draw inferences from conduct, untouched-

It would leave it totally untouched; common law would be there. For the Attorney-General's Department to pretend that, by omitting such a section, the bulk of the common law would be overwhelmed is pathetic and is, in my mind, an attempt to mislead this place.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The motion before the Chair is for referral of the Bill to a Senate committee. The honourable senator is perfectly in order to draw attention to the sorts of matters which justify such a referral. To argue them in detail is going beyond the motion.
—I thank you, Mr Deputy President. I am simply outlining the sort of nonsense the Senate has been inundated with on individual clauses to outline--
—Have you been instructed to filibuster or can't you help yourself?
—I feel it important that these points, which have not in fact been raised in the Senate--
—But you had your chance.

—I trust that I am taking it now in this general issue to debate whether or not the combination, the total, of these extraordinary problems that emerged throughout the Bill merit reference to a committee-not separating one individual bit that happens to suit the political purpose of the Australian Democrats but referring this Bill, which has quite properly generated the concern of the Scrutiny of Bills Committee, as a whole to a committee.

SPEECH.PARA: By way of conclusion, I simply point out that other clauses-for example, the definition of `recall'-creates problems. As the Scrutiny of Bills Committee points out, this is a matter of major moment which clearly should be referred to a committee. The Scrutiny of Bills Committee points out:
Under new section 65R it would be an offence for a supplier to fail to notify the Minister within two days where the supplier voluntarily takes action to recall goods.

No definition of what constitutes a recall of goods for the purposes of this provision is given and the Committee was concerned that there might be some uncertainty as to the obligations placed upon suppliers. The Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) once again responded with, I submit, some more nonsense. I commend to the Senate that, when deciding whether or not this matter should be referred to a committee, it give close attention to the overwhelming volume of evidence, firstly, that this Bill is improperly prepared; secondly, that it is incompetently supported in the letters from the Attorney-General that are revealed in the report of the Scrutiny of Bills Committee; thirdly, that it covers many matters that are half thought out; and, fourthly, that it has serious consequences which have been pointed out by the Law Council of Australia and which have not been adequately responded to by this Government.

I thank the Minister for Resources and Energy (Senator Gareth Evans) for his yawn because there is no doubt that the list of the Government's offences in this area is so incredibly long that when they are listed together, they create such a pile that it is a yawn to go through them. That is why I have touched on only a few of those matters which clearly merit reference of this Bill to a committee. If Senator Chipp is interested in what they are, I encourage him to read the very informative speech that I made at the second reading stage of the Bill. It may provide some light and wisdom to him, light and wisdom that he clearly lacks in the circumstance. However, I note that he still has his political antenna on high and is endeavouring to reduce this debate and this issue to a simple matter of how the Democrats can try to win some votes out of an issue which is surely much more important than that.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

That is the position that the Opposition has maintained from the beginning in relation to this legislation. Our course of action is in no way dictated by any recent events of the Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd take-over proposal. Our stance was formulated before that situation arose; indeed, it was taken some time ago. SPEECH.PARA: Although there has been extensive debate on this piece of legislation both in the other place and here in the Senate during the second reading stage and now in relation to my motion to refer the Bill to the Senate Committee, and although there is the prospect of a Committee of the Whole debate of some magnitude and amendments have been foreshadowed by the Government, the Opposition and the Democrats which have been on the table for some weeks, until today not one of the proposed amendments has related to the section that has become the subject of public notoriety over the last two or three weeks. —No.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition is concerned about sub-section (7) of the new section 46 which is proposed by clause 16 of this Bill. The new clause deals with the misuse of market power and it makes a number of changes. The one we are particularly concerned about is sub-section (7) which reads:

SPEECH.PARA: Without in any way limiting the manner in which the purpose of a person may be established for the purposes of any other provision of this Act, a corporation may be taken to have taken advantage of its power for a purpose referred to in sub-section (1) notwithstanding that the existence of that purpose is ascertainable only by inference from the conduct of the corporation or of any other person or from other relevant circumstances.
Of course, the matter that has to be proved is whether a corporation has breached, for example, proposed new sub-section (1), which provides:
A corporation that has a substantial degree of power in a market shall not take advantage of that power for the purpose of-
(a) eliminating or substantially damaging a competitor of the corporation--
