What has to be established is that the corporation is doing these various things for a purpose. Clearly enough, the purpose the corporation has will not be easily or usually proved by direct evidence but by inferences to be drawn from conduct. The way that that is done with the law as it is enables that purpose to be ascertained by what the proposed new section says is the `conduct of the corporation or of any other person or other relevant circumstances'. That is exactly the way in which a purpose is proved now. That is the way the state of anybody's mind is proved in law and has been so in the law of evidence for a very long time. It is a total mystery to the Opposition why the proposed new sub-section has been included.

We are concerned that if there is some subtle purpose in the proposed new section which goes beyond the existing state of the law we will have to oppose it. However, before we take that step I want to know from the Minister for Resources and Energy (Senator Gareth Evans) whether this is merely a restatement of what has been the law. If that is the case, why on earth is it there anyway? I do not know whether we would be too upset or excited about it if the Minister says that that is all the provision is here for. However, as I said, if it goes beyond that we will hear what the Minister has to say and in that case we will probably have to consider opposing the clause. That may be going too far. At this stage I simply raise the point with the Minister so that he can tell us why this sub-section is appearing in the clause.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am advised that this is intended to capture at least the spirit of the existing law whereby purpose may be inferred from conduct. As a practical commercial matter it was felt that people needed a bit more evidentiary assistance than they were given by existing law, which was essentially silent on the mode by which purpose could be established. It was felt desirable to spell out the fact that it might be ascertainable in other ways. There is quite a substantial body of correspondence and consideration that has been given to this matter through the initial consideration of it by the Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills, on a reply in February to that Committee from the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen), and a subsequent further whiff of grapeshot from the Committee in the last day or so to which, I gather, some further points in reply are presently being drafted. I think, if that is helpful, that that is as much as I can say at this stage. I will see where Senator Durack wants to go from there.

—The difficulty I have at the moment is that I have not seen the correspondence referred to by Senator Evans. Perhaps he could tell us whether the correspondence indicates any different position from the one he has stated. It seems very odd to me. I do not understand the answer he has given. Is it simply re-stating the common law position? If it is not, just exactly what is it meant to do? Is it meant to draw the attention of judges to what they know perfectly well, or is there some other purpose? The Minister talked about giving them a nudge. I would like to know what that means.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: — There have been some cases in which Australian courts considering this matter have demonstrated an unwillingness to take the step which I think most lawyers would have thought previously, on the authorities, would have been a proper step, namely, ascertaining purpose by inference from the conduct of the corporation or other relevant circumstances that are indirect in character rather than direct-in other words, the language of section 46 (7) now written. I am not armed at the moment, I am afraid, with a full legal analysis of the point in the way that Senator Durack has chosen to raise it. There was certainly a feeling in government, I am advised, that this clause does not represent any new adventure so far as legal principle is concerned. It is simply an attempt to articulate the point in a way that is helpful for small business, which might be minded to use this section, and more particularly for the courts that are then obliged to interpret and ascertain Parliament's intention.

SPEECH.PARA: The other issue here, I suppose, that underlay the Government's feeling is that it was not just from the point of view of giving some guidance to the courts but more particularly some guidance to individuals about the way in which these particular sections might be used to their advantage. There has, I think, been a perception, which has become apparent in the course of the Government's consideration of this issue, by those who might reasonably wish to use section 46 that some direct evidence of purpose is the only way they can get to first base. If they are not armed with some leaked piece of correspondence or something of that kind from a company, then there is simply no point in their seeking the assistance of this section. I think it was a desire to lay out what really previously was implicit, not explicit, in the procedures and in the operation of this section in a way that would be helpful both to those who might be minded to use it and to the courts which would in due course be faced with the task of applying it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills has been engaged in the correspondence dealt with by the Minister for Resources and Energy (Senator Gareth Evans). As the Senate knows, clause 16 of the Bill seeks to amend section 46 of the principal Act to prohibit a corporation that has a substantial degree of power in a market from taking advantage of that power to eliminate or substantially damage competitors, to exclude potential competitors, or to prevent a person from engaging in competitive conduct. The new sub-section 46 (7) proposed to be inserted by the clause provides:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . a corporation may be taken to have taken advantage of its power for a purpose referred to in sub-section (1) notwithstanding that the existence of that purpose is ascertainable only by inference from the conduct of the corporation or of any other person or from other relevant circumstances.

The Scrutiny of Bills Committee suggests that the effect of the proposed new sub-section would be that proof of particular conduct, for example, pricing at below average cost, might give rise to a need for the corporation concerned to adduce evidence in order to rebut an inference which the court might otherwise draw that it had the purpose of destroying actual or potential competition. I dealt with this matter earlier when we were discussing a previous matter, but I would like to go into a little more detail. The report states:

While a breach of section 46 only results in a liability to pay a pecuniary penalty to the Commonwealth (section 76) and not in criminal proceedings (section 78), the Committee expressed concern that, in circumstances where a corporation might be liable to a substantial penalty (up to $250,000), it should bear the onus of adducing evidence that it did not have the special purpose required rather than the onus of establishing this purpose resting on the Minister or the Commission. In this connection the Committee drew attention to the recommendation of the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs in its report on `The Burden of Proof in Criminal Proceedings' (Parliamentary Paper No. 319/1982) that provisions imposing an evidential burden of proof on defendants should be kept to a minimum.

It was that point to which the Attorney-General's Department responded, and it was that response to which the Scrutiny of Bills Committee, as Senator Evans said, fired another whiff of grapeshot. I presume Ministers, to the extent to which they are terrorised by the Scrutiny of Bills Committee, would always feel uneasy when they see a sentence starting: `The Committee thanks the Attorney-General for his response'. That is the same way of saying `We have no basic objection to this matter, but' and we have the but.

I outlined earlier that the Committee did recognise that it is always open to a court to draw inferences. It suggests that proposed new sub-section 46 (7) goes beyond this accepted principle in permitting inferences to be drawn from the effects of the corporation's conduct. I outlined why that inference is underlined by the Green Paper and by subsequent statements and even the explanatory memorandum. As I said earlier, the Scrutiny of Bills Committee's point is that the burden will probably be cast upon the corporation concerned to provide the countervailing evidence referred to above. So, following up Senator Durack's point, it does appear that this legislation does more than simply state the existing position. It pushes it considerably further. The Committee, as I said earlier, does concede that there have been difficulties in establishing that corporations have had the anti-competitive purpose and that that matter was raised. I repeat, because it is central to the issue, that the Committee feels that some doubt remains whether this is an appropriate case for imposing an evidential burden on the defendant and, further, whether, if it is, the corporation should face the task not merely of rebutting inferences drawn from its own conduct but also of adducing evidence to counter inferences drawn from the conduct of others. Accordingly, the Committee continues to draw section 16 to the attention of the Senate. The matter does not simply rest there in what we would suggest was a clear extension of the existing law.

The point I was endeavouring to make, when the Deputy President quite properly took me to task, was that the Attorney-General's Department's suggestion that if this were withdrawn it would create its own inference that in fact these things were totally acceptable was a clear nonsense. The outline of the Scrutiny of Bills Committee is as follows:

However in the present case the mere omission of new sub-section 46 (7) should leave the common law, and the power of the courts to draw inferences from conduct, untouched, rather than having the positive and contrary effect argued for by the Attorney-General of negating all possibility of drawing such inferences.

We suggest that the terrorising of the Senate, if you like, by the Attorney-General suggesting that if we do withdraw this section it will leave all the naughty people in the world this enormous scope to wreak havoc upon society is arrant nonsense.

TALK.START.PARA: —You have to concede that it was a pretty ingenious argument.

—Ingenious, but not clever. The Scrutiny of Bills Committee says that if the Attorney-General were correct as to the effect of the omission of proposed new sub-section 46 (7) this would as a general proposition enable the Executive to fetter to a considerable extent the Parliament's freedom of action in relation to legislation. The report states:

SPEECH.PARA: In a case where a court did consider it appropriate to refer to the legislative history of a Bill under section 15ab of the Acts Interpretation Act 1901 one would imagine that all that would be necessary to prevent the court adopting the construction advanced by the Attorney-General would be a clear statement in the course of debate by the parties opposing the amendment of their reasons for doing so. The rejection of an amendment which is, for example, considered unnecessary given the current state of the law could hardly be construed as an attempt to alter that current state of the law in the contrary direction.

So I state what I stated earlier: It seems to me that the last correspondence that the Committee had from the Attorney-General's Department deserves not only a whiff of grapeshot but a 15-inch shell right through the engine room. It is a nonsensical proposition and I would be interested to see the response to the Scrutiny of Bills Committee that Senator Evans has promised we will get. I presume this means that we will get it after this matter has been dealt with, which will not be terribly helpful to the Senate. As a result, I stress the significance and the importance of the line being adopted at the moment by Senator Durack. In the absence of a coherent response from the Attorney-General and certainly in the absence of any detail as requested by Senator Durack from Senator Evans, there seems little point in proceeding with the Government's amendment in this area. I join Senator Durack in asking Senator Evans whether in his view the extension, as indicated by the Scrutiny of Bills Committee, does exist or does not exist.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: — There is a point in proceeding with this amendment because there are very good grounds for thinking that for all practical purposes the Trade Practices Amendment Bill would go on being unworkable without this clause, such is the disincentive posed by the existing provision with its language about establishing a purpose and the belief that seems to have been encouraged around the place that that purpose can be established only by some very direct evidence in the form, as I say, of leaked correspondence or something of that kind. It is important as a practical matter that litigants, particularly the small business people that were always envisaged to be the major beneficiaries or potentially very significant beneficiaries of proposed section 46, should have a provision available to them that is workable.

SPEECH.PARA: All that is proposed here is, and I sought to indicate before that there was nothing particularly unusual in principle about it, to make it clear that certain inferences can be drawn from conduct. The response of the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) to the initial report of the Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills drew attention to seven or eight pieces of legislation cast in very similar terms-the Evidence Act, section 7f (2); the Crimes (Aircraft) Act, section 20c (2); the Companies Code, section 301, and so on. There are many other examples lying around the statutory landscape.

I think the next point to make is that it has to be appreciated that the effect of particular corporate conduct, that is to say, in terms of the elimination of a competitor or something of that kind, will not be of itself enough to attract the inference of a breach of section 46. All that is involved here is, as in any other case where a prima facie case is established, that the defendant then adduces evidence going to the matter in issue. All this enables the plaintiff to do is to get to first base, as it were, on the question of purpose in a way that there have been very real obstacles to so doing in the past. The matter is by no means resolved by the inferences being able to be drawn under the language of proposed section 46 (7). It then becomes a matter for the court actually drawing the inference and that will be done on the balance of evidence that is adduced in the ordinary way.

The most recent report, the so-called whiff of grapeshot from the Senate Standing Committee, when properly construed-and I have only had the chance to look at it in the last few minutes-pretty clearly comes out in an evenhanded sort of way drawing the Senate's attention to the issue, saying: `These are the arguments on one side; these are the arguments on the other side. Our duty is to advise the Senate of a potential issue of this kind. Let the Senate make up its mind'. That is a very common kind of report for a Senate standing committee to make and it has commonly resulted in the past in the Senate being duly grateful for the assistance thus rendered and then proceeding down the track of supporting the original legislation because there are good reasons for doing so.

I draw the Senate's attention in particular to page 35 of the most recent report, where the Committee squarely and frankly acknowledges that there are good public policy reasons for going down the track of this particular sub-clause. Let me quote the relevant passage:

The Committee concedes that there have been difficulties in establishing that corporations have had the anti-competitive purposes required under section 46 and that this may be an appropriate case for the imposition of an evidentiary burden on the defendant corporation. In this connection the Committee notes that the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs in its Report referred to above was prepared to see an evidential burden imposed on the defendant in criminal proceedings where the prosecution faces extreme difficulty in circumstances where the defendant is presumed to have peculiar knowledge of the facts in issue.

There endeth the paragraph from the Senate Standing committee. It is the case that we are here talking about civil proceedings rather than criminal proceedings, but the point the Committee is making by way of analogy is that there has been a willingness in the past to shift a burden on to defendants-even in criminal proceedings, where public policy demands a much greater reluctance to shift burdens in that way. There has been a willingness in the past to shift an evidential burden on to defendants in criminal proceedings in circumstances where the other side faces extreme difficulty because the defendant is presumed to have peculiar knowledge of the facts in issue. I suggest that this is very much the matter in issue here. When we talk about purpose, we are very often talking about something in relation to which the person who is alleged to have the purpose is certainly the person best equipped to give direct evidence about it and, for practical purposes, may be the only person able to give direct evidence about it, unless one can rely on inferences drawn from conduct. I suggest that this is a very appropriate piece of reasoning by the Senate Standing Committee. The most recent response by the Standing Committee contains reasons which are entirely sufficient for this chamber to support the position that has been taken by the Government.

What we are about here is protecting people against corporate predators, in particular protecting small businesses which have a great deal of difficulty in protecting themselves, in circumstances where public policy demands that they should be protected because the activity of the predator has no redeeming larger justification. I suggest under those circumstances that Senator Michael Baume ought to consider where his true loyalties lie, rather than working himself up into a frenzy of anticipation over there as he stands ready to weigh in for the next round of this argument.

TALK.START.PARA: —I simply want to ask a question. Why did you leave out `Nevertheless' at the top of page 36? You said `There endeth the lesson', but the lesson does not end there. The Committee, having said that, then said `Nevertheless'.

—I know that Senator Michael Baume was a star schoolboy debater, but he is in the grown-ups league now. I began by saying that the Committee ended with an even-handed approach. On the one hand it may well be argued, the Committee said, that there is a good case that it may be appropriate to go down this particular track. It then said:

SPEECH.PARA: Nevertheless the Committee feels that some doubt remains whether this is an appropriate case for imposing an evidential burden on the defendant-
It went on in a similar vein, concluding with the statement:
Accordingly the Committee continues to draw clause 16 to the attention of the Senate in the hope of promoting a fuller consideration of the issues . . .

It does not draw this particular clause to the attention of the Senate in order to strike it down with all the vigour that is demanded of the Senate when confronted with a totally unconscionable and unacceptable piece of indefensible nonsense. That is not the way this particular argument is being put. It is a very gentle, dignified and gentlemanly reminder to us of our obligations to consider carefully these issues and to weigh and balance the competing public policy and legal considerations involved and to decide accordingly.

TALK.START.PARA: —And you have done so!

—We have had a gentlemanly debate about it. We have given it fuller consideration-rather too full consideration, looking at the way time is ticking away-and I suggest, under those circumstances, that we proceed to adopt the clause.

—I do not disagree with most of the various points Senator Gareth Evans has made, but it worries me very much that this clause is interpretable in more than one way. I read at random one of the many submissions that have been put to us all; that is, the claim that the amendments proposed to section 46, and to section 84, to which we will come later, will have the effect of stifling entrepreneurial activity and limiting competitive behaviour. I am sure that Senator Evans has had the submissions put to him in that way, as have the rest of us. I do not want to go over the ground that has been traversed already on the question of the inferential aspect, but I ask Senator Evans for a clear statement that nothing in the proposed section is intended to affect normal vigorous competition and that the proposed section is intended to protect competition, not individual competitors. Will Senator Evans give the Senate a clear indication of that?

— Senator Short thinks that I would deny motherhood. Yes, I am perfectly happy to give the Senate such an assurance. The whole philosophy of this legislation is to promote vigorous competition. The purpose of this clause is to protect the competitive process. It is not to protect individual competitors who may find themselves put to the wall by a proper and vigorous exercise of competitive forces in the market-place. Senator Short offered a very apt description of how legislation of this sort should be construed and I am happy to give the assurance in the terms in which he sought it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The consideration of this clause is confirming more strongly my view that the Trade Practices Amendment Bill should have been sent to a committee for consideration. I am particularly surprised that the Australian Democrats so far have not participated in this very important question about a burden of proof and the report of the Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills, in which the Democrats usually take a lot of interest. I commend the Democrats to look at this question, because the question the Opposition has raised here is of particular interest to this chamber and is usually of particular interest to the Democrats.

SPEECH.PARA: I have now had the opportunity of reading the correspondence from the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen), which is referred to in the report of the Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills. The report is couched in its usual tactful and diplomatic way. I think it ought to firm up a bit on its views when it reports to the Senate. It seems clear to me that the Committee continues to have real concern about this clause. Having listened to Senator Evans trying to explain the purpose or effect of this clause, I am left with great concern as well. I hope that the Democrats will give it some thought, although I know that their attention in this debate seems to be on completely different concerns. I do think that this emphasises the fact that this debate is not all about the BHP take-over, it is about a lot of other major things. The amendments to section 46 of the Act deserve quite a lot of consideration. I refer to the report of the Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills of 12 March. Having discussed the views of the correspondence to the Attorney-General, on page 36 it states:

Nevertheless the Committee feels that some doubt remains whether this is an appropriate case for imposing an evidential burden on the defendant and whether, if it is, the corporation should face the task not merely of rebutting inferences drawn from its own conduct but also of adducing evidence to counter inferences drawn from the conduct of others.

Accordingly the Committee continues to draw clause 16 to the attention of the Senate in the hope of promoting a fuller consideration of the issues involved at the Committee stage of debate on the Bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —We would not be sloughed off.

—Of course, Senator Evans is anxious to slough off the debate, which adds to my concern. He also wants us to get on with the debate, as he usually does, but we are simply not going to do that. We are not just going to get on with it. The Scrutiny of Bills Committee has enjoined the Senate to give very close consideration to this matter `to promote a fuller consideration of the issues'. That is what the Senate very definitely needs to do. In the circumstances I propose to move to delete clause 16 (b), proposed new sub-section 46 (7). The reason why I am doing that is that the Attorney-General, in his response to the Senate Committee, seems to be somewhat uncertain of the effect of this clause. In his first letter, which appears on pages 32 and 33 of the Committee's report, he states:

SPEECH.PARA: Section 46 (7) does not reverse the onus of proof. It merely corrects the possible construction that the absence of direct express evidence of its purpose, from the mouth of the corporation . . . is a fatal flaw in any section 46 proceedings.

I do not know what construction that would be. Apart from this, as far as I am aware, we do not have any directions to the court about how it is to construe the section. It is well known that courts determine purposes by examining and drawing inferences from conduct, amongst other matters. I do not really understand what the Attorney-General is getting at. He has said that section 46 (7) does not reverse the onus of proof. I must admit that that is a good start. He continues:
Section 46 (7) makes it clear that a court is entitled to infer purpose from conduct, notwithstanding the absence of expressed statements of purpose.

Courts have been doing this sort of thing for donkeys years. This business about parliaments today having to tell courts what to do about the evaluation of evidence is really just a lot of nonsense. The last paragraph on page 33, still quoting the Attorney's letter, states:

The example used by the Senate Scrutiny of Bills Committee, where it suggests an inference could be drawn merely from the fact of pricing below average cost, is, with respect, not correct. Below average cost pricing, of itself would not be sufficient to enable an inference as to the purpose to be drawn. It would only be where that below average cost pricing is combined with other circumstances or other conduct by the corporation or the target that an inference could be drawn.
That is not what the section says, nor do I think it is a correct assessment of how courts would proceed. Proposed new sub-section 46 (7) clearly states:
. . . notwithstanding that the existence of that purpose is ascertainable only by inference from the conduct of the corporation or of any other person or from other relevant circumstances.

The Attorney-General's answer on that possible case and way of proving a breach of section 46 is not consistent with what this new sub-section actually says. In a later letter the Attorney-General makes the most extraordinary statement. As quoted on page 36 of the report, he stated:

. . . to omit proposed new sub-section 46 (7) might have-particularly serious consequences, since an amendment to remove from the Bill provisions already introduced into Parliament would almost certainly lead courts to the construction that the omissions were deliberately designed to negate what they would have provided for. The courts would, because of this, hold that `corporate purpose' could not be inferred and could only be proved by direct unequivocal evidence emanating from the highest level of management.

That is absolute nonsense. The courts have already got perfectly clear rules of evidence on how these matters are to be proved. The mere fact that a proposal was put in a Bill in this Parliament and then was not acceded to by the Parliament would be completely neutral so far as the rules of evidence on which the courts proceed are concerned. To say it would have serious consequences and could lead to courts taking this step is quite unbelievable. It simply would not occur. The courts would not be construing a section in an Act to see what Parliament did because of its ambiguities. It would not be in the Act if we delete it. It would not be there. If the courts did look at the debate in the Parliament on this subject, which is highly unlikely, they would find very clearly that Parliament removed it only because it was thought that it was not adding anything to the present method of proof, but it was concerned that it might be seen to be changing the present method of proving a purpose. So the Attorney-General's argument just would not arise at all. The adding of a new sub-section like this, which does not on the face of it change the way in which matters are now proved in courts, may well lead to the courts being concerned to work out whether some change was intended and what it was. There do not seem to have been any substantial reasons advanced as to why it has been added. I think it will only confuse things if it remains. It may lead to interpretations which were never intended by the Parliament or which certainly have never been adopted by the courts. For those reasons, on behalf of the Opposition, I move:
Page 7, paragraph (b), proposed new sub-section 46 (7), lines 12 to 20, leave out the proposed paragraph.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Haines Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Just occasionally I wish that Liberal Party of Australia senators would match their behaviour in this place with their rhetoric with regard to their concern for small business people. Today they have made a sometimes spirited, sometimes less spirited, defence of what are essentially predatory companies which already have an advantage both in the courts and in the market-place because of their power over small businesses and consumers. They have argued that there is something sinister and quite undemocratic about the fact that there will be a reverse onus of proof when that onus is simply an evidentiary one. One day I will be able to cope with the inconsistencies that occur in the minds of honourable senators on my right, but I do not think it will happen today.
—That is a dangerous assertion for a Democrat. I think you had better get on to another point.

—You cannot talk either, and on the basis that it takes one to know one, I would keep quiet if I were you. Essentially, this clause aims to provide some protection to small businesses and consumers from larger companies. If anybody needed any evidence at all-
—Do you think it has that effect?

—Yes, I do. I think it does have that effect. If anybody in this place thinks there is not an increasing shift, if you like, in the market-place, he needs only to look at recent merger activity in this country to know that Australian industry is becoming more and not less concentrated and hence more uncompetitive than we would like to see it, with some firms having, acquiring or increasing what are already substantial market powers and, of course, in doing so, acquiring the potential to abuse that power.

SPEECH.PARA: As far as we are concerned, the changes to section 46 with regard to lowering the threshold test for determining whether the section is or is not applicable to the conduct of a corporation will assist small businesses. In addition, of course, it will assist consumers, but it will assist small businesses in particular which have been refused supply as a result of misuse of substantial market power. Our concern is that the clause does not go far enough, that it does not extend to certain other groups and dealings in the community and that, of course, is what is behind the amendment that we intend to move-if we ever get past this clause in the Bill-in order to extend it to other dealings. I will refer to the examples that I want to raise with regard to that amendment when we consider that amendment. Certainly, we do not see any particular problems in this clause in the Bill. We believe it will have a distinctly positive effect on small business dealings with larger corporations and businesses. We would certainly not like to see that diminished or derogated from in any way.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I did not intend to speak further at this stage. But Senator Haines's sanctimonious, hypocritical comments in terms of what her Party is proposing in its support of small business leave me with no alternative but to say a couple of words on that point. I do not know how the deputy leader of a party, and an aspiring leader of a party, that claims to represent small business can say what she did. That Party will vote to support a capital gains tax which will hurt every small business person in this country. It voted to support the taxation of entertainment expenses, which hurt a range of small businesses in this country. It will support the Government, apparently, in regard to the fringe benefits tax on motor vehicles, which is already in the process in my State alone of putting thousands of car dealers out of business, let alone the small businesses that require those cars. It is a party that is opposed--
—Order! This is getting a long way from the clause.

—This is my last point and I will then come back to the clause. It is also opposed to negative gearing which, along with all the other matters, will hurt small business. It is absolutely appalling and it is about time that the Australian public awoke to what the Australian Democrats are about.

SPEECH.PARA: The argument that Senator Haines put was that our opposition to section 46 is damaging to small business. The inference is that the proposal is only in the interests of large business. That is simply not true. One of the major submissions that have been made on this subject, for example, is a public document in the form of a media release of 11 February from the Law Council of Australia, which I assume could hardly be seen to be a mouthpiece for big business in this country. It makes the point in relation to section 46 that it is bad law. Regardless of whichever group in the community one may think one is protecting or serving by introducing a piece of legislation, bad law is bad law and if it is bad law, it ought to be corrected. I will quote briefly from the media release of the Law Council of Australia of 11 February:

Section 46 is to be changed to prohibit corporations from engaging in competitive behaviour in a market where the corporation has a substantial degree of market power. The amendment should clearly establish that the predatory purpose of a corporation cannot be inferred merely from the inevitable consequences of genuinely competitive conduct. For example, profitable but low pricing by existing efficient manufacturers which prevents less efficient competitors from entering the market should not be interpreted as an abuse of market power. The Act should make it clear that predatory purpose can be inferred only from conduct inconsistent with any reasonable alternative conclusion.

One of the major concerns that we on this side of the chamber have about proposed new section 46 (7) is that it is not clear that that predatory purpose inference will be taken only in those cases. If one is not clear on that point, one is putting into the law a very dangerous clause because it will be unclear, confusing and difficult to interpret. Senator Durack, on behalf of the Opposition, has moved that section 46 (7) be deleted. At the very least, if that is not acceptable-obviously the Democrats will not support us on that once again-I believe that there should be an addition to section 46 (7) to make it clear that predatory purpose can be inferred only from conduct inconsistent with any reasonable alternative conclusion. If Senator Evans is not prepared to accept that on behalf of the Government, I believe it places very consider- able doubt on the assurance which he gave me and for which I thanked him a few moments ago. I was stirred to make some comments by Senator Haines's remarks, but I am speaking as well in support of Senator Durack's amendment. I also seek a comment from Senator Evans on the point that I have raised.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: — Let me turn aside from this rather unedifying spectacle of the Liberals and the Australian Democrats competitively slavering after the small business vote. Everyone knows that the present Labor Government is the strongest supporter and defender that small business in this country has ever had. Among the evidence for that is the present section 46 which we are now debating and to which I rapidly return, as this Committee should have.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me address the sort of points that were made by Senator Short and, rather more laboriously, by Senator Durack earlier on. The kind of problem that exists with section 46 is the one that was shown up in the CSPB v. Farmers Ltd. case in 1978 and which has hindered the effective operation of section 46 in practice ever since. What we had in that case is a classic demonstration of the problem. We had a manufacturer in Western Australia-all these things involving predators of one kind or another seem to be over there but I will pass that by-who dramatically and spectacularly dropped his prices in the face of the imminent entry of a competitor into that particular market place. As the law then stood that was the only evidence that was before the court. The plaintiff sought to ask the court to infer section 46 breaching conduct from that. The court, I suppose, had the capacity in principle to do that but was met with no evidence from the defendant other than a straightforward denial, without any further evidence being adduced in support of it, that he was doing anything other than just dropping his prices, full stop. There was no question of there being some sort of evidentiary onus on the defendant, as there would be now under this provision, to go further than that and actually give credible reasons why he dropped his prices other than for the purely predatory purpose of driving out the potential competitor with there being no other commercial justification.

Had there been this kind of provision in section 46 (7) in place at that time the matter would have been able to be dealt with properly and fully by the court weighing and balancing the evidence before it. As it was, the court was not inclined, without legislative support of the kind that is involved here, to go down that particular track. The case was lost by the plaintiff and section 46 has been very little relied upon ever since, with the view being very strongly taken, as I said earlier on, by the business community that unless one has something directly out of the mouth of the defendant itself, clearly establishing one or other of the prohibited purposes, it simply is not worth going to court over it. The section has been, for practical purposes, a dead letter. That is what we are trying to do with this legislation.

Senator Short says that we ought to go further than the language of the section and actually spell out that the inference can only be drawn when the conduct in question is susceptible of no other conceivable interpretation than that it was motivated by these prohibited considerations. I honestly do not believe that it is necessary to go that far. Courts can be relied upon to weigh and balance the evidence that is before them and to draw the appropriate conclusions. The clause here in issue, after all, is not one saying that a predatory purpose must be inferred from conduct or shall be inferred from particular kinds of conduct. All it says is that a predatory purpose may be inferred from that particular kind of conduct. What will happen is that when there is prima facie reason for supposing that there is some breach of this particular section, there will be an evidentiary onus then having to be borne by the defendant. The defendant will have to advance some explanation for the conduct in question and the court then will be in a position of weighing and balancing, in the normal civil proof way, the competing considerations. Against that background of the litigation history of this particular clause, I think it can be understood why the provision is in its present form. While acknowledging the general point that Senator Short has made, the Government and I do not honestly believe that it is necessary to go any further in stating the form of the amendment.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The CHAIRMAN

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 12.45 p.m., it would be convenient if the Minister moved that progress be reported.

INTERJECT.PARA: Progress reported.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Senator Gareth Evans) agreed to:
That, unless otherwise ordered, till 2 p.m. this day, matters of public interest may be discussed by senators, provided that no senator shall speak for more than 15 minutes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kilgariff Sen B.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise today to speak on the trachoma and eye health report, which has been prepared under the auspices of the Department of Aboriginal Affairs and the Department of Health, with Professor F. C. Hollows, and is dated October 1985. I do not believe this report has come into the Senate, but it has been circulated and is one of some considerable interest to those who follow the problem of trachoma. The terms of reference of the review committee were to provide a scientific report of the ocular health status of Australian Aboriginals, assess the effectiveness of existing anti-trachoma and eye health programs and to make plans to deal effectively with trachoma and poor eye health amongst Aboriginal Australians. However, an examination of the report shows that it has failed to meet the terms of reference. I seek leave at this point to table a document, which is the response of the Northern Territory Trachoma Control and Eye Health Committee to the trachoma and eye health report.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —The response details the report's inaccuracies and omissions and the mathematical errors in a proposed budget, and I will go into this in more detail later. Unfortunately, the report deals with only Western Australia, the Northern Territory and South Australia; it does not deal with Queensland and other places. I feel that I must speak on this report today as trachoma is, of course, a widespread problem in some Aboriginal communities in the Northern Territory and other places. I certainly do not criticise the Federal Government if its intention in commissioning this report was to aid in the more efficient control of the disease. However, I fear that if the recommendations in the report are adopted trachoma treatment and control will not be improved. Indeed, the implementation of the report's recommendations, I believe, would give the opposite result. There would be a lessening of the effectiveness of trachoma control programs.

SPEECH.PARA: The program with which I am most familiar is that which operates in the Northern Territory. I would like to outline to the Senate the way in which that program operates. The body which manages the trachoma control program in the Northern Territory is the Northern Territory Trachoma Control and Eye Health Committee. This is an incorporated body of some 10 members. The interesting thing is that the majority of the members of this Committee are Aboriginal people of that area. On the executive of this Committee are the Chairman, Brian Dixon, the Deputy Chairman, Terry Tilmouth, and the Treasurer, Sam Wickman, all of whom are Aboriginal people. Also on the executive is Dr Devanesen, a very dedicated doctor from India who has given much to the Aboriginal people of the Northern Territory, particularly on trachoma, and who is looked upon by the people with considerable respect and affection.

The program works with regional co-ordinators in Alice Springs and Katherine who visit all Aboriginal communities and has some 250 trained Aboriginal health workers in the communities. These people have varying degrees of expertise in the detection and treatment of trachoma, but those who received training specifically aimed at trachoma control are regarded as being every bit as competent, if not more so, than many European health workers. The trachoma training that has been provided has been provided by Dr Jim Rogers, a specialist ophthalmologist from Tasmania who, I understand, has been less than impressed by the findings of the report which cast doubts on the abilities of the Aboriginal health workers in the Northern Territory. I understand that Dr Rogers regards the Aboriginal health workers as extremely competent, as well he should. The suggestion made in this report that trained ophthalmologists are needed to identify the different varieties of trachoma just does not stand up against the experience of the Northern Territory, where trained Aboriginal health workers are very good at distinguishing between the strains of trachoma at a very early stage of the disease. I would suggest that people who disbelieve this statement should go to various places in the outback to see the health workers at work.

Father Frank Flynn was the man who really first identified the need to treat trachoma back in the 1940s, and since then there has been an ongoing program of one sort or the other in the Territory to aid in the control and treatment of the disease. The current program has been in operation since 1982 but it is, in effect, a continuation of previous programs. The Aboriginal health workers involved in the program in the communities are known to the Territory Trachoma Committee and I believe that it is quite correct to say that a rapport has been built over the years between the Department of Health in the Territory and those involved in Aboriginal communities in the trachoma program, such as Dr Hargrave, who did so much work in leprosy, and Dr Ella Stack.

The report has recommended that the operations of the State and Territory trachoma committees be wound down in favour of setting up a more centralised organisation which would have its headquarters in Sydney. To do so would be to run the risk of damaging the good working relationship which has been built up over many years as a result of a lot of hard work by Aboriginal people and the Department of Health workers in the Northern Territory. The feeling of those who have been involved in the program in the Territory is that implementing the recommendations in this report would give no better result than is presently being obtained but that it would be almost certain to lead to a poor result in treating trachoma.

The fact that some Aboriginal communities which were to be surveyed by the review committee would not co-operate is an indication of the reluctance of the Aboriginal people to depart from the established relationship which has developed between themselves and the Northern Territory health workers, and I believe too that there is some antipathy towards Dr Hollows. The Federal Government should bear that fact in mind before taking any decision to alter the existing arrangements, which would certainly be to the detriment of the Aboriginal people. I would see that there should be better co-ordination between the Federal and the regional health organisations, with the Aboriginal people certainly being encouraged to continue doing the work that they are doing.

The other point which should be made is that, apart from logistical difficulties which would arise from the centralisation of the trachoma programs, there would be staff costs-the cost of travel by staff from the headquarters in Sydney and accommodation expenses-as well as equipment costs and the possible duplication of administrative costs and procedures stemming from the need for a head office and regional offices. All of these would have major financial implications.

I understand that the trachoma report estimates that at a cost of $347,220 a committee would be able to be set up to service the central Australian area. Apart from the fact that arithmetical errors have been demonstrated, which would increase that figure to some $402,820, it must be pointed out that a similar sum would need to be spent to provide for a program in the north. It should be pointed out, too, that this compares extremely unfavourably with the figure for the entire budget requested for 1985-86 by the existing Northern Territory Committee-which, as I have mentioned before, consists mainly of Aboriginal people-which was some $199,000. The cost of the proposals in the Northern Territory would seem likely to amount to at least four times that figure, on the basis of the estimated figures in this report.

The reason for the lower figure required by the Northern Territory Trachoma Committee is that that figure does not include any staff costs whereas the report proposals include calculations for wages and salaries. The present Territory program is staffed by full time Department of Health workers who are already paid by the Department of Health and whose duties include the management of the trachoma program. It is therefore far less expensive than what has been proposed.

The Department of Health in the Territory has an extensive Aboriginal health section and its programs are comprehensive. To remove responsibility or substantially reduce its responsibility for the management of the trachoma control program will disrupt entire Aboriginal health programs and cut across the philosophy of the entire Department. The Federal Government owes it to the Aboriginal people of the outback and those who have devoted so much effort to the present program to think long and hard before it implements significant changes such as were suggested by this Trachoma and Eye Health Review.

There is no doubt that the control of trachoma is a serious matter and even though it is now detected much earlier than used to be the case the requirement for funding is still there. I think something like 2,000 people were looked at and reported on by Dr Moran from the Prince of Wales Hospital in Sydney, and he found about 43 people who were blind. I understand that of the $199,000 requested by the Northern Territory Committee this financial year it has so far received $98,000 in three separate payments. This piecemeal arrangement places serious limitations upon the existing Northern Territory program because it does not allow the Committee to determine fully programs for the year in the knowledge of having access to adequate funds. I believe that the Federal Government would be better served if it recognised the excellent work of the Northern Territory Trachoma Committee and the Aboriginal health workers and provided the funds the Committee needs before dismantling it in favour of a more expensive and less effective proposition.

All in all, I guess this was an attempt to bring about a report, but the report, as I have said before, is deficient in various areas. I wonder why Queensland was included in this. Queensland, as I understand it, certainly has a high incidence of trachoma. There is another deficiency in the report. It provides various statistics, including a breakdown by race of the numbers of people screened during the 1985 review, particularly those communities examined in Western Australia, the Northern Territory and South Australia. It seems to me obvious that hygiene comes into this too in the control of trachoma. When one looks at the statistics and moves around the outback-it appears that there is less trachoma in settlements on river banks or on the coast. That seems to suggest that hygiene must come into it too. Where the children and grown-ups are close to rivers, the sea and such there is better hygiene and there seems to be less trachoma.

In any case, I believe it is very heartening to see the work that the Aboriginal health workers are doing now in the outback. The work that they are doing now within their Trachoma Committee and the work that they do out in the bush amongst their own people has to be seen to realise the valuable asset that they are developing. Various inspections have been made and reported on in this report, I believe for statistical purposes. Such inspections should be kept up to show the results of the work that is taking place.

I say to the Federal Government: Beware; in assuming that this report and its recommendations are correct it is being directed along the wrong road. I suggest very strongly to the Federal Government, to these people who are responsible for the funding of Aboriginal health in the outback, that they look very carefully at the work of this Northern Territory Trachoma Committee, which I believe is doing such a tremendous job in handling and controlling the trachoma problem.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mason Sen C.V.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to raise today the question of whether or not the jury system as it applies in Australia now is the most suitable and equitable system of determining court verdicts. I particularly want to address my remarks to the role of the jury in determining verdicts in criminal trials which require lay persons without any special knowledge or background or educational qualifications to analyse and make the most profound and final judgments on complex evidence of a scientific, legal or commercial nature-especially complex forensic matters. In the past few years there has been increasing concern expressed in a number of quarters about the role of the jury in the Australian legal system and, according to one commentator, Peter Sallman:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . we are probably overdue in Australia for a full scale inquiry into the criminal trial process. There have been plenty of thorough inquiries into the police, pre-trial criminal investigation, sentencing and prisons, but nothing serious on the trial.

I think that has to be qualified by the point that, as I recall, several law reform commissions have had a go at the jury system. It seems to be the fate of law reform commissions to be ignored substantially in their recommendations. That is not a criticism of the government; it is a statement of fact with which the chairmen and ex-chairmen of a number of law reform commissions would concur. At least one has certainly mentioned it to me on a number of occasions. Therefore it would seem that on a matter as important as this it will become necessary to try another way; in other words, to come at this situation differently. I will propose at some stage here, and I intend this speech to be a sort of curtain raiser to that, that an inquiry, possibly by our own Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs, be made into that matter. Senator Puplick shrinks at the thought and I do not blame him.

TALK.START.PARA: —As a member of the Committee, I certainly do.

—As he is a member of the Committee, I sympathise with him greatly, but I would have thought that this matter is now becoming so important that at some stage it would be a matter that this Senator could properly concern itself with. It is wise to bear in mind, I think, the conventional wisdom. There are two prevailing community attitudes. The first is that any criticism of the jury system is rather like being anti-motherhood-it is one of those things that you do not criticise. Then a rationalisation follows: If trial by jury is not perfect, it is at least the best system we have. I suggest that is not adequate for present day conditions. We speak and think of this now with the Splatt case in South Australia in the recent background, with its complete reassessment of forensic evidence after a commission of inquiry had looked at it, and of course the Chamberlain case is very much in the news at this time with its highly controversial material concerning forensic evidence.

SPEECH.PARA: The system of trials has undergone a long process of evolutionary change. Trial by ordeal, with the use of hot and cold water and by other means, was the oldest form of trial. It was replaced by trial by battle, a period of inquisition and the star chamber system, until eventually the Magna Carta basis for the right of trial by jury appears to have come into common use. `No free man should be taken or imprisoned but by lawful judgment of his peers or by the law of the land', as chapter 29 of the Magna Carta says. By 1640 defendants had the right to call their own witnesses, whose word was not doubted unless contradicted by another witness. By the nineteenth century juries could reach their verdict only on evidence produced in court. Then, of course, there developed the traditions of beyond reasonable doubt and proof of innocence.

We are looking back, then, at a relatively simple world compared with the world of the present day. I think this is really what is at the heart and core of this argument. Life, and indeed trials-criminal matters-are becoming far more complex than they ever were. I think we have to look really at whether or not a jury of persons taken off the street can reasonably be expected to make judgments on such matters. I think in some States in Australia already there have been changes in the law where matters of computer crime and things of that sort occur. Certainly, in that area it ought to be recognised that it is not really possible for a lay jury to make the kinds of assessments which would be necessary to come to an equitable verdict.

Of course, it has been argued in some cases that we might replace the jury with a judge in such a case, or perhaps a judge and assessors, but there is no guarantee that a judge would have any greater understanding of complex facts in which he or she is not trained. It has to be said, with all respect to that learned fraternity, that surveys have found that some judges at least, and perhaps most judges, are reluctant to undergo specialised training for particular cases. There are many in the community who would argue that the jury system, even as it stands, is the best in existence and should be retained. I tend to share that view.

The Canadian Law Reform Commission has argued that a jury brings to bear on its decision a diversity of experience, that it deliberates as a group and has the advantages of collective recall and that the deliberative process of a jury contributes to better fact finding because each detail is explored and subjected to constant scrutiny by the group. It has been said too that a jury, unlike a judge, can take into account the human factor and bring to bear the broad community conscience in its verdict and that there is a certain relief from the judge of the sole responsibility of making a decision, which in serious cases is important, all of us being no more than human beings. It has been claimed the jury system is a kind of bastion against oppression because juries are often reluctant to apply the law in cases where unjust, unfair or harsh results will occur. Of course, juries have been criticised for that tendency as well. Those comments are, I believe, idealistic. The system is not working well enough and is not likely to change and work well enough in the future unless somebody, somewhere, soon has a look at it and tries to do something about it.

Just to look briefly at this question of trial by judge: If it were introduced on a wider scale, I think great difficulties would be encountered on matters of time. We have the present quite intolerable situation in which, in the Family Court of Australia, judges can take up to 18 months to hand down a final decision once hearings have finished. That is, of course, the cause for additional delays before hearings can begin. I do not think we could tolerate a situation where we made changes which made that situation even worse.

The alternative to the jury system as it presently operates that has been advocated to me by a considerable number of lawyers, including some in this Parliament I might say, is the possibility of an examination of the idea of a trial before a judge and specialist juries in some cases. This would call for specialist panels of experts who are available for jury service in complex cases and who are empanelled in very much the same way as a jury is empanelled now, with the rights of challenge and with the normal provisions to provide inasmuch as that is possible, a jury as unbiased, as fair and as broad in its view as is possible. In other words, if we had a panel of experts, so called, they would not necessarily want to be the kind of experts who were unanimous, who were so close to their subject that they felt they would be uniform for that reason alone. I think it is necessary that such a panel would have to have a variety of experience and background and to be able to approach any subject, especially forensic evidence, from a variety of points of view.

There are many questions that would need to be answered on that before that alternative could be implemented. This would include: Who would be on the jury-how indeed one does assemble these panels; what qualifications and/or expertise would be required of people who are on that panel-whether they went on to the panel as volunteers or whether they went on as normal citizens because it was regarded as part of their community service; would there in fact readily be available a sufficient number of such expert people in all categories and, if not, which categories could be used. Then, of course, there is the point: Should not such experts really be in the witness box giving evidence and explaining it and not on the jury trying questions of fact? I do not go along very much with that last point because both are possible, plainly. It is possible to have an expert jury and an expert giving evidence and there is at least then a better chance of the jury understanding what the expert is on about.

Having briefly considered some of the more popular alternatives that have been advocated to the jury system, I would like to turn my attention to some of the reforms that I believe, and that people who know better than I do believe, should be instituted so as to make for the more efficient operation of juries. These reforms, which have come from a variety of expert experience, include: That jurors be provided with indexed copies of transcripts of evidence and written directions on points of law. That seems to me so self-evident that it ought to be implemented forthwith. The second reform is the narrowing of reasons for exemption so that jurors can be more representative of the community. I think that this in the modern world is something which is worth thinking about.

An interesting and innovative one is that issue papers be produced for each juror, which would set out, among other things perhaps, the following: Those matters in the trial which are in dispute and those which are not; a summary of the prosecution and defence views of the issues, prepared by the prosecution and defence; and a glossary of technical terms and their meanings which have been agreed to by the judge and/or counsel involved in the case. The third reform is the provision of improved access to interpreter services. That, I think, is a continuing problem in the whole of our legal system. Aborigines, in particular, because so many of them are involved in criminal indictments in this country, should receive education on the nature of the criminal trial so that they really understand what their rights are and what is happening to them.

Finally, judges who are required to hear trials which include the admission of complex evidence of a medical, scientific or corporate nature should undergo some mandatory special training in such subjects. I am not so cynical as to believe that many judges would do that of their own accord. They are plainly not going to sit on a case, in most cases, without at least trying to have some awareness of what they are working on. It is a busy life for our judges. They are all overworked, as we know. Some special provision might be made. Perhaps provision might be made for a group of judges who wanted to specialise in certain areas. That is another point of departure that might be studied.

When one goes over all that two things are clear: First, when so many eminent people in the community find it necessary to criticise aspects of the jury system, which as all honourable senators will agree is one of the fundamental tenets of our democratic system, there is an urgent need for an inquiry into that system. The second point is that it is not going to be easy. No one person or no group of people are going to come up with the answers to this easily or quickly. If anything is done, it has to be done in a systematic way.

I intend to move at some stage for an inquiry into the jury system and how it operates in this country, possibly by the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs. That Committee, with the benefit of public input, could inquire into the jury system and could determine, I think, in broad terms, what might be done to improve the system. I do not say that such an inquiry would solve all the problems, but even if it looked at some of the things that I have mentioned in this speech, which have been raised by very respectable legal authorities in this country, the report of that Committee to the Senate might be something that the Federal Government might look at.

It might be possible, in that way, to get this important matter elevated to a higher profile than it has had before we get a situation in which more and more Australians, who may be innocent, are found guilty because of the inadequacies of the system. I think once we look at it from that point of view, without going into individual cases or personalities-even to admit the possibility of injustice to the community and members of the community, whom it is the first duty of government to protect-the importance of this matter begins to be seen. It is not just an academic matter; it is a matter which concerns very directly the life and liberty of citizens of this country. On that basis I think it must assume a considerable importance.

I have raised what I have said today as a preliminary to those interested giving some thought to that matter. It is clear that certainly not I-I am not a trained lawyer-and perhaps not any other individual group would have all or perhaps even most of the answers to this very complex question, but it is clear that when the question of the operation of the jury system has been subject, and reasonably, to study by three State law reform commissions and has been criticised by many more eminent people in society than I am, the time has come for a full scale inquiry into that system that will be effective. The sooner that happens, the better.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jessop Sen D.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to support the concern expressed by Senator Kilgariff in drawing attention to some of the omissions and inaccuracies in the report on trachoma and eye health which was presented in October last year by a review committee comprising representatives of the National Aboriginal and Islander Health Organisation, the Department of Aboriginal Affairs, the Department of Health and Professor F. C. Hollows. I have taken a professional interest in follicular trachoma for a long time. I recall meeting Father Frank Flynn at Darwin many years ago now. Father Flynn was an opthalmologist himself and he displayed a lot of concern about the incidence of trachoma at that time, amongst Aborigines in particular. Four or five, or perhaps six, decades ago trachoma in Australia was a real problem, not only amongst Aborigines but also amongst white people living in dry, arid zone areas, which provided the environment for the spread and contraction of this disease due to the dusty conditions that they were living under. Of course, that is one of the main reasons why people contract the disease follicula trachoma.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Kilgariff referred to hygiene. Really, it is a question of hygiene and training Aboriginal people living in the more remote areas to look after their health in this respect. I recall going some years ago from Port Augusta to Coober Pedy, where I carried out, to my knowledge, the first optometrical clinic there. This was well before I was in Parliament. I examined 30 or 40 Aboriginal people at that time and I was unable to examine the eyes of half of them because they had mucopurulent conjunctivitis and, I strongly suspect, were well on the way to contracting trachoma. I had to ask the sister to provide them with chloromycetin to get rid of that infection before I was able to examine the patients, which necessitated a further visit.

The Aborigines in that area, of course, are in an ideal environment to contract this disease. It is a disease that emanates from the eyelashes. In the old days it used to be called granulated eyelids, which is, in effect, what it is. The lids become granulated and blinking the eyes causes scarification of the cornea, which eventually results in the cornea becoming opaque and ultimately the patient becomes totally blind. Those Aborigines in Coober Pedy were white with the dust of the opal mines there. Of course, that dust causes corneal irritation. There are a lot of flies in the area which transmit disease. Also, it is interesting to note that the eyelid action of Aborigines is far slower and far less frequent than that of Europeans. The flies can do their work a little bit more effectively because of the slowness of the lid action to dispense with them.

It is a serious matter and I do not think this report is a very credible document. Certainly it attempts to come to grips with the problem but, as Senator Kilgariff has said, to suggest that a body be established in Sydney is quite ridiculous. There is far more merit in developing greater co-operation with the Commonwealth and ensuring that more funds are made available so that these diseases can be dealt with more effectively by the States and the Northern Territory local government.

A critique, I suppose, of this report was presented by a committee which consists of 10 members, seven of whom, I understand, including the Chairman, are Aborigines. There is also an Indian, a Filipino and Dr Ella Stack, who is a medical doctor in Darwin and a former mayor. These people decided to get an independent assessment by an epidemiologist of excellent qualifications. He has been somewhat critical of the misinformation that this report contains. Senator Kilgariff pointed, I think, to the arithmetic errors in the report. At the end of the report it is suggested that 50 pairs of spectacles were provided at a cost of $80 each. The amount shown is $40,000, whereas it should be $4,000.

Senator Kilgariff referred to Professor Hollows. There is no mention in the report of the fact that he was unable to perform the various clinical inspections himself and had to rely on others to do it. I see in the comments on the misinformation in the report that Professor Hollows was not acceptable in some areas of the Northern Territory and in fact was unable to gain admittance. There are other omissions in the report. For example, when it refers to the southern committee of the Northern Territory it does not mention the fact that, for the first time, a medical officer has been doing almost full time work on trachoma and, on every trip that he has carried out, has written several articles and reports containing accurate information and pointing out the discrepancies that occur from time to time.

The statement also states-but it does not go into this in a great deal of detail; it should have more regard to it-that the Central Australian Aboriginal Congress does not give particular priority to trachoma treatment in screening because of the various priority needs in the area. Three Aboriginal health services agree with that. Certainly there is a significant incidence of severe trachoma amongst Aborigines around Alice Springs and this will continue to produce an unavoidable overburden of blindness for Aborigines. This area also has a high incidence of hepatitis B, respiratory disease and sexually transmitted diseases. That is quite a significant and damning statement, I think. This has been a great worry to people in the Alice Springs area, as this pool of untreated trachoma lies around the periphery of the town. It shows that the Central Australian Aboriginal Congress does not place as much emphasis on the problem of trachoma as it does on other areas of Aboriginal health. Nevertheless, it is a serious matter. I agree with Senator Kilgariff's suggestion that more attention ought to be given to the good work that is being done and has been done by the Northern Territory and State health departments. I think, it ought to be followed up with more co-operation from the Commonwealth, more funds and assistance in this very important area.

I want to raise briefly another matter; that is, the problems that we are experiencing and have experienced for some time with lightning strikes by parliamentary staff affecting the provision of meals here. I know it has been a long and protracted problem, but I do sympathise with the staff. They have co-operated in changing operational aspects of their management in providing the Parliament with food and drinks, and I think that that is commendable. There are matters that need to be discussed and some that have been the subject of continuing discussions. I think this morning there was a meeting with the conciliation and arbitration people in the Australian Capital Territory, and that was followed by a meeting with Joint House and union representatives. It seems to me that it is a matter that ought to be easily resolved.

I understand that 22 years ago the mother of one of the present staff was a permanent casual here. The present employee indicated that her mother was receiving $5.20 an hour for that sort of work 22 years ago. Today they are receiving something like $8 an hour. Permanent employees get about $6 per hour. That seems to me to be a very small increase in their hourly rate of pay after such a long time-22 years. We have to consider that people in their sort of employment outside this Parliament attract tips that I have not seen evident from many members of the House or the Senate, which provides added remuneration outside. I do not think that staff here expect that.

I do think it is fair to suggest that something ought to happen quite urgently on this. It should be in the hands of the Presiding Officer to make some sort of determination about it. I do not think it comes under appropriations and staffing. The Clerk is shaking his head. Nevertheless, I think we as members of parliament ought to be concerned about it, particularly when we are deprived of the vital sustenance that enables us to stand on our feet and contribute so vigorously to the debates in the Senate from time to time. Through you, Mr Acting Deputy President, I do urge the President and the Speaker to do all they can to resolve the problem quickly and perhaps to present a report to the Senate, hopefully today. I would like optimistically to believe that in the very near future the problems of the staff in Parliament will be resolved.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —On this occasion I wish to make some remarks regarding the success of an undertaking which has been promoted by the National Film and Sound Archive known as the Last Film Search. I am glad that Senator Ryan is the Minister on duty in the chamber because I know that she and many members of her Party have given a great deal of support to the film industry and to the work of the National Film and Sound Archive, and that she and others have a great personal interest in this matter. On 20 October 1981 the Last Film Search was launched by the film maker Peter Weir at a ceremony in Melbourne. The purpose of this exercise was to scour Australia, and indeed to extend the search to overseas, in order to try to find as much as possible of the remaining holdings of pre-1951 nitrate film. Most of this film, of course, has already entirely vanished. It has decayed and decomposed and simply physically does not exist any longer.

SPEECH.PARA: The Last Film Search got under way with its theme `Nitrate Won't Wait'. That is precisely the problem. A great deal of Australia's film heritage is on nitrate film, which is simply incapable of lasting many years. The object of the film search was to discover as much of this nitrate film as possible and to preserve it: Where it could only be preserved, the preservation itself was a worthwhile exercise; where, however, it was in a condition to be copied, the film is being copied on to stable acetate stock.

The film industry in Australia is one of our oldest industries. It dates back well into the 1890s. This country was an absolute pioneer of the development of the moving picture industry and there is, in terms of Australia's recorded heritage, a greater proportion of our country's heritage recorded on film than there is of almost any similar country's heritage anywhere in the world. The film industry and the non-commercial sector of film making have a major contribution to make in preserving Australian history and identifying unique features of Australia and its national life.

The search was conducted, not only in terms of an advertising campaign sponsored by the National Film and Sound Archive but equally by having a quite unique program in which the field officer of the Last Film Search, Mr Michael Cordell, in fact spent two years travelling Australia by car and caravan. In the course of those two years he probably travelled more extensively throughout Australia, including its most remote regions, than almost anybody else has in recent years. The aim of the project was to take the caravan into remote locations; to get coverage in the local media and local radio and, where possible, local television; to indicate to people that if they had old nitrate film, would they please bring it to Mr Cordell and steps would be undertaken to acquire it or to get it on loan, or whatever it happened to be.

I think it is also important to recognise that this is an expensive process and to recognise that Kodak (Australasia) Pty Ltd was prepared to contribute $100,000 to this undertaking. I think it is deserving of very great credit for having been prepared to be a major sponsor, indeed the major sponsor, of the whole project. I think it is important to indicate that this project-the Last Film Search-has been an outstanding success. Let me put it in this perspective: A silent feature film is approximately 6,000 to 8,000 feet in length and the Last Film Search has already acquired more than a million feet of film and is currently negotiating for the acquisition of almost as much again-almost another million feet of film, which it hopes to be able to acquire. This, by measure of its own success, has caused some difficulties to the extent that, I think, the success was far greater than anticipated. As a result, delays of up to two years are being experienced in examining the material and in turning it round; that is to say, in turning it into a usable film on stable acetate stock.

It is important, I think, similarly to indicate that some very significant discoveries have been made. For instance, the search has recovered the whole of a feature film made by the great film maker, Longford, in 1918, called The Woman Suffers.
