It has recovered further segments of The Kelly Gang, a film made in 1906, which indeed was the world's first feature film. I think that is indicative of not only the great success of this project but also the great historical significance of the Australian film industry. Mr Acting Deputy President, I seek leave to have incorporated in Hansard a brief summary of the feature films, short films, films about personalities and films about major events which have been recovered as a result of the success to date of the last film search.
Leave granted.
The summary read as follows-
SOME MAJOR FINDS:

Feature Films: Several minutes of The Story of the Kelly Gang (1906); complete copy of The Adorable Outcast (1929); incomplete and decomposing copy of The Woman Suffers (1918); fragments and partial copies of others from the silent and sound eras including two silent films that cannot be identified from existing histories of the Australian film industry.

Short Films: The 1897 Melbourne Cup; Harum Skarum Skirt, a 1908 comedy made in Newcastle; scores of fragments and complete issues of Cinesound Review, Australian Movietone News, Australasian Gazette and other newsreels; a hard-core pornographic film from the 1920s; film of every royal visit to Australia this century; numerous theatrical commercials and electioneering films which give a fascinating window on Australian life in the first half of this century.

Personalities: Documentary, newsreel or home movie footage of Prime Minister Bob Hawke (as a child of 5), Sir Robert Menzies, Boy Charlton, Walter Lindrum, `Smithy', Amy Johnson, Banjo Paterson, etc., etc.

Events Great and Small: The unveiling of the `dog on the tuckerbox' near Gundagai; everyday life in Brisbane in the mid-1890s; Scotch College, Melbourne, in the 1930s; Neville John Dossetto in the maiden flight of the first aircraft built in Queensland; new technology in farming methods in the 1930s; the first car to travel around Australia; Aboriginal life early this century, etc.

TALK.START.PARA: —The other thing that I think ought to be indicated is that it is not just the recovery of film that has been successful. The Last Film Search has brought to light materials such as stills, posters, photographs, scrapbooks, scripts, vintage equipment and so on. Indeed, at a fascinating visit to the Film and Sound Archive I had an opportunity to look at some of the diaries recovered as a result of the Last Film Search. These include diaries of people actually involved in film making, books of newspaper cuttings of films and films actually being produced, letters memento and memorabilia, all of which are important for an understanding of film culture and for an understanding of the historical development of the Australian film industry. Australia has, unfortunately, a rather poor record in terms of the amount of the silent films made in this country which have actually been recovered-probably only about 5 per cent. This is considerably less than is the case in places such as the United Kingdom or the United States of America.

SPEECH.PARA: At the same time, the film search has given an impetus to a search to collect our old recordings. If one looks again at the collection of the National Film and Sound Archive, some of the old sound recordings, some of the old gramophone records, some of the old Edison cylinders, some of the material which is preserved there are quite fascinating. There are, in fact, gramophone records which are made on aluminium discs rather than on the sort of vinyl that is current. There are the old Edison cylinders which are still in playable form and, more to the point, there are enormous resources and collections of sheet music, a great deal of it unlikely ever to be played again but, nevertheless, indicative of part of the nation's cultural history. I understand that the Australian Broadcasting Corporation later this year is to produce a one-hour documentary on the success of the Australian film search, the Last Film Search, and I think that will bring to further public attention the great work that the Film and Sound Archive has done.

In mentioning the Archive, I think that both Graham Gilmour, as the Director of the Archive, and Ray Edmondson, as one of the principal people concerned with the preservation of Australia's film heritage, deserve a degree of public recognition which is as great as the recognition actually given to the film stars and the film makers because they are contributing mightily to the Australian film industry.

Mention of the ancient sound recordings gives me the opportunity, perhaps, to raise one matter with the Minister for Education (Senator Ryan), which I am sure she would view sympathetically. That is that, of course, the old silent films were accompanied by piano music. Most of that piano music was in the form of piano roll and piano rolls are one of the very small but interesting areas which have been adversely affected by the Government's decision to reimpose a sales tax previously removed by Mr Howard when he was Treasurer. In the latest changes to sales tax arrangements the piano roll has been resubjected to a 15 per cent sales tax.

There is only one company in Australia, that is in New South Wales, the Mastertouch Piano Roll Co., which actually continues to make piano rolls. Interestingly enough, there are no longer any companies in the United Kingdom making piano rolls and there are only two companies in the United States making them. This company, which operates in Sydney, not only is producing piano rolls of contemporary music but, of course, is seeking to recreate the music which was appropriate to the old films and music which has some historical significance. Some of the reproductions, for instance, of original piano rolls which actually feature Percy Grainger's playing of his own music and playing of some of the great classics, is a very important contribution in a very small area. I would hope that the Government, when it is doing its next Budget sums, would be able to look sympathetically at the very simple proposition: Here is one company with a small output but, nevertheless, the margins are very, very small and I do believe that freeing them from the imposition of that sales tax would be of assistance.

There are two other matters which I raise very briefly. The first is that I have recently written to the Victoria Racing Club suggesting that one of the things that it might like to undertake as a bicentennial project would be to create a documentary history of the Melbourne Cup. Interestingly enough, the first film actually made in Australia is a film made by a visiting French cameraman with a Lumiere Camera, of the 1896 Melbourne Cup. In the Last Film Search a film of the 1897 Melbourne Cup was recovered. My understanding is that within the holdings of the Australian film archives probably almost every Melbourne Cup since 1896 has been recorded in whole or in part on some sort of reproducible film. I believe that the Club responsible for sponsoring the Cup could well find it a very worthwhile project to put together, with the assistance of the Film and Sound Archive, the history of the Cup, which would be a history revealing not only the great horses and jockeys but also the fashions, the personalities, the people involved with the Cup. Perhaps nothing could be more appropriate within the framework of the significance of the Melbourne Cup in Australia's national life. In fact, this would be worthwhile as an undertaking.

The other point is that I hope the Government will look at one of the recommendations of the recent report of the advisory committee inquiring into the Film and Sound Archive under the very distinguished chairmanship of Joan Long. That report dealt with the question of compulsory deposit. Although at this stage the advisory committee has recommended that deposit of film made in Australia should in fact be on a voluntary basis, I believe in fact it should be on a compulsory basis in the same way as the deposit of books with the National Library of Australia is made compulsory and that we should require film makers, particularly those who are benefiting from the Government's tax assistance and subsidy measures, to deposit with the Film and Sound Archive a completed film, a master, and certain other materials such as a completed script and a completed cast list.

I am glad to have had the opportunity to record in Hansard the success of the Last Film Search, to pay great tribute to those who were involved with it and to record my belief that the preservation of Australia's national heritage in film and sound recordings is a major contribution to the cultural life of Australia. I know it has great support on this side of the chamber. I know it has support from the Minister and from her side of the chamber. I hope that in the years ahead the Last Film Search and its extension to the search for sound recordings will continue to have great success and will continue to be a great credit to all of those involved.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Today I want to draw the Senate's attention to some far more disastrous figures that are hidden in the detail of the balance of payments figures that came out yesterday. These balance of payments figures, in themselves, were sufficiently serious to concern most commentators. Within those figures there is in fact a far more serious, far more disturbing element; that is, that there is $3 billion of tax revenue now put at risk as a result of the collapse of oil exports revealed in the February figures and the massive reduction in motor vehicle imports.

SPEECH.PARA: If we can deal with the oil exports problem first, because this is a problem that I have been drawing to the attention of the Senate for quite some time. The collapse in oil prices has been seen generally by most commentators as only having an impact on our balance of payments, but if the current trends continue-those that have already been shown in the February figures-the Government revenue by way of levy and tax relating to oil exports will fall by $1,500m in the coming year. The impact that will have on the Government's budgetary strategy is, of course, enormous. That $1,500m is self-evident from the figures that we have had available. The balance of payment statistics demonstrated, for example, that in February exports of mineral fuels-that is, excluding coal, coke and briquettes; in other words, exports of mineral fuels made up of oil, condensate and liquefied petroleum gas-fell from the January figure of $355m to only $95m. In the financial year 1984-85 these exports totalled $2.4 billion and Australia became, for the first time in its history, a net oil exporter.

We can see what happened in February, according to those statistics, and that is not simply a once off situation. It is now a permanent disaster, not only for Australia's balance of payments but also for the revenue collecting arm of this Government. This Government, of course, has yet to acknowledge it, yet to recognise it and yet to act on it. Having looked at this figure and, of course, the dramatic drop in revenue that will emerge as a result of the fall in motor vehicle sales, one wonders how safe our $2m in tax cuts that are promised for September are. Already we have seen the Government announce that it has to cut government spending by $1.4 billion if it is not to have a deficit of $6.4 billion in the coming Budget. Given this additional inevitable burden, unless something dramatic happens to change it, the Government is going to face an additional blowout of that deficit to make up for this extraordinary, this enormous collapse in revenue.

Let us see why the oil revenue collapse is certain to continue. The documents in response to the takeover bid from Mr Holmes a Court indicate quite clearly what the Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd. thinks will happen to oil exports in the coming months; that is, of course, provided the world oil price remains low, and most forecasts are that it will. The company has released information that it would expect Bass Strait to cut back production from 500,000 barrels a day to about 430,000 barrels a day, of which 350,000 would go to domestic refiners. The Sydney Morning Herald has reported:
The oil can stay in the ground, but the Government, which charges the partners an average of about 55 per cent as levy on the exports-
that is levy on exports alone, apart from any other taxes--
stands to miss out on $1.19 million a day and the partners jointly will lose $975,000 in revenue a day, on the loss of 80,000 barrels a day in exports.
That is what the Sydney Morning Herald reported last week. This week the Australian reported, under the heading: `Oil price plummet forces Kingfish rig to shut down':
The crash in world oil prices forced the indefinite shutdown yesterday of a production platform in Bass Strait, Australia's main field.
This was Kingfish A. The article continues:
Kingfish A is one of 12 production platforms in Bass Strait which together produce most of Australia's crude oil requirements.
The rig has produced about 35,000 barrels of oil a day from a total Bass Strait production of 400,000 barrels.

We have already seen BHP's forecast becoming fact. One oil rig so far has been shut down and on top of that other exporters have had great difficulty in proceeding to sell the oil for which they have already received export permits from the Government. The Australian article mentions this, saying:
Oil industry analysts speculated that one of the main contributing factors in the decision to close Kingfish A was Esso/BHP's inability to export crude recently.
Three export cargoes-two from Esso and one from BHP-have been due for shipment in the past six weeks but none has left Australian shores.

The fact is-I raised this with Senator Evans some weeks ago-that, as I understand it, many approvals that the Government has given for exports simply cannot take place because the price is too low and clearly will stay too low. As I said, we have always concentrated on the impact that is having on the balance of payments. We saw in yesterday's figures the continuing disaster, that the fall in oil exports was certainly one of the major elements in the deficit going out by another $1.03 billion in February, to take the eight-month total to $9.5 billion as a current account deficit. Despite what Mr Hawke has said-I am grateful to the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Button) for at least telling the truth on this matter-there is no sign of any turnaround.

As I see it, it is not simply the balance of payments problem that should concern the Senate or Australia; it is this incredible impact on Government revenues. Quite frankly, I think the Sydney Morning Herald massively understated it. As I understand it, there is a range of excises and duties on export oil, the minimum being about 50 per cent and the maximum being up around 90 per cent. I think it would be appropriate to say that on average about three-quarters of each dollar of oil revenue goes to the Government. That would mean, of course, that if we had these huge export revenues last year we are going to see a revenue cut of $1.5 billion to $2 billion if the the current inability to sell oil is perpetuated. If the Government really wishes to encourage oil exports, I suppose the only thing it could do would be to reduce its slice of that action, but if it did so, of course, that also would have a downward impact on Government revenues. I just wonder whether the $6.4 billion dollars deficit figure which we were warned of last week in the leaked Cabinet document does not include any kind of estimate of this magnitude-$1.5 billion to $2 billion-for falls in Government revenues from oil this year.

This is only half the story. The other half relates to another $1.5 billion in revenue to be lost from motor vehicle sales. The Sydney Morning Herald on 12 March ran a story headed: `Car sales slump set to force tax repeal'. Here was the suggestion that, because motor vehicle sales had dropped so dramatically because of the fringe benefit belting that the Government gave this industry last year in its fringe benefit taxes, the Vehicle Builders Union had been sufficiently effective and dynamic to force the Government to change its policy and reduce the level of tax.

Let us face it: What this is all about is that the Government now recognises belatedly that by trying to get more tax out of people by fringe benefits it has destroyed the tax raising prospects, which are big bickies, involved in the actual sale of motor vehicles. On top of that we had devaluation, which has destroyed the competitive capacity of a large proportion of imported vehicles-that is, of course, where the Government makes most of its money. The revenue consequences now are enormous. I spoke this morning to one group in the motor vehicle industry, who told me that in February sales of motor vehicles overall were down about 25 per cent, which is about 10,000 units, and that a bigger proportion of the fall came from these far more expensive imports, with Japanese prices going up 30 per cent or so because of the devaluation.

The reality is that not only do we have the enormous excise; we also have enormous sales tax. So there is a double whammy involved every time there is a reduction in motor vehicle registrations. We have already heard from the vehicle builders union a claim that General Motors-Holden's Ltd dealers in New South Wales showed an overall drop of 45.16 per cent in company fleet passenger purchases. We have had a suggestion that in Victoria there has been something like a 20 per cent cut in passenger sales. The significance is obviously enormous when we look at the sort of revenue the Government makes from motor cars. In an article by Mike Kable in today's Australian newspaper he points this out:
. . . the 57.5 per cent tariff is applied on the landed cost of cars, not on the ex-factory price.

As most senators would know, the minimum price now for a reasonable imported car is about $25,000, apart from once offers at around the $10,000 level. That would not be the landed cost; there would be a reasonable margin between that and the landed cost. On top of that landed cost we have sales tax involving $3,500 on a car selling for $25,000. So we end up with something like $12,500 per imported vehicle, being the total revenue to the Government. If we did have a reduction of just 5,000 imported vehicles a month that would involve something like $60m overall per month, because there is a $12,000 or so loss of revenue to the Government per vehicle. That alone works out at about three quarters of a billion dollars in revenue, plus that sales tax of $150m or so. It is just under $1 billion even if the registrations are cut by only 5,000 per month, yet the evidence so far is that the figure is 10,000. It seems to me that $1 billion to $1.5 billion is a very moderate expectation of the revenue fall if the difficulties in the motor vehicle industry, that have largely been generated by this Government, are not resolved.

Imports have been cut. Perhaps this is the only example of Mr Keating's J curve working. Presumably he hoped that he would have a 100 per cent failure rate with the J curve, because this in fact will cause a revenue disaster for the Government. The consequences for taxes and government spending are indeed enormous. I do hope that the Government applies its mind to this matter because it seems to have escaped its attention so far. It is a matter of the gravest consequence to Australians' hip pockets, to the tax rates they are going to face. I believe it puts in serious jeopardy the tax cuts that this Government has promised for September of this year. I ask the Government to give a guarantee that they will proceed.
(Quorum formed)

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Finance and Minister representing the Treasurer and follows the question I asked yesterday about the Government's ability to meet the trilogy commitment with respect to revenue. I remind the Minister that he pointed out yesterday that he did not have precise figures in his head but gave the answer that, on a more strict definition of the trilogy, the commitment would be met. I further remind the Minister that in the Budget Papers circulated by him at Budget time it is made quite clear on pages 59 and 382 of Budget Paper No. 1 that the trilogy commits the Government not to increase tax revenue as a proportion of gross domestic product in 1985-86. Is the Minister now in a position to give a firm assurance to the Senate that the Government will meet that trilogy commitment during the current financial year?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Treasurer was asked a very similar question yesterday. I do not know whether Hansard is out, but I have here a proof copy of what he said:

ANSWER.PARA: It is not yet clear how receipts will finish the year, as it is not yet clear how the trilogy ceiling will settle down.

He added that at this stage we have only one quarter's national accounts and, therefore, the estimate of GDP at this stage must be considered to be somewhat uncertain. As I said yesterday, the figure of $1.1 billion increase in receipts was alleged to have been contained in a submission of the Treasurer which was leaked, and the most recent estimate of which I am aware is that the receipts will not overshoot the Budget estimate by that size; it will be something less than $1 billion. At this stage, until the final outcome, both of GDP in this year and of receipts, becomes clearer, one cannot give a precise percentage. As the Treasurer said yesterday, present indications are that the receipts as a proportion of GDP will not exceed those of 1984-85.

I think I perhaps should add that both outlays and receipts have been artificially inflated because of the Government decision to compensate oil refiners to some extent for the stocks which they held and which they were continuing to accumulate, through the month of February in particular, at prices well above the actual import parity price. The Government was in a position-and bear in mind that there has never been any legislative backing for the crude oil absorption policy-where the refiners could have refused to take delivery of oil in February at the then administered price of about $A44 a barrel and waited until the 1 March crude oil price adjustment which brought the price down to about $A28 a barrel. Knowing that that was the position, the Government agreed, subject to the refiners maintaining their lifting schedules, that they would be compensated to some extent for the stock losses held. The effect of that has been to artificially inflate both outlays and receipts for that year compared with what would have happened had the Government not made that decision. Presumably oil refiners would have lifted a good deal less Australian crude in February than they did and the Government would have lost revenue on the crude oil excise but saved the compensation which is recorded as an outlay.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have a supplementary question. I thank the Minister for that answer and acknowledge that, if the Government chooses to incur extra expenditure and to raise extra taxes, that will change the figures. Given the uncertainties which the Minister has outlined in his answer, is it not true that he is telling the Senate that it is not possible for the Government to give a firm and categorical assurance about meeting the trilogy and that in fact that will have to be a matter of retrospective assessment when the final figures become available some time in the next financial year?

—Senator Chaney should be well aware of the fact that final outcomes deviate very substantially from Budget estimates. Anybody who was a member of the Government in which John Howard was the Treasurer should be aware of that because, as the Treasurer noted yesterday-and in this he was mildly in error-the cumulative total overrun of the Howard deficit was $2.8 billion. In fact, that was the overrun in the deficit in the last Budget that Mr Howard presented; in one Budget alone the deficit blew out by $2.8 billion and in all of his five Budget outlays were in excess of Budget estimates, most spectacularly in the final, irresponsible year in office, when outlays were in excess of Budget estimates by almost $2 billion. Members of the present Opposition who were members of that Government ought to have a very good idea, ought to know very well, that estimates put out in the Budget are never precisely matched by the outcome, but the difference between this Government and the discredited former Treasurer and the Government that he represented is that this Government presents honest estimates and, of course, the discredited former Treasurer in Budget after Budget produced dishonest estimates of what outlays would be.

—Did the Minister for Education indicate on 14 February that the Government would be able to respond to the 1984 report of the Senate Standing Committee on Education and the Arts entitled `A National Language Policy' in the next few months? Has the Minister received a letter from the Federation of Ethnic Communities Councils of Australia dated 20 February in which it is claimed that she indicated to the Federation that `in the next few months' actually meant the end of this year. If so, can the Minister comment on the Federation's claim and indicate whether it is correct?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —As Senator Colston, and I believe other honourable senators who are interested in this matter, would be very well aware, the achievement of a national language policy which is equitable, able to be implemented and able to be adequately resourced is not a task which can be completed very rapidly. Since receipt of the Senate Committee's report I have had officers in my portfolio working on the achievement of that task. It is true to say that, because of the complexity of the task, we have not yet arrived at a draft which I believe should be the basis of a Cabinet decision. However, I am hoping to announce shortly that some increased resources will be going to the performance of this task. In the meantime further consultations, as I have promised, have been undertaken.

ANSWER.PARA: I had a very full meeting with FECCA on 18 February and during that meeting I tried to explain to its representatives some of the difficulties entailed in developing a national language policy. There was some impatience, I understand, expressed by FECCA members and they were very anxious that I pin myself to a precise date for the production of this policy. It is not possible to put a precise date on this, if only because further consultations are necessary. I think FECCA would be very displeased if we were to rush a policy which did not meet its aspirations. However, I still believe that we will be able to produce a policy in the next few months. I told FECCA that at that time. I cannot be more precise than that at this stage, but I have invited it to make further comments on the detail of that policy and on the mechanism for implementing the policy. It has undertaken to do so and I look forward to receiving its suggestions and incorporating them into this very important exercise.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. Does he agree that the fall of 0.7 per cent in the index of manufacturing production during the December quarter seriously threatens the Government's growth predictions, especially its oft repeated forecasts of strong import replacement growth and an improvement in the current account? In the light of this disturbing result and yesterday's unconvincing trade figures, will the Government undertake to relieve Australian manufacturers of the crippling burden of high interest rates as well as the imminent additional costs, in particular its new taxes and the superannuation award?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I suppose that the short answer is no. On the basis that Senator Watson put so much intellectual effort into his question, let me put a little into my answer. First of all, in respect of the very slight fall in manufacturing production output for the December quarter, one has to remember that that was a fall on what was a record base in terms of the last four years. For the first time, in that quarter and in the preceding quarter, manufacturing production had risen to a level as high as the levels of manufacturing production before the resource boom. Senator Watson seems to have a pained face. Perhaps he can elucidate later any problems he has.

ANSWER.PARA: Senator Watson asked whether, because of that fall and because of what he characterised as the disappointing trade balance figures published yesterday, the Government would embark on a series of what he would perhaps call remedial measures that he thinks might correct that situation. The first of those related to the Government doing something about high interest rates. I have answered that question on a number of occasions before in the Senate. The Government will be judged on the timing of any decision it makes on that issue, but the Government has to make a judgment about it. In respect of the question of taxes--

TALK.START.PARA: —That is fairly precise. You have to make a judgment.

—The point is that the judgment will not be made by Opposition senators; it will be made by us and we will be judged on it. That is the point honourable senators opposite have to understand. No amount of questioning in the Senate will influence that decision very much, particularly questioning of the calibre we have had this week. On the second measure-the question of new taxes-I do not know what the honourable senator means by that. What taxes is he suggesting we should change as a result of his flimsy little set of figures?
—What about the fringe benefits tax on cars?

—I say to Senator Watson that I have answered that question too once or twice this week. If the honourable senator does not bother to listen there is not much point in his coming into the Senate. I do not propose to answer that question again. The Government will decide that matter and will make an announcement about it pretty shortly.
—And live with the consequences.

—And live with the consequences, yes, of course. I know that Senator Chaney finds that statement disarmingly frank, but it is true. Senator Watson also asked about the superannuation case. That will go ahead.

—I ask a supplementary question. I acknowledge that the index has fallen from a perhaps higher base, but should not manufacturing activity be increasing due to the effects of the devaluation of the dollar?

—Yes, it has. I said in my original answer to the honourable senator that levels of production in the manufacturing sector were higher than they had been for five years. Some of that may be attributable to the devaluation.

—I refer the Minister representing the Minister for Local Government and Administrative Services to a comment in the local media and to statements in the Department's 1984-85 annual report on inadequate transport services in the Australian Capital Territory. What steps are being taken to alleviate this problem?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is true that for many years, particularly when Parliament is sitting, there have been problems associated with public transport in the Australian Capital Territory and there were inadequate resources in the combined public and private sectors to move government passengers from both Parliament House and the Canberra Airport. Honourable senators would be aware that from time to time this has been a point of some contention with members of parliament as well as citizens, especially when peak periods coincide. Honourable senators would also be aware that there was a very serious decline in airline traffic in the last two years of the Fraser Administration. In the last three years there has been a substantial improvement in traffic movement at the Canberra Airport. In the peak periods difficulties occur from time to time when passengers need to be shifted from the airport into the city and to various other parts of Canberra.

ANSWER.PARA: The Government was aware of the problem and took steps in 1983, when that upturn in traffic took place as a result of the Government's economic policies. Some 54 additional drivers were made available in the Canberra area by the Department of Administrative Services to cope with the increased traffic so that less pressure would be placed on the private transport industry. That move has made some impact upon the problem.

The Government now finds it necessary to examine the problem further because there has been a tremendous increase in traffic movements at the Canberra Airport. Currently the Government, in consultation with the Transport Workers Union, is looking at improving the service still further by using small buses, freight drivers on overtime, and attempting to increase the availability of hire cars and taxis. We believe that all those steps the Government is considering at the moment, as well as those steps that have already been taken, will not only improve the traffic from the point of view of members of parliament but also make private transport more readily available to the citizens in Canberra.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs. Why did the Government in the person of Mr Hayden, on Friday, 21 February, at the time when the corrupt dictator Marcos was beleaguered in the Philippines, announce twice on that day that if the United States bases in the Philippines were under threat from guerrillas-he did not say whether he meant Aquino guerrillas or communist guerrillas-the ANZUS Treaty could be invoked, if not activated? Would this mean that as a result of such an invocation or activation he had in mind that Australian troops could be committed under ANZUS to defending American bases in the Philippines? Will the Government give an assurance to the Australian people that it was not asked by the Americans to sound out the Australian public on that day and that those statements were not made at any suggestion of the United States Government? Will the Minister get an assurance from his colleague the Minister for Foreign Affairs that under no circumstances, whatever happens in the future to American bases in the Pacific, would Australian troops be committed to defend them under ANZUS?

—The Government, through Mr Hayden, had two principal reasons for drawing public attention to the possibility-no matter how remote-of developments in the Philippines leading to invocation of the ANZUS Treaty. One reason was to ensure that it was well understood that the Treaty had a two-way function and that it carried not only assurances of support for Australian security, but also obligations which Australia might incur. I believe that that answers the last part of Senator Chipp's question. The other reason was to underline that what was happening in the Philippines was of direct relevance to Australia in a number of important respects of which this was one. What was said, I am assured by Mr Hayden, derived in no way from suggestions or promptings by the United States or anyone else.

—I direct my question to you, Mr President. Can you advise the Senate of the result of this morning's hearing in the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission concerning the parliamentary catering staff? What order was made by Mr Commissioner Caesar?

—First, I appreciate the interest that the honourable senator has taken in this matter and I also appreciate the number of occasions on which he has been to see me in a genuine attempt to secure a settlement of the matter. In accordance with my practice of making statements to the Senate on matters of this nature, I intend to make a brief statement on this matter to the Senate after Question Time.

—Has the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce noted a paper by one of his leading parliamentary colleagues and a leading member of the Government's Industry Policy Committee, Dr Theophanous, entitled `The Reindustrialisation of Australia'? What would be the effect on Australian industry if Dr Theophanous's proposal that further import quotas be introduced and linked to the proportion of domestic manufacturing which a company carries out were implemented across the main areas of demand for manufactured goods? Does the Minister agree with his colleague's proposals and does he consider that they would improve Australia's competitiveness? Also, would he agree that Dr Theophanous's views appear to be supported by statements by the President of the Australian Council of Trade Unions, Mr Simon Crean, following the meeting in Melbourne yesterday of the Executive of the ACTU, that the Hawke Government has failed to develop policies which would exploit Australia's devalued dollar and make local manufacturing more competitive?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have not had the opportunity of reading Dr Theophanous's paper which, I understand, amounts to some 75 pages. In fact I do not believe that I have seen it at all--
—You can have my copy.

—I have been offered Senator Evans's copy. Dr Theophanous was certainly a prominent member of the Industry Committee, but I am not certain whether he still is. As I understand it, the burden of his argument is that there are two essential points: First, he advocates a move away from multilateral trade negotiations towards bilateral trading arrangements; and, secondly, he suggests that there should be quota restrictions on imports with those quotas being granted to businesses which agree to manufacture a matching amount of goods locally.

ANSWER.PARA: It is incorrect to characterise Australia's trading position as being exclusively locked into multilateral negotiations. Australia pursues both multilateral and bilateral trading arrangements and will continue to do so because both have their advantages. It certainly would not be in Australia's best interests to move away from the multilateral trade negotiations which are currently taking place and will take place further later this year, particularly, if for no other reason, because of our very deep interest in those negotiations relating to agricultural products, for example.

As to the imposition of quotas, the first thing which should be pointed out about the imposition of import quotas is that they create artificial scarcity for goods and the first impact is inflationary. This Government has sought to avoid that because the reduction of inflation is a policy which we have pursued with vigour since our election to office. Secondly, the effect of quotas would be to disadvantage the poorer sections of the Australian community because in a sense quotas constitute a regressive indirect tax. These are quite compelling social and community reasons for not introducing import quotas of the kind advocated by Dr Theophanous.

There is another important policy reason. The very real problems that Australian industry has at the moment are a result of policies over a long time which have led to structural maladjustment in the economy and structural incapacity in Australian industry. Those things have occurred because of the pursuit of those policies on quotas which Dr Theophanous seems to be advocating. In answer to a question yesterday I referred to the survey by the National Australia Bank on these matters and its views about the likely consequences of and the speed with which the J curve effect might be obtained. One of the things it pointed out in that article was that these problems which the country is facing at the moment are 30 years old and stem very much from wrong policies of the past. One of those policies which were wrong in the past was the cosseting of Australian industry by regimes such as quotas. The effect of that was that not only did costs rise-and this was detrimental to poorer sections of the community in Australia-but also the Australian industry concerned became out of touch with technological and marketing developments and all those things that were happening in other countries.

The successful manufacturing countries in the world-and I particularly mention countries such as Sweden and West Germany-would never have considered the imposition of policies of this kind for the simple reason that they know their success is based on their international connections and competitiveness, particularly their competitiveness in terms of technology innovation and so on in their industry. A quota is a shield against that. The bottom line is that one has to choose, as I have said on a previous occasion in connection with the motor vehicle industry, between putting industries in iron lungs and saying to them `get up and walk'.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs. Has the Minister's attention been drawn to statements made by the Indonesian Armed Forces Commander, General Benny Murdani, reported in the Northern Territory News of 4 March, in which he said that there was a danger in too much liberalisation, that unlimited freedom would only give birth to various types of anarchy and the revival of communist forces and that Indonesia should prevent a revival of the liberal democratic parliamentary system? Can the Minister tell the Senate what the Government's response to these statements is, and whether it has any intention of responding to these statements in the same manner as it responded to similar recent sentiments expressed by the Government of the Republic of Korea about opposition demands for constitutional reform?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government has seen the Press report to which Senator McIntosh referred although we do not yet have the full text of General Murdani's reported speech. The Government does not wish to be drawn into a debate on points reportedly made by General Benny Murdani. Questions related to the type of government which there should be in Indonesia are clearly matters for Indonesia and its people to determine.

ANSWER.PARA: However, I should say on behalf of Mr Hayden that the record of the Suharto Government in maintaining political stability and promoting economic growth in Indonesia has been an impressive one. But, just as Australia has done in relation to other countries, we have made clear to the Indonesian Government our views on certain aspects of developments in Indonesia which have been of concern to Australia, and we will continue to do so.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Finance. In view of today's labour force figures that reveal an increase in unemployment to 8 per cent, does he agree that this confirms the reported prediction by the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations that unemployment will increase this year? Are further increases predicted by the Government or was the Treasurer speaking for the Government when he said on the Sunday program of 2 March that unemployment would not rise again?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —If Senator Lewis would care to think back a bit I trust that he would remember my saying on a number of occasions here that any single month's figures for the number of people employed based on that Australian Bureau of Statistics survey are unreliable. I have said that in the months when the figures have gone up-not just in this case.

ANSWER.PARA: To give Senator Lewis some idea of the sort of variability that that series displays, it showed that in the previous month, from December to January, there was an increase of 60,000 in the number of people employed; an increase of 88,000 in the number of people employed from October to November, even though it showed a fall of 16,000 employed in the month from September to October. I repeat that figures for any single month from that series are known to be unreliable.

If we make an assessment over a somewhat longer period and plot a trend, that is likely to be more reliable. On that basis, for the three months ending February 1986 the unemployment rate, seasonally adjusted, fell from 8 per cent to 7.9 per cent, in spite of the fact that the participation rate increased from 61.1 per cent to 61.5 per cent. Of course, a rise in the participation rate normally is an indicator of a healthy labour market, that is, people who are marginally interested in employment are being encouraged actively to seek work whereas in a depressed labour market they would not be.

I also draw Senator Lewis's attention to the job vacancy figures of the Australia and New Zealand Banking Group Ltd which in February showed a higher level of job vacancies than applied in January. In other words the indications from the ANZ Bank and the ABS employment and unemployment figures for February reveal that they are running in opposite directions. One should not assume from either of those series, being for one month only, that they indicate any particular direction. One can only get a meaningful assessment of that over a considerably longer period.

TALK.START.PARA: —Can the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs advise the Senate of details of any aid the Government may have committed to the Philippines in the wake of the election of President Aquino? Is the Government taking any steps to establish whether ex-President Marcos had any investments or holdings in Australia? If some investments or holdings are established, will the Government take action to return them to the people of the Philippines?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —We noted the sceptical interjections on this matter from the other side of the chamber which are entirely consistent with the course honourable senators opposite took over the years in defending the Marcos administration. I have no doubt they are profoundly disappointed with the change that has occurred there.

ANSWER.PARA: During Mr Hayden's visit to Manila earlier this week he did, on behalf of the Prime Minister, invite President Aquino to visit Australia. While he was there he announced a number of further measures of support. In the first place Australian bilateral aid to the Philippines will be increased by 50 per cent to $25m. A team of officials will be visiting the Philippines in the near future to discuss the appropriate programming of that aid.

Secondly, we have expressed willingness to help in establishing appropriate arrangements to co-ordinate international aid and economic assistance. Thirdly, a revolving trade credit of $50m, which had been due to expire on 15 March, will be continued following on negotiations with the Philippines Government. Fourthly, training under the defence co-operation program, which was suspended last month, has been resumed.

Let me take this opportunity to correct a media account of comments that were reportedly made by the Philippines Defence Minister Mr Enrile in this respect. According to those reports, Mr Enrile's comment about not requiring Australian military assistance was clearly in reply to a question about the possibility of direct assistance in contending with the forces of the New People's Army. Mr Enrile is reported as going on to say that he saw no need for an expansion in the defence co-operation program although he did comment favourably upon the high quality of Australian military training forces. Of course, it is in the context of training forces that that military aid has essentially been directed in the past.

The final matter is that Australia has indicated through Mr Hayden that we will give sympathetic consideration to any request by the Philippines Government for assistance in securing the return of assets and investments outside the Philippines. I understand that no evidence of actual investment in Australia by the Marcos family, or anyone on its behalf, has yet been uncovered. But the issue was discussed by Mr Hayden with President Aquino and Mr Hayden said then that Australia would do whatever it could to assist in the repatriation of assets consistent with the due process of the Australian legal system.

The Government is investigating whether any assets in Australia were acquired by Ferdinand Marcos or his associates with official funds and what action might be taken in respect of any such assets. The issues are obviously complex and it would not be appropriate to make any further statement about the complex issues that would arise from the resolution if evidence of such assets did turn up.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs and is in relation to the $3m being spent by the Department of Foreign Affairs in respect of the International Year of Peace. Are all the recipients of grants required to submit an audited statement with respect to the spending of those grants? Secondly, are the recipients of the grants permitted to spend grant moneys on the purchase of equipment, for example, typewriters and copiers? If so, what happens to this equipment at the end of the International Year of Peace?
—I may have some briefing on this, but I think under the circumstances it would be appropriate if I sought a detailed reply from the Minister and let Senator MacGibbon know as soon as possible.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: DEFENCE SERVICE HOMES CORPORATION: SURPLUS LAND

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to my good friend the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, Senator Arthur Gietzelt. The Minister would be aware of media speculation that the Commonwealth disposed of some surplus Defence Service Homes Corporation land to the New South Wales State Government at below the price offered by private developers. Was this the case? Is the Minister prepared to elaborate further on the principles which apply in the disposal of surplus Commonwealth land?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —It used to be the function of the Defence Service Homes Corporation when it was known as the War Service Homes Commission to acquire land, subdivide it, build homes on that land for veterans and provide a subsidised interest arrangement which is characterised now in the Defence Service Homes Corporation.

ANSWER.PARA: Over the years DSH set about disposing of surplus land when the policy to build homes was changed some time in the 1970s, and its only purpose now is to provide home loans at a subsidised interest rate. The Corporation therefore no longer buys land, subdivides it and builds homes on it. The consequence is that over the years there have been disposal arrangements in respect of the land that was acquired in the 1950s, 1960s and 1970s.

The land to which I think Senator Richardson is referring is a site of about 40 hectares in the Castle Hill area which was disposed of by the Department of Local Government and Administrative Services to the New South Wales Land Commission.

The processes that operate in respect of such disposal are that that Department, on policy grounds, makes available to either the State Government or the local authority any surplus lands that are not required by the Commonwealth. With this particular site the Commonwealth Government took steps to get a valuation from the Australian Taxation Office and then proceeded to offer it to the New South Wales Government. Agreement was reached on a price in excess of the valuation made by the Taxation Office valuation section. The price that was finally negotiated with Landcom New South Wales was in excess of three quarters of a million dollars more than the valuation placed on the site by the valuation section.

The Government's attitude is that the States should be given priority in respect of this land. I remind Senator Richardson that this policy has not greatly changed from that of the previous Government when Prime Minister Fraser made the condition that it must be available for private home building purposes. Of course that meets the criteria of Landcom which carries out subdivisions and makes land available for private purchases. So we have met not only this Government's policy but also that of the previous Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Prime Minister. If, as the Minister has already indicated, the Federal Government is preparing to review the fringe benefits tax because of its likely adverse effects on the vehicle building industry, will the Federal Government also provide a similar review of the quarantining of farm losses, given that the introduction of quarantining is likely to cause a slump in rural land values, and in fact is already starting to affect the price of rural land and causing hardship?

—I cannot answer that question precisely. All I know is that there have been a number of discussions with concerned bodies about aspects of farm quarantining in the fringe benefit tax package. Perhaps the greatest area of concern, to my knowledge, has been the possible effects on the forests industry. I cannot answer the question any more precisely than that, but of course the Government is always prepared to ensure that the tax regime is beneficent rather than benign, and I am sure discussions will take place.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Arts, Heritage and Environment. I refer to and welcome the highly pragmatic decision of East-West Airlines Ltd to withdraw its plans for a $340m resort complex on Lindeman Island in the face of popular opinion so clearly demonstrated by the people of Queensland and elsewhere in Australia. Subsequent to the withdrawal of the East-West scheme, what is the present and anticipated future status of the national park at Lindeman Island? Will the Minister give an assurance to the Senate that the Federal Government will monitor any possibility of future development on Lindeman Island, or on any other declared national park in Queensland along the lines of the now abandoned East-West concept?

—Like most senators in this place, I welcome the decision of East-West Airlines to withdraw from proposals to develop a major tourist resort on Lindeman Island. As to the present status of Lindeman Island, Lindeman Island is a part of Queensland, although located within the outer boundaries of the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park. I deplore the Queensland Government's original decision to revoke two-thirds of the national park so that it could be developed as a private tourist resort. The Commonwealth Government has responsibilities relating to the Great Barrier Reef under the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Act and the Environment Protection (Impact of Proposals) Act and the World Heritage Convention. On behalf of the Minister I can assure the Senate and the Australian public that proposals for developments on Lindeman Island, and indeed all other parts of the reef, will be monitored closely in the light of those responsibilities.

—Will the Minister representing the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs explain the circumstances surrounding the landing of six Indonesians near Darwin this week after allegedly travelling by fishing boat from Jakarta? Is there any connection with the circumstances that led some eight Indonesians to the Torres Strait Islands last year? Have the six Indonesians applied to stay in Australia? If so, have any of them made previous applications for Australian residency? Was their presence detected by our coastal surveillance organisation, or is it true that they spent two days on Melville Island before being discovered by local Aboriginal residents?

—I do have some information in response to Senator Teague's question in several parts. Those parts of it which are unanswered I will refer to the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs for further information. On 11 March this year an Aboriginal settlement on Melville Island, just north of Darwin, reported to the Northern Territory Police the arrival of a fishing vessel and the beach landing of four males and two females. The landing was at approximately 2 p.m. on 11 March on an isolated beach near Snake Bay which is inaccessible by land. The Northern Territory Police reported the landing to coastal surveillance, who in turn advised Customs, health, quarantine and immigration authorities. The first report received by the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs at 8.30 p.m. on 11 March was that four males and two females of Vietnamese appearance had landed from a dilapidated fishing boat. A second report at 11 p.m. on 11 March was that an Indonesian fishing boat under sail containing four males and two females had run aground at Snake Bay. Further unconfirmed information received is that the group has informed Melville Islanders that they are Indonesians seeking refugee status. The Northern Territory Police launch left Darwin for the area late in the afternoon on 11 March and was expected to arrive at Snake Bay early on the morning of 12 March. It is understood that a Customs launch with quarantine and health officials on board left later in the evening and was expected to arrive mid-morning. The incident was reported on Australian Broadcasting Corporation news, Darwin, at 7.55 a.m. Darwin time on 12 March as the landing of a group of Indonesians on Melville Island. Because of the condition of their boat members of the group are to be moved to Darwin. The situation will be assessed at that time. That is all the information I have available to me at this stage.

—Can the Minister for Education give an indication of how successful the secondary allowance scheme publicity campaign has been? How long will the campaign run, and are schools involved in the campaign?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to report that there has been a significant increase in the number of students applying for and gaining the secondary allowance. Part of that increase is, I am sure, due to the publicity campaign which we have been running. Also contributing to the success of the growth of the scheme, I am sure, is the active participation of schools, school principals, school counsellors, the Australian Teachers Federation and parent bodies. At the beginning of March this year there had been an 8 per cent increase in applications for the allowance compared with a similar period in 1985. My Department has mounted a concerted effort since the last Budget to encourage applications for benefits under not only the secondary allowance scheme but all other schemes of financial assistance to students as a part of encouraging young people to stay in the education system. This, of course, is consistent with our policy of encouraging increased participation by young people in years 11 and 12. Publicity for this scheme will continue for some time yet, but will eventually be subsumed by a new campaign which will emphasise the benefits of the single age related scheme of financial support for young people which will begin in 1987.

ANSWER.PARA: Honourable senators will remember that as a first step towards the implementation of the new arrangements the Treasurer announced in the last Budget an increase of more than 50 per cent in the secondary allowance scheme benefits for 1986 and the means test was eased. Publicity materials have been widely distributed through the schools and other avenues. In conclusion, I am asked to put in a further promotion and to remind honourable senators that the benefits have been substantially increased, and in their visits to schools or the contacts with the schools authorities I think it is very important that they continually remind people in the position to advise young people of these increased benefits.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industry. On Tuesday a Labor senator for Tasmania, Senator Coates, asked a misinformed question relating to a Federal-State agreement for the export of woodchips beyond 1988. He stated:

QUESTION.PARA: It is a fact that the Premier of Tasmania is displaying an extraordinary lack of co-operation and is still refusing to sign the agreement with the Federal Government for the export woodchip industry beyond 1988 . . .

The Minister, Senator Walsh, did not answer that part of his question. I ask the Minister: Is it a fact that the Premier of Tasmania, Mr Gray, indeed signed the agreement on 9 January and is presently waiting for the signature of the Minister for Primary Industry? Can the Minister tell the Senate why Mr Kerin has not signed the agreement? Is it a fact that now the election is over Mr Kerin is going back on his agreement and seeking to interfere with domestic timber operations in Tasmania? If so, has the Minister the constitutional power to do so?

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not know whether the agreement was signed or not. I will seek a response from Mr Kerin. I find it highly improbable that Mr Kerin is going back on any agreement. I find it highly believable that Mr Gray is.

—Has the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister on the Status of Women seen the article in the South Australian Advertiser yesterday headed `Half the nation's managers soon will be women'? Mr John Young, one of Australia's top management consultants, claimed that women are often better managers than men, they are more personable and are better equipped than men to make tough decisions. Can the Minister say whether this attitude, which clearly is in sympathy with the affirmative action legislation, is representative of employers more broadly in the community?

—My attention had been drawn to the advertisement referred to in Senator Crowley's question, but I am very pleased to hear about it at this stage. I am sure all honourable senators with progressive views who are committed to improved opportunities for women will be pleased to hear that there has been such a vote of confidence in the capacity of women to undertake managerial positions in the private sector by a leader from that sector. I can say that there has been a very heartening response by leaders in the private sector to the Government's affirmative action proposals. I think it is being recognised more and more that in denying opportunities to women the private sector is denying itself a very important pool of talent from which people of executive capacities can be drawn. It is heartening that a reform such as this is receiving such broad-based support. I hope that the somewhat ambitious claim of the person Senator Crowley just quoted will be realised in the very near future.

—I direct a question to the Minister representing the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs and refer to a report in the Australian this week concerning the Burke Government's package of Aboriginal land rights for Western Australia, which includes the removal of the right of veto over mining on Ab- original land and the exclusion of consideration of the value of the minerals to be mined from factors to determine the level of compensation to traditional owners. I ask: Is the Western Australian package acceptable to the Federal Government? Does the Federal Government have any disagreement with the two aspects concerning veto and compensation to which I have referred? If the Federal Government does agree with the Western Australian Government's land rights proposals, why is it not prepared to implement amendments which would apply the same conditions in the Northern Territory, instead of proceeding with its proposed amendments, which do not remove the right of veto or eliminate the matter of the value of minerals to be mined from considerations going to the determination of compensation to traditional owners? Could it not be said that these are only two of a number of deficiencies in the Federal Government's amendments which will see the development of the Northern Territory, a non-Labor Territory, continue to be fettered while Western Australia, a Labor State, will be permitted to get on with developing its resources?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Kilgariff is obviously giving us a bit of a promo for the speech on his private member's Bill he will be making later this afternoon. As to the attitude of our Government to the package of improvements for Western Australian Aboriginals, agreed to last week, it will be clear to Senator Kilgariff and to other senators that our Government has accepted that package as being, at this stage, the most practical way of ensuring that Western Australian Aboriginals get permanent title to a significant amount of land in Western Australia.

ANSWER.PARA: There are other aspects to the package which are also pleasing to us, such as the commitment by each of the State and Federal governments of $10m per year over a period to develop infrastructures such as water supply, sewerage and shelter in those areas of Australia where Aboriginals are living in the poorest circumstances. It will also be clear to honourable senators that the package does not represent what we would have liked to see in Western Australia but is, rather, a realistic assessment of what is possible in Western Australia at this stage.

There is absolutely no reason why, having achieved a modest package of advancement in Western Australia, we should agree to erode rights that have already been achieved in another part of Australia. As Senator Kilgariff is very well aware, we will not undermine the veto rights of Aboriginals in the Northern Territory. We do not believe that the veto as exercised is making any real difference to mining activity in that Territory. There are other factors for a drop-off in mining activity in the Territory. It seems a false kind of argument to suggest that, because the achievement of land rights in Western Australia has not been accompanied by the achievement of a right to refuse mining entirely on Aboriginal land, we should attempt to remove this from Aboriginals in the Northern Territory who already have it.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister representing the Special Minister of State aware of ongoing disquiet about the future role of the Australian Federal Police in north Queensland? When will this unit's operations be placed on a secure planning base, with funding and staffing priorities determined according to, firstly, the size and difficulties of travel in this area, and secondly, responsibility for two international airports? Can the Minister give an assurance that the present internal review will give urgent attention to the special characteristics of this region for Federal Police operations and set appropriate levels of resources, personnel and independence in decision-making?

—The Special Minister of State advises me that he has received representations concerning the Australian Federal Police presence in north Queensland. The role of the Australian Federal Police, as provided in legislation, is principally to provide police services in relation to the laws of the Commonwealth. This role will continue to be discharged, having regard to the resources available and the priorities indicated by the Government as guidelines for the Commissioner from time to time. Any alleged disquiet which may have been brought to the honourable senator's notice is likely to be related to a failure to perceive this role in its full context. As the honourable senator is aware, the Government has indicated that AFP investigations into drug trafficking, organised crime and large scale fraud on Commonwealth revenue are to be accorded the highest priority. I can assure the honourable senator, on Mr Young's behalf, that any future review of resource deployment will be made in that context and decisions made by the Commissioner following the most careful consideration. The full resources of the AFP will remain available to combat its major priority targets wherever the criminal activity occurs.

—I ask a supplementary question. Could I receive some assurance that the Australian Federal Police in north Queensland will not continually have to run cap in hand to officers in Brisbane before they can actually follow up the guidelines the Minister has read out?
—I will see whether Mr Young wishes to make any further response in reaction to that last question. I think discretion is the better part of valour.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Attorney-General. I refer him to his Government's intention to ask the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission to investigate Queensland electoral laws. Does he agree that the right to a fair hearing is a fundamental legal right and that the Human Rights Commission denied that right to the Queensland Government when it did not even interview the Queensland Government when it was investigating Queensland industrial laws last year? Is he aware that the Human Rights Commission has been thoroughly discredited in the eyes of Australians by its actions in banning parliamentarians from its offices, distributing a paper which advocated the killing of disabled infants, distributing educational material which contained extreme left wing assertions about our society, refusing to investigate a private citizen's complaint of trade union intimidation, and advocating homosexual immigration on the grounds of family reunion? In light of this sorry record, does he have any confidence at all that this Commission would be capable of conducting any impartial and thorough investigation of Queensland's electoral laws?

—All I can say is this: Without conceding any of the particular allegations that have just been made by Senator Boswell, so long as the Commission continues to incur the displeasure of Senator Boswell and those like him, I think we can all be confident that it is in excellent hands and doing a first rate job.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct a question to the Minister for Finance. It relates to the question that was asked earlier by Senator Chaney and the statement of the Treasurer yesterday on the trilogy. Did the statement of the Treasurer yesterday and the answer which was given to Senator Chaney commit the Government to a subsequent adjustment in taxation paid by Australian taxpayers if the collections for 1985-86 show the outcome of an increase in the proportion of the gross domestic product, or can the trilogy be regarded as a Budget aim and not a firm policy commitment, as it was presented by the Prime Minister at the last election?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The first time that the Prime Minister referred to the trilogy it was put in terms of an average over three years and did not refer to any particular year. I know that different versions have appeared since. If I understood it correctly, the main substance of Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle's question was whether the Government would adjust taxation levels or rates at this stage in order to ensure that there is no very minor overrun as a proportion of GDP. The answer to that, of course, would have to be no because at this stage nobody knows what GDP will be for this year. Nobody knows either, with precision, what total tax receipts will be. Therefore, we have two uncertainties; so we cannot calculate one as a proportion of the other, when neither the numerator nor the denominator is known.

ANSWER.PARA: The Budget Papers this year did forecast that taxation receipts would be the same proportion of GDP as they had been in 1984-85. I think from memory that that figure was 23.3 per cent. I do not know whether one could be certain that when the national account figures for the last financial year are revised, the 23.3 per cent for 1984-85 will no longer apply, or if it does apply it will be because of an action of rounding out the figure. The national accounts figures are subject to very large revisions. Surprisingly, this takes place sometimes as long as two and three years after the event. When those figures are revised, of course, that affects the GDP as recorded at that point.

The general picture is that it is still expected that taxation receipts as a proportion of GDP will be very close to that proportion which was forecast in the Budget. But one cannot be sure of either the numerator or the denominator. I will pass the proposal on to the Treasurer, but I would say that it is highly unlikely that the Government would make any adjustment to taxation rates for that reason.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — Mr President, I ask a supplementary question in order to clarify my question to the Minister. My question was: If the outcome of the figures when they are known shows that the revenue collections exceed the expectations of the trilogy, will the Government make a subsequent adjustment? Is the trilogy to be regarded simply as an aim when setting the Budget parameters, or is it a firm commitment that adjustments will subsequently be made?

—I am sorry if I misunderstood. If the question was whether there would be some adjustment in the next year if there is an overrun in one year, I would certainly expect that that is a factor which would be taken into account. Just to set the record straight, my attention has been drawn to the fact that the figure which appeared in the Budget Papers for 1984-85 for tax receipts as a proportion of GDP was 25.3 per cent, and not 23.3 per cent.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Short asked me a question on 11 February-and he raised the matter again some time later-regarding the Footscray Swim Centre. I understand that Mr Willis has replied by correspondence, but I seek leave to have incorporated in Hansard the further information.

ANSWER.PARA: Leave granted.
The document read as follows-

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Senator Walsh

TALK.START.PARA: —On 11 February 1986 Senator Short asked me, as Minister representing the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations, the following question relating to the Footscray Swim Centre CEP project.

INTERJECT.PARA: Is the Minister aware that the project is massively behind schedule and has major cost over-runs? I ask the Minister whether it is a fact that a private company, formerly called Elate, but now called the Footscray Swim Centre Pty Ltd, appears to control the project and the CEP funds, rather than the Footscray City Council, which is the legal and authorised sponsor. If so, was this arrangement contrived to avoid the Hawke and Cain Governments' directives in relation to the Builders Labourers Federation? I ask also whether the arrangement has made the swimming pool project and the Commonwealth liable for State payroll tax and higher workers compensation charges. Finally, I ask whether the Minister will undertake to have all the circumstances surrounding this CEP project, which is rapidly taking on all the appearances of a major scandal, made the subject of urgent investigation, including the background to its initial approval. Will the Minister give the Parliament an assurance that no further CEP funds will be allocated to the project in advance of such investigation?
I have a supplementary question. I ask Senator Walsh again for an assurance that all the circumstances surrounding this project will be the subject of urgent investigation.
I undertook to seek further information from the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations and he has provided the following response:

I am aware that the project is behind schedule and that costs have exceeded the original project estimates for reasons largely beyond the sponsor's control. The principal reason for the delays has been the increasing unavailability of skilled tradespersons among the long term unemployed. Against a background of significant reductions in unemployment in the building industry in Victoria, particular difficulties have occurred in recruiting plumbers, carpenters, electricians and some professional categories. The delays have caused serious disruption to the work schedules and adversely affected productivity of workers on the site. They have been compounded by additional man hours lost in the following ways:
* workers compensation...11037 hours
* sick leave...4989 hours
* unpaid absenteeism...2043 hours
* bereavement leave...230 hours
* inclement weather...5808 hours
* industrial action...5800 hours
* removal of asbestos...65 hours
The delay and cost overruns, while regrettable, do occur in large scale and complex construction undertakings.

On advice from the State Industrial Relations Task Force, the then State Ministry of Employment and Training requested that the Footscray City Council form an independent construction company on the basis that the State Building Awards applicable to independent companies are more suitable to building and construction activity than the Municipal Award.

This arrangement was not contrived to avoid any Federal and State Government ``directives'' regarding the Builders' Labourers' Federation. The establishment of the independent company necessitated new arrangements for workers compensation (costing $247,457 to 17 December 1985) and incurred a liability for State payroll tax (costing $66,518 to 17 December 1985), and additional expenses tied to the various awards. These costs were met with CEP funds. I have written to the Victorian Treasurer seeking agreement to exempt the Footscray Swim Centre project from payroll tax.

The Footscray City Council remains the authorised sponsor of the project and controls the CEP funds. The Footscray Swim Centre Pty Ltd operates under the direction of the Council and the majority of directors of this Company are councillors and council employees.

It has been agreed by all parties involved in the construction of the Footscray Swim Centre that an independent audit be undertaken by a private firm of chartered accountants and a feasibility study be carried out by the State Public Works Department. These have already been arranged.
Decisions on the possible provision of funds over and above those already agreed will not be made until the results of the financial audit and feasibility study are available.

The initial approval of the project was made jointly by the Commonwealth and State Government delegates following recommendation by the community based CEP Consultative Committee in Victoria. Information provided by the Footscray City Council in support of the need for and benefit of the project includes the following.

The old swimming pool had serviced the whole of the Western Suburbs providing swimming lessons for 70,000 school children from 40 schools, forming part of the education, recreational and social life of about 125,000 people and employing 19 people.

By 1983 the pool was in such a bad state of repair that it was losing $180,000 per annum and Council was faced with a choice between demolishing the pool or rebuilding it. If the pool had been rebuilt without CEP funds Council would have had to impose a 6% rate rise for all Footscray residents over ten years.
