The project, when completed, will have had considerable benefits to participants, Council and the community by providing work experience and training for disadvantaged unemployed people which has enabled the majority of ex-participants to obtain permanent employment in the normal labour market; a multi-purpose swimming/health centre for people of all age groups in the Western Suburbs, including 180,000 to 200,000 school children (more than double the number using the old pool), general public access for 92,000 people and permanent employment for at least 50 people.

Senator Short raised this matter again in the Senate Adjournment Debate of 13 February 1986. The information provided in response to Senator Short's Question Without Notice of 11 February 1986 has covered many of the issues raised in the Adjournment Debate. However, the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations has provided additional information as follows:

The project was approved to employ 124 people over 12 months. The employment of target group labour was staggered over the first few months as detailed planning and design phases of the project had to be completed before the construction commenced.

The original approval provided for a CEP grant of $1.974m towards a total project budget of $2.824m of which $850,000 is being contributed by the Footscray Council. As a result of delays and cost overruns, variations totalling $445,000 have been approved, bringing the total CEP grant to $2.419m.

The project approval required an $850,000 sponsor contribution by Footscray Council. Of the $850,000 contribution, $200,000 has been expended and the remaining $650,000 has been committed to the project.

Following preliminary discussions, I chaired a meeting of all parties involved on 5 March 1986. All parties were in favour of completing the project but agreed that decisions on possible additional funding should await the results of the independent audit and feasibility study referred to above. The Council will release the remaining already committed sponsor contribution, as the funds are required.

In relation to the Honourable Senator's inspection of the site, while it is not disputed that there have been delays, it is clear that substantial progress towards completion of the project has been made. It is not possible at this time to give any assurances as to the the final amount and a time-scale for the completion of the project. As I have said, the provision of any further funding will be dependent on an audit of the project's finances and a report by the State Public Works Department.

I am aware of the agreement between the Mayor, Councillors and Citizens of the City of Footscray and Footscray Swim Centre Pty Ltd which is what I understand the Honourable Senator is referring to as the ``trust deed''. This agreement stipulates that upon completion of the project the construction company shall return to the Council control of the Swim Centre. I should point out that Council has retained legal ownership of the Centre during the construction phase and has indemnified the directors of Footscray Swim Centre Pty Ltd.

Trojan Owen and Associates was appointed by the Footscray Council to manage the project under the direction of the Footscray Swim Centre Pty Ltd. Trojan Owens was selected by the Council, without tender, on the basis of its previous experience in management of construction projects.

The responsibility for the selection of Trojan Owen and Associates as project manager rests solely with the Footscray Council. The Federal Government agreed to this decision on the basis that all management fees would be paid by the Council from its sponsor contribution. I understand that as at 17th December 1985, $170,601 has been paid by the Council in management fees.

The CEP Guidelines require that sponsors must provide an audited statement/certificate as required. It is normal for this certificate to be provided at the completion of the project. The independent audit of the projects' finances now being arranged will clarify the situation as will the investigation of the construction aspects of the Swim Centre by the State Public Works Department.

Under the agreed administrative arrangements governing the operation of CEP, sponsors are required to provide the State Government with regular financial statements detailing payments. I am advised that these have been provided.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was asked a question yesterday by Senator Sheil about the Vietnamese Army. I seek leave to have the answer incorporated in Hansard.

ANSWER.PARA: Leave granted.
The answer read as follows-

The Government is not aware of a decision by Vietnam on 14 January to prepare to attack a civilian refugee camp inside Thailand. The Government has seen, however, recent press reports indicating that in early March 1986 Approximately 1,000 Vietnamese troops attacked a military base of the Khmer Peoples' National Liberation Front inside Thai territory, opposite Cambodia's Battambang Province. These reports indicate that no attack was made on any civilian refugee camp, in particular on the site two camp situated in Thailand 8 kilometres to the south-west of the scene of the Vietnamese attack. The likelihood of attacks on civilian refugee camps has been reduced since the last dry season military operation because of the separation of Cambodian resistance military bases from the civilian camps.

We have made it abundantly clear in the past that we condemn armed incursion into the sovereign territory of another State. The Government condemned the Vietnamese incursion into Thai territory during the 1984-85 dry season and will continue to condemn Vietnamese incursions into Thai territory. The Government has frequently deplored the prolongation of the cycle of violence in Cambodia; we believe that a solution should be pursued by peaceful means, not by armed conflict. We shall continue to call for dialogue between the principal parties.

The Government suspended its bilateral development assistance program to Vietnam in January 1979 following the Vietnamese invasion of Cambodia. This aid has not been resumed. Australian contributions to United Nations and other multilateral organisation projects has continued. Cutting out this essentially humanitarian and emergency assistance would be a punitive measure, with no prospect of furthering the achievement of a satisfactory resolution of the Cambodia dispute. It would be a counter-productive step which would merely serve to isolate Vietnam further internationally and in the region.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yesterday Senator Haines asked me a question concerning domestic violence. I seek leave to have the answer incorporated in Hansard.

ANSWER.PARA: Leave granted.
The answer read as follows-
I refer to Senator Haines's question on domestic violence directed to me in this place yesterday.

The two conferences on domestic violence referred to by Senator Haines arose out of a resolution of the ALP National Conference in 1984. As a result of that resolution I, as the then Attorney-General, requested the Australian Institute of Criminology to hold a national conference on all aspects of domestic violence against adults and children.
The Institute convened a two part conference in Canberra on violence in the family-the first on domestic violence was held in November 1985 and the second on child abuse was held in February 1986.

The principal aims of the conference were to identify a body of common information and agree upon future strategies to deal with violence in the family. Included in a comprehensive range of resolutions and recommendations passed by the conference was a call for an immediate national response to the problem of domestic violence.

I am informed that the Institute forwarded the resolutions of the domestic violence conference to the Attorney-General on 20 December 1985 and those of the child abuse conference on 4 March 1986. At the same time the Institute also forwarded copies to 50 Commonwealth and State Departments and agencies with a covering letter to the effect that the Institute will be following up this matter in June to seek an account of actions taken in response to the resolutions. The replies will then be collated and forwarded to the Attorney for action to be taken at the national level. In the meantime the resolutions are under consideration by the relevant Commonwealth Departments.

As Senator Haines might be aware, the Law Reform Commission's report on domestic violence is expected to be available to be tabled by the Attorney-General shortly. The Attorney wishes the report to be given urgent consideration so that action can be taken to introduce legislative reforms on domestic violence in the Australian Capital Territory.

In addition to legislative reforms, the Attorney-General is also anxious to provide what might be called ancillary relief. He is anxious that there be support for victims and counselling which may avert some instances of domestic violence as well as provide relief for those who have been its victims. This, of course, will require additional resources and the Attorney-General will be actively seeking those.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coates Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I seek leave to make a personal explanation.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was misrepresented by Senator Walters a few minutes ago in her question to Senator Walsh in his capacity as Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Kerin). Senators Walters accused me of asking a question-a misinformed question, I think were her words-on Tuesday. I am afraid Senator Walters has indulged in her usual tactic of misquoting and half truths. She quoted me as having asked:

SPEECH.PARA: Is it a fact that the Premier of Tasmania . . . refusing to sign the agreement with the Federal Government for the export woodchip industry beyond 1988 . . .
My words that she omitted to add immediately followed, and they were:
. . . in the terms to which he agreed towards the end of last year?

The fact is that I understand that Mr Gray has signed a piece of paper containing words which he drafted. But it is not the terms of the agreement which he made with Mr Kerin towards the end of last year.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to make a personal explanation, Mr President.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Coates has tried to explain away his question of misinformation. Indeed, he and I quoted exactly from the Hansard. The point is that Mr Kerin has not yet sent an alternative agreement for Mr Gray to sign. So he has not refused to sign Mr Kerin's request. He has signed an agreement which Mr Kerin has refused to sign. Mr Gray has not refused to sign an agreement because no alternative agreement has yet been sent to Mr Gray. So Senator Coates is quite wrong and is misinformed.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —On Tuesday I informed the Senate that the Presiding Officers and the Public Service Board, as respondents to the relevant industrial award, had lodged with the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission a formal notification of an industrial dispute within the Commonwealth Parliamentary Refreshment Rooms. The matter was listed for hearing this morning before Mr Commissioner Caesar. At the conclusion of the hearing Mr Commissioner Caesar issued a statement and order as follows:

INTERJECT.PARA: On the basis of the undertakings given to me by Mr Banks and Mr Barry of the Federated Liquor and Allied Industries Employees Union that they would take all necessary steps to have industrial action cease I order the parties to this dispute into conference, the subject matter of that conference to embrace all matters of concern to the members of the FLAIEU. The conference to be held as a matter of urgency and a report on the progress of the conference to be made to me at an appropriate time.
I request the union to accept the responsibility of notifying me when such a report would be appropriate and in any event before any further industrial action is taken in pursuance of their claims.

I have been advised that at a subsequent meeting of catering staff who are members of the Federated Liquor and Allied Industries Employees Union, it was resolved to lift all bans in line with the order given by the Commission.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —I have received a letter from Senator Messner proposing that a matter of public importance be submitted to the Senate for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The need for the Government to change its policies in response to the emerging crisis in economic management.
I call upon those senators who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of senators required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Although this matter of public importance speaks of the emerging crisis in economic policy, it is about one thing only, and that is jobs for Australians. The whole point about the economic crisis that is developing in this country is that the Government's policy is aimed at improving the situation in respect of jobs but clearly it is leading us in another direction. The view is put forward by many in the Government-and, of course, this one emanates very frequently from the left wing of the Australian Labor Party-that there is one very simple reason for the job creation, and that is the increase in production. What that means is improving and increasing the opportunities for people to find work in factories, in offices and throughout the whole community and ensuring that the gross or the overall product of Australia is advantaged. The emerging crisis that is coming, then, is a crisis for the aspirations for the Australian people.

SPEECH.PARA: Over the last few years, and certainly the last few days, we have seen the Government wallowing in an orgy of self congratulation on the third birthday of its having come to power in 1983. One of its great claims to fame has been the so-called creation of some 600,000 jobs over those three years. While we acknowledge that the Government has done that, the fact remains that there is still some 8 per cent of the work force out of work. The Government has made very little impression upon that hard core of unemployed people in Australia. Indeed, when we break down the statistics further-and I do not want to bore the Senate with too many statistics-we find that 21.3 per cent of young people are still unable to find jobs. This is notwithstanding the ineffective Priority One: Young Australia campaign that was so deftly and cleverly exposed by Senator Vanstone here during discussion of a matter of public importance a few weeks ago.

A second point of great importance so far as unemployment is concerned is the growing average time that people are finding themselves out of work. Compared with a shorter period some three years ago when this Government came to power, people are now out of work on the average for 41.3 weeks in the year.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tragic.

—That is a tragic situation for Australians. But this is only the start. This is only the point that we have reached now. The Opposition is looking forward to what is to come according to some of the basic indicators that are emerging at the moment. The statistics that have come forward on unemployment over the last six months show that the level of unemployed people in the community has bottomed out at about 8 per cent. That means that the Government has made no impression on finding jobs over the last six months. Fewer people each month are finding work in the work force notwithstanding seasonal variations that have occurred in the last few months. The whole process of job creation as defined by this Government has wound down. This Government is finding it increasingly difficult to create jobs at anything like the rates that are necessary to bite into that hard core of unemployed that we see before us.

SPEECH.PARA: This is the reason why there is a growing perception in the community of a sense of crisis. This is why people are worried about job opportunities for their children. They cannot see where the jobs will come from in the future. They keep reading of bad reports from overseas. They keep reading about the inadequacy of this Government's measures and its outright failures in coming to terms with such projects as Priority One. They read of the useless waste of money that is going to such projects as Tilley Devine's centre in Canberra. Rightly or wrongly, $140,000 has been tossed down the drain and this money will not create very many jobs in the community. If Senator Elstob wants any further proof of the sense of crisis that is developing in Australia, let me just read to him a few newspaper headlines.

TALK.START.PARA: —Was Tilley Devine Priority One?

—I believe she was somebody's priority one. I can take at random numerous examples of newspaper headlines which demonstrate the growing perception of a crisis in economic management. Today's Australian Financial Review has the headline `Fringe benefit tax threat hits car sales'. That headline refers to a major threat to one of Australia's main industries as a result of this Government's positive attempt to introduce a most damaging tax which is going to tear apart the car industry, not only in my State of South Australia, in particular, but all over the Commonwealth. The Australian of 5 February has the headline `Government ``is killing the housing industry'' '. A headline in the Australian of 1 March 1986 reads `Home loan rates won't fall, warn housing experts'. The Australian Financial Review of 24 February has the headline `Government pressed to bail out housing sector'. A headline in the Australian of 25 February reads `Why not a farmers' strike?'. If anything gives one the impression of a sense of crisis in the country it has to be the fact that normally conservative farmers are prepared to do that kind of thing.

SPEECH.PARA: What about those who are less fortunate who are finding it difficult to find homes? What about the people who are unable to live on their incomes at present because of inflation? More and more newspaper articles are being written about their problems. One article which appeared in the Sydney Morning Herald talked about the poverty epidemic in Sydney and the burden on Sydney's emergency services. The article is headed `Nowhere they can call home'. Another article refers to one of the jewels in the crown of the Labor Government-the so-called health insurance program, Medicare. We learn from the Australian of 6 January that, even with the marvellous Medicare looking after us, there is now a waiting list for surgery topping 50,000 throughout the Commonwealth. We are told that, as a result of this Government's incompetence, 50,000 people are unable to get the surgery that they need. The Courier-Mail of 18 July tells us that families need help. An article in the Australian Financial Review refers to another attack by this Government on the major employment generating sector. The headline to this article refers to record high bank rates-that is, interest rates-which are threatening small business. We all know about interest rates. This Government has had a positive and determined policy to keep interest rates high in order to ensure that there is some control over the Australian dollar. Of course, this is having widespread and devastating effects on small business and on housing starts. We are finding that fewer and fewer people are able to obtain their first homes. As a result fewer and fewer jobs are being created in the building sector.

While we have had a look at the short term effects, maybe we should consider the long term time frame of these events. I would like to refer to the National Australia Bank's latest issue which talks of Australia's balance of payment problem. We have all read about that. We all know about the difficulty that has been brought about through this Government's deliberate policies. I quote one particularly interesting point. The bank talks of current account structure, the difficulties of trading and imports versus exports. The article states:
While most major industrialised countries have in- creased their share of world exports over the last 15 years, Australia has fallen from a world ranking of eighth to 23rd.

It goes on to say in another part of the same paragraph that the proportion of manufactures in Australian exports was 28 per cent in 1983-84, less than half the proportion in most industrialised countries. That means that manufacturing jobs are not being created or generated for kids who live in the outer metropolitan areas. When this Government tries to convince us that somehow we are improving opportunities for Australians by introducing such things as fringe benefits taxes and capital gains taxes and by abolishing negative gearing for the building of homes for Australians, we have to wonder what it is on about because clearly it is not interested in the welfare of Australians or in giving Australians homes or jobs.

TALK.START.PARA: —And it is killing small business.

—Or, as Senator Short points out, small business, which has been a great generator of jobs throughout the Australian community in the last 30 years. Let us remind ourselves of that time frame again. In the 15 years from 1970 to 1986 the Australian Labor Party has been in office for six years. We all know the difficulties that the Fraser Government had in coping with the first period of Labor government from 1972 to 1975. There is another factor common to that time of which we also ought to remind ourselves. For the first 10 of those 15 years the President of the Australian Council of Trade Unions was none other than Mr Robert Hawke, now Prime Minister of Australia. In that period we saw the damage done to the Australian economy and the jobs destroyed by the Whitlam Government. The combination of the Whitlam Government and the presidency of the ACTU by Bob Hawke was enough to destroy hundreds of thousands of jobs in 1974, and we all know that we are still suffering the effects of that period of government.

SPEECH.PARA: In the last five of those 15 years we have been plagued again by Mr Robert Hawke, who has been Prime Minister for three of those five years. One has to ask who has really been guiding this economy for the last 15 years. On the evidence provided by the National Australia Bank, the most important and critical area of job creation has not delivered. Why? I put it down to the fact that we have had Mr Robert Hawke in charge of major sections of the economy, a man who has had no concern for Australians. He has concern for the power of the trade union movement, yes, but not for ordinary Australians and for the creation of jobs in Australia. It is pretty clear that Bob Hawke lies down at every opportunity when put under pressure from his trade union friends. He has no option. We remember the Tax Summit last July when the Prime Minister weakly bought himself out of a deal in order to save his own face and rubbed Mr Keating's right in it. That is the kind of Prime Minister we have. He will not stand up to union pressure, which of course we are all suffering from in terms of lack of opportunity at present.

We also saw Mr Keating yesterday going cap in hand to see Mr Kelty and Mr Crean of the ACTU and being told that the Government was not doing enough for the economy. We do not even have to listen to the National Australia Bank; we get it straight from the trade unions, who are saying that this Government is on the wrong track and that Mr Keating and Mr Hawke are on the wrong track. Indeed, they are saying: `We have done our bit. How about you doing your bit for a change'. Those unions are clearly putting more and more pressure on this Government for change, as is the gang of seven Ministers and as was Senator Gietzelt yesterday when answering questions here about affairs in his Department.

The fact is that the crisis which is coming upon us is critical to the future of job opportunities. We now know that there is need for change in the economy. We need a changed approach to improving the competitiveness of Australian industry, and that means taking on the trade union movement. Senator Button knows this because every day at Question Time here he hedges all over the place when asked about the balance of payments problem and about the fringe benefits tax. Even left-wingers such as Dr Theophanous are talking about these issues as well. We have seen the introduction of a capital gains tax obviously designed to stifle incentive and investment in the economy, notwithstanding that the Australian Council of Trade Unions says that there should be more investment. Present policies have to change. They are leading to an increasing burden of debt in this country, the total debt having doubled since this Government came to power from around $30 billion to more than $60 billion.

While all these back bench pips in the Labor Party are starting to squeak in their rural seats and other places about interest rates and what is happening to farmers, to homes and to jobs, the larger pips are now also starting to squeak. I recall Senator Button's answers in the Senate in the last day or so. He cannot give us any indication of when the so-called J-curve is going to bring us out of this horrible time into some Garden of Eden where jobs will be created. He says that it is not next month or the month after, or the month after that. He cannot give us any indication of when he expects that to turn around, notwithstanding the fact that Mr Hawke in his ignorance is saying that it has happened and has turned around.

TALK.START.PARA: —If Senator Button isn't stupid, who is?

—We know who has led us down the wrong path in the past and it is pretty obvious that the Prime Minister is the one. Let me just come to one thing that puts this whole matter into perspective. One half of the Chinese word character for crisis is the point of danger. The second half is opportunity. The point is that this Government has the opportunity right now to grasp a change of policy and a change of direction to provide jobs for Australians and to provide security for Australians. It is very fond of taking away security from Australians as it did for pensioners through the assets test and the lump sum superannuation tax. Now is the time for it to change its policies so that it will head Australia back in the right direction towards improved competitiveness and an increase in job opportunities.

SPEECH.PARA: It should be producing policies which will reduce interest rates, not increase them. It should be abandoning its disastrous tax package of a fringe benefits tax and a capital gains tax and the abolition of negative gearing. It should be attacking the whole question of the slowness of job growth. If it relies, as it is now doing, upon the statistics that have been thrown up over the last three years and crowns itself with glory in the hope that it will convince Australians that that is going to continue, it is wrong, because the signs are on the board, and are coming up faster and thicker in the official indicators now that this Government is in real trouble with its economic policy. Unless it changes direction, the children of Australia and those who have been unemployed for nearly a year on average now will find it harder and harder to obtain positions in the future. It is those things which the Government should be attacking, not patching up the cracks in the wall with approaches such as Priority One, which has already proven to be an absolute shambles, and such silly moves as the Tilley Devine and Wyuna-type community employment programs which are of such short duration. Let me conclude on this point: The time has come for a change not only of policies but also, hopefully, of government. We are looking forward to that change at the next election, whenever that may be.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Maguire Sen G.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The matter of public importance on the economy which has been proposed by Senator Messner is a typical Liberal Party nonsense. It is a typical knocking effort by the Opposition. The Liberal Party is hoping for an economic collapse in Australia; in fact that is its only policy. It does not have an economic policy. It is particularly unfortunate that this matter of public importance has been submitted by a former Minister in the Fraser-Howard Government, a government which presided over the plunge of Australia into the deepest recession since the 1930s, a recession which saw the destruction of Australian manufacturing industry and jobs lost in the hundreds of thousands.

SPEECH.PARA: The fact is that there is no crisis of economic management in Australia. The real crisis is a crisis in the leadership of the Liberal Party. Yesterday, in various opinion polls, we saw the judgment of the Australian people on the leadership of the Leader of the Opposition, Mr Howard. Today, the Melbourne Age has a major article entitled `Backbenchers rebuff shadow treasurer'. That article points out that the shadow Treasurer of the Liberal Party, Mr Jim Carlton, is `struggling to establish his authority'. The real crisis at the moment is a crisis in the economic policy leadership in the Liberal Party. It is that sort of crisis which has prompted responses from the Liberals such as the matter of public importance we are discussing today. They are trying to keep the troops together, trying to keep on the rails a seriously divided party. The Liberal Party is seriously divided over economic policy. It is seriously divided over privatisation, and that was evident in the recent South Australian and Western Australian elections. It is seriously, perhaps critically, divided over wages policy.

The final division to which I referred-the division over wages policy-was heavily underlined and underscored at a recent meeting in Melbourne of Liberal Party Executive members with the Business Council of Australia. The wages policy the Liberal Party puts forward appears to be different for big business and for small business. There is considerable anxiety within the Business Council of Australia about the Liberal Party's wages policy. Quite frankly, that is understandable.

Ordinary Australians know that there is no economic crisis in Australia. In fact, any economic problems which might be occurring at the moment are due to the Government's success in boosting economic activity and demand. This country is experiencing faster economic growth than was forecast, and I believe that that growth is probably the principal cause of any problems we may have at the moment. I prefer by far to have rapid economic growth and the problems we have at the moment than the stop-go, no growth, stagnation policies of the Fraser-Howard Government.

The principal policy espoused year in, year out, by spokespersons of that Government was one of fighting inflation first. That is what it told the electorate. It asked the electorate to make sacrifices, to pull in its belt, to fight inflation first. Every other policy objective was subservient to that policy. Unemployment was deliberately run up and excess capacity created in industry, all in the name of fighting inflation. Yet the Liberals left office with inflation at 11.5 per cent per annum. Mr Fraser and Mr Howard said they would bring inflation down to below double digit levels, but when they left office it was running at 11.5 per cent per annum.

In the name of the objective of bringing inflation down, employment was devastated and despair and misery were created for young Australians, with a youth unemployment rate in the vicinity of 30 per cent. In the name of that policy, interest rates charged by savings banks for home loans rose from 9.5 per cent in early 1980 to 13.5 per cent two years later-a 4 percentage point rise in interest rates in just two years under that Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —What are they now?

—Interest rates are 13.5 per cent. That Government left office with a prospective deficit of $9,600m. That was the legacy of the Liberal-National Party Government. It left a prospective deficit of $9,600m, despite a sevenfold rise in five years in petrol revenues. The Liberal record was one of declining investment, falling production, small business collapses and soaring unemployment. That is what the Australian people were left with. The people did not want a government with that record. They did not want Mr Howard. They wanted jobs and opportunities. In 1983 the electorate overwhelmingly rejected that Government's policies. That is why the Liberal Party is in opposition now and that is why the community sought change. It wanted growth and not stagnation.

SPEECH.PARA: This Government was elected on a policy of giving a controlled stimulus to the economy without the inflationary pressures experienced under the previous Government. We undertook to fight inflation and unemployment simultaneously through the vehicle of an incomes policy and, particularly, the prices and incomes accord-the agreement negotiated between the Government and the Australian Council of Trade Unions. A key element of that agreement was the indexation of wages and salaries for cost increases as a result of increases in the consumer price index. A vital part of that policy was the mechanism of centralised wage fixing through the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission. That was a key element of this Government's policy, and it remains so. Wage indexation through that process enables the purchasing power of wages to be maintained. Most importantly, in particular circumstances, the centralised wage fixing system allows the discounting of wages for specific or special reasons, for example, inflationary pressures occasioned by a devaluation of the dollar. Those sorts of pressures have came through into our consumer price index, and the mechanism of centralised wage fixing will allow those factors to be taken into account.

As I have indicated, the crisis for the Liberals is that they do not have a wages policy. They cannot decide whether they want a centralised or decentralised wage fixing system in this country. In fact, very important elements of the Opposition want to emasculate the Arbitration Commission and end the centralised wage fixing system as we know it. That raises the very pertinent question of how, in the unlikely event of the Liberal Party being elected to government, it could then discount wages for such a special factor as the devaluation of the dollar. The Liberals still do not have an answer to that question. We are still waiting, as is the electorate, to hear what their policy will be on that matter.

Next month's national wage case will be based on consumer price index rises in the September and December quarters of last year. Those rises totalled 4.2 per cent, but after the wage case hearing, which is to get under way next month, wages and salaries will increase by only around 2 per cent. The other 2 per cent will not be awarded as a response to the devaluation of the Australian dollar. Discounting will enable the devaluation effects on Australian price levels to be quarantined without creating further rounds of wage and price increases. Following the national wage rise next month, there will be another Government initiative to keep down wage pressures in the economy. The first round of income tax reductions will start in six months' time, in September. I am pleased to see that the trade union movement in Australia has accepted the discounting of wages in return for this tax reduction. That is a very far-sighted move by the union movement which is recognising that the sources of one's disposable income are many and varied and that take-home pay can be affected just as much by reductions in income tax as it can by higher money wages. Those income tax reductions which will occur in September will match the 2 per cent discounting of wages and salaries through the national wage case.

As I have already indicated, there is no crisis in economic management in Australia. In fact, the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development, the Paris-based club of the world's rich industrialised nations, has painted a glowing picture of the Australian economy on many occasions. It has indicated that in a range of reports on the Australian economy. The OECD certainly does not see an economic crisis in this country, and neither does the Australian community. The fact is that this country has had the strongest economic growth of any major Western country over the last three years. For several years we have had a growth rate that is among the highest in the industrialised world. That is a far cry from the past and a very refreshing change from the stop-go policies of the Fraser-Howard administration. As I said earlier, that Administration depressed the economy in order to hold down prices and it even failed in that-it failed to hold down inflation.

Over the past three years real economic growth in this country has averaged almost five percentage points a year. That is a very high figure by world standards and it is certainly extraordinarily high compared with the negative growth in the economy recorded in the last year of office of the Liberal Fraser-Howard Government. By next June the Australian economy will have grown by almost 15 per cent compared with March 1983, when we came to office. In a three-year period the Australian economy will have expanded in size in real terms by about one-seventh and that is a major achievement for this Government. The Liberals destroyed jobs; we have created them. Economic growth in this country plus the process of wage indexation has had the effect of lowering real unit labour costs for production. That is something honourable senators opposite do not talk about very much, but the fact is that since this Government has come to office there has been a very big improvement in the real unit labour costs of production in this country. That in turn has worked to improve the competitiveness of Australian industry.

There is no crisis for Australian business. Businessmen know that the sorts of claims that are being made by Senator Messner and others are rubbish. One only has to look at the share market this week. Liberal senators believe that the share market is an important indicator of economic activity, it is their sort of indicator of what happens out there in the real world. The share market is setting new records at the moment. As that is the sort of indicator that honourable senators opposite believe in, I am surprised that they do not seem to be aware of that trend. Business knows that under this Government there has been strong growth in investment and production and that is being reflected in the financial markets. Under the Fraser- Howard Government the only growth in this country was in receivership and liquidation. This Government has brought down inflation from 11 1/2 per cent in the declining year of the Fraser-Howard administration to 8.2 per cent now and, as I indicated earlier, there is the prospect of discounting wages in next month's national wage case which will hold down future price rises and give further relief on the inflation front.

We have created hundreds of thousands of jobs, not destroyed them like Mr Howard did when he was Treasurer. During the 1983 election campaign the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) pledged to create 500,000 jobs in three years. That pledge was ridiculed by the Liberals but accepted by the community and endorsed overwhelmingly. Let us look at what has happened since the National Economic Summit in April 1983. To be quite truthful we did not actually create 500,000 jobs in our first three years in office, we created 590,000 and the three years is not even up yet. We have over-achieved our target of jobs created and we have done it in a shorter time than we anticipated. We still have two months to go with that particular pledge.

The 1985 Budget target has been exceeded in employment growth. The jobs forecast has been over-shot. It is out of date and it has had to be changed. Unlike the previous Government, we did not need to reduce our employment forecast, we had to increase it. Earlier, Senator Parer asked where these new jobs were being created. Overwhelmingly they are being created in the private sector. These are not band-aid or `make work' jobs under some schemes; between 80 per cent and 90 per cent of new jobs in Australia are being created by the private sector as a result of the expansionary policies of this Government. They are being created in a wide range of industries throughout the nation. As a result of the expansion in employment under this Government, there has been a very significant fall in the jobless rate in Australia. I do not find the present 8 per cent unemployment rate at all satisfactory, I would like to see it reduced significantly again and again, but the fact is that since the peak in the recession under Mr Fraser and Mr Howard when we had 10.4 per cent unemployment, there has been a 2.4 per cent reduction in this rate. That is a very significant reduction.

Unfortunately, economic recovery in Australia is being held back in certain areas. It is of great concern to members of the Government that the State of Queensland is not pulling its weight in the recovery. I notice today that Senator Parer, who is from Queensland, is on the list of speakers in this debate. Perhaps he will refer to these problems later. I notice that once again Queensland has the highest unemployment rate in Australia of 10.3 per cent.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about its bankruptcy rate?

—That is just so bad. Queensland's unemployment rate is the only one in Australia in the double digit range. It is no secret that the State with the second highest unemployment rate is Tasmania with 9.7 per cent. It is a matter of great regret that these areas of Australia are holding back the national economic recovery. Senator Robertson correctly pointed to bankruptcy levels. The fact is that in the 1985 calendar year there was a 22 per cent rise in bankruptcies in Queensland, from some 900 to more than 1,100.
—What was it in the Labor States?

—Significantly less than that. The only State with a bankruptcy increase rivalling that of Queensland was Tasmania with a 20 per cent rise. Obviously policies need to be changed in those regions of Australia in order to help broaden out the economic growth that has been occurring in the economy.

SPEECH.PARA: There has been a significant growth in consumer spending in Australia. This reflects enormous consumer confidence. Clearly consumers do not see a crisis in this country as claimed by Senator Messner. Retail sales are growing at an unprecedented rate of 13 per cent a year. That growth is about 4 or 5 per cent above the inflation rate and it is a rate that has been unheard of in Australia in recent years. We have had extremely strong investment growth in this country and that trend is continuing this financial year. I have made out a case that there is no economic crisis, no emerging crisis in Australia. The Hawke Government has major economic achievements. It has major runs on the board in less than three years. It has presided over rapid investment growth, rapid production growth, as well as rapid growth in employment. Australians are going back to work, and going back to work in record numbers. Most particularly this Government is trusted by the community as an economic manager. We are more highly regarded by the community as economic managers than is the Opposition. I believe it is a matter of fact that the Opposition will not regain public confidence with its current divided economic policies. That is why the Opposition will stay in opposition after the next election.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I believe Senator Maguire's contribution reflects a general attitude within the Australian Labor Party in that it is so preoccupied with history that it is blind to the economic realities of today. One only has to hear Senator Walsh's answers to questions to know that that is true. I would like to take up points made by Senator Maguire in his contribution to the debate. He talked about growth. The question I would like to pose today in the Senate in this matter of public importance is this: Growth, but at what cost to the Australian economy? I acknowledge that there has been an artificial growth. We all know that. Those happy days are coming to an end. Even the Australian Manufacturing Council is concerned now. It recognises that what it has referred to as the short term boom related only to a short term situation. It is concerned about the longer term implications. We are now coming to the time of those longer term implications. We have to acknowledge that in the last 12 months the Australian Labor Party has been boasting of its tremendous achievements in the area of growth. We have heard members of the Australian Labor Party make such boasts today. We will continue to hear those boasts. We will continue to hear of its tremendous achievements in the areas of employment and its ability to manage the economy. We all know how well it is going. However, if these achievements were real we would now be sitting on top of the world. Instead we are now sliding down a precipice with increasing speed. It is a tragedy.

SPEECH.PARA: What has really happened to our economy? There has been a massive devaluation of our dollar which has affected the ability of Australians to pay their way. How does the international community perceive Australia and Australian economists? Go overseas and ask people what is going wrong; they will tell you. They ask us what we are doing about it. They are literally amazed that we are not doing enough about it. What should have happened? We had a devaluation of the Australian dollar. We were told that exports would rise and that imports would decrease. However, no one really took into account the seriousness of the effect of the devaluation on the Australian manufacturing sector. Unfortunately, the Australian manufacturing sector, as a result of the Government's policies, has been left very uncompetitive. I believe that it will take some years to rectify that position. The manufacturing sector just cannot turn the tap on and off and find manufacturing jobs overnight. Unfortunately, the percentage of our manufacturing output today is below that of a number of countries which we would normally regard as inferior to Australia in terms of productive capacity. I refer to countries such as New Zealand and Sweden.

Devaluation should have led to a decrease in imports. What has happened? The reverse is true. Unfortunately, because of the Government's policies the boom in what we term ready money has led to a huge increase in imported goods such as cars, furniture and a whole range of white goods. Imports are still exceeding exports. This is the major problem we are facing. This is leading to a worsening balance of payments situation. We are not exporting sufficiently; we are importing too much. These higher costs of imported goods in turn are causing a rise in inflation. Our level of inflation is substantially higher than that of our major trading partners. In fact, if we look at inflation and interest rates we will see that they are more than twice that of our major trading partners-the people we are supposed to export to. What hope have we got unless we rectify the situation? Therefore, we are seeing an acceleration of inflation and on unacceptably high interest costs which are having a very bad effect on long term investment prospects.

In reality, we now have a situation which is not related to the history of six months ago or even four years ago, which we hear so much about, but one which is deteriorating towards stagflation. What has happened? Labor's policy on wages costs and its unrestricted growth-which I acknowledge-have led to a policy which I believe has been detrimental to the long term prospects of the Australian economy. Unfortunately, the Labor Party's attitude has shown a complete lack of appreciation for the effects of commodities on the economy and the effect its policy is having on our manufacturing sector. That is tragic. What have these policies led to? The have led to massive increases in imports. They have led to a worsening of the balance of payments situation. They have led to a drop in the value of our Australian dollar. They have led to increasing inflation and crippling interest rates. What are we now faced with? We are now faced with the prospects of reduced employment and investment opportunities.

Till now I have talked very much in generalities. Let us get down to the specifics. Let us get down to the substantial increase in overseas borrowings. Borrowings accounted for 84 per cent of the total inflow of foreign investment. That is a tragedy. However, we have been led to believe that it is essentially the private sector that has been responsible for most of this increase in more recent times. The reality is that it is in the public sector where this is happening. Public sector borrowings have far outpaced private sector borrowings, certainly over the last three-year period. The official foreign debt, which is the Federal one, rose by 129 per cent but the non-official public debt has skyrocketed to a massive 361 per cent. Therefore, it is the semi-government authorities and commissions such as the electricity authorities which seem to be totally unconcerned. The Federal Government seems to be totally unconcerned about what this sector is doing. The Government is washing its hands of and is ignoring the situation. There is nearly a 400 per cent debt. It is true that the private sector debt has increased, but by not nearly as much. It has increased only by 169 per cent. The total public sector share of the debt has risen from 37.5 per cent in 1982 to 41.3 per cent in 1985.

We have already seen that we have a significant overseas debt problem. I think that Senator Townley has spoken on this matter on a number of occasions. Since 1982 we have seen this debt increase threefold-it has tripled. At what cost? In 1982 our total debt was just over $24 billion. Within three years, by June 1985, the debt had reached $69 billion. Even if we take into account our international reserves we see that our net overseas debt is $56,635 billion. By the end of June this year it is expected to reach $80 billion. The consequences are that our interest bill will go up quite significantly. In fact, our interest bill in relation to the debt I have been speaking about has risen from 7.7 per cent of total spending in 1983-84 to 8.9 per cent last year. It is estimated to lift to over 10 per cent in the current year. That is a distressing figure. Our capacity to service this debt is becoming an increasing problem. It increasingly depends on the performance of our export sector. However, our export sector is not performing for a number of reasons. True, some of those reasons are of an international character. Many of them of course are of an internal nature and are the responsibility of the current Government.

So in the past we have sat back and expected that the sheep's back would not crack under the weight or strain of carrying an increasing non-productive sector of the population. We have had to place reliance on our primary industries. Our continued neglect of the manufacturing and tertiary sectors and of research and entrepreneurial development has led to this once great economy now finding itself in the realms or classification of a developing-type economy in terms of our output, our debt structures and in our ability to compete with the rest of the world. The Government's short term strategies have failed to take into account the long term trends in the commodity markets and the increasing adverse effect these are having on the Australian economy.

Let us look at the import purchasing power of a range of important export commodities including wheat, rice, grain, sorghum, sugar, beef, bananas, oranges, tin, nickel, bauxite, aluminium and a number of others. They all play a very important role in the Australian economy. But we are finding that the prices for them have been steadily eroding over time. Prices have been declining in the last decade. The tragedy is that these commodities, when compared with the cost of importing manufactured goods, have lost half their relative value. In other words, the commodities on which our economy depends are able to demand less and less in terms of imports, including sophisticated machinery, which includes computer equipment, engineering products, advanced consumer goods, and so on, being imported in increasing quantities. We have been experiencing a squeeze in commodities that is not expected to improve, certainly in the short or immediate future. What is happening? In the mining industry we are seeing depressed world prices. There is a problem with world over-supply and dumping in the dairying industry, the sugar industry and the wheat industry. I believe that this Government's policies are not directed to overcoming some of the international problems that are going to have a major impact on our community.

We cannot take into account economic policy without considering what is happening to the rest of the world. The rest of the world has failed to grow at a rate sufficient to accommodate Australia's own growth ambitions. This is one of the problems. We have to acknowledge that because of low commodity prices around the world the resources boom has now fizzled. Australia's current account trade deficit cannot be allowed to continue to grow at its present rate. Unfortunately, the Australian Labor Party has been so locked into its own rhetoric and its own publicity programs that it is beginning to believe itself. The economic recovery certainly has come to an end. There are serious problems. Even the left wing of the Labor Party is acknowledging these sorts of problems. The Australian community cannot afford the continual undercutting of the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission's wage hearings by the Government and the Australian Council of Trade Unions-in effect, deals which are done in advance. What about the manufacturing sector?

TALK.START.PARA: —But your Leader is going to undercut it altogether.

—I acknowledge the dilemma that the Minister is in. I acknowledge that he is trying to do something about removing the awful fringe benefits tax. I only wish that he could persuade a few more of his colleagues to change their tune, because I believe he is trying to do the right thing. He can see the problems and is one of the few in his Party who can. Some of his left wing mates at the back of this chamber can see the problems, but the trouble is that the rest of the leadership, the Hawkes and the Keatings, cannot see the problem, and until they come around to the Minister's view and those of some of his colleagues who might not share his political philosophy, Australia is going to have a problem. That is what is happening.

SPEECH.PARA: One of the great tragedies about the Labor Party is that it is integrating itself with big unions and big business and it has turned a blind eye to the poor. Australia is a lucky country for the 25,000 millionaires, the 100 deca millionaires and the one per cent who control 25 per cent of the nation's wealth. But what about the two million people who live below the poverty line? Under this Government we have never seen such a rash of takeovers. This Government will be identified as the takeover government. Industries are being taken over as never before, and this Government just sits by and does nothing-it allows these things to prosper. I only wish I had more time to continue because I believe the economic performance of this Government is abysmal.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not quite certain what to make of Senator Watson's contribution but I feel it probably deserves some comment. The first point I would like to make, having listened to him, is that perhaps he has not been an avid student of the newspapers. If he had been reading them of a day he might have remembered that only a few weeks ago certain big names in the Liberal Party of Australia-Mr Howard, Mr Brown and others-trooped along to the Business Council of Australia, finally got in the door and found that unanimously members of the Business Council lambasted them for an hour about this nonsense of accusing the Government of being all about big business and about big unions. Senator Watson obviously missed all of that. The reality is that John Howard had to troop out the door, tail between his legs-I might say a position that he has become used to in recent times-with a hangdog look, with all the troops following him, their chins hitting their feet as they walked out. And why? Because the business base of the Liberal Party told them where to go and how to get there. The reality is that that business support cannot ever be won back. The Party has ratted on its base; it has ratted on everybody else in the community and it has nowhere to go.

SPEECH.PARA: I think the important thing is to take it further with these fascinating comments on take-overs by Senator Watson. I do not know whether the huge crowd assembled here in the chamber caught it all, but as I could pick up his remarks I gleaned a certain disdain and distaste for take-overs-a plea, a crying out if you like, for the Government to intervene and stop these things. I must say that that seems to run contrary to every other voice from the Liberal Party over the last few days and weeks. I suspect that it is merely another manifestation of the hopeless split that exists in Liberal Party ranks. I am not sure whether Senator Watson is part of the Howard camp, the Peacock camp, or whatever camp. I cannot quite work it all out; it is a bit much for me. One thing I can say is that if I had the misfortune to lead the Liberal Party at any time I would be awfully worried about having people such as Senator Watson behind me.

I turn to more substantial matters than criticising Tasmanian senators, which, as you know, Mr Acting Deputy President, is something that happens all too often in this place. I turn to the actual terms of the matter of public importance. It refers to the emerging crisis in economic management. I wonder by what standard we have worked out that there is a crisis. It seems to me that when there is an economic crisis the first people to wake up are the vast numbers of people out there generally referred to as Australians. They seem to be able to work out when things have turned sour and things have gone wrong. I recall looking only last Saturday and Monday at the Age and the Herald and seeing some polls on what Australians thought of the political leadership of the country and of the alternative political leadership. I recall that Mr Howard has hit a new record low of 13 per cent. I know he is working hard at achieving single figures and I am one who believes that within a matter of weeks it can happen. The realities are that Government popularity, way ahead of the Opposition's, has remained high in all of the recognised opinion polls right through the term of this Government. In mid-term it is pretty difficult for governments to be so popular. It has not been a feature of Australian political history in the last 20 years, but it is a feature of Australian political history as it is being made right now. And why should it not be? The reality is that with consumer spending high-and getting higher-consumer confidence getting better and investment growing the people of Australia just cannot see where the crisis is.

It is all right for oppositions, travelling in the polls in the way they are, with that desperate need to find some issue to kick themselves along with and to score at least some points, to try to talk up a crisis. I suppose if I were in opposition I might consider it myself. The reality is that with the economy in the shape it is in at the moment it will be a bit difficult. Those opposite will have to do a lot better than the contributions made by Senator Watson and Senator Messner to get us to the point of crisis. I suspect that they will have to do better than the contribution Senator Parer is about to make.

However, if one looks at the terms of the matter of public importance-`the emerging crisis in economic management'-the first and most striking point one really has to ask is just how thick can the hide of this Opposition be? If we were handing out awards for gall and hide, this Opposition would have to take the cake. I have been known to have a pretty thick hide and a bit of gall myself over the years, but I have to take my hat off to those opposite. This is spectacular. If we look at what this Government inherited only a few years ago after a dark, bleak leadership period for Australia under Fraser and Howard, we see what it has had to contend with. It will be instructive for honourable senators to bear with me for a few moments while I go over some of the things we inherited and then turn to a comparison with the things this Government has done.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about today's problems?

—I will try to explain it to the honourable senator. I know it is difficult, but I will try to explain that all those people out there, generally called Australians, do not believe there is a crisis, have faith in the Government, and will re-elect it. I know it is a problem for the honourable senator and I know he is ambitious, but he will just have to be patient.

SPEECH.PARA: I turn now to what we inherited just three years ago when we came to office. As someone endowed with a somewhat long memory, as some of my colleagues well know, I remind honourable senators of what devastation the conservatives were responsible for inflicting on the Australian economy during those seven years. I notice in Senator Watson's contribution we had yet again that other quaint Liberal trait of saying that we have to acknowledge the extraordinary international difficulties that Malcolm Fraser and John Howard encountered. The Whitlam Government had to face the oil shock of 1973. If one looks at the last 15 years, that was the single biggest international event of economic impact we have experienced. Those opposite try to write that off as Whitlam's fault, but when it comes to the regimes of Fraser and Howard, which existed under very fortunate economic climes around the world, they try to infer that in some way they were the victims of an international collapse. The reality was that there was a collapse of competence in their government and that is why it had a problem. The previous Government inflicted a mauling on the Australian economy that it had not experienced since the catastrophe of the 1930s and the Great Depression.

Let me just go through a few of those points. Dealing with unemployment, the main reason why this Government was elected, in my view, was the issue of jobs. By the time we got into government unemployment was 10.4 per cent of the work force. Malcolm Fraser in his 1975 election policy speech stated:
Only under a Liberal-National Party Government will there be jobs for all who want to work.
Let us look at the record of how many jobs there were for all those who wanted to work.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tell us about now.

—In August 1975-in case Senator Peter Baume has forgotten-278,000 people were officially unemployed and they represented 4.6 per cent of the labour force. By March 1983 the number of unemployed had grown to 731,000, or 10.4 per cent of the labour force. During the last year of the Fraser Government, from March 1982 to March 1983, the number of unemployed increased by 270,000 people. That means that people were being thrown out of jobs at a rate of almost 750 every day. For every week the Fraser Government was in office between 1975 and 1983 another 1,000 Australians ended up on a dole queue. That is the sort of crisis those opposite gave us; it is the sort of crisis we have helped to cure.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us look at inflation. When we came to government it was 11.5 per cent. Looking ahead to next year, it will finish up at 5.5 per cent and going down. That is still too high in terms of what our trading partners have, but the reality is that this Government started from a miserable position and it takes some time to catch up. We have the runs on the board and we have shown that we can get inflation down. We will keep that up.

I would like to make particular reference to interest rates, because that subject seems to have achieved a bit of publicity in recent days. A number of people on the other side have tried to claim that they are the highest for 50 years. If one looks at the statistics, that really cannot be backed up; it is not correct. In June 1979 interest rates on 10-year bonds and 90-day bank bills were 10 per cent. In the last year of the Fraser Government that had risen to 16.5 per cent. Today the rate is 13.5 per cent and going down. In 1979 the interest on bank bills was 10.35 per cent, in the last year of the Fraser Government the rate was up to 18.75 per cent, and it is now 16.5 per cent and going down. Home owners with a mortgage in June 1982 would have been paying 13.5 per cent interest. That ceiling has been maintained. Those Australians who own homes are still paying 13.5 per cent and will continue to do so. Every time housing interest rates went up under the previous Government-if we go back to 1979 they were 9 per cent-it meant $300m was transferred each year from the pockets of Australian families into the financial institutions of Australia. That was not unusual.

More importantly and significantly, let us look at John Howard, that man who has masqueraded as an economic manager. I know Australia saw through him a few years ago-probably not half as much as they will next year. Let me just go through his record as a person framing our Budgets. Every one of the five Howard Budgets was overspent-every one of them. If we look at the Budget estimate and the actual result, we see that he went too far. Not surprisingly, the worst excess was in the financial year 1982-83-a big year for John Howard and Malcolm Fraser. In 1982-83 we had a Budget estimate of expenditure of $47,067m. By the time the figures all came down we had $48,982m, a massive increase and one that should have surprised no one because that was at the stage when the economy was free-wheeling, when the Government had given up trying to manage it, and it made its last desperate attempt to win an election. Of course, it did not succeed because the rest of Australia saw through it.

Let us look at deficit projections, which are probably more important from the point of view the way the financial markets judge governments these days. In only three out of five Budgets the deficit turned out larger than John Howard thought it would be. But 1982-83 again was a big year because there was a massive blowout in the Budget deficit from a projected figure of $1.6 billion to $4.5 billion. This was the biggest blowout Australia had ever seen. Had that Government stayed in power longer, as I heard Senator Maguire say earlier, it would have been facing a deficit of the best part of $10 billion. When we look at Liberal promises, at the extraordinary promises Mr Howard has been making of late, that $10 billion would be chicken feed. That would be passed in the run to the first turn, let alone the home straight. God knows where Australia would finish up if we had to put up with it.

I also heard the plaintive cries from the other side about wages explosions. In the last two weeks in two statements, one by Mr Howard and one by Mr N. A. Brown, the Opposition has done its third somersault in six months on wages policy. We understand that and we are used to it. I understand that Mr Brown has now said categorically that wages will be set mostly by the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission. He walked away from the previous nonsense of the Fraser experiment-the evidence of 1981-82, when wages grew by 13 per cent or 14 per cent two years in a row. Once we let the handbrake off, wages will go berserk. Big unions will continue to win big increases and damage the economy. That is something this Government has stopped by a process of conciliation. It is something we will continue to stop. We will manage this economy as well as we have in the past. We will be re-elected because Australians accept the fact that this Government has done the job and it has the runs on the board.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Parer Sen W.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to support my colleagues on this matter of public importance relating to the need for the Government to change its policies in response to the emerging crisis in economic management. Senator Richardson in his opening remarks somehow tried to denigrate the fact that talks were held between the shadow Ministry and the Business Council of Australia. Yet yesterday or today we saw in the newspaper a photograph of the Treasurer (Mr Keating) who has been called to Melbourne to attend a meeting of the Australian Council of Trade Unions to get his marching orders because obviously he too has some concern about the economic management of the country, but he cannot do much without getting Mr Kelty's approval.

SPEECH.PARA: The crisis is an economic one and it is of the Government's own making. Either through stupidity, false optimism or simple deception the Government has kept the people in the dark about the serious economic problems of the country. Government policy is going in the wrong direction and the Government must change its policy mix. We have seen recent attempts to do this by the more responsible people on the other side, such as the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh), but each time he has been shot to pieces. Senator Maguire and Senator Richardson both have said that there is no crisis at all; there is not an impending one, nor will there be one. They are telling the Australian public, small businessmen and farmers: `You have never had it so good'. We have heard that before. That has shades of the Whitlam era-`You have never had it so good'. I do not know why they would take that view when they have only to look around the countryside and talk to people and they will find mass meetings of small business people saying: `We have come to the end of our tether, we cannot afford this Government. What can we do to get out of it; what can we do to get rid of it?'. That is the sort of message I get when I speak to those people. The Chairman of the National Farmers Federation is stopping farmers from taking violent action because of their concern. The two senators on the Australian Labor Party side have said that there is no crisis.

Let us look at it. We have signs of slowing economic growth-the cornerstone of government policy-and we have a fall in manufacturing production for the December quarter. There was talk about something to do with the previous Government being responsible for the fall in the manufacturing industry. I will tell honourable senators what killed the manufacturing industry: It was the policies of the then leader of the ACTU, who is now the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), who did the damage to the manufacturing industry and I do not think that it will recover. It is a great shame. Who would be brave enough today either to extend his or her industry or to start another one, even on an import replacement policy, with the sorts of problems these people have in front of them, such as interest rates and the uncertainty of labour costs?

We have had a drop in motor vehicle registrations in January, for the fourth consecutive month. The Minister for Finance often claims that motor car registrations are a good guide to the economy. The number of building approval has fallen sharply since September; bank deposits have fallen in January, for the third consecutive month; and home lending by building societies fell by 12.7 per cent in December. There are indications that the current account deficit is not about to turn around, as is evidenced by a continuing poor export performance. The dollar has further declined by 4.6 per cent in the past month and has declined by 17.3 per cent since February 1985, according to the trade weighted index. We have continuing high interest rates, which are choking economic growth, at a time when interest rates are falling world-wide. We have inflationary forecasts of around 8 per cent for 1986; over double that of our major trading partners and four times that of Japan. In fact, a study by a senior Treasury official, Mr Alan Henderson, cites the following features of the Japanese economy which contributed to Japan's performance:
A decentralised labour marker that is sensitive to trends in profitability.
A degree of unionisation with unions being company-based.
A small government sector.
Absence of wage indexation.
A substantial part of earnings (over 25 per cent) made up of bonuses.
Bonuses are based on profitability, not paid automatically, whether or not a profit is made. He further states:
Flexibility in structure of relative wages, level of wages and in the administration of minimum wage laws.
An export-oriented manufacturing sector that focuses the attention of key unions on international competitiveness.

Another sign of crisis is that our expected earnings growth in 1986 is around 10 per cent, including two national wage hearings and a productivity increase. We have a growing overseas debt, now running at over $70 billion and increasing at the rate of $1 billion per month. It has been calculated that for every taxpayer in Australia this represents approximately $17,000 and it means that every baby born this year will be given a debt of $6,500. We have record low farm incomes and declining rural land values, reflecting a price-cost squeeze. There is a likely increase in the level of unemployment, due to the choking off of economic growth, as indicated by the Australia and New Zealand Banking Group's index of job advertisements. These are very ominous warnings that we are heading towards a recession. I quote from an article by Christopher Jay in the Australian Financial Review of 5 March 1986. He said:

The clouded cuckooland of economic optimism which has been dominating so much public commentary on the Australian economy has abruptly foundered on the gathering reality of a deteriorating balance of payments.

After all the celebrations of increasing consumer spending, strong real growth rates and falling unemployment, the concealed corollaries have emerged into the light of day. The whole exercise has been based on continued borrowing from overseas, at levels which are unsustainable in the long run, and which are already imposing tighter and tighter clamps on the Government's freedom of manoeuvre.

In other words, the so-called trilogy has imposed disciplines on the Government only insofar as domestic borrowings are concerned. Nothing has stopped the Government from borrowing up big and putting the country into hock overseas to pay for the party at home.

It seems that the party may be over. Even the Prime Minister has realised that the world does not owe Australia a living. Our debt is more than $70 billion. When the Hawke Government came to power it was $36.4 billion; that is, half of what it is today. Our current account deficit for the year 1985-86 is likely to be approximately $13 billion. This will automatically add on to our overseas debt, which is already pre-empting one export dollar in every three for debt servicing. This is also despite a 20 per cent depreciation of the dollar in the past 12 months; a depreciation which the Treasurer and Prime Minister promised would make us more competitive. The Federal interest bill has risen from 7.7 per cent of total spending in 1983-84 to 8.9 per cent in 1984-85 and about 10 per cent this financial year. That is more than we spend on defence, health and education. As a share of gross domestic product, the net debt has risen from 6 per cent in 1980 to over 25 per cent in 1985.

The hole that this Government has dug for us is a very deep one. The current situation cannot easily be turned around, for we need a massive increase in exports to get the current account right. It is only then that we will make inroads into the debt problem. In the meantime, most of our current account deficit has to be covered by new overseas borrowings. More importantly, the recent released figures show, contrary to what the Treasurer has been saying, that in the last three years borrowing by the Government has easily outstripped private borrowings overseas. Hence it is a problem created by government policy and it must be solved by government policy. Ross Gittins, a journalist not noted for his antipathy to this Government, has said:

The economy (by mid year) will be heading inexorably towards recession and rising unemployment. If that happens, many things will start falling apart. The employers' claim that they can't afford the 3 per cent productivity-superannuation deal will be considerably more persuasive, the accord will be looking shaky and well-placed unions will be tempted to get in for an extra bite of the cherry before it disappears for the duration, the trilogy will be out the window, the Cabinet will be panicky and the loony left will be running in all directions.

When journalists such as Ross Gittins say that things are bad, things are very bad. But we do not have to take his word for it. The Government itself has begun to let the cat out of the bag and to inform the public that all is not well, despite its own glossy rhetoric over the last 12 months. The Secretary to the Treasury, Mr Bernie Fraser, recently conceded that we are still yet to see the effects of the November credit squeeze. One can only imagine what this will do to interest rates and to economic growth. But Government spokesmen themselves are now admitting this. A Cabinet document called something like `1986-87 Budget Strategy', which strangely made its way into the national media recently, reveals the economy to be at a critical stage. The Treasurer is said to hold out little hope for further falls in unemployment in the next financial year due to a marked slowdown in economic growth to 3.5 per cent. But the Prime Minister himself, in his birthday speech, admitted:
In a sense, the difficult economic issues we must now address are in fact the price we pay for the very success of our policies, and the strength of the growth that has been achieved in the economy.

When translated from Hawkespeak, this simply means that we are now paying the price, through lower living standards, for the excesses of the last three years that have been brought about by the Government's own policies. These admissions by the Government, some intended, and others not, are meant to give the Government a soft landing. Whether or not the economy has a soft landing is entirely another question.

The Government has not always been so frank with the Australian people. Despite warnings by the Opposition and by some other enlightened commentators, the Government has blustered on over the last few months.
