At best, it has been foolhardy and has believed its own rhetoric. At worst it has not been telling the truth to the electorate. The hyperbole of this Government knows no bounds when it comes to its own achievements, whether it be the accord-a disaster for Australia; Medicare-running totally out of control; Priority One-the biggest joke since the Tax Summit. On all these things, the Government is full of self-praise. On Budget night the Treasurer claimed:
The Hawke Government stands before the people of Australia tonight proud of its record of economic success.
We have turned the economy around from deep recession to a rate of growth which is one of the fastest in the Western world.

He pointed to the Government's achievements in reducing inflation and arresting the growth in Budget deficits. What he did not mention was that our inflation rate is now more than twice that of our major trading partners, and as I mentioned earlier, four times that of Japan, and that domestic deficits have been allowed to stabilise only because of massive Government borrowings overseas. He spoke of the Government's achievements in reducing unemployment. Yet unemployment throughout the Hawke period has been higher than in all but five of the 86 full months of the Fraser Government. I repeat: Unemployment throughout the Hawke period has been higher than in all but five of the 86 full months of the Fraser Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —It was higher under Fraser than at any stage under the Whitlam Government. What does that mean?

—I am pleased with the Minister's interjection because to a large extent I approve of what the Minister is trying to do to ease this crisis. But he does not seem to be having a lot of success. I read with great interest his recent paper on privatisation, a paper which I would like to have given myself. I hope he does not mind if I use it some day.

SPEECH.PARA: We heard a lot about the J-curve last year as the solution to our moribund competitive position. Now the Government cannot make up its mind whether it is a J or an L. Mr Hawke still proclaims an improving competitive position. But if one asks Senator Button, things are not so rosy. According to the Treasurer, in 1985 `we have set our sails for growth'. In 1986 we appear to be running out of steam. I know I am to be followed in the debate by Senator Cook. I will be interested to hear what he has to say because he is on record as having said:
We are a big spending government. We have to be to implement our reforms.
How on earth can someone like Senator Walsh, who is trying to do something about the crisis in the economy, cope with that sort of attitude?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Parer should quote me correctly. I do not intend to inform him what was the correct quote, but it was not exactly what he said.
—It was very close.

—No, it was not close at all. This is the fourteenth or fifteenth time in the last three years I have participated in a debate on a matter of public importance concerning the economy. Increasingly I have come to the view that these debates not only have become turgid and disappointing in terms of real fire from the Opposition, but are also becoming a waste of time. All that the Opposition ever does is debate the economy by attacking the personality of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), be referring to his record with the Australian Council of Trade Unions, blaming the unions for what happened while Fraser was in power, referring to his record in government, and pretending to blame the Government, although that defies the imagination. So there is a personality dimension to the Opposition's economic debate.

SPEECH.PARA: There is also a tendency in the economic debate to ignore the past. Of course, members of the Opposition would want to ignore the past. The past is not very pretty. They pretend that they come here with clean hands, able to debate with a clean slate. They cannot ignore the record of massive inflation, galloping unemploy- ment--

TALK.START.PARA: —Howard's trilogy.

—Yes, and a devastated industry base in Australia during their period in office. They debate the economy by confusing the statistics, but they do not present any analysis of the meaning of those statistics. They simply draw rhetorical points from them. They do not ever put forward an alternative that can be examined as a model for what could otherwise be the economic managerial direction of Australia. They come here without any plan of their own. Of course, towards the end of these debates they always give in to their intrinsic hatred of trade unions, ignoring the fact that on the latest figures 56 per cent of Australians are members of trade unions. However, members of the Liberal Party, ignoring numbers and trying to destroy their own standing in the community, continue to attack that group of Australians who have organised to protect their rights by joining trade unions.

SPEECH.PARA: Finally, whenever they debate wages they see them only as a cost. They never see them in their two-dimensional and true aspect, as both a cost and a purchasing power in the hands of consumers able to create demand. They never see it in those terms. They recite their dismal and petty tale of economic argument, all of which is, I think, somewhat discouraging for anyone who wants to have a genuine discussion and debate about the Australian economy, because there are a number of things that require some analysis and consideration. Economic management concerns identifying what the problems are and structuring policies to deal with those problems.

Today we have heard from Senator Parer about the photo in today's Australian of Keating and Kelty as if that were an economic argument. We heard today from Senator Watson how the manufacturing base in Australia has declined over the last 15 years, as if his Party were not in government and did not take any responsibility for that. But the performances of those two honourable senators was topped by the opening remarks of Senator Messner when he read the text of the matter of public importance, which is as follows:
The need for the Government to change its policies in response to the emerging crisis in economic management.

He then said that that is not what it is really about. He said that what the debate is really about is employment. No member of the Opposition-particularly a former Minister in the Fraser-Howard Government-has any right to talk about employment, as if that Government demonstrated any compassion for the unemployed.

Let us start with what Senator Messner said. Let us deal with the question of unemployment. This is the third anniversary of Labor's election. It is indeed passing strange that Senator Messner should choose employment to be the theme of the alleged crisis in the Australian economy. When we came to power we promised the creation of half a million jobs. We have created near enough to 600,000 new jobs. We have overperformed on that policy.

That is, of course, turning around the situation. There was negative job creation during the last months the coalition was in power. Eighty per cent or more of the jobs we have created are in the private sector. Australia still is regarded as leading the industrialised world in growth and job creation. We still are creating jobs at a rate four times faster than did the previous Government. So we would enjoy having some analysis made of what Senator Messner wants to make the basis of this debate.

Senator Messner based the percentage of unemployment on the figures released today by the Bureau of Statistics. He said that there are still 8 per cent of Australians unemployed. Of course, on those figures there are still 8 per cent of Australian unemployed, which is slightly up, by 0.2 per cent, from September last year. We do not take any joy from that figure. We have always regarded the level of unemployment as being too high. The difference between us and the Opposition is that we have had a policy which has been bringing the level of unemployment down from 11 per cent, the level when the coalition was in office.
In dealing with unemployment on the basis of today's reports the Opposition has ignored what what the Commonwealth Statistician has counselled. The Statistician said:
Particular care should be taken in the interpretation of the seasonally adjusted series in this publication as the short-term movement--
and I emphasise his words--
cannot be assumed to indicate changes in trend.

If one looks at the unemployment figures on a three-month trend basis one can see that, between the three months ending November 1985 and the three months ending February 1986, the seasonally adjusted unemployment rate fell from 8 per cent to 7.9 per cent and the seasonally adjusted participation rate rose from 61.1 per cent to 61.5 per cent. The rise in the participation rate is important because it means that people who have not entered the active job market because of the strength of the economy and the possibility of getting employment are now emboldened to seek employment whereas in the past they were discouraged from doing so. The increase in the participation rate is a sign of a healthy labour market with persons wanting jobs being encouraged actively to seek work.

The other significant point about the ABS figures is that if the participation rate had remained fixed at 6.1 per cent during the three months to February the recorded unemployment rate would have been 7.3 per cent, which would have been a real reduction in terms of the level of unemployment. So one cannot pretend to any rigour in economic analysis and in isolation quote one figure-that is the percentage figure of unemployment-and ignore entirely the increase in the participation rate because to do so is to create a false picture. That false picture was, unfortunately, the main weapon with which the Liberal Party proposed to attack the Government today. It has been defeated on the very centrepiece of its attack.

As we know, the Australia and New Zealand Bank's job vacancy index rose for February. As we know, the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development predicts that this year there will be a further growth in employment in Australia. As we know, with an increased participation rate we are still vastly better off in terms of employment in Australia because under the Liberals we had 11 per cent unemployment with record low participation rates. The truth is that we have economic settings which we will not be panicked into changing. We have economic settings which are causing the economy to improve step by step. However, there are occasions on which blips come across the screen and they have to be taken into account. But one does not move away from one's basic settings; one continues on the course that has been set. The truth is that in the last three years we have improved the economy significantly. When we embarked on that course the Opposition said that could not be done. Well, we have done it. Now it says: `You are not going to do it in the future'. Well, we say, as we said three years ago: `Just wait and watch us because you will see what will happen'.

In the few minutes available to me I want to refer to some of the aspects of the matter of public importance itself. Of course, one expects that the major reason for this matter of public importance being brought on today is the current account figures that were released yesterday. Once again the Opposition has been deficient in citing bald figures without analysing what in fact the current account or the balance of payments figures show. The Treasurer said at a meeting of the Economic Planning Advisory Council on the 7th of this month that we expect that we will not be able to meet necessarily the forecasts in the August 1985 Budget for the current account and the balance of payments. He said that the results will be a bit weaker. There are two main reasons for this. Bald figures have been cited but no analysis has been engaged in. However, one cannot understand the significance of the figures unless one looks at them. Let us look at the two main reasons. Export volumes have been up. However, the fact is that export receipts have been lower because we are trading in commodities such as primary produce and minerals. We can increase the volume of those commodities but the prices abroad have gone down. That has had an impact on the balance of payments.

The other key factor is the growth in gross domestic product within Australia which has increased more than expected because we have sucked in over the last months more imports than we predicted. While one is concerned about that and while one would have liked to have seen greater import replacement, if we look at the types of imports that have been sucked into the economy we find that in the main part they are significantly investment-type goods. These investment-type goods, which add to the deficit now, will add to our industrial base and therefore add to our productive capacity later. They will enable the J curve effect to take place. In fact, there will be a greater import replacement in the future because of the investment that is being made now in capital goods. We will be in a position to export more in the future. So those aspects of the current account should be considered by the Opposition. However, they were never mentioned. That analysis was never engaged in and an artificial and false position was presented.

We are dealing as a government with a massive economic imbalance inherited from the previous Government. We have been grappling with that significant problem. There was an over-valuation of the Australian dollar under Fraser and Howard. There was a wages explosion in 1981 and 1982 under that administration. During that period the Howard-Fraser Administration flirted with free collective bargaining in the economy. Because of that, wages blew out, and that has damaged our international competitiveness, caused a fall in productivity, caused a fall in business investment and wrecked our manufacturing base. Now we have Senator Watson coming along and pretending that that did not happen in those terms. He argues that this Government is responsible for what has happened to our manufacturing base in the last three years when this Government in the last three years has been pursuing policies aimed at re-establishing our manufacturing base.

We have had a wages policy in government which has led to a real drop in unit labour costs-a drop to the level of that of the late 1960s. We have had a wages policy in government which, in terms of shares of GDP going to profits and shares of GDP going to wages and salaries, has seen a return to the profit side of the ledger. We have now begun to see a beginning of private investment in the economy because of that. We have seen a period of industrial calm settle upon Australian industry because of the prices and wages accord with the Australian Council of Trade Unions. This has enabled workers to predict job security and economic security-something that workers did not have in the law of the jungle during the Fraser years. As a result, workers sought to protect themselves. We now know that business investment is recovering.

In terms of fiscal policy, we have closed the tax rorts that the Fraser-Howard Government tolerated, tax rorts which bled investment funds away from productive industry into tax shelters. We have reformed that. That enables an efficient allocation of resources--

TALK.START.PARA: —John Howard reformed it.

—No, we have reformed it. That is enabling an efficient allocation of resources and investment to take place. We have the trilogy which, of course, enables the private sector to predict what the Government in general broad terms will be doing in the economy. It can be sure that it can operate in a stable macro-economic environment.

SPEECH.PARA: We have done all of those things and we will continue to do them. I return to the point that when we embarked upon government three years ago and embarked upon the ACTU-ALP prices accord, the Opposition attacked us for this being a wrong method of approaching economic management in Australia. That method has produced magnificent results for this economy and we are not now going to be panicked into changing course.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired. The discussion is concluded.

DEBATE.TITLE: NATIONAL ENERGY RESEARCH, DEVELOPMENT AND DEMONSTRATION COUNCIL

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sanders Sen N.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

This paper is the annual report for 1984-85 of the National Energy Research, Development and Demonstration Council and it is an indication of the complete lack of commitment to renewable resources in Australia. In fact, this report shows that NERDDC is really being used as a means of channelling public money to large private companies which should be tackling their own programs. This I think is probably understandable when we look at who was on the Council as at 30 June 1985. The Chairman was Mr J. E. Kolm, former Technical and Research Director of ICI Australia Ltd. Members included Mr B. R. Griffith, General Manager, Exploration, BHP Petroleum Pty Ltd; Mr A. H. Hams, former General Manager and Director of Research, Australian Coal Industry Research Laboratories Ltd; Dr R. A. Durie, Chief Scientist, R. W. Miller and Co. Pty Ltd; and so the list goes on.

This is reflected when we look at the actual expenditures of NERDDC at page 20 in the list of grants approved in 1984-85. In the first place the total was a measly $13,938,606, a paltry sum compared with the importance of this operation. Let us see how it was distributed. Under the heading `Oil Shale and Tar Sands' we find that, for the new retorting process for Toolebuc oil shale, CSR Ltd gets $387,000. CSR gets another $80,000 for finding out what are the marketable transport fuels from Toolebuc shale oil. Under `Coal' we find that the State Electricity Commission of Victoria gets $2,110,800 for a solar dried slurred low-rank coal-pilot plant. W. M. McQueen and Co. Pty Ltd gets $951,000 for a deep seam-face automation-stage 3 continuous haulage and miner remote control system. Capricorn Coal Management Pty Ltd gets $382,000 for a program of rapid access longwall mining from open pits. The Utah Development Co. Ltd, not one of the smaller outfits, gets $321,000 for a feasibility study of thick seam, single pass, longwall mining in the Bowen Basin. These programs should be undertaken by the companies themselves. Why should the public purse pay for this? It is a means of milking the Treasury. When we add all this together, it turns out that coal, oil and gas get 73 per cent of the total NERDDC allocation for the year.

Let us look at renewable resources-wind energy, for instance. It gets 2.5 per cent of the total allocation, or a total of $347,000, a paltry sum. Then we find that the Hydro-Electric Commission of Tasmania gets $100,000 of that. The Commission is wedded to the concept of hydro-electric power and has taken every step possible to eliminate wind power in Tasmania, yet it gets $100,000, which it will no doubt squander, as it has squandered all the money it has received for wind power in the past. It will come up once again with the proposition that the wind does not blow in Tasmania and that wind power does not work. What a waste of money!

We find that some worthwhile projects are being instituted. A 64-kilowatt wind generator with enhanced low wind output from Wind Technology Pty Ltd gets $90,000. That is fair enough. A variable speed fixed pitch 30-kilowatt wind turbine from Westwind Turbines gets $39,000. That is very good. But this country is falling far behind the rest of the world in its implementation of the new technologies simply because we have troglodytes such as those who sit on my right who say that wind power will not work and solar power will not work-it has never been proven, mumble mumble. They have never been to actually see these things working. They have never been out of their caves in Tasmania. Talk about troglodytes! There they sit, and they do not believe in new technology. They are still living firmly in the nineteenth century. These projects can work here. They can enhance Australia's energy situation. They must be implemented. We do not need to study renewable resources. We need to implement them or we shall remain in the dark ages in which we have resided for so long with these people on my right presiding over them.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to commend the National Energy Research, Development and Demonstration Council, with which I have had very close association. I rise to condemn what has just been said by Senator Sanders. As a troglodyte to his right, I want to say that I have travelled the world studying both wind power and solar power. I ought to have gone to Tasmania, but the fact is that there could not be more nonsense than is talked by him. Indeed, through NERDDC and through the department I was privileged to preside over, Australia did work in solar power and in solar arrays that led the world. If Senator Sanders were to go to any university or to Rottnest Island in Western Australia he would see examples of great experiments in wind power and solar power. But that should not divert me.

SPEECH.PARA: The fact is that this Council's main work was conceived at a time when there was an energy crisis throughout the world because of the very high price of oil. One danger now is that, because oil has temporarily fallen in its price, there is a belief around the community-utterly wrong-that we do not need to look at energy conservation or energy research and that we can coast along on oil at a low price per barrel. That could not be more wrong. First of all, of course, oil and coal are both non-renewable resources; there will be in five to eight years time another world crisis in oil. Far more important than that is that Australia faces one problem that overrides all others. We in Australia are being costed out of world markets. We cannot employ people in manufacturing. Where there used to be 28 per cent employed in that sector now the figure is 16 per cent because we cannot compete with world imports, even with an additional barrier of 30 per cent resulting from the devalued dollar. We cannot do it. Our costs are too high. Yet in energy and many other resources we do very little to cut our costs.

When I was privileged to be a member of the International Energy Agency and to represent Australia it was said and proven in other countries that there could be a conservation of 30 per cent in energy without a lowering of living standards. Both Japan and America proved this. This was not only fundamentally important simply to save energy; it also saved costs. The best way to save the need to build another power station is to save electricity. Then one does not need to build another power station. In other words, if Australia wants to get to the heart of its problems, that is, the costs of production, here is one situation in which we can apply our minds.

Let me tell the Senate something that will get to the heart of this. In 1981 a survey was done of the predicted annual increase in the use of oil in Australia. It was decided that in Australia it would be about 0.5 per cent a year in the 1980s. That was roughly what was predicted in America. America today is running at 0.6 per cent. What is Australia doing? It is running at a fraction under 2 per cent per year. That is absolutely suicidal with regard to the conservation of our fossil fuels. We are in fact putting our heads in the sand, just as we are in exporting our oil in order to earn some balance of trade money. I rose simply to say that the work of NERDDC was never more important than it is now. Conserving energy, both in the case of fossil fuels and non-renewables is important because getting costs down is fundamental to solving the great issues in Australia. We must keep that target in mind no matter what we do.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Townley Sen M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I cannot let some of the things that Senator Sanders said go without making some comment. Before doing that and perhaps to give him time to get back to the chamber in case he wants to listen to what I have to say, I congratulate the National Energy Research, Development and Demonstration Council on the work that it is doing. I think that Senator Sanders has not understood the whole basis of the work of this Council. Its aim is to try to encourage conservation in the use of energy. It is trying to stimulate programs of development in technologies that are now available. For Senator Sanders to say that certain companies or organisations should not be allowed to participate in these programs when they may be very large users of energy and experts in the energy field, as is the Hydro-Electric Commission in Tasmania, just shows how wrong is his attitude to energy.

SPEECH.PARA: I am sure that Senator Sanders would like to see everyone in the world switch off all electric power and turn to wood burning. Where would he get the wood? He does not want trees to be cut down even though in his absence from here, I believe, he was selling wood burners on a Saturday in Salamanca Place in Hobart. It seems a bit strange to me that he is a man who does not like trees being chopped down but who sells wood burners to make profit for his own pocket.

TALK.START.PARA: —They pollute the atmosphere too.

—I will get on to that in a moment. We would all like to see energy being generated from non-polluting sources. We note the trouble that Europe is having now with acid rain. The two prime causes of acid rain are energy from motor cars and from coal-burning power stations. The wind drifts mainly from England across to Europe and the pollution is causing quite a dangerous situation for Europe's trees and forests.

SPEECH.PARA: I am pleased to say that of the 114 projects approved during the year 36 related to energy conservation. Is Senator Sanders saying that he does not want that to happen? Twenty-nine were related to renewable energy sources. For Senator Sanders to say that honourable senators on this side of the chamber have not bothered to investigate these kinds of things just shows that he has not bothered to investigate what we have looked at. In the United States of America I have visited the Solar 1 power plant. It is the largest solar plant. It occupies a very large area and involved a big capital investment. It generates about 10 megawatts. It is nowhere near the stage of being commercially feasible, but it is still being investigated. I am sure that other ways of generating power from solar sources will gradually be developed, but at the moment they do not exist.

Another area in which I believe the Council should be encouraging investigation is nuclear energy. I notice that page 10 of the Council's annual report for 1985 mentions nuclear energy. It goes on to mention a very important area of Australian research in this field-the synroc development which is being carried on in Sydney. That will make disposal of waste products from atomic or nuclear-powered plants very much easier and safer to control. That problem has worried many people during the life of the nuclear-powered stations in the world. It does not particularly worry me because I believe that engineers can handle the problem. For Senator Sanders to come into this chamber and denigrate a report and the work the Council is doing in looking for conservation measures and in its research into renewable sources of energy purely because the research may not be done by people whom he likes is downright scandalous.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vigor Sen D.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak on the annual report of the National Energy Research, Development and Demonstration Council. I think a point has to be made, although I would not put it in the way that Senator Sanders did. Out of the $13.94m that comes from the energy research trust account of the Department of Resources and Energy and the 5c a tonne coal production levy allocated under the Coal Research Assistance Act 1977, which amounts to $1.89m-those figures add up to just over $16m-the projects which have been funded by NERDDC involve grants of $600,000 for heating and cooling using solar energy; $500,000 on photo-electrics, which involves obtaining energy from the sun; only $300,000 on wind energy; and only $200,000 on biomass, which is the use of rubbish and polluted materials to produce energy. These grants amount to less than $2m out of $16m; yet these are the areas on which we really ought to be concentrating in Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: About 15 years ago we were leading the world in areas of solar energy research. Fortunately, we are still doing so in some areas. I commend the University of New South Wales which is involved in one of the NERDDC projects. This project has the highest conversion efficiency rate so far achieved for silicon photo-voltaic cells. I believe that that is a real breakthrough. However, we have fallen behind in the area of solar energy research and we are now something like twenty-sixth on the world scale in terms of development and handling of solar energy and renewable energy sources.

I note also a few other holes in the NERDDC program. There does not appear to be an enormous amount of money being spent on looking at insulation and design of buildings, which are rated in the report as being only of `medium priority'. I believe that the United States of America managed to save an enormous amount of energy by research into insulating houses. What we have to do in Australia is to start looking at saving energy as a part of our program instead of just going helter skelter, using more and more energy.

The next issue I want to raise is co-generation. On a small scale, we can produce electricity in domestic environments, for example, on a farm. Currently, if we produce more than we need, we have to have expensive battery and storage systems. That is the main reason why those types of small generation plants are not used.

Is there a possibility of being able to feed back the power into the electrical system? This happens in California where firms keep their generators going in off peak time to feed the electricity from them back into the system and get paid by the electrical distribution companies for the electricity that they produce. These are areas at which we must look. I commend the report to the Senate. I believe that NERDDC is a worthwhile organisation, but its priorities should be looked at and some money should be spent in those extra areas that I have outlined.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

I remind the Senate of some advice given to the Government by the Australian Manufacturing Council when it expressed the concern of its members that the so-called economic recovery might be short lived unless accompanied by an upturn in private investment. The Council resolved to advise on the need for the maintenance of incentive to private investment. High inflation and high interest rates are certainly no incentives. In fact they are real impediments to investment. Undoubtedly the Australian Manufacturing Council believes that a vigorous manufacturing sector is vital to the Australian economy and a positive industry policy is an integral element in achieving stronger economic growth and increased employment.

While the Government claims that its specific policies are designed to maintain a manufacturing sector which is growth oriented, I believe that that is a complete falsity. Let us look at the situation today. We have high interest rates and high inflation. Our economy is now paying for our neglect of the manufacturing sector and our refusal to recognise the problems it has faced in the last few years. Unfortunately, the result of this neglect has been that many of our once thriving industries have been taken over, absorbed, wiped out or have simply become redundant. Some of the high costs that industries are facing are due to the devaluation effects of the dollar because the import component of their raw material costs is now so much higher. Manufacturers have high costs to face which include government taxes and charges. This Government bows down to the conservative unions which are concerned only with their status quo and to some big businesses which are concerned only with their interests and not with investment in the country's future.

This situation will not improve while our industries have to cope with the continuing spiral of increasing wage costs, shorter working hours, a litany of labour on-costs, higher taxes and charges, over-generous workers compensation schemes and soon-to-come very much dearer superannuation schemes. I believe that Mr Keating must face the facts that the Government's economic policies are strangling our economy. They must be changed now. Tough decisions must be made, particularly on the wages front, if we are to cure this malaise which has beset the manufacturing sector.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to speak briefly about a couple of points that arise from the annual report of the Australian Manufacturing Council. I believe that this is the first annual report of this Council which was established by the Hawke Government in 1984, replacing some of the other advisory councils and bodies that had been in existence to advise successive governments over the years prior to that.

SPEECH.PARA: At the outset I wish to congratulate John Ralph, the Chairman of the Manufacturing Council, for the work he has done in the initial period. He was a great choice as Chairman of the Council and that choice has been fully vindicated by the work that he has done. I also congratulate the other members of the Council who have come from the tripartite fields-from industry, from the union movement and from government. I also congratulate the Executive of the Council, led by Mr Tom Hogg. Before I was reincarnated as a politician about 18 months ago, I had the pleasure of being fairly closely associated with the early months of the Australian Manufacturing Council as an adviser to one of the industry members and I am delighted to see the way in which the Council has developed.

However, there are some aspects of the Council's report which cause me concern. It is no secret that we, on this side of politics, have been somewhat sceptical about the potential role of the Australian Manufacturing Council because there lie in it the very real seeds of a government body which smacks of two very worrying things. The first is the development of corporatism-the link between big government, big unions and big business. One of the defects of the Council is that it does not have on it adequate-in fact, I am not sure that it has any-representation from the small business sector. That is a matter of real concern for the Council. On the other hand, it has achieved the advantage of having some members of the trade union movement talking for the first time in their lives to members of the business community and some members of the business community who had never before talked to trade union members sitting around a table in a co-operative working sense. There is a great advantage in that. The lack of small business representation is, however, a problem. The second worrying aspect is the prospect that the Council will become more than just an advisory and consultative body and that it will lead to policy prescriptions on government which are in the interests of corporatism, as distinct from the wider interests of the community. In that context I note that the manufacturing sector is of vital importance to Australia as a whole as it has ramifications for the whole context of Australian life, but there are not representatives on the Council or the industry councils from that wider community of interest.

In its report the Council talks about the need for improved competitiveness. This is mentioned on both page 29 and page 46 and I will concentrate on that aspect in the concluding moments of my speech. Competitiveness is really what we are all about as a country. It is what we should be all about if we are to have a resurgence of the manufacturing sector which we believe is vital to this country. We must do much more than we are doing at the moment to restore our productivity and competitiveness in the domestic and international scenes. The clash today between the Government's policies and the policies of some Labor back benchers, notably Dr Theophanous, is a very worrying development. It shows that the Australian Labor Party is split over its idea of the industry policies which should be followed by this Government and is indicative of the major problem that the manufacturing sector is facing in this country because of a continuing lack of sensible economic policies by the Government in the area of inflation and cost containment.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before I call Senator Sir John Carrick I should warn him that he has only three minutes before the time for this debate expires.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I commend the work of the Australian Manufacturing Council. In the decades of the 1950s and 1960s when we had Liberal governments and full employment in Australia, manufacturing grew to provide some 28 per cent of employed persons in Australia with work and it was fundamental to full employment. Today that proportion has dropped to 16 per cent and it shows no signs of doing anything other than basically declining. Recently the Government took great credit for saying that it had created some 600,000 new jobs in the period of three years or more in which it has been in office. To put that into perspective one must remember what the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) said in his policy speech. He said that even before we find one new job we must create more than 130,000 jobs a year just to take account of population growth. All that advertising we have at the moment is a nonsense. On the Prime Minister's own figures any new jobs that have been created amount to a handful of only 100,000-perhaps slightly more.

SPEECH.PARA: The fundamental reason I rose is to say that in my judgment the argument of the Government in relation to the development of manufacturing is utterly spurious. The people of Australia cannot compete because imports are cheaper. The Government says: `We have given you the benefit of a devalued dollar; you have the extra protection of something like 30 per cent. Get behind that protection and undertake import replacement'. If we look at that the ridiculousness of the argument becomes perfectly clear. First of all the Government is asking people to borrow at record interest rates of 20 per cent or more. Secondly, however, the Government is saying to them that here is the protection but not telling them that that will be a transient protection.

Indeed, if we are to succeed in Australia the value of our dollar must rise. If the value of the dollar rises the Government is removing protection. The answer is not the devalued dollar but the answer is, as Senator Short said, an increase in productivity and a decrease in costs. If we do that we can compete overseas; we can create jobs for our own people. There is no plan by the Government at all to create jobs. I want to say that hiding behind the devalued dollar is a confidence trick. It is wrong. Manufacturing industry will be destroyed if it tries to hide behind it. We all ought to be trying to get the world to value our dollar higher. The value of the dollar is low as a result of the judgment of the rest of the world that the Australian economy is bad. The world has judged us and said that our dollar is low. What we want to do is to give the world a better opinion of our dollar so that it values our dollar higher. Every time we do that we remove protection.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Report on Telecommunications Research and Development

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 20 February, on motion by Senator Vigor:

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vigor Sen D.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —Australia's failure to invest in research and development is matched only by its failure to exploit the research and development in which we invest. We are a Third World country already through our failure to grasp the opportunities of new technology. One of the main reasons for this is the failure of government departments and statutory bodies to support Australian high technology manufacturers. How can our manufacturers market their products overseas if their products are not even endorsed by their own Government? We need a policy of affirmative action for Australian products.

SPEECH.PARA: This report of the Australian Science and Technology Council underlines the need for Telecom Australia to promote Australian manufacturing and service industries in the field of telecommunications equipment. Telecommunications is one of the fastest growing industries in the world. The world export market for telecommunications is estimated to exceed $US100 billion per annum by the year 1992. Major sectors of our economy such as finance, commerce, trade, computing services and defence, are becoming increasingly dependent on telecommunications. Yet, in 1981-82 Australian firms imported more than 98 per cent of their technical know-how-75 per cent being payments to overseas companies related to local firms, particularly those in parent-subsidiary relationships. One can only guess at the amount of price padding that may be going on in this area and the amount of tax evasion which is probably going on through transfer pricing. That is yet another way in which we are losing money through not developing our own technology and having to depend on foreign technology transfer.

Disturbingly, Australian electronics firms more than halved the proportion of their income spent on research and development in the seven years from 1976 to 1983 while overseas similar organisations are increasing their research and development to enhance their competitiveness. We are going down the drain. While most Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development countries import some proportion of their telecommunication requirements, all except Australia export almost as much as or more than they import. I seek leave to incorporate a summary of the OECD nations' trade in telecommunication products for 1980.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. I suspect that Australia's relative position has in fact worsened since this report was produced. It is amazing that with Australia's isolation from world markets and the distances between its own local centres it is content to depend on imports when its finance, commerce, trade, defence and information services are totally vulnerable to the long communication lines. We have no suitable way of maintaining our communications equipment if we do not produce it locally. It is just suicidal. As well, Australia is missing out on opportunities to gain a valuable share in world and regional export markets in the telecommunications equipment and services area. It should be noted that the figures I incorporated are for telecommunications equipment only. The situation for components is even more serious as almost all components used to manufacture telecommunications equipment in Australia are imported. I implore the Government to do something about Austrade's proposal for improving export help in our own technological industry and also to require the Overseas Telecommunications Commission, Aussat Pty Ltd and Telecom to buy Australian instead of importing technology. We have got the research capacity; we can do it. I implore all honourable senators to realise that this is one of the most important things we can do for the Australian economy.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 20 February, on motion by Senator Vigor:
That the Senate take note of the paper.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vigor Sen D.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —Half a decade has passed since the Government of Malcolm Fraser established the Australian Institute of Sport. It is now an appropriate time to review the aims and objectives of the Institute. In fact, a complete review is required. In five years the Institute has changed and grown dramatically. There has been a remarkable growth in facilities, in the number of athletes attending the Institute and in the scope, variety and depth of programs which are offered by the Institute. The Institute has also commenced to decentralise. In fact, in Brisbane we have centres for squash and diving and in Perth a centre for hockey.

SPEECH.PARA: The Australian Democrats recognise the need for a centre of elite sport in Australia. It must have greater justification, however, than just `giving young people the opportunity to compete with the world's best through the unlimited development of their competitive skills'. That is a wonderful aim. However, I believe that we have to look at the whole structure of the Australian community and let the excellence which comes from our Institute of Sport pervade the whole of our society. The Institute must become more than just a source of nationalistic pride, developing excellence for a few athletes. It must be more immediately relevant to all Australians, and some of the new advances and achievements of 1984-85 will assist in broadening that link. Research in the fields of sports science and sports medicine can benefit the whole community, because by looking at the very healthy athlete we can learn a lot about ordinary people in the community. The information facilities, library, and general assistance provided by coaches in the Institute will also be of benefit to all and not merely to the elite.

However, problems have been identified at the Australian Institute of Sport. In November last year a newspaper report led to the Price Waterhouse internal audit review which identified a number of issues. The Institute needs better systems for keeping records. It also needs to make certain that it does not go over budget. The Price Waterhouse internal audit review identified serious problems with staff morale. On page 23 there is this remark:

There is a considerable amount of dissatisfaction amongst staff and some are highly critical of the financial management of the Institute. Some of the criticism arises from the lack of understanding, but some is undoubtedly valid.

There is concern that the Minister for Sport, Recreation and Tourism (Mr John Brown) in his parliamentary statement made no mention of the morale issue. The staff must remain dedicated for the Australian Institute of Sport to improve and maintain its high standards. It must not be allowed to remain dissatisfied or critical, otherwise standards will slip and it will lose the single-minded dedication necessary for success in international sport. Many countries spend an enormous amount on sport, particularly countries behind the Iron Curtain. We have to compete with them in sporting events and we put our national pride on the line. A spirit of dissatisfaction in our centre of sports training can only engender an atmosphere in which it is difficult to seek excellence.

Mr John Brown in his parliamentary statement identified two positive steps, both overdue, that would improve the Institute's morale. The first is changing the Institute to a statutory authority better able to cope with a growth in different objectives, plus the increased responsibility which would come from a decentralised structure. The second is a review of the basic structure of the Institute, which should be conducted jointly with the Department of Finance. This review should aim to increase the efficiency of the larger institute. I am advised that those steps are being under taken. The joint review will build up the internal audit review and satisfy those who are disgruntled and feel dissatisfied. It is disappointing though that the opportunity provided to review properly the basis and objectives of the Institute during the restructuring is not being used. It is important that the Institute should be recognised for what it is-a real resource in Australia for the development of sports medicine and for sporting excellence. I commend the report to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —There has been a lot of criticism recently of the level of Australian international sporting achievement. To a very large extent I think this criticism is unjustified. I believe, for instance, that swimmers such as Jon Sieben and athletes such as Darren Clarke are in no way lesser world champions than Dawn Fraser, Murray Rose, Herb Elliott or Marjorie Jackson. What has been occurring, I believe, has not been an absolute decline in the level of Australian sporting achievement but rather a very considerable increase in the level of resources devoted to the promotion of sport and to the achievement of international success in sport by a number of other countries. It is interesting to note that in the October-November 1984 edition of the ANZAAS Journal Search there was a paper by Graeme Caughley of the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation entitled `Determinants of Olympic Performance', in which he indicated quite clearly that a comparison of the performance of the top 25 countries at the 1984 Olympics indicated that medal score was tied closely to a country's gross domestic product rather than to the particular institutional arrangements it put in place.

SPEECH.PARA: The report of the Australian Institute of Sport gives us an opportunity to focus on a couple of issues. The first of these, in line with what I was just saying about the level of Australia's international performance, is that outstanding athletes of Australian origin usually have to make their mark on the international competitive stage outside Australia. One thinks in particular of the great current success of Phil Andersen as a cyclist. My attention was particularly focused upon this by an article in yesterday's Sydney Daily Telegraph in which the national cycling coach, Charlie Walsh, launched into a very bitter criticism of the Minister for Sport, Recreation and Tourism, Mr Brown, for failing to honour his promise to include cycling as one of the sports catered for by the Australian Institute of Sport.

TALK.START.PARA: —Particularly in relation to Tasmania.

—As my colleague says, particularly in relation to Tasmania. There is no doubt that sport plays an important part in the life of this country, perhaps more in some respects than in the life of many comparable countries. I know, for instance, the enormous pride I had in going as a spectator to the last Olympic Games in Los Angeles and seeing Werner Birnbaum in particular performing in the gymnastics, one of the most internationally competitive sports one can imagine, and bringing great credit to his country and pride to myself and my wife. I have gone along to watch the Australian men's field hockey team-an outstanding performance. My only complaint about that was that I went to see the match against the United States in which we beat the United States, but the rotten Americans confiscated my flag on the way into the ground on the basis that there had been a punch-up between the Indian and Pakistani spectators the day before and they had some suspicion, I think, that the performance was about to be repeated. Nevertheless, there was great joy in watching us thrash the Americans.

SPEECH.PARA: The Institute itself was established as an initiative of the Fraser Government and in particular an initiative of the then responsible Minister, Mr Ellicott. Indeed, it was yet another initiative, very typical of the initiatives taken by Mr Ellicott and by the Fraser Government in fields such as sport, the arts, recreation and environment protection. Many of the things for which this current Government seeks to claim as its own successes in fact are based entirely upon Fraser Government initiatives.

The Institute certainly has been subject to a great deal of criticism, some of it, I think, not altogether justified. Despite the problems, Dr Cheffers has been attempting to grapple with many of the difficulties. I know, for instance, that an article which appeared in the National Times edition of 17 January criticised the Institute for its failure to help certain junior athletes and brought to attention the outstanding junior athlete Peter Mapstone. The Institute replied to that criticism, although I do not recall seeing its reply actually printed in the National Times. Therefore, I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a copy of the Institute's reply to that article.
Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
To the Editor-The National Times
From Tony Rice-Co-ordinating Coach Track and Field-AIS
Letters to the Editor: Re Jeff Wells' article
`CHAMPIONS NEED HELP TOO' 17.1.86
Dear Sir

When is a critic too critical and when has a critic not done his homework? Jeff Wells, in writing on the problem faced by any talented junior athletes in this country, and in particular, Peter Mapstone, was not entirely accurate.

Mr Wells made no attempt to contact the AIS to see if firstly we had heard of Peter and, secondly, to enquire if we were interested in helping him. If Mr Wells had done either of these things, he would have found `yes' the answer to both.
I have been well aware of Peter Mapstone's emerging talent since he was 14, both through my position as NSW coaching director and more recently as co-ordinating coach at the AIS.

I met Peter again, at the Australian schools cham- pionship in Perth during December where, after I had congratulated him on his fine performances at the meet, we discussed his progress and his future.

Then, on January 3rd, I received a phone call from Mr Ray Durie, President of NSWAAA informing me that Peter (or more particularly his mother) had been enquiring about the possibility of AIS scholarships. The relevant information on scholarships was sent to Peter on that day.

I should point out however, that AIS track and field residential scholarships are not awarded to high school students. It has been found that youngsters at this stage of their education are not able to cope with both the time required for school certificate and higher school certificate study as well as the high intensity training at the Institute.
So, far from ignoring up and coming Australian talent, the State coaching directors and AIS will continue to monitor Peter Mapstone's and similarly talented juniors, progress.

The resources available to sport in Australia are not unlimited. The support given by families such as the Mapstones to their talented youngsters will continue to play a vital part in developing Australian sporting excellence. Meanwhile, the Australian Institute of Sport will maintain its program of supporting and developing as many of Australia's post-school-age athletes as possible.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Institute has and continues to have the support of the Opposition parties. We believe that it does a particularly valuable and important job. We believe that there is a place in Australia for the promotion of centres of excellence in sport, just as there are centres of excellence in arts and in culture and in education generally.

SPEECH.PARA: I believe that once the Institute has come to grips with the problems identified in the Price Waterhouse report and in some of its own internal reviews it will be able to get on with the significant job of assisting that part of the Australian community which focuses its non-professional activities on sport and assisting those who make a profession of sport. I commend the report to the Senate.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 20 February, on motion by Senator Sir John Carrick:
That the Senate take note of the paper.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The paper before the Senate is really an exchange of papers between the British and Australian governments in order to set up a technical assessment group arising out of the Maralinga Royal Commission. The assessment group has been agreed to without any prejudice at all and without any admission of liability by the British Government, and rightly so. The report of the Royal Commission into British Nuclear Tests in Australia has done great harm to the whole concept of royal commissions. It is and must be an embarrassment to the present Federal Government, to the people of Australia and, indeed, to anyone who believes that a royal commission ought to report in objectivity and depth. It is, in fact, a report without merit. It is conceived in hate, in political bias and in anglophobia. It is written in a rhetoric which ought to disgust any reasonable person. It does nothing. The fact that we have to have a technical assessment group to find out what the problems are in Maralinga is the very condemnation of the Royal Commission itself, absolute condemnation of it.

SPEECH.PARA: The Royal Commission could not find anything. It did not know the magnitude of the problem at all. It was long on rhetoric and short on facts. It was a royal commission that did not even try to test the wildlife on Maralinga, Emu or Monte Bello. It wanted to be able to say that there must be lethal radiation and yet it had wildlife, ground eating animals such as hares, rabbits, dingoes and all the reptiles on Maralinga and Emu and the whole of the turtle and reptilian ecology on Monte Bello. It rejected the chance to test the ground eating and ground breathing animals to see what particulate plutonium or radiation would do, just in case there was any doubt about it.

I asked the relevant Minister repeatedly in this Parliament whether the Royal Commission was going to do so and whether the Government asked it to do so. How could anyone come down on any judgment on what was damaging by way of radioactivity without, in fact, testing it? But the Royal Commission did not test it at all.

It had an epidemiological report which I had set up as Minister. By clear instruction-all honourable senators would have heard me say it to the people of Australia-we wanted to find out whether any person, in the 15,364 people who had been there, had claimed that he had been hurt in any way. We offered medical tests and the facilities of the Commonwealth Employees Compensation Tribunal. We asked these people to come forward. We located 8,018, sent out questionnaires and contacted them a number of times. We located 1,560 death certificates. No investigation has been carried out in so much depth. I said: `Find out whether anyone has been hurt at all and let us have it'. The study which was carried out by the Department of Health could not find any atypical circumstances at all. The result for the population that was working there was the same as the result for a control group outside. That is good for Australia. At least we tried; at least we tested on animals and we sought information from people. We cleaned up areas, whereas the Whitlam Government did nothing and said nothing during its time in office.

What a terrible indictment it is that a Labor Government had the chance during the Whitlam Government's three years to hold an inquiry when people who took part in it were alive-when Sir Howard Beale, the responsible Minister, was alive, when Sir Robert Menzies was alive and when members such as Sir Leslie Martin and others were capable of taking part. The Whitlam Government did not do it then. The Labor Party waited until these people had died so that they could inveigh against their characters, so that there was no response at all. I know nothing more ugly than a pretence of judicial inquiry which inveighs against dead men, which puts its political hates and vituperations on paper and produces something that says nothing at all and now has to have a technical assessment group to find the nature of the radiation in Maralinga, Emu and Monte Bello. This was the purpose for which the Royal Commission was set up. I believe this report has done more damage to the concept of royal commissions than any other matter. I regret that very much. It is a shameful thing for Australia and, indeed, to our image abroad.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kilgariff Sen B.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to speak briefly to the report of the Royal Commission into British Nuclear Tests in Australia and the technical assessment group. As the previous speaker, Senator Sir John Carrick, has said, it has been rather an amazing series of events which has culminated not only in the report of the Royal Commission but also the statements made in the report and the attacks on the various individuals in Australia, who have little chance to stand up for themselves. There has been a wave of concern around Australia. A while ago there was a letter in the Australian dated Friday, 13 December 1985. I will name the writer later, but I believe I can do no better than read this letter to the Senate. I believe it clearly outlines the situation. The letter was headed `Too much venom, victimisation'. It stated:

SPEECH.PARA: Sir-If the Australian Labor Party had genuinely sought to probe the facts of the British atomic tests on Australian soil, it should have done so at a time when the main public participants were still alive-the then Prime Minister, Sir Robert Menzies, the responsible Minister, Sir Howard Beale, and the members of the Atomic Weapons Tests Safety Committee.

But in the relevant years 1973-75 the Whitlam Labor Government was totally inert on the subject. It made no probe. It initiated no health study of those servicemen and civilians who worked at the site. It took no active interest in their health or their possibly valid claims for compensation. It undertook no major clean-up of the test sites. These matters were left for the Fraser Government to do.
The character and purposes of royal commissions are demeaned when assertions are made without the possibility of rebuttal and when political acerbity and anglophobia are substituted for objectivity.

A stark insight into the subjective mental processes of the commission's chairman is revealed by this statement: `I used to see her (Mrs Thatcher, the British Prime Minister) on those cold winter nights looking at British television and formed such a loathing for her that it got out of control.''

What an amazing statement by a chairman of a commission. One can only agree with that statement he made, that it got out of control. What a dreadful thing. It is a complete disgrace. The letter continues:

The report's venom and victimisation of the distinguished Australian scientist, Sir Ernest Titterton, are further examples of bias. Only Sir Ernest remains of the members of the Safety Committee so he, however articulate, is very vulnerable.
The commission made no tests on the abundant animal life at the Monte Bellos, Emu or Maralinga to determine the existing effects of radiation.

It could find no evidence that the health of those 15,364 Australians who worked at the site was affected. A thorough epidemiological study by the Fraser Government had already reached that conclusion.
The commission was unable, in its absence of knowledge to make precise recommendations as to the nature of the future clean-up required.

The Fraser Government, in a meticulous two-year investigation, had located 8018 surviving Australian participants and a further 1560 death certificates, representing 62 per cent of all. The medical records locations of individuals in relation to test sites and dosimeters (radiation detectors) of all participants were examined.

All survivors located were offered a medical check-up and facilities of the Commonwealth Employment Compensation Commission. The matter was widely advertised throughout Australia with the aim of reaching every person involved.
What use are recriminations 30 years after the events and when the `key' decision-making figures are dead? Why, then, the royal commission at this time, except for partisan political purposes?

I have great pleasure in indicating that the writer of that letter was Senator Sir John Carrick, a senator here tonight. I, like very many others, am concerned. I have on notice within this Senate a series of questions relating to this particular incident and the nuclear blast. I ask the Government to take note of those questions on notice, because not only I, but all Australians, need the answers.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cooney Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —Clearly this paper gives rise to issues that ought to be debated at fuller length than can be done presently. The statements of Senator Sir John Carrick-a very honourable senator of this place-were made, perhaps understandably, in an emotional context. Against that it has to be remembered, firstly, that this report must be looked at in its entirety. Secondly, when criticising any report-although it is reasonable to extrapolate from that report passages which may indicate evidence for a particular line of argument or proposition-overall it is a matter of looking at the whole report to see what useful matter arises from it. An attack has been made on the Commissioner of the Royal Commission into British Nuclear Tests in Australia. The Commissioner is a man who has served in this place and as a judicial officer in New South Wales. The criticism has been made in very robust terms by Senator Sir John Carrick and Senator Kilgariff. On the other hand, a balance must be struck and I simply want to do that in these short moments.

SPEECH.PARA: The fact is that proceedings have been taken by people arising out of alleged injuries that occurred as result of British atomic tests in Australia. It was proper that research into this issue be undertaken. Whether or not it should have been undertaken earlier is a matter for debate. Clearly, the earlier investigations are made, the better the results are likely to be. I simply rise to throw into the balance in favour of the Commissioner and in favour of the report the good that has come from it. The evidence has been attacked. Nevertheless, the evidence has been brought forward and the propositions have been put and recommendations have been made by the Commissioner.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Consideration resumed from 11 March, on motion by Senator Sheil:
That the Senate take note of the paper.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: AUSTRALIAN NATIONAL PARKS AND WILDLIFE SERVICE

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed for 12 March, on motion by Senator Puplick:
That the Senate take note of the paper.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —The 1984-85 report of the Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service is, in my estimation, one of the most valuable reports to have come forward from any of the wildlife, conservation and environment authorities responsible to any Federal Minister. It is an excellent report and the Director of the Service, Professor Ovington, and his officers are to be highly commended on the very useful material, both in quality and amount, which is provided in the report.

SPEECH.PARA: The report draws attention to a number of matters which are of great significance in the wildlife and conservation debate in Australia at the moment. For instance, it launches fairly boldly into the question of the kangaroo monitoring unit. I have great faith in the kangaroo population figures which are produced by the Parks and Wildlife Service and I am perfectly happy for them to be used as the basis for the establishment of quotas. I make it clear that I believe an effective management program which includes the use of culling and quotas is absolutely imperative, not only for the land use policies of Australia but also for the kangaroo population itself. Encouraging news is given of the discovery of species previously believed to be extinct, such as the Christmas Island shrew. Indeed, specific management programs, such as we have seen in the restoration of the position of the Norfolk Island wood hen, are of great significance.

The report deals with the export of koalas. The report provided by Professor Ovington on his return from Japan, dealing with the death of two koalas in Japanese zoos-an excellent report which I have had the pleasure of reading with some considerable care-encourages me to believe that the steps since taken are such that the strictly controlled and limited export of koalas to zoos of international significance should be resumed. There is a great deal of work to be done in looking at the disease problems of koalas and in particular the current problem as a result of chalamydia psittaci. I believe it is worth putting on record that the donation of up to $200,000 by American Express International Inc. towards this research program is something which ought to be recognised.

A number of matters raised in the report are of concern. In the Ashmore Reef National Park area there continues to be a degree of penetration by unauthorised Indonesian vessels and I believe that the Service is lacking in the resources it needs to have so it can effectively monitor and control activities in that national park area. The indication of the seizures made under the Wildlife Protection (Regulation of Exports and Imports) Act is very important. I would have spent some time dealing with this matter, except that a Bill was introduced yesterday into the House of Representatives making amendments to that Act. Therefore, the Senate will shortly have the opportunity for a more prolonged debate on the operation of the legislation. It highlights once again the significance which attaches to the illegal trade in Australian flora and fauna and to the penetration of organised crime into the smuggling operations. When that legislation comes before us we will be able to deal with that in more detail. This report simply indicates that between May and December 1984 seizures of 365 items were made under the legislation and that the attempted export of Australian native birds is a matter of continuing concern.

The report updates the situation on whaling. Again I pay tribute to Professor Ovington and his officers for the way in which, through the International Whaling Commission, they have had further success in limiting the future whaling activities of the Japanese and the Soviets. As I said, this is an excellent report. Some legislation will be forthcoming which will give us a chance to debate part of the Government's wildlife policies. On the matters I have raised, I believe that the report is indicative of the fact that the National Parks and Wildlife Service is discharging its responsibilities properly and adequately and to the great credit of all concerned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collard Sen S.J.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLARD
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I too, like my colleague Senator Puplick, commend the Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service on its report and the role it is playing in our national parks. We could almost say that national parks in this nation are the sacred sites of the white man. If one were in any doubt about that, one would have had only to follow the news in the past few days. It is good that we have national parks, most of which are managed at the State level, and that people are taking greater notice of them and making greater use of them.

SPEECH.PARA: It is also good that there is that necessary co-operation at both the Federal and State levels between the relevant Ministers for the management and utilisation of our various national parks.

Page 8 of the report refers to the Kakadu National Park. My view is that that park should not be so much under the control of a Federal body but rather should be controlled on a co-operative basis-as is the case with the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park-with the Northern Territory authorities having responsibility for the day to day management. On a brief visit to Kakadu National Park I talked with the rangers. They are using fire as an important part of their park management and operation. Quite significantly, they are trying to use it in the manner in which Aborigines used it for thousands of years. I think we are learning from the Aborigines something about husbanding our national resources, not only in Kakadu, of course, but across the nation. Fire was used by Aborigines ostensibly, I suppose, either to flush out game or to promote a green pick, as we would say, to encourage game. In doing so, albeit probably not knowingly, they were providing a very useful environmental management tool. I find it quite ironic that at Cooktown, for instance, one sees a sign which points to Grassy Hill. It was named Grassy Hill by Captain Cook when the Endeavour was brought in for repair after striking a reef. Captain Cook went up there every day to use his telescope to try to find a way through the reef for the Endeavour when it was refloated. Grassy Hill is no longer a grassy hill. There is a lot of stunted growth and rubbish, purely and simply because since the Aborigines have left the area husbanding by fire has not been carried out.

One other matter I bring to the attention of the Senate is the Ashmore Reef National Nature Reserve. In 1974 a memorandum of understanding with Indonesia allowed Indonesian fishermen access to those islands for both fishing and the purpose of fresh water collection. Unfortunately, that memorandum of understanding has been breached quite significantly. The fishermen are not only coming ashore for the purpose of water collection, they are also taking sea birds, turtles and their eggs, cutting down vegetation for firewood, and using the islands for camping and the drying of fish and bird carcasses. Indeed, there is a photograph in the report of an Indonesian fisherman with an estimated 2,600 tern eggs. It has been established that the lesser frigate bird and the brown booby, which are two of the largest species on the reserve, have failed to breed successfully on the islands in recent years because of poaching and disturbance. It is also noted that two other birds have attempted to breed there and that process has also been upset by the fishermen visiting the islands.

Significantly-there is also a photograph of this-in November 1984 Coastwatch aircraft reported approximately 50 rings inscribed in the sandy shallows 2.5 kilometres off-shore in the reserve. These proved to be marks left by turtles tethered by Indonesian fishermen who hoped to avoid detection. The Australian National Parks Wildlife Service has sent patrol boats to the area. Patrols by Coastwatch, the Royal Australian Navy and the Royal Australian Air Force have continued to observe the fishermen in that area. I think much more serious notice must be taken by our authorities. Indeed, it should be brought to the notice of the Indonesian authorities and action should be taken by them. I commend the Service for its report.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boswell Sen R.L.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I too would like to make a couple of remarks about the 1984-85 report of the Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service. I wish to address my remarks to the kangaroo culling industry. I have accompanied Mr Tim Richmond and his officers on two trips to the Roma, Longreach and Hughenden areas. Mr Richmond and the officers who accompanied him on the trips have been patient and understanding when they have explained their duties and their scientific evidence to the people-the graziers, the kangaroo shooters and the farmers-in the western areas of Queensland. It is pretty hard to talk to some of these people about scientific matters. They see the kangaroos eating their crops and destroying their livelihoods. They cannot understand why they are unable to get export quotas when they are actually culling under a State law and leaving the carcasses there. Mr Richmond and his officers, on the trips on which I have accompanied them around Queensland, have taken a lot of trouble to explain their scientific research and methods. I think they should be congratulated by the Senate.

SPEECH.PARA: Kangaroo culling will always be a very controversial issue. It is an issue that animal liberationists seem to be getting their teeth into at the moment. I would say there is not one grazier, not one farmer, not one person in Australia who wants to see the demise of the kangaroo population. Everyone would say that they want kangaroos, that they like them, and that they love to see them on their properties. But what the farmers and graziers are saying, particularly during droughts, is this: `Let us have a reasonable culling figure. Let us keep the kangaroos in reasonable check and let us make our living'. Of course, all sorts of red herrings are being dragged across the path of kangaroo culling. I put on record that harvesting or culling is carried out in Australia by the most humane method available at the moment. If emotional people come into the Senate and suggest that no kangaroos be culled, that kangaroos should be allowed to breed until they take over the properties, I believe some sort of limit will be imposed by the farmers and graziers. They will take matters into their own hands.

I say to the people who do not support any form of kangaroo culling: Be very careful because in the end this will lead to a method of culling which is nowhere near as humane as the way in which they are controlled at the moment. I cannot think of a more humane way of culling kangaroos or keeping them in check than by shooting in the head. In an instant, in a half second, the kangaroo is down and out. Sheep, cattle and pigs are taken to abattoirs in a truck, put down a race and the whole process takes hours in an extremely unfriendly environment. I would like people to compare that with killing a beast in its natural environment in a split second.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kilgariff Sen B.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to speak very briefly on the 1984-85 annual report of the Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service. This very involved and good report deals with many of the activities in which the ANPWS is engaged. I believe that some parts of the report are extremely good but I take exception to other parts. I think the Service is doing very good work in respect of the International Convention for the Regulation of Whaling. I hope that three whaling nations-Japan, the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics and Norway-eventually come within the scope of the International Convention.

SPEECH.PARA: I have considerable interest in Ashmore Reef. As we know, Indonesian fishermen have been going to the reef for centuries. I believe that at times they live on the Cartier and Ashmore Islands for a considerable period. I am not too sure whether Australia has a presence in the area. However, I believe the time has come, having in mind the importance of Cartier and Ashmore Islands in the present scope of things, situated where they are, for Australia to have a continuing presence in the area. I believe the Royal Australian Navy still continues to visit the area but in my opinion this is quite insufficient.

Time does not permit me to speak in detail about Kakadu National Park and Uluru (Ayers Rock-Mount Olga) National Park in the Northern Territory. The question of whether these national parks should come under a Northern Territory authority or a Federal authority has been debated far and long and the debate will continue for quite a long time yet.
