The question, of course, is why should a Federal organisation such as the ANPWS be responsible for national parks in the Northern Territory when it is not responsible for national parks in other places. However, this matter goes much further than that. The ANPWS should be taking more notice of the Conservation Commission of the Northern Territory and that Commission should be carrying out its proper role in terms of day to day management. This is a very controversial matter because the ANPWS does not see it that way.

There are many aspects to this matter. I am disappointed, as are many people in the Northern Territory, that this matter cannot be resolved. The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and the Director of the ANPWS have said various things. However, when one looks at the matter closely one finds that what they say in public really is not correct. It is most disappointing to see that the people of the Northern Territory are being treated differently from the people of the States. The Northern Territory Conservation Commission has considerable expertise which, I believe, can be measured against that of any other organisation of its kind in Australia or, indeed, overseas. The expertise that has been gathered by this organisation as a result of the work it has done in the past and the work it is doing now is such that it is quite capable of taking over and being responsible for these national parks. Yet that is not to be. I would hope that eventually, as time goes by, a Federal government-not this one, of course, which has clearly indicated, in line with its centralist view, that the national parks will not be handed over to the Northern Territory-will bring about such a change. The report refers to many matters. However, the following statement is made in respect of one small matter:

Arrangements were made for the Mutitjulu community to make use of the buildings at the Red Sands and the Inland Motels on an interim basis until permanent facilities appropriate to the national park setting are constructed.

As I understand it, the Mutitjulu did take over the Red Sands and Inland Motels. However, I have taken up one matter with government in respect of something which seemed to be completely wrong to me. The Mutitjulu community accepted the Inland Motel and all of its facilities and it was agreed that compensation should be paid to the owners, yet not one dollar has been paid in compensation for the takeover. Maybe it is a minor matter but I believe it is one that must be resolved.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 12 March, on motion by Senator Boswell:
That the Senate take note of the paper.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brownhill Sen D.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I take this opportunity to comment on the 1984-85 annual report of the Australian Wheat Board and on the performance of the Board in what must be regarded as one of the toughest marketing periods that it has ever had. I believe that the Wheat Board has performed admirably in meeting the challenges of the current world wheat environment. It is competing with the European Economic Community as well as the highly subsidised markets of America.

SPEECH.PARA: I note from the report that 1984-85 saw shipping records of almost 15 million tonnes in a world environment of a record 521 million tonnes production. I note also that long term agreements were negotiated successfully with Egypt, our biggest customer during the period, and Iraq and Abu Dhabi in market circumstances where, as I have already said, the trend was for prompt shipment arrangements. This result has been achieved in a very oversupplied world market. We have been able to retain our position as preferred supplier to China. We have moved again into Pakistan and Sri Lanka. Also, we made our first sales to Ethiopia and inroads into South America after a lapse of 13 years. This record highlights the aggressive and successful marketing approach adopted by the Board. I think it is important that its performance be highly commended.

On the financial side, the Wheat Board is a significant borrower, having an offshore borrowing capacity to approximately $US2 billion. The Board's investment income for 1984-85 was $25.2m; so it plays a very significant role in Australian primary industry. It is therefore vital that the Board operate in a commercially viable and fully accountable manner.

I am concerned that there should be continuing grower involvement in the operations of the Wheat Board. It is for the benefit of growers that the Board exists and the industry must and should be prepared to take a responsible part in its operations. The past year has seen some changes in operations. For example, we now have domestic trade arrangements for stockfeed wheat that can be purchased direct from growers. This is a sensible approach and one that I support. New arrangements with the State grain handling authorities for storage and handling have been signed into operation. This is a weak link in the chain of wheat production in this country. It is an area to which more attention needs to be paid.

There is considerable grower resentment about the grain handling charges and freight charges. In my own State of New South Wales those charges have risen dramatically in the last year. They are not the direct responsibility of the Wheat Board but the Board has an obvious involvement and must play its part in improving this area. There is also a big difference between the price received by the Board and the price that gets through to the growers and this is causing some concern to people in the grain growing areas. It is something to which the Board must address itself. Like the rest of the farming community it also has to reduce its costs.

It is good that the Board has now opened offices in London and New York. However, it must not neglect the domestic scene. The wheat growers of Australia have suffered a disastrous season with weather damaged crops and the Board's task in selling wheat on a world market that is already flooded-if I may use that term-with similar grain will not be easy. However, I am confident that the Board, with its renewed aggressive marketing approach, will again meet with the success that it achieved in the past year. The wheat industry is vital to the Australian economy and I commend this report to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I too would like to comment briefly on the 1984-85 annual report of the Australian Wheat Board and to echo and endorse many of the comments of my colleague and friend Senator Brownhill. First of all, I think it is a very good report in terms of its production and the information that it contains. Of course, 1984-85 was a very good year for the wheat industry. At page 10 of the report some of the highlights of 1984-85 as far as the Board is concerned are set out. It is worth noting that highlights of the year included a new annual shipping record of almost 14.6 million tonnes of wheat, long term agreements renegotiated with Egypt, Iraq and Abu Dhabi, and the first sales to Pakistan since 1978-79.

SPEECH.PARA: If one looks at some of the details one sees some questions that the report raises. For example, in the accounts for the year the figure for administrative expenses under the heading `Other', the second largest item in the administrative expenses accounts, almost doubled. That is a surprising figure. There appears to be no explanation of it. It is an increase of something like $3m, so it is a significant amount. It is also recorded that staff numbers increased during the year by 48. That is an increase of almost 15 per cent at a time when labour saving techniques were coming into the Wheat Board. That also is a matter for some questioning, I think.

What I want to say mainly in these remarks is that great concern at present is being felt in most of the grain growing areas of Australia. Last week I spent two or three days in the main grain growing area of Victoria, the Wimmera and Mallee regions, where for the third time in four years the grain growing industry is experiencing a crisis which is now of unprecedented proportions. The problems facing the industry certainly in that part of Australia-and I think they are echoed in other parts of eastern Australia-are much more serious than in the catastrophic drought years of 1982 and 1983. There are very real risks of the industry collapsing in that part of Australia if significant measures are not taken to overcome the problems. The real problem is that the industry is caught in a vicious cost-price squeeze. Part of the problem, of course, arises from the easing world prices, although that effect has been diminished significantly by the devaluation of the dollar.

The real problem arises because of the increase in costs that the industry is experiencing. To outline just some of the cost increases that have occurred in the rural sector in general over the last few years, interest rates increased between 1980 and 1984 by no less than 45 per cent, government taxes and charges have gone up by 38 per cent, and electricity costs are up by 29 per cent. The really big increase, the really big cost burden for the industry, is in freight and handling charges. It is salutary to read in a recent Economic Planning Advisory Council report that over the past six years transport costs per tonne for wheat in Australia have increased by no less than 52 per cent. Our two major competitor nations are Canada and the United States. In Canada the increase has been only 37 per cent and in the United States there has been a decrease in transport costs per tonne of wheat of 18 per cent. The cost competitive situation facing the Australian industry has progressively deteriorated over recent years. For that both Federal and State governments must bear a major part of the blame.

There is an inflation squeeze in this country which is now twice the average of those of our major trading partners. It is four times the average of some of them, including Japan and West Germany. We have had a staggering increase in freight and handling charges. Fuel prices, despite the recent changes, have gone up staggeringly. There is throughout rural Australia a very grave feeling of concern that this Hawke Labor Government not only knows nothing about the real problems facing the rural sector but cares even less.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 12 March, on motion by Senator Sir John Carrick:
That the Senate take note of the paper.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —This paper, the report by the Australian Electoral Commission on informal voting in the 1984 Senate election, is a very useful contribution to the understanding of informal voting. It is, of course, the first report that could be made under the new system, called the list system, whereby it was possible for an elector simply to place a one in the top square and therefore cast a whole list of preferences. Therefore, one can test both the desire of people to choose between the two systems and the effect upon preferences. The fact is that informal voting fell significantly throughout Australia. It fell to about 7 per cent or below in various States. It is interesting that Queensland seems to have more informed voters than other States, and I acknowledge the present occupant of the chair in that regard. A measurement of the rate of informal voting for the Senate is that it is about the same level as it was in the Scullin by-election a few months ago. The equation is that it is about the level of informal voting for a lower House Federal seat. That in itself means that there does not appear to be any reason to do anything drastic or legislative. There is good reason to inform the public about the list system, particularly so that any spill-over of error into the lower House is picked up.

SPEECH.PARA: Generally speaking, I cannot comment on behalf of the Joint Select Committee on Electoral Reform of which I am a member and which will no doubt report in the future, but I want to comment in general on this whole concept of informal voting. There is a great misunderstanding about it in Australia. We keep repeating the falsity that we have compulsory voting. We are almost unique in the world in that only four or five countries have what is called compulsory voting. Almost all the democracies have voluntary voting. I believe that voluntary voting is a vital thing, but strangely enough what we have is a compulsion for people to go to the polling booth and get their names crossed off the roll and not to take the ballot paper out of the booth. They may eat it or put it in a rubbish bin; they do not have to vote. A considerable number of people obviously indicate that they do not want to vote. They do that by one of two means-either by getting a ballot paper and putting it in a bin or by casting an informal vote. There are people who have a conscientious objection to voting and it seems incredible that one would force people to do this.

There is great confusion between the principle of the right to vote, the fundamental right of everyone to vote, and the compulsion to vote. They are two quite different things and ought to be understood as two quite different things. I believe that one of the dangers we have is one about which enough is never said. By and large, in elections for both the Senate and the lower House and in Federal and State elections the decision as to which party wins is the decision of only about 2 per cent. If we force to vote people who do not want to vote, who are apathetic or who are even angry about voting and who therefore will approach it with carelessness and with no judgment, we may bring about a situation in which the result is determined by the apathetic and those who do not want to vote.
Sitting suspended from 6.30 to 8 p.m.

DEBATE.TITLE: ABORIGINAL LAND RIGHTS (NORTHERN TERRITORY) AMENDMENT BILL (No. 2) 1985

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 2 December, on motion by Senator Kilgariff:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —This evening we are debating the merits or otherwise of a private member's Bill-the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1985-introduced by Senator Kilgariff to amend the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Act. Most of us will remember the day the Party to which the honourable senator belongs took pride in introducing the principal Bill into the Senate. This Bill when introduced was heralded, and rightly, as a major piece of legislation which would benefit Aboriginals in the Northern Territory. So it is rather curious and, I suggest, somewhat a waste of the time of the Senate that we are now spending time debating a Bill whose intent is to undermine that very progressive piece of legislation that was introduced recently.

SPEECH.PARA: A number of provisions of Senator Kilgariff's Bill have been derived from the Government's preferred national land rights model which was issued in February last year. I refer, for example, to the proposals to prevent claims for crown land which has been set aside for public purposes such as stock routes and reserves, to prevent the conversion of pastoral leases held by Aborigines to inalienable freehold title, and to provide a mechanism for the Northern Territory Government to be able to access Aboriginal land for necessary public purposes. Although we do not quarrel in principle with such proposals, we have a number of very serious reservations about the form in which they have been put by Senator Kilgariff. Our Government will shortly be putting forward its own legislative proposals for dealing with these matters, and those proposals, in contrast with Senator Kilgariff's, will reflect the extensive consultations that the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Holding) and his officers have had with all interested parties-the lands councils, the Northern Territory Government, pastoral and mining interests and many others. This legislation will be drafted with the full skills of the Office of Parliamentary Counsel on the basis of well considered policy positions. Surely, therefore, the sensible course for the Senate is to set this present Bill aside and await a properly researched and drafted piece of legislation that will represent the proper balancing of interests in these matters.

One of the proposals in the Bill is to set a time limit on the lodgment of claims. Again, we have no quarrel with that in principle. The preferred model suggested a time of 10 years. Perhaps that is longer than is needed in the Territory. But the Bill before us proposes a cut off of 1 July 1986. So, were this Bill to become law, which, of course, it will not, the door would be slammed shut almost immediately. I think that simple fact in itself speaks volumes about the degree of sincerity of the Bill's supporters for the cause of Aboriginal land rights.

Our Government has a well known commitment to amend the Northern Territory Act, but unlike Senator Kilgariff, it went about its commitment in an open and proper way. Let me quote the honourable senator from his own Press release of December last on this matter. He said:
In preparing the Bill I have tried to balance the needs and aspirations of the community, but I have not yet solicited opinions from any lobby group or industry organisation.

Quite frankly it is amazing that the honourable senator asks the Senate to agree to this Bill without having asked the various parties who are likely to be affected whether they agree or not. What is even more startling is the fact that we are now asked to consider what one man wants in respect of land rights in the Northern Territory I suggest that the honourable senator should have more respect for the members of the Senate than to ask us to agree to his own perception of the way to provide for our indigenous people in the Northern Territory.

To demonstrate our Government's commitment to consultation, Mr Justice Toohey was invited to review the operations on the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Act seven years after its enactment. Mr Justice Toohey was appointed in September 1983 and his report provided the Government with a number of recommendations designed to improve the operations of the Act. The Government then invited comment on Mr Justice Toohey's review. There have been extensive consultations with interested parties, as I have already pointed out.

Further in August 1984 Dr Jon Altman was appointed to undertake a review of the role, structure and functions of the Aboriginal benefit trust account. Aboriginal organisations were invited to participate in that review. As a result of that review, and a further round of consultations, this Government is now taking steps to improve the operations of the Aboriginal benefit trust account.

Let me return, however, to the detailed proposals in Senator Kilgariff's Bill, and in particular those dealing with mining and exploration because they are probably the most sensitive and difficult aspects of land rights. If one listens to the mining industry, the only reason why the Northern Territory is not buzzing throughout with mining and exploration activity is the land rights Act. To put it mildly, that is an exaggeration. For many years there was a freeze on new exploration proposals. But at present the mining industry is in a world-wide depression, which inevitably impacts on mining and exploration activity in the Territory. Furthermore, Aboriginals have made it clear that they are not a group inevitably opposed to mining.

None of this is to deny that the present operation of the Act in respect of mining and exploration can be improved. Our Government's preferred national land rights model put forward proposals for mining and exploration which, applied to the Northern Territory, would require a number of significant amendments to the Act.

The Government had received strong representations from Aboriginal groups, church and community leaders, and the Australian Labor Party in the Northern Territory that the ability of Aboriginals to control mining on Aboriginal land is paramount to their cultural and spiritual survival. On this basis, we made the decision that the legislation should continue to respect the views of traditional Aboriginal landholders who have a fundamental objection to any exploration on their land; in other words, in our legislation, the basic veto right of Aboriginal land owners will be maintained. The amendments that our Government will be putting before Parliament will therefore include provisions for retaining the right to refuse an exploration proposal, while also ensuring that, where there is a willingness to negotiate, the processes of reaching decisions on arrangements for exploration and mining are not subject to unnecessary delay.

The essence of the new mining consent provisions is that Aboriginal land owners would have the right to refuse, subject, as at present, to overriding national interest provisions, an exploration proposal. They will have to decide on a proposal within a limited time. If they refuse it, that will then be the end of the matter for a five-year period. If, however, they are prepared to let the exploration proposal proceed, there could be no later exercise of the veto. This provision will help ensure that the veto is not used as a bargaining device at the development stage but to protect those Aboriginal landowners who fear that exploration and any subsequent mining would interfere unduly with their enjoyment of their lands. If there is disagreement on terms and conditions of exploration or for a subsequent mining proposal, the matter will be referred to an arbitrator who will have power to determine it. As is the case under the Act at present, limitations will not be placed on the terms and conditions which may be agreed between the parties or determined by an arbitrator.

I suggest that these proposals are a reasonable compromise. They will meet the fundamental concern of Aboriginals, while also removing much of the difficulty that the mining industry and the Northern Territory Government have with the present arrangements. Of course, the Bill before us-Senator Kilgariff's Bill-however, would deny Aboriginals the right to exercise some control over their land-a control that everyone with a real concern for Aboriginal well-being, from Mr Justice Woodward onwards, has recognised as vital. Under Senator Kilgariff's Bill the presumption is always in favour of one side-the miner. That is not a balancing of interests; that is bias. The Senate, therefore, should set this Bill aside, and await our Government's proposals.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are discussing the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1985, a private member's Bill introduced by Senator Kilgariff. It concerns the current land rights Bill in the Northern Territory. This is an appropriate time to look at this issue, given the fact that the Commonwealth Government has made a range of announcements, some of which have just been rehearsed by the Minister for Education (Senator Ryan) in her response to the Bill. I am sure that it will come as no surprise to honourable senators to hear that the Australian Democrats are opposed to Senator Kilgariff's Bill. We are also deeply concerned at the moves the Government has suggested in the Northern Territory. The basic principle that one must first consider is that which was enunciated by Mr Justice Woodward when he said:

SPEECH.PARA: Of all the questions I have had to consider, that of mineral rights has probably caused me the most difficulty and concern.
But he concluded:
I believe that to deny Aborigines the right to prevent mining on their land is to deny the reality of their land rights.
He reached this conclusion after setting out the mining industry's submission in some detail and he added:
. . . because while accepting many points made, I am unable to accept the main result contended for.

Likewise of course the most recent report which again sought to rehearse the connection between mining and land rights-that of the Seaman Aboriginal Land Inquiry in Western Australia-came to an identical conclusion: That there was in fact no other way of dealing with the issue other than providing the Aboriginal people with what Mr Seaman noted `the Aboriginal people have almost uniformly claimed-that it should be an offence to enter into their land without a permit'. Later he discussed how it was impossible to have any land rights without that veto power.

Essentially that proposition rehearsed by Mr Justice Woodward depends on some prior positions being taken in this debate. Looking back over some of the judgments made in the highest court of this land, from which upon the recent proclamation of the Australia Bill there is no other avenue of review at the High Court level, it is interesting to note some of the remarks made by those eminent judges. For example, Mr Justice Deane of the High Court said this in a judgment:

. . . two centuries on, the generally accepted view remains that the common law is ignorant of any communal native title or other legal claim of the Aboriginal clans or peoples, even to ancestral tribal lands on which they still live. If that view of the law is correct . . . the common law of this land has still not reached the stage of retreat from injustice which the laws of Illinois and Virginia had reached in 1823 when Marshall accepted that . . . the original inhabitants should be recognised as having a legal as well as just claim to retain the occupancy of their traditional lands.

That is a very clear and forthright claim that we are confronted with in Australia, that our law is so deficient that it has not even got to the stage where American law was 150 years ago with regard to the original inhabitants. Another judge in discussion on this matter pointed out that there was:
. . . a need for acceptable laws and policies to mitigate the effects of past barbarism.
Again, a quote which goes to the heart of a lot of the racist comments that are made in Australia about this issue is this:
The difference between land rights and apartheid is the difference between a home and a prison.

Those quotes from eminent justices on this issue are prior positions that must be taken before one can follow Mr Justice Woodward down the track that he has suggested. Indeed, it is a situation that we are confronted with in terms of Senator Kilgariff's Bill in that it moves much further than the Australian Labor Party has done in recent weeks. However, I am not at all sure that the end result of Senator Kilgariff's Bill would not be almost identical to that of the Government's recent announcement.

I wish to read into the record the position of the main Aboriginal group in the Northern Territory, the Federation of Land Councils, in terms of its concern about the current stance of the Government and the current debate, part of which is occasioned by Senator Kilgariff's Bill and part of which is occasioned by the Government's recent announcement. The Federation says:

We are concerned that there is a move to weaken the Labor Party platform and in particular to make amendments to those sections dealing with the undertaking to grant land rights for Aboriginal people throughout Australia using the principles and recommendations of Justice Woodward; the undertaking to use Commonwealth constitutional and legal powers to ensure that the status achieved the objectives of granting land rights in accordance with the Woodward principles; the undertaking that Aboriginal and Islander people shall have the right to refuse mining and development upon their land and to impose conditions upon which any mining and other development may take place;

It is this last point that a number of items in Senator Kilgariff's Bill would directly oppose. Yet, as we have seen, the Woodward principles make very clear that without that right we are not talking about land rights in any shape or form. The Federation continues:

. . . the guarantee of mining royalties' equivalents to Aboriginal people for their use and to be administered by them. Aboriginal people, our organisations and representatives are appalled at the prospect of returning Aboriginal affairs to the disastrous situation that led up to the 1967 referendum.
Up until then years of colonial and then State government policies had decimated and all but destroyed Aboriginal people.

I think it is interesting that Senator Kilgariff has introduced into this chamber a Bill which deals with the Northern Territory because this chamber still has control over that land rights legislation. Indeed, the Commonwealth in the exercise of its powers should have that kind of control over land rights legislation throughout Australia because that was the import of the successful referendum carried in 1967-to provide the Commonwealth Government with those powers and subsequently with the responsibility.

Yet this Government has decided, because it is not acceptable, that it should back away from its solid commitment in this area. I wish to quote from an article published in 1979 by Senator Chaney, the present Leader of the Opposition in this place. He was commenting directly on Aboriginal land rights. In that article he said:

The concern about inequality in favour of Aboriginals is often used by those who are opposed to land rights and other Aboriginal programs. One would pay more heed to the argument if it were not so selective. Few of those who advance it are prominent in demanding equality in circumstances where Aboriginals are clearly in a position of extreme disadvantage. It is only when Government introduces some advantage for Aboriginals which is meant to overcome some of the disadvantages that there is a sudden concern for equal treatment. I would have to say that I am not impressed by the selective indignation.
I think those statements by Senator Chaney in 1979 were very clear and correct. I hope he still stands by those statements today.

I suggest that that leads one to the inevitable conclusion reached by every major inquiry in this area in Australia. That is, one confronts directly the moral problem. The moral problem is this: Possession of land anywhere in Australia either comes from prior ownership or successful acquisition in a voluntary manner. When we talk about having land rights as white Australians, if I may use that term, we talk about the right to keep our land, not to have it stolen from us, not to have it traded away from us. It is only by holding to that moral understanding of what grants us the right to our own property that we can understand the moral basis for the claims the Aboriginals have.

The legal situation in Australia is quite different. When the flag was raised in 1788 and this country was claimed in the name of the King of England Aborigines as far away as Arnhem Land were transformed into subjects of the British Crown. Indeed, the legal fiction has to go even further. Since it says that this land was vacant, it is obvious that the only way the Aboriginal people could get here was by invading British territory. So the absurd legal situation is that the Aboriginal people of Australia invaded white Australia. We live with that legal position. We live with that to the present day. Is it any wonder that the Aboriginal people-those people who owned this land and who in many parts of Australia have always lived on that land; there are many parts of Australia in which that occurs-still do not have title to that land? In my own State we have the situation where the Premier has gone to some of the islands in the Torres Strait and given title to the people there. The effrontery of the exercise of giving land back to people who have never relinquished their land, who have lived on it for centuries, ought to strike anybody as obscene. Yet that is precisely the sort of thing that is going on in this country today.

It is only if we recognise the morality of the claim that we can then confront the problem. I suggest that Senator Kilgariff's Bill and the rehearsal of the Government's position just made by Senator Ryan both fail to meet that central problem. When the Liberal-National Party Government in 1976 passed the land rights legislation to which Senator Kilgariff's Bill is an amendment, it proudly proclaimed its faith that what it was doing it was doing in terms of the morality of the issue and that it was setting right an historical wrong. Let us not believe that by that one action we could do that. The problem still exists. Until it is settled on an Australia-wide basis, quite frankly there is no way it will be settled. It cannot be confronted simply in the Northern Territory, it has to be confronted fairly and squarely by all the Australian people. It seems very odd that in moving to the bicentennial celebrations of white Australia we should now come to the point of denying so forcefully the aspirations of the original inhabitants of this land.

As I said some time ago in a debate, it is not fair, it is not just, to say to the Aboriginal people of Australia: `Forget about it. It is in the past'. We do not say that about any other people who have suffered the same sort of holocaust the Aboriginal people have suffered. We do not say that to our soldiers who fought for this land in two world wars and in subsequent engagements. Why then do we say it to those Aboriginal people whose parents, grandparents and great-grandparents have fought and died for their own land? I believe that that too is an obscene statement to make. I have met Aboriginal people-I am sure Senator Kilgariff has also in his close association with Aboriginal people-who have seen their own parents killed in this country. It is something that many white Australians refuse to accept about our history, but it is true. I challenge any honourable senator in this place to face one of those Aboriginal people who has seen his parents shot in what was euphemistically called a boong hunt, to face those Aboriginal people who have seen their parents butchered in that way, and say to them: `Forget about it'. If we had been in a similar situation-we could have been if the invasion of Australia had been successful in the last world war-I am quite sure that those of us who had parents fighting in that war would still be maintaining our right to this land. We would not simply be saying: `Fine, we will forget about it because it is something in the past'.

I urge honourable senators at least to empathise with the original inhabitants of this land, to try to understand their anguish and their agony; at least to find it in their hearts to say that at some stage we must have the guts to do something about it, because ultimately the so-called Aboriginal problem of Australia is not an Aboriginal problem at all, it is a white problem.
Debate (on motion by Senator Kilgariff) adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: ADMINISTRATION OF THE AUSTRALIAN CAPITAL TERRITORY

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lewis Sen A.W.R

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate draws attention to the Federal Government's maladministration of the Australian Capital Territory (ACT) and-
(a) condemns the Federal Government for:

(i) its failure to consult the people of the ACT in its deliberations on the system of machinery of self-government of the ACT, whether by utilisation of members of the current ACT House of Assembly or by any other means,
(ii) its repeated demonstrations that militant industrial action will succeed ahead of moderation thereby encouraging widespread militant industrial disputation in the ACT,
(iii) its precipitate disbanding of the Capital Territory Health Commission at a time of crisis and before properly determining the nature of the bureaucracy that the new authority would inherit,

(iv) its failure to ensure that the National Capital Development Commission planning is sensitive to the needs and desires of the people of the ACT and failure to provide the Commission with adequate direction to ensure that proper consideration is given to community representations,
(v) its disgraceful administration of the ACT Housing Loans Scheme,
(vi) its failure to provide adequate and stable hospital services and to reduce the delays for patients awaiting surgery and casualty treatment,
(vii) its failure adequately to assess and meet the needs of the frail aged in need of nursing home accommodation,
(viii) allowing the ACT Trades and Labour Council to dictate what secondary schools will be built and where,
(ix) its failure to provide adequate long term parking in the Civic area,
(x) its failure adequately to fund the ACT Schools Authority,
(xi) its failure to rectify the potentially dangerous underground petrol pollution in the Civic area,
(xii) its failure to provide adequate mental health facilities in the ACT,
(xiii) its failure to replace obsolete or worn out vehicles and equipment in both the ACT section of the Australian Federal Police and the ACT Fire Brigade,
(xiv) its failure to encourage private enterprise to provide low cost housing for rental to the homeless and low income families, and
(xv) its failure to resolve with the New South Wales Government the problems of parole and remission of ACT prisoners; and
(b) calls on the Federal Government to:
(i) provide adequate machinery for the rapid resolution of industrial disputation in the ACT,
(ii) provide financial impact statements on all proposed changes in administrative or other Government arrangements affecting the ACT before implementation so that there may be informed debate, and

(iii) encourage greater non-Government participation in Canberra development projects by clear demonstration that such investment is welcome and does not have to overcome favoured treatment to semi-Government authorities.

My notice of motion asks that the Senate draws attention to the Federal Government's maladministration of the Australian Capital Territory. It then condemns the Federal Government in 15 listed items of failure in regard to the administration of the Australian Capital Territory. I add that when I listed those 15 items I overlooked one, and I refer to the Government's failure to appoint an Ombudsman. The notice calls on the Federal Government to do certain things which may have some corrective possibilities.

It is very interesting that shortly after I gave that notice of motion the Minister for Territories (Mr Scholes) responded by denying many of the particulars of the notice. Notwithstanding his denial I felt that my notice of motion was, in fact, verified by the Canberra Times of the day after I gave the notice of motion, because as I picked up the Canberra Times on that day I discovered on the front page the heading `Doctors close waiting lists' and `Nurses' pay ``in chaos'' '. Both related to the Australian Capital Territory. There were a number of other stories, including the failure to replace the Commonwealth Ombudsman. All of those stories, as I say, confirmed in my mind the notice of motion which I had given.

One of the accusations which the Minister made in response to the notice was that I was proposing substantial increases in expenditure. May I say that, on the contrary, I do not propose any substantial increases in expenditure. What I am proposing is very well summarised in a letter written by Dr Frank Long to another doctor in the Australian Capital Territory in which he passes on some thoughts which might be given to me in relation to the health problems of the Australian Capital Territory. In that letter he said:
There really is quite a lot of money going into health in the ACT, but it is being misdirected and misused.

He then gave a number of examples where money is being taken away from hospitals, when it is in the hospitals, as he said, that the sick people are treated, and he gave examples of how it is being frittered away on a lot of trendy health initiatives. For example, there are three trained nurses in the Australian Capital Territory, working 68 hours a week, operating a salt advisory clinic, so that when people ring up they may be advised on how they can go on a low salt diet. Those three trained nurses are providing this service to the people of the Australian Capital Territory while people who are in dire need of major surgery are unable to get into the hospitals because of a shortage of nurses. That is why I say I am not proposing substantial increases in expenditure-I am complaining about the maladministration of the Australian Capital Territory. I seek leave to have incorporated in Hansard the letter from Dr Long dated 7 March 1982. It is addressed to Dr V. M. Goldrick and attached to it is an unpublished article of his entitled `Can there be health with Medicare?'.
Leave granted.
The documents read as follows-
7th March, 1986.
Dr Veronica M. Goldrick,
73 Wilkins Street,
Mawson, ACT 2607
Dear Veronica,

You asked me if I could set out some thoughts for you to pass on to Senator Austin Lewis and I will be pleased to do so. In the short time I cannot really carefully revise this document to make it as succinct and useful as I would wish but it will have to go to you as I indicate it.

In summary one can say that the ACT Public Health system is run down, there has been a reduction in services, a loss of expert personnel and a demoralisation of the nursing services. The effects of this are already a little noticeable but obviously it will take about five years for the full disastrous effect to become obvious.

There really is quite a lot of money going into health in the ACT but it is being misdirected and misused. The previous administration responded to political and pressure group coercion to take money away from the hospitals, where after all the sick people are treated, and fritter it away on a lot of `trendy' health initiatives. Examples of this would be the Health Centres. Senator Reid has already incorporated into Hansard in the last couple of years figures showing that the work output of the salaried general practitioner was so low as to be a laughing stock. The STD Clinic is burgeoning with a continual increase in staff and the Drug and Alcohol Dependant unit is doing the same. There is no doubt that these are significant problems in the community but it is typical of the state of Australia that money is being wasted in these ways on people who, in general, are unlikely to be cured and not available for the good, normal solid citizens who need to be treated so that they can carry on leading useful and productive lives.

The push for wasteful initiatives has not altered as I noticed at the moment there is pressure for a Women's Health Centre and a Youth Centre. It is not necessary for me to stress what will be the main interest of the Women's Health Centre and it is ridiculous to suggest that youth who really have genuine illnesses will not go to see normal medical practitioners.
The major Public Health menaces-tobacco, alcohol and obesity-can only be controlled by broad education by the media and individual or group counselling methods are not cost effective.

The situation with the nurses is very unsatisfactory; there are wards where nurses are very busy but there are also nurses in the system doing jobs which are unnecessary. There are two trained nurses and a nursing aide operating the Outpatient clinics at Woden Valley Hospital and I doubt that that number of staff are necessary. I also understand that there are some trained nurses operating a Salt Advisory Clinic so that when people ring up they may tell them how they may go on a low salt diet. One would imagine that a printed form would be adequate for this purpose. I do not know the proportion but whenever I go to a ward now I find that there always seem to be some relieving and casual staff there. The solution to the nursing problem does require better pay but perhaps more important it requires that the career structure should be such that nurses who are in charge of wards are adequately rewarded. At the present moment the only way that a nurse can receive a greater pay and promotion is to give up caring for patients and to become a supervisor and it would be very much better if the good nurses could be kept in the wards and their pay could be raised appropriately.

As an example of the current situation I was told that there would be only ten elective operations in the six theatres in the Royal Canberra Hospital either in the week I am dictating this letter or in the next week.

Canberra depends upon having good doctors. The doctors, and especially the surgeons and anaesthetists, are frequently the meat in the sandwich between members of the Authority's staff engaged in disputation and the Authority itself. When the nurses go on strike it probably makes very little difference to the income of the other people working in the hospital but whoever is on strike the doctors cannot work. This has the effect of decreasing their interest in the hospital and causing them to look elsewhere in the hope that they can practise medicine as they would wish. In the long run it is also very serious if the surgeons do not have sufficient work to do to keep them in good practise. The way things are going all the people with the get-up-and-go will get up and go, leave the public hospitals and find some way to operate in private. I believe that this would be a major problem as the ideal arrangement is to have an efficient public hospital system catering for anyone who wishes to enter and offering the very best possible service.

As regards the solutions the first is that the central organisation of the Health Authority is much too big. Since that is where the money comes in any needs of that organisation are attended to before the money goes anywhere. Although it is too late to change it now it is also a disaster that the two hospitals should have a single administration. It was suggested that this could be done to prevent competition but that could have been done by the overall manager of the Authority. Hospitals are very complex organisations which really do depend upon an esprit de corps and it will not be possible to achieve this under the recently introduced arrangements. Many of the people working in the Central Authority have had no contact with hospitals and no understanding of what is required. It is also a sad fact that many of them have a strongly anti-doctor attitude, probably because of their political views. If there should be any doubt about that I could make available to you a legal opinion from one of the Authority's lawyers. It demonstrates an extraordinary distrust and suspicion of the medical profession.

Many of the positions in the Authority are Public Service positions and, of course, the Public Service was basically established to make decisions on policy matters. It never was, and never will be able to actually operate anything. One long range objective should be to get those who are running and working in the hospitals out of the Public Service.

Each hospital should receive a set budget and be allowed to spend it as it wishes. It should also be free of the normal Public Service restrictions that all money has to be spent in one year so that the management can actually manage and, if appropriate, accumulate money for the purchase of equipment or other useful aims.

The Histopathology Department at the Woden Valley Hospital has practically collapsed and I understand that Dr Tony Booth who has been operating the Nuclear Department in Woden Valley Hospital for at least ten years is now leaving to go into private practice.

One way which could be used to keep good people in the Public Hospital system would be to have a system of leasing space and facilities to those people who would like to use them. I am sure that Dr Booth would probably have been prepared to stay in the hospital had some arrangement been made that he could lease the space and facilities and employ his own staff and run the operation as a private practice. If this were done it would make things easier for the Authority and I am sure give the doctors in the various units a much greater sense of responsibility.

This is probably more than the Senator wishes to know and therefore I will leave it at that. I am enclosing a copy of an article which I submitted to the Canberra Times and which was not printed. Senator Lewis might also find that interesting.
Yours sincerely,
FRANK LONG
CAN THERE BE HEALTH WITH MEDICARE
by F. L. Long.

Now that the strike of nurses in the Capital Territory Health Authority's system has been settled it is very important to consider the state of our health services and look beyond the immediate symptoms to try to identify the underlying disease. In this article it is intended to discuss the present situation, how it came about and what can be done to provide good health care for the Australian population.

The first thing that must be stressed is that nurses are among the hardest working employed people in the country. Their level of pay is very much less than would be justified by the degree of responsibility which they bear, the heavy work, both physically and psychologically, which they do and the fact that they provide care 24 hours a day, seven days a week. Nurses are wonderful because, despite these difficulties, they, in general, do their work with a cheerfulness and dedication which is now rare. Basic pay rates of nurses are less than in most clerical and secretarial positions and yet they carry a work load and responsibility which would have many employees in other occupations off on sick leave for ``stress'' within two weeks. The health system needs good nurses and some way must be found to show our appreciation of them and to adequately reward them.

One of the difficulties is that, although many people have contact with their general practitioners, there is only a relatively small proportion of people who are in hospital for more than two or three days in any year and, often, in two or three decades. Most women have contact with hospital after confinement but are usually well at that time and require little actual nursing care. The effect of this is that from a political point of view the interests of the majority of voters are related to medical contacts outside hospital. This has allowed scarce financial resources to be diverted from where major illness is treated-the hospitals-to all types of ``health initiatives'' in the community which appeal to well-intentioned, enthusiastic but ignorant minorities but rarely do anything for health. Handling the major public health menaces-tobacco, alcohol and obesity-is only practical by broad education by the media and is not cost effective in the individual or group counselling situation. The previous Health Commission over the years responded to pressure group and political pressure by allowing its resources to be withdrawn from the hospitals and frittered away on a top-heavy bureaucratic structure and on projects of very much lower priority and utility.

The average person in the community therefore does not realise that relatively few people die in the community, that all serious illnesses are treated in hospital and that hospitals rely absolutely on their nursing staff.

Having pointed out how essential adequate appreciation and recompense of nurses is we have the problem of explaining how things have come to this pass. How could a group of highly dedicated, very responsible nurses, within two years of the initiation of Medicare, be marching in the streets of Canberra, accompanied by the acknowledged terrorists of the trade union movement while the helpless in the nursing homes could not be provided with proper care or meals.

When the present Government came to power it put forward a universal medical insurance scheme-Medicare. It was said that the levy would fund the scheme. This has never happened and now I note that as the scheme becomes worse and worse suggestions are being made that the levy should be raised. Labor Party policy, which of its nature tends towards centralisation and control, has for many years been anxious to bring the medical profession under its control. There are many reasons for this: the egalitarian ethos, the dislike of ``tall poppies'' and the lack of understanding of the very high level of intelligence and hard work required to even graduate in Medicine, let alone achieve specialist qualifications. I have had sons who have graduated in Law, Economics and in Science and the level of difficulty of those courses could not in any way be compared with that of the medical course.

Another strong element in the Labor Party is that the socialist principle is opposed to self-employed people. Large companies are already largely under control of the unions, the Government employs about 23% of the population, small business and farmers are disorganised and frequently struggling so that the only large group in the community which are reasonably coherent, articulate and independent are the professions. Of these, the medical profession is probably the largest and certainly the one with which the public has the most contact. Normally, people may only need a lawyer once or twice in their lives and many members of the population would never have professional contact with accountants. If the doctors can be brought under Government control it will be relatively easy to ``mop up'' the other professional groups and remove these independent obstructions to Labor Party control. Given these strong ideological motives and the fact that a large part of the population could be deceived into thinking that they can have medical care cheaply it is no wonder that the Labor Government was anxious to introduce Medicare.

When one considers the matter it is obvious that the scheme must increase the cost of medical care in Australia. Firstly, because people have to pay a small part, or none, of the cost directly out of their pockets, since the Medicare levy has been paid anyhow, there is a considerable inclination to over-use the system. In fact, there is a football team in Sydney which Mr John Brown, Minister for Sport and Tourism, calls the Sydney Medicare Team. The organised medical profession opposed the introduction of Medicare saying that abuses were inevitable, the Government took no notice and when abuses arise those who warned against them are then castigated. Bulk billing was introduced both as an idea to save money and also to enable the doctor to adjust the noose gently around their own necks so that the Government could pull it tight at any convenient time. Where the patient has no direct interest in the bill there must be an enormous scope for dishonesty. One cannot help but feel that the Government considered that the purchase of a football team or two is probably a small price to pay for dangling this bait before the medical profession with the opportunity to denigrate it generally if abuses did occur and then to introduce further controls.

Many medical consultations fall into the category of discretionary expenditure. Patients visit doctors for a great variety of reasons, many of which cannot be expected to improve their health. I think that this is perfectly appropriate as long as the person initiating the consultation is responsible for payment. However, with the type of scheme we now have all the taxpayers of the country have to pick up the tab for these discretionary consultations.

The cost must rise because there is little or no direct expense involved for the person initiating the consultation. In addition to that whatever money is spent on health must have the very considerable added bureaucratic costs of operating the scheme. When Medicare came in it was said that it would operate more cheaply but it is known that Medibank Private used to cost considerably more to operate than the private funds and it would be hard to believe that Medicare, operating in a public service milieu could be a lean, efficient and inexpensive operation.

Professor David Pennington was quoted recently as saying that Medicare was `a blank cheque.' He suggested the only way was to have a two tiered system with a basic `no frills' system available in the public hospitals and the less basic services available outside. This certainly will be the inevitable end of Medicare but it is most undesirable that nearly all the most innovative, enthusiastic and hard-working doctors and other health professionals will gradually be driven from public hospitals to the private institutions. The solution of the socialists to the suggestion of the two tiered system would be to abolish any private medicine and make sure that the entire health care of the nation was provided at the bottom level.

Coercion of the doctors may work for a time to keep the system operating but coercion cannot produce good medicine any more than it can produce good literature, good music or an efficient economy. If the doctor's loyalty is, of necessity, displaced from the patient to his political and bureaucratic masters, it will be the patient who will suffer even more than the doctor. Good medicine cannot be provided by disillusioned, disgruntled and embittered doctors.

The difficulty with our political system is that there is no time to allow evolution. Difficulties are noted and instead of them being allowed to correct themselves in a natural, evolutionary manner, some short time solution is imposed which generally ends in long term disaster. For 20 years, from about 1960, there was an under supply of doctors. This resulted in considerable expansion of medical schools and now we have reached the stage where, because of the very long lead times, there will be a considerable over-supply of doctors by 1995. If there was no interference the effect of this would be that life as a doctor would appear less attractive and the number of people going into Medicine would fall so that the problem could be corrected over the next 25 years. The foolishness of Government interference can be seen in the fact that the Medicare rebate of 85% acts as a floor under medical charges. There are certainly areas now, in the cities, where there is very considerable competition between doctors and were it not for this income support scheme initiated by Doctor Blewett PhD, medical charges might well fall below the 85% level in some areas.

What have we got from Medicare? A Medicare levy, that is an extra tax on top of our already excessive taxes, strikes by nurses in at least Victoria, New South Wales and the A.C.T., confrontation with doctors and certainly no diminution in the industrial campaigns of the Hospital Employees Federation. It was supposed to provide health care for all and what do we find? The old and helpless in the nursing homes have to have volunteers bussed up from Sydney to care for them and the rest of the population could not get into the Health Authority's hospitals in Canberra unless they had a broken leg, a heart attack or some other major catastrophe.

Medicare insists on doing everything for everyone and the result is that often it can do nothing for anyone. These problems must continue because the Government, despite its confiscatory taxation is heading for financial disaster. It is seen as an impersonal employer with control of the printing presses and everyone in the community knows that so much money is being wasted in other directions that they feel there must be room for them at the trough also. The market mechanism for deciding the value of most people's labour has been replaced by evaluation by bureaucrats, or Conciliation commissioners or Arbitration Court judges. How can anyone decide whether a nurse is worth one and one-half clerks or three-quarters of a plumber or two politicians. All rational decision making is removed and these matters are decided on an entirely arbitrary basis. The effect of this is that any change in the system has to come about by coercion and since the Government can always print more money there is not the normal safety valve that coercion can be self-destroying if it causes the bankruptcy of the employers.

Having insisted on taking on the cost of health care and finding it cannot afford it the Government feels it has to reduce expenses. Every group in the system is entrenched and refuses to be disbanded or reduced in importance and the only future for the public hospital system is continuing confrontation. Do not be deceived into thinking things will get better. The problem is basic to the system and can only be changed by changing the system.

The solution to these problems lies not in further tinkering with the system, further coercion of the doctors, preventing people from going to hospital so that nurses are not so busy or printing a few million extra dollars to add to our already disastrous deficit. The solution lies in a change of thinking. All Australians under 45 would have lived from the age of about 10 onwards in a gradually evolving welfare state. It is most difficult for most of the adults in our country to imagine any other kind of system.

In about 1900 Australia had the fourth highest standard of living in the world and now it has the 19th. I notice that the idealists (the non-realists), especially those whose income is guaranteed from Government sources, frequently say that Australia is a rich country. There are not many countries below us on the standard of living ladder for whose social systems and population welfare we would have a high regard. In 80 years this country has been transformed from a nation of self-reliant pioneers to a nation of spongers where everyone considers that his fellow citizens owe him a living. We may be able to fool ourselves for some years to come but the rapidly sinking Australian dollar shows that we cannot fool the world in general. We must get back to being a self-reliant society.

There is a great deal of misinformation and deliberate falsehood propagated for reasons that are difficult to understand. The mad and the bad seem to have preferential access to the media. $100,000,000 was wagered throughout Australia on just one horse race, the Melbourne Cup, and the amounts spent each year on gambling would be considerably more than the total cost of the welfare system, even over-inflated as it is by trendy and worthless ``health initiatives''. We do need some type of social security net for genuine cases but that number is very much smaller than those at present being covered. The percentage of the population entitled to cut-rate medical treatment has increased from 9.4% in 1970 to 23.1% in 1985 and these consume 35% of all medical services. With the exception of those in genuine need the remainder of the population must be free to make their own arrangements. Those who have no intention of ever paying the doctor or the hospital will probably not insure at all and for the remainder there should be a wide range of deregulated insurance services offering no-claim bonuses, reduced rates for those who wish to pay the first one hundred, three hundred or five hundred dollars themselves and all the variety of schemes which a free and unregulated insurance industry would provide. The total cost would almost certainly be less and people would have regained their freedom to make their own decisions.

If the population was paying for what it wanted in health care there would be no need for the dead hand of Government to come down with restrictions on the type and numbers of hospital beds which can be provided, the number of new, painless and efficient diagnostic techniques and equipment which could be introduced and the opportunity to steal the health dollar would practically disappear.

It is likely that this solution will be criticised as simplistic; most great advances in human progress are simple once they are understood. It is simple that the world is round, that matter and energy are interchangeable and that ``Love your neighbour'' could regulate human affairs.

To return to the original question, there cannot be good health with Medicare for very long. Confrontation with the nurses bears out that the end result of the Welfare State is the War of All against All as every group has to resort to coercion of its fellow citizens to wrest what it believes to be its rights from the all encompassing, all paying Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. I am not saying `spend more money'. What I am saying is that the scarce resources of funds are not being properly utilised. They are not being properly utilised for philosophical as well as for bureaucratic reasons. There are many other examples that I am aware of since I have taken over this shadow portfolio. For example, there is the duplication or provision of services which are already provided by non-government agencies. For example, another trendy and apparently popular idea was to establish a drug and alcohol dependency unit. That seems great and the people of the Australian Capital Territory might say: `Yes, that is a good idea'. But in the background that unit, we must remember, is being utilised and serviced at the cost of people missing out on major surgery. The truth is that the Salvation Army runs a Mancare facility in the Australian Capital Territory which is just as good as the drug and alcohol dependency unit and costs about one-quarter of the costs of the unit that has been established.

SPEECH.PARA: There are in the Australian Capital Territory dental and medical clinics established at great expense and competing with private practitioners. There are private medical practitioners all over the Australian Capital Territory. To think that there are dental and medical clinics with paid medical officers servicing them is an absolute nonsense. After all, both are being paid out of one fund in the long run, the taxpayers' purse, and are set up in competition with one another.

I made a speech in the Senate on 28 March last year in which I pointed out that on the average salaried doctors at these centres are seeing between 13 and 15 patients per day. I tabled a document which gave the number of patients the doctors were seeing at these clinics. It is in that speech and is available if anyone wants to look at it. On one occasion one doctor managed to see one patient. This sort of terribly expensive service is being provided in the Australian Capital Territory. If one works out the cost per treatment of these salaried doctors seeing between 13 and 15 patients per day and if one listens to Senator Grimes attacking the doctors in the community who want to get a little bit more for their services-he says they are the greedy ones-of course there is really no comparison.

Other services which could be more economically run by non-government services are the nursing homes, aged people's accommodation. There is no reason why they have to be run by governments as they are private organisations that are prepared to look after our aged people, and they do it extraordinarily well. Other trendy alternative services provided to minority groups in the Australian Capital Territory at the expense of efficient essential services include the community housing expansion program which produced the Wyuna disaster. There was also the provision of funds for the Tilley Devines Cafe Gallery. On the other hand, let me make this perfectly clear in response to another accusation by the Minister: I am not proposing or suggesting the running down of the Australian Capital Territory economy. I am suggesting neither an increase nor a reduction in the funds being spent on the Australian Capital Territory. What my motion is doing is highlighting the maladministration which is evident in areas of health, including the hospital services such as the hospital laundry facilities in the Australian Capital Territory which are known to the people of the Australian Capital Territory as being absolutely disastrous. Those employees are always going out on strike and creating great chaos in the hospital services of the Australian Capital Territory.

There are education problems in the Australian Capital Territory. It has bus service problems at present. There is the failure to repair and replace the bus services so that in the end the people of the Australian Capital Territory, apparently, will be handed over a service in which the buses are in a rundown condition. There is the failure to provide proper repair and replacement of the buses. There are also the fire services in the Australian Capital Territory and the disaster that that has been; the firemen have been repeatedly on strike; the refusal of the fire brigade in the Australian Capital Territory to accept the appointment of the new Commissioner. There are also the construction industry, housing, social welfare, garbage collection, road construction, planning, maintenance and indeed every aspect of life in the Australian Capital Territory.

If you were not satisfied, Mr Acting Deputy President, with the page of the Canberra Times on the day after I gave the notice of motion, look at today's Canberra Times and you will see three stories about maladministration in the Australian Capital Territory. You will see the headings: `Diluted plan for self-rule'-I will come back to that in due course; `Many buses are remaining idle' and `113 more nurses needed, Sax says'. That kind of thing happens every day. Every day one picks up the Canberra Times it is full of stories indicating the maladministration of the Australian Capital Territory.

The Minister, I might say, errs when he claims some credit for the current growth in the Australian Capital Territory economy. The current growth is, no doubt, due to the initiatives of the Fraser Government. I refer to the new Parliament House, the Australian Defence Force Academy, the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation headquarters and the White Industries Ltd conference centre and I also refer to the wage pause. These items have led to the recovery in the economy in the ACT. This Government has done nothing except continue those projects. This economy has become very heated in the last 12 months or so as these buildings have come to fruition. It may very well be that the Government could have effected some economies in this area by perhaps slowing down the construction of the new Parliament House, but not on your life. It is quite clear that in 1988 Mr Hawke wants to be the Prime Minister who opens the new Parliament House. So he is not going to have it delayed until 1990-he may not be here in 1990-so the money is going to be found no matter what happens to the economy.
Let me turn to some of the specifics of the motion. The first point states:
condemns the Federal Government for:

(i) its failure to consult the people of the ACT in its deliberations on the system of machinery of self-government of the ACT, whether by utilisation of members of the current ACT House of Assembly or by any other means.

This is one of the matters I have been raising repeatedly. I said earlier I would come back to the article relating to self-government on the front page of today's Canberra Times. Some time last year, in a number of public speeches and in this House, I suggested that the people of the Australian Capital Territory were not being properly represented in any negotiations with the Government about self-government. I suggested that the existing House of Assembly be formed into committees and that those committees be given funds to enable them to employ expert consultants who could advise them as to the nature of the agreement that they should have with the Commonwealth Government over self-government. If the Government was not satisfied with the existing House of Assembly, it could have had an election for a new House of Assembly which would specifically have the responsibility of negotiating on behalf of the people of the Australian Capital Territory with the Federal Government to come to some agreement about self-government. This happened in the Northern Territory. When the Fraser Government was negotiating with the Northern Territory to provide self-government the people of the Northern Territory were represented. But who is representing the people of the Australian Capital Territory in the current negotiations? The Minister is negotiating with the bureaucracy and his own Cabinet. No one has the specific job of representing the people of the Australian Capital Territory. I do not claim to represent the people of the Australian Capital Territory in these negotiations even if the Minister were prepared to negotiate with them. When I made this criticism the Minister said `Well, Senator Lewis does not even know what is going on in his own Party', because I regularly confer with a member of the Liberal Party in the House of Assembly. I say to Mr Scholes quite frankly that whoever that Liberal member of the House of Assembly is he does not necessarily represent all of the people of the Australian Capital Territory either. There needs to be some elected body which represents the people of the Australian Capital Territory and which can protect the interests of the people of the Australian Capital Territory.

When we look at the self-government proposals there seems to be a promise that the Australian Capital Territory will look after the finances for the first two years and then the finances will come up for review, whatever that might mean. In today's Canberra Times we learn that even the miserable proposals which Mr Scholes put forward on the previous occasion are to be deleted further. The Government is proposing, in typical fashion, that the powers of the Executive be increased to the detriment of the powers of the Parliament. Under this proposal the Executive in the future will apparently have the power to disallow laws of the new council of the Australian Capital Territory, but the Parliament will not have power to disallow laws of the Australian Capital Territory. That is the way governments always tend to act-to take away the powers of the Parliament wherever possible. It appears that instead of it being a plenary body the new council of the Australian Capital Territory is in fact just going to be some statutory authority created by the Federal Parliament. The House of Assembly has not been consulted in any way about these proposals. So much for Mr Scholes's claims about consultation with the people of the Australian Capital Territory. The second point I made was that the Senate condemns the Federal Government for:
its repeated demonstrations that militant industrial action will succeed ahead of moderation thereby encouraging widespread militant industrial disputation in the Australian Capital Territory.

There is no doubt that this Government has demonstrated to the people of the Australian Capital Territory that the way to get what one wants is to be militant. It is all very well summed up in an editorial in the Canberra Times on Monday 20 January this year. The editorial states:

Living in a town dominated by the left of the trade unions and subject to the activities of the rent-a-crowd, rent-a-picket variety can be exasperating. One has to become inured to the demonstrations, the pickets, the squats, the posters, banners and graffiti that proclaim their superior moral outrage and social consciences. Many residents try hard to suppress revulsion at seeing the completion of a retirement village delayed, the public-hospital system reduced to pandemonium, sub-contractors beaten up, and the formation of industry cartels by union pressure.

The fact that this situation is the result of the supine behaviour of elected representatives in the Federal Parliament, which is responsible for Canberra and in particular for its building and construction industry and its public hospital system, makes it even more difficult to keep the bile down.

I think that that editorial sums up all of the problems that are created by this militant industrial disputation which this Government encourages in the Australian Capital Territory. I know it does not go out and say `This is the way we want you to act', but it responds in such a way that if a person is militant he achieves something; if he is not militant he does not achieve something. If that is not sufficient, let me quote the Minister's own admission reported in the Canberra Times of 1 February this year. He stated:
There are, for instance, great difficulties in getting major projects committed in Canberra because we are perceived to have a very bad industrial record.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. It is not surprising when one looks at that list that the budget for the new Parliament House now tops $809m-that is $178m over the original budget figure. The sweetheart deals indicated in that table are clear. I understand there are some sweetheart deals with subcontractors for additional overaward payments of up to $125 per week for working on the new Parliament House. As I have said, the militancy has paid off. I mentioned before that the firemen of the Australian Capital Territory have been on strike regularly. I just learned last week that not one fireman has been docked any pay for the period he has missed while he has been on strike. Just imagine that. These firemen have missed days, amounting to weeks, in industrial disputation and not one has lost $1 in pay as a result of it. I can see the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Button) smiling as he wonders what he is going to do about it. It is just unbelievable. Not 1c has been docked from their pay for all the days they have had off, so they have been encouraged to go on strike.

SPEECH.PARA: There has certainly been no discouragement to go on strike. A builder in the Australian Capital Territory had been trying for some considerable time to get electricity installed on a site on which he was building. What did this builder do? He parked his car in front of the Australian Capital Territory Electricity Authority building and put some signs on the front of the car. Guess what happened? That is right. His electricity commitment was fixed up that day. The only way to get anything done in the Australian Capital Territory is to be militant about it. That is why the Territory is the way it is at present.

This is all happening under a Government which claims that it has some special relationship with the trade union movement. I refer to an administration which is so inept that Commissioner Caesar of the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission had something to say about the Department of Territories concerning the recent bus dispute. I hope Senator Button will listen to this because it is an absolute ripper. The Commissioner said:
. . . the problem confronting the department `lies squarely at the feet of the department and at this stage I really fail to see how this commission can assist in solving the questions put to me'.

He was surprised that a `mere overtime ban' could so quickly bring so many bus services to a halt. This indicated to him that the work had not been properly planned and an examination of the overtime spread showed that most of the work could be done during normal hours. He believed that trying to convince the Department of this during Commission discussions would be `like trying to shift mountains'. He said:
The solution is in the hands of the department and those who work for them.
If ever there was an indictment of this Government's administration of the Australian Capital Territory, it is there.
