Ever since the dispute between the nursing staff at Woden Valley and Royal Canberra Hospitals and the Capital Territory Health Commission in November 1985 over staffing levels, there has been increasing difficulty in admitting patients to Hospital. The same applies to referrals from outside of Canberra. The Canberra hospitals have for many years serviced the South Coast, Yass and other neighbouring country towns and it is no longer possible to do so.

One other problem that has not been voiced relates to the levels of pathology, paramedical and other support staff in the hospitals. With the reduction in beds, these services are no longer required to the same extent. On the other hand I believe that there have been no reductions in the number of these staff. Dear Senator Lewis,

The other day I was speaking to Dr. Veronica Goldrick about the sad state of affairs that our health care is in at present in the ACT, and in particular, the lack of available beds in the Hospital Commission hospitals. This situation has created great hardship to the patients involved, but unfortunately most of the general public is not aware of this unless they are personally connected or involved. Dr. Goldrick felt that it would be a good idea for me to write to you to give you a little information, simply as a small indicator, to reflect the big trouble that our community is in at present. I have practised medicine in Canberra since 1959, firstly as a General Practitioner, and in the past fourteen years as a Specialist Ophthalmologist. In the light of this experience, my opinion is that the bad hospital situation and the lack of proper available care and available beds from the Commission hospitals has never been worse. What is more, I cannot see matters improving under the present conditions. One supposes that it can only become worse, but indeed, it cannot become much worse, as it would seem that we are at the bottom of the barrel now.

In the Royal Canberra Hospital, where I have done the major part of my work, the facilities for patient care has gradually diminished over the last ten years. Over the past eighteen months, at times it has become non-existent. In the early to mid 1970's, I performed a minimum of 20 elective cases monthly at the Royal Canberra Hospital. In 1985, my elective cases were 38% of that of 1984. So far in the first two months of 1986 I have had available facilities for eight routine elective surgical cases (three of these were fortunately assigned to me because of the absence of another eye surgeon) two additional admissions were treated on an emergency basis, a total of ten cases in two months. Over the past three weeks, the entire Royal Canberra Hospital has had ten beds available for elective surgery per week. None of these beds have been allocated to any one of the ten ophthalmologists for routine elective surgical cases. In other words, no routine elective eye surgery has been performed in the Royal Canberra Hospital over the past three weeks as far as I know. From the patients' point of view, elderly people who need urgent restoration of sight from conditions such as cataracts are waiting months on end, and now indefinitely, for their operations. Children with strabismus requiring surgical correction within two to three months if their sight is not to be damaged for the rest of their lives are now having to wait months and months before their admissions are available. In past years, patients have received their admissions within three to six weeks of booking. Now, I have patients who have been waiting since August, 1985, and there are other surgeons whose patients have been waiting for over twelve months. As matters stand at present, all those on the waiting list do not even know when their admission will be available. They cannot plan ahead; all they can do is wait in frustration. When sent for, they are given less than one weeks' notice, and many patients are unable to accept the time given and thus forfeit their admission.

If you so wish, I feel sure that other medical practitioners in Canberra will supply you with additional and further evidence of the terrible situation the Health Care system is in at present, not only in Canberra, but all over Australia, and needless to tell you how bad things are in New South Wales.

Something will have to happen and be done soon. We have all tried very hard in recent years and months to help correct the illness in our hospital system, so as to restore the proper health care for our community. However, matters worsen month by month, and one is overcome by the feeling of helplessness. The great fear is that this ``sickness'' in our health system may eventually infect all other segments of our society, if it has not already done so.
Yours sincerely,

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. I am running out of time so I will leave it to my colleague Senator Reid to develop this point about the health care services in the Australian Capital Territory. These letters and the letter of Dr Long, which I incorporated earlier in my speech, confirm this statement in the letter of Dr V. M. Goldrick:

SPEECH.PARA: We have regressed 30 years in the last twelve months.

I could give the sort of detail that I have provided on those points about each of the other points listed in my notice of motion, but because I am running out of time I will pick up just some quick examples. The fourth point reads:

Its failure to ensure that the National Capital Development Commission planning is sensitive to the needs and desires of the people of the ACT and failure to provide the Commission with adequate direction to ensure that proper consideration is given to community representations.

A Bill has been languishing in the Parliament since May 1985, the purpose of which is `to modernise the structure of the Commission'-whatever that means; how one modernises a statutory authority I do not know-`and make it more accountable and responsible to the Government and to the ACT community'. That Bill has been languishing there since May last year. It largely ignores the report of the White Committee of Review of the Role and Functions of the National Capital Development Commission, which was tabled on 21 September 1983. The NCDC is not publicly seen as being responsive to the Australian Capital Territory community. This Government's actions in regard to it have been largely cosmetic and pandering to minority groups.

On the question of housing loans, the maladministration of the Australian Capital Territory housing loans scheme resulted in the scheme running out of funds in the first month of the last financial year. Then there was the disgraceful passing of the buck by the then Minister for Territories, Mr Uren, on to his public servants. Wyuna Community Ltd-I do not have to say any more, other than to mention the name of that effort. The low cost housing and mobile homes problems have arisen in the Australian Capital Territory because of the failure of this Government to encourage private enterprise to provide low cost housing for rental and its failure to develop a site for mobile homes.

On the question of car parking in Civic, there are letters to the editor every day about the problems of car parking in Civic. The problem of duplication is mentioned in the report of the Vinson Review of Australian Capital Territory Health and Welfare Services. That report reveals a lack of co-ordination between the Department of Health and the Department of Territories in the provision of social welfare services. As a consequence there is a substantial degree of overlapping in the provision of services. The Vinson report has now been buried. I have already mentioned the White report, which is languishing in the Parliament. On the question of the cost effectiveness, the Vinson report, although in my view not a very well written report, reveals the inefficiencies and duplications between departments and highlights the failure to examine alternatives on a cost-effective basis.

I believe that Canberra has the talented and dedicated senior public servants it needs to provide the information and recommendations that would eliminate this waste and duplication, if the Minister and this Government would allow them to do so and would allow some private enterprise activities to move into the system. I acknowledge that one of the major problems in the Australian Capital Territory is that it is run by the Trades and Labour Council, the unions and the Administrative and Clerical Officers Association. Those organisations make most of the decisions in this town; not the Minister or the Government. Indeed, this Minister and this Government are unable to do anything in this town without first getting the approval of the union movement, as was clearly demonstrated in regard to Radford College on the northern side. I give the Senate the example of the cartel that has been established by the unions in the Australian Capital Territory which limits to 68 the number of concrete agitator trucks which are allowed to pour the massive amounts of concrete required in the Australian Capital Territory this year. That cartel is enabling drivers to gross in excess of $110,000 per annum each, at least. This Government is hopelessly unable to do any- thing at all about it. Another example is the lengthy picketing of a foreign embassy by the Trades and Labour Council, contrary to the Vienna Convention, and the related matter of the failure of this Government to remove illegally erected buildings from public land.

TALK.START.PARA: —Not true.

—The Government has not yet removed those buildings from that public land. The Government did not do anything about it for six months. It threw the Aborigines off when they put up their tent city here, but it did not do anything about this matter because the buildings were established by the TLC, and they stayed there for six or eight months. This Government can do nothing about it. This Government simply responds to the pressures of the moment, and that alone is maladministration. The evidence of maladministration is overwhelming. It is clear that the Government simply wants to dump this mess into the laps of the people of the Australian Capital Territory with a miserable apology for self-government for them. I rest my case.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reid Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Lewis's notice of motion lists some 15 items relating to the administration of the Australian Capital Territory by this Government and the problems faced by the community. As Senator Lewis has already indicated, there are other matters which were not included. The debate tonight could not do otherwise than deal specifically with the problems and crises that now exist in the health services in the Australian Capital Territory. It has now reached a crisis point and nobody can really ignore what is happening to the sick people of Canberra, those who need help and who are in a position where they are least able to help themselves or speak for themselves. On 12 February I asked a question about health services in the Australian Capital Territory. When I did so the Minister representing the Minister for Health (Senator Grimes) answered by indicating that really health services in the Australian Capital Territory were no worse than in the rest of Australia. Having looked a little further into that to see whether perhaps we were being unreasonable, I find that health services are bad in the rest of Australia, but to say that they are no worse here than in the rest of Australia really does not do anything for us at all.

SPEECH.PARA: One reads of cases in New South Wales where relatives are being asked to assist with patients in hospital care because of a lack of nursing staff. There was a report recently of a hospital in Essendon in Victoria which, although it has been open for about four years, has not yet received a patient. One would have thought that that was a joke if it had not been found to be true. At the same time, of course, one learns that in Victoria there are about 25,000 people on waiting lists requiring surgery, and nationally this list is said to comprise over 50,000 people. The Government will try to explain that away at present by saying that people are now asked to put their names on lists so that numbers are known. It does not really matter whether one keeps waiting lists or whether one does not. The number of people in need of surgery are exactly the same. But what we know is that the numbers are growing and the service is shrinking.

What has happened to our health system and where are we going? They are questions that must be answered. In Canberra, at the Woden Valley Hospital, the waiting list is now about 32 weeks and at Royal Canberra Hospital it is 12 weeks. There are 2,300 people awaiting surgery. I want honourable senators to think about the frustration of the families of those people as they await surgery and are constantly delayed. Over the last two years there have been constant delays. Surgery lists have been cancelled and people have been told that they will be admitted to hospital next week. They make all the necessary arrangements with their families and their employers. In many instances, of course, they arrange for a relative to come to Canberra to look after the family while they are in hospital and then they are told at the very last minute that the surgery has been put off. They are not even told, of course, that it has been put off to a particular time. It is just cancelled and they wait and wait. People suffer frustration and anguish. It is said, of course, that emergency surgery goes ahead, but that is few and far between. The fact is that there are 2,300 people awaiting surgery at present. I guess none of them would think it was elective surgery that can wait indefinitely. They want to get on with living their lives and organise themselves so that they know what is happening.

A young man came to see me recently who was to have been admitted to hospital for what was about the tenth in a series of operations which he had required from the time he was about 10 years old. He attended the hospital on 12 November when he was told he was to be admitted, but that was in the midst of the nurses strike. He got there at 2 o'clock in the afternoon and sat there until 4.30, waiting to be admitted. At 4.30 he was informed that the nurses were going on strike, the operation could not proceed and he could not be admitted to the hospital. Even at that time he had been waiting to be admitted for some weeks. It was an operation on his head. I am sure honourable senators can imagine at least a little how he must have felt on hearing that news. As it was, he was suffering from headaches and discomfort. Finally, I am glad to say, he was able to have the operation on 4 February. But he should not have had to face that situation.

It will be interesting to look at the operating time of the theatres in the two Canberra hospitals over the last six or eight months. Frequently less than the full numbers of theatres are operating. Mostly the theatres are not all operating and on two occasions, I believe, only one theatre was available, and that for emergency cases only. I am dealing, of course, specifically with the impact on patients and those who are sick. But one could make the observation in passing that if the theatres are not operating, the surgeons and anaesthetists are suffering as well and that is a significant aspect in regard to employment, especially as there is an agreement between the doctors and the Australian Capital Territory Health Authority that the doctors will have access to theatres. I suggest that the Health Authority is not adhering to that part of the agreement.

But we did have a nurses strike for two weeks last November. The Government then, I suppose, decided that there must be something wrong and they asked Dr Sax to inquire into the matter. It is worth reviewing some of the things that Dr Sax said as a result of his inquiry. Those who had family in hospital know what the problems are. The nurses know what the problems are. But it was necessary for a report to be provided. We hope that the Government will now appreciate what the problems are and will act upon them. Dr Sax stated in his report:
Nurses were tense, edgy, and rushing around.
He called then for more nurses. In today's paper we see that he has again referred to the need for 113 nurses. The report stated:
Efficient admission and discharge policies are essential for the smooth operation of modern hospitals.
The implementation of such policies and of work load monitoring procedures is strongly recommended.
The proportion of registered nurses on each ward should be progressively raised.
An adequate pool of permanent relieving staff would reduce the necessity to deplete the small groups of core staff by redeployment.
There is a serious lack of morale and job satisfaction, and high levels of stress among ACT nurses.
Resignation rates, sick leave and absenteeism increase as staff morale falls.
Failure to resolve the root causes of dissatisfaction will have serious implications for health care delivery in the ACT.
Evidence taken from both nursing and medical personnel indicates inadequate levels of skilled nursing staff to match work loads.

Meanwhile, it would be reasonable to anticipate that increasing demands will be made on existing services, and that a start should be made on the expansion of the qualified nursing workforce by adding 20 registered nurses each month for three months.
They are just some of the comments made by Dr Sax in his report. The sorts of things that led him to this conclusion also need to be looked at. He stated:
Both hospitals are said by resident medical officers to have insufficient nurses in real numbers and in terms of skill mix to the extent that even basic nursing observations were being omitted.
There are insufficient trained staff to handle more than one complicated delivery with foetal distress at any one time.
The obstetricians at this hospital are concerned about litigation arising out of unsafe care due to inadequate numbers of nurses.
There has been an increase in nosocomial infection because of a lack of experienced staff on the wards.
There is no time for proper communication between nurses and patients and relatives; nurses even get resentful when they are asked questions.
That is because of the pressure they are under in the wards. In regard to another area he stated:
Mothers with breast feeding problems are getting little help.
Babies for whom hourly feeds have been ordered may be fed two or three-hourly.

That is the state of our hospital system. It is not because the hospitals are overcrowded. There are spare beds in both of the hospitals. In fact, the occupancy rate has dropped over the last 12 months.

The problem is not restricted only to that area. Several weeks ago I raised in the Senate the delays in the Coroners Court and the distress that this was causing the surviving relatives of the deceased who were awaiting coronial inquiries. I suggested that the Minister should see whether the courts were under pressure and not able to cope or whether the delays were in the area of the police investigation, because we have had problems with police staffing. The answer was that the problem arose in the health area, in getting pathology reports from the Woden Valley Hospital. It is very apparent that the pathology section of the Woden Valley Hospital has not had adequate staff to do the work that it is required to do for the living-for the patients who are in the hospitals, and for this work in the coronial area. I guess that in this area one puts off what has to be done. That does not help those, of course, who are bereaved and who are awaiting the coroner's report.

There have been reports of the oncology unit not operating as it should because of a lack of staff. People who are suffering from cancer and need the services of that unit find it distressing to be delayed or to have to wait for their treatment during periods when the unit is closed. I think they suffer enough stress knowing that they need treatment for cancer without feeling that they have to wait for reasons that are totally unjustified.
I want to refer to some of the things that have occurred. Senator Lewis has had incorporated in Hansard a letter from a doctor which states:

In the last two weeks alone I have had an 86 year old lady with a second deep vein calf thrombosis sit in Casualty for 7 hours (after I foolishly believed that I had organised a bed) and a 76 year old lie vomiting for a week at home `waiting for a bed'. There are many more tales to tell.
She goes on to say:
The poor, the elderly and the chronically ill are suffering as never before in the history of the State.

I have another letter which was written by the daughter of an elderly woman to the Chairman of the Australian Capital Territory Health Authority. The daughter refers to her mother who had collapsed at home on 18 January 1986 and was taken to the Royal Canberra Hospital. The letter outlines the story of what went on that day at the hospital. The letter states that the mother had collapsed several times before arriving at the hospital. She was told at the hospital that she would have to wait for a trolley. When the daughter arrived at the hospital at about 7 p.m. the mother was told to stand up to have her blood pressure taken. Apparently the doctor suggested that if she was able to stand up he could discharge her. The story about what happened to this elderly woman during that evening goes on and on. The letter states:
Finally, after seven hours of persecution my Mother was admitted.

The letter goes on to ask some questions. It is not satisfactory but it is pleasing to note that the Health Authority did take the complaint seriously. A letter dated 27 February 1986 from the Chairman of the Authority, Mr Bissett, to the daughter of the woman concerned admits that there problems at the hospital. He says, in part:

The facts and the events you have complained about do not reflect well on the Authority and they certainly do not represent an acceptable standard of patient care that the community is entitled to expect from what is and should be an excellent public hospital system in the ACT.
He goes on later to say:
I have been advised that the level of nursing staff available on the evening concerned was a factor in the delay in admitting your Mother to the ward.
To his credit, Mr Bissett has in fact disclosed what did occur. That was of little benefit, of course, to the patient who was suffering at the time.

There is another report of a woman who was concerned that her 89-year-old father was not being fed properly during the nurses' strike. She said that the nurses who were on duty were doing their very best to look after patients and she had no criticism of them. But this elderly man was not able to look after himself and she was concerned for his welfare. There was a report on the front page of the Canberra Times of 20 February 1986 about a little six-year-old, Adam Collins. The report states:
Adam Collins lies bent backwards and in motionless sleep on the lounge room floor.
The report also stated:

Adam's tortured muscles have strained further and further back-`he is bent backwards like a banana'-and, about three months ago, his hip pulled out of its socket. He needs an operation to fix the hip and free the muscles.'
`He is in constant pain . . . It is so bad that he has fits.'

The fact is that Adam was to have gone into hospital the next day but the surgery was cancelled. They tried to explain this away by suggesting that it was his doctor who made the decision as to whether he would receive the operation or not. In a sense, I suppose, that might almost be said to be the case. But this is not so when we understand that the doctor had had his surgery time cut dramatically. The doctor was left in the invidious position of making a decision as to whom he would operate on. In consultation with other doctors, the decision was made that there was another patient, in even greater need than Adam, who should have surgery. I am sure that if one read about the case of Adam Collins one would agree that his position was also urgent and it was not the doctor's fault that surgery was deferred. It was the hospital system that precluded that little boy from having his operation at the time that he needed it.

There are other letters. I have one from the Chairman of the Australian Capital Territory Health Authority apologising to a woman whose mother had died in hospital after she wrote and complained about the problem. He agreed again that what had happened was not an acceptable standard of health care.

Mr Acting Deputy President, I am sorry to have to tell you that I could go on all night telling you stories of what has occurred to sick people in this city, people who have had their lives disrupted by not being able to get treatment when they needed it. It is quite clear that more nurses are needed in our hospitals and a great deal of investigation is needed to be carried out to see that the hospitals provide the service that people expect of them. We are not asking for anything new; we just want a return to the standards that we have had in the past.

I also want to refer to the problem of the frail aged in our community and the nursing home situation. I have spoken of this matter before in the Senate but the problem has not gone away. I think that the first time I raised the question of the needs of the frail aged about 120 people who had been classified as being in need of a nursing home bed did not have that facility. The number is now about 186. I heard on the radio this week that there were to be another 60 nursing home beds in Canberra-40 at Mirinjani and 20 at Kankinya. However, I have seen no Press release to substantiate this. At this stage I can only say that I hope it is correct that approval has been given for those extra beds. Of course, that is not of great consolation at present for those 180 people who are in need right now.

I would remind you, Mr Acting Deputy President, that it does not seem to include the nursing home bed at Morling Lodge that has been empty now for a very long time. I would like to remind the Senate of the story about that nursing home bed. When Morling Lodge was extended, for some reason or other the building contained one more bed than had been approved when it was completed. At first the department apparently said that the bed could be occupied. Then it was discovered that the bed should not have been there and the nursing home was told to get the patient out. Of course, the nursing home had to wait for someone to die before that could occur. That bed has remained empty and that is something that I find beyond belief. I hope that that bed will be occupied as well. One might think that one bed might not make all that much difference but it certainly would to the person who would have the opportunity to use it. There are now close to 200 people assessed and waiting for nursing home beds. These are people whose families no doubt look after them as best they can. However, those families do not have the skills necessary to care properly for people who have reached the stage of being frail aged and not able to look after themselves.

There are problems with the patient-staff ratio in nursing homes and there is difficulty in recruiting staff into the geriatric care areas. The formula for staffing in the hospitals in Canberra does not really seem to help. The hospitals have a six-week roster of nurses who circulate between hospitals and nursing homes. Some nurses prefer geriatric nursing and would like to be permanently on the nursing home roster but are not allowed to be. Again, that seems to me to be an administrative arrangement which falls short of providing the sort of care that would be best for those in nursing homes.

There is no place in Canberra where anyone who has been in hospital can go to convalesce. As a consequence, some patients go home much earlier than they ought to after they have had surgery or have been in hospital. In some instances people stay on in hospital much longer than they would have to if they were able to go to a place to convalesce where the nursing care that is required is much less than it is while they are in hospital. If we had some place for people to convalesce this would mean that more beds would be available in hospitals to be used by some of the 2,300 people who are awaiting them.

The same thing applies to respite care. Many people being cared for at home by their families ought to be able to go somewhere for a couple of weeks every now and again so that the family can have holidays or go away, but that sort of care is not available in Canberra. If it becomes a real crisis the only place for them is hospital, again taking up resources which need not be used for that person. Frequently old people are not sick; they may need a great deal of care and support but it is not necessarily specialised nursing care. In this area it is also useful to go back to the Sax report, which states:

Great difficulty has been experienced in matching staff levels to workloads in accordance with the agreed formula. As a result, admissions have not been taken for prolonged periods. Even when resident numbers drop to match available staff levels and admissions are taken again, situations not infrequently arise when the nursing staff level available drops a few days later and dissatisfaction among the nurses on duty quickly reappears.

The refusal of admissions is not a satisfactory way of balancing workloads and available staff. Basic causes of the staffing problem should be addressed. By refusing admissions, not only are severely disabled persons and their carers made to suffer, but increased strain is imposed on community nursing services, and long-stay patients accumulate in the hospitals. During the course of the inquiry there were between 36 and 40 chronically disabled nursing home patients who had been occupying hospital beds for long periods. For them, hospital care is inappropriate, and for the hospital, they are occupying accommodation that could be put to more appropriate use.

Dr Sax, I think, knows exactly what is wrong with the system and what needs to be done to correct it. I certainly understand the difficulties faced by staff in our hospitals and nursing homes. Some flexibility needs to be brought into the system and we need to remember that we are dealing with aged people who, though not necessarily sick, are definitely in need of care. Dr Sax referred to the problems with the recruitment of staff in the geriatric area-I too have referred to them-and went on to suggest some possible solutions. I hope that the Government is examining these closely because they warrant examination. Amongst the solutions suggested are: The establishment of basic programs in the care of those with chronic disease and disability; a change in the orientation of the nursing homes towards their inclusion in a broad program involving day care and community care as well as institutional services; a change in community attitudes towards nurses' work, which they would welcome; the provision of child care facilities for use at least by those on morning and evening shifts; an assurance of adequate and regular relief staff, if necessary by the establishment of an independent relief pool for the nursing homes; and sufficient assurance that nurses be able to take the study leave to which they may be entitled. He also suggested the sale of nursing homes to run them differently.

There is, of course, in Canberra the problem of the formula under which the number of nursing home beds are made available. I have referred to that in the Senate previously and to the need for that formula to be reviewed. It seems to me quite absurd to suggest that those who are in receipt of the domiciliary nursing care benefit should have an impact on the number in frail aged beds. I recommend to the Government that the formula be reviewed. The problem is the same in the area of mental health. We have a new ordinance. Patients from the Australian Capital Territory can no longer go to Kenmore.
Debate interrupted.

DEBATE.TITLE: JOINT SELECT COMMITTEE ON AN AUSTRALIA CARD

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Aulich Sen T.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) That the following amendment be made to the Resolution of appointment of the Joint Select Committee on an Australia Card, viz.:
Paragraph (12), leave out the paragraph, insert the following paragraph:
`(12) That the Committee report by 30 April 1986.'.
(2) That the foregoing resolution be communicated to the House of Representatives by Message requesting its concurrence in the Resolution.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Consideration resumed.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The CHAIRMAN

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Durack has moved an amendment to clause 16.

INTERJECT.PARA: Question put:
That the amendment (Senator Durack's) be agreed to.

ROW.ENTRY: (Senator Robertson did not vote, to compensate for the vacancy caused by the resignation of Senator Peter Rae)

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Amendment negatived.

TALK.START.PARA: —The question now is: That clause 16 stand as printed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —Earlier today in the discussion on clause 16 I made the point that members of all parties had received submissions in relation to section 46 of the principal Act and the concern expressed by organisations such as the Law Council of Australia in its media Press release of 11 February 1986 that proposed new section 46 (7) should make it clear that predatory purpose--
—On a point of order, Mr Chairman: We have just voted on a motion to delete proposed new section 46 (7) and now we are embarking on another debate in relation to it.

—The question before the Chair is: That clause 16 stand as printed. The Committee has voted to reject the deletion of clause 16 (b), but it is in order for the Committee to discuss clause 16 as a whole.
—I am foreshadowing an amendment to add words at the conclusion of clause 16 (b).

—I seek clarification. I take it that it is not in order for Senator Short, in pursuing whatever course he now proposes, to canvass matters relating to the content of proposed new section 46 (7) since we have just voted expressly on that issue. To do so would be to make nonsense of the proceedings.
—Senator Durack's amendment that clause 16 (b) be left out was defeated. It is now perfectly in order to move amendments to clause 16 (b) but not to move that it be left out entirely.

—I propose to move an amendment to existing clause 16 (b). It is along the lines I foreshadowed in our earlier discussion today, when I pointed out that all parties had received submissions from a wide range of community groups concerned about the wording of proposed new section 46 (7) to the effect that the Act should make it clear that predatory purpose can be inferred only from conduct inconsistent with any reasonable alternative conclusion. The Minister in his response to the point I made earlier today said-this is not literal-that he acknowledged the point I was making and did not disagree with it but that he did not think it was necessary to go further in terms of the actual wording of the clause. I shall move an amendment to the clause as drafted to add to clause 16 (b), in other words, proposed new section 46 (7), additional words. I therefore move:

SPEECH.PARA: Page 7, paragraph (b), proposed new sub-section 46 (7), at end of sub-section add: `, provided that that purpose may only be inferred from conduct inconsistent with reasonable alternative conclusions.'

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I will make the situation quite clear: The Committee has voted to retain the words in existing clause 16 (b), proposed new sub-clause (7). It is in order to propose additions to that clause but it would not be in order to propose to delete any words.

—I have proposed an addition to the existing words. I am not suggesting any deletion or amendment of the existing words. I have moved this motion on behalf of the Opposition, fortified by the clear statement Senator Gareth Evans gave me on behalf of the Government earlier today in response to a specific request from me that nothing in the proposed new section is intended to affect normal, vigorous competition and that it is intended to protect competition, not individual competitors. It follows logically from acceptance of that proposition and from Senator Gareth Evans's acknowledgement of the point about predatory purpose to which I earlier referred, that it would be acceptable to add the words I have proposed because they do nothing other than to make legislatively clear the clarification and assurance Senator Gareth Evans gave me earlier today.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would appreciate a copy of that text in front of me as soon as possible, but from what I have understood from Senator Short's description of his amendment, I find it unacceptable to the Government because it takes the whole process a step further in the restrictions that it now imposes than is the case under the existing common law rules. The common law allows a court to draw inferences from an objective conduct as distinct from drawing inferences or conclusions only from direct evidence of subjective intent. I repeat that the common law allows inferences to be drawn from objective evidence of conduct. Senator Short's amendment would say that the only circumstance in which inferences can be drawn from objective conduct is when that objective conduct is in turn susceptible of only one possible interpretation. To emphasise the contrast again, in common law the court can say this: `The evidence is susceptible of this interpretation, there is a counter claim that is not so susceptible. Weighing and balancing the competing arguments, the force of the evidence and the demeanour of the witnesses and so on, we find on the balance of probabilities that there was a particular predatory intent and that the evidence is sufficient on balance to persuade us that there was that intent. We are prepared on balance to infer that from the objective conduct in question'. Senator Short is seeking to remove the existing capacity of a court to make that sort of finding on balance and to say that the only circumstance in which a court can make a finding in the absence of direct evidence as to direct intent is where the objective evidence is susceptible of only one possible interpretation.

SPEECH.PARA: I am sorry that that is a fairly complicated response; it is a complicated technical point that we are discussing. However, I think if Senator Short thinks about it he will see that that is so. As I said earlier on, of course I acknowledge that section 46, as is the Act as a whole, is about preserving vigorous competition. I think I also acknowledged earlier that as a practical matter I did not see that a court would be likely to find against a defendant unless the evidence was pretty strongly biased towards a finding of predatory intent and that the objective circumstances were such that the force of that evidence was pretty overwhelming. I did say that. However, Senator Short is trying to take that one step further and actually deny the capacity of a court to perform a balancing act in these circumstances, which it is entitled to do as a matter of common law. Senator Short has-no doubt with the best will in the world-taken that one step further than could possibly be accepted if one wanted to preserve some meaning, content and vitality for section 46, as I think we all do, as a protector of small business.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —In response to the Minister for Resources and Energy (Senator Gareth Evans), I think that his interpretation of what I am attempting to do is wrong. With respect, I say that he is placing too narrow an interpretation on it. I am not attempting to remove any scope for on-balance judgments. The amendment simply says that if one is to have an inferential situation involving section 46 (7) which the Government is proposing in relation to predatory purpose, that inferential situation can apply only in relation to conduct which is inconsistent with any reasonable alternative conclusion. In other words, if this amendment were not accepted, the conclusion would surely have to be that a predatory purpose can be inferred from a range of reasons other than `reasonable conclusion of an other than predatory nature'. As the Minister said earlier today, that is not the Government's purpose. I do not think I am adding or detracting anything from my understanding of the Minister's earlier comments of what the Government is about in this clause. I am simply trying to make it clear because at the moment there is that difference of interpretation and scope for lack of clarity and confusion in what this clause and its intent are really all about.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment negatived.
Clause 16 agreed to.
Proposed new clause 16a.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Haines Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) Page 7, after clause 16, add the following new clause:
`16A. The Principal Act is amended by adding after section 46 the following section:
``Unconscionable conduct

``46A. A corporation that is in a position substantially to control a market for goods or services shall not engage in unconscionable conduct in its dealings with its suppliers, agents or distributors.''.'.

I said earlier today when we were originally debating section 46 of the principal Act that we believed that it had quite a significant role to play inasmuch as it extended protection to small businesses and other consumers in a number of ways. The Opposition parties do not seem to accept that fact, but our main concern with it is that it simply does not go far enough. Senator Durack said earlier that he thought the problem with section 46 and the amendment in clause 16 of the Trade Practices Amendment Bill 1985 are a classic example of why the whole Bill should have been sent off to the Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs. I can only ask, as I think I asked at an earlier stage, what the Opposition parties believe the Constitutional and Legal Affairs Committee could determine in the couple of months that it would have that reference that the people who came up with the Green Paper could not determine in two years of inquiry. The Green Paper has this to say about section 46, its application and hence its extension through the amendment that we are putting forward:
The existing monopolization provision (section 46) relates to corporations in a position substantially to control a market.
In the Green Paper the word `control' is underlined and for good reason. The paper continues:

Such corporations shall not take advantage of that power for the purpose of eliminating or substantially damaging a competitor, preventing the entry of a person into the market they control or deterring or preventing persons from engaging in competitive conduct.
A little later in that particular section it goes on to say:

It is also widely accepted that there are many corporations with a substantial degree of market power-but which could not be said to be in `substantial control' of the market-which engage in conduct falling into one or more of the three categories in paragraphs 46 (1) (a) to (c).
It finishes by saying:
Accordingly this Clause would amend the section to cover predatory conduct by a corporation which has a substantial degree of market power.
Again, those last words are underlined. The statement continued:

This was an amendment proposed by the Trade Practices Consultative Committee in 1979 and it should be emphasised, as it was by the TPCC, that the amended section would not catch legitimate competitive behaviour.
Some paragraphs later it went on:

There have been difficulties arising from the term `purpose' in existing section 46. It has introduced a highly subjective element into the operation of the provision. This difficulty is especially the case where it is necessary to prove the mental state of a corporation. The nature of this difficulty has been highlighted by the recent decision in TPC v. Tubemakers of Australia and others.
It finishes up by making the point a little later:

The words `or that has or is likely to have the effect' would be added to sub-section 46 (1) to give litigants an alternative method of establishing a contravention by proving the effect or likely effect of the corporation's conduct rather than having to establish a predatory purpose.

One of the concerns that was expressed to us was that in the form that the amendments to section 46 take in the Bill before us tonight not enough attention has been paid to other areas beyond the very narrow ones that have been specified. An example of this is contained in the letter we received from a group representing the Australian Petroleum Agents and Distributors Association-the petrol distributors and agents group-which says in part:

According to the explanatory memorandum (p. 20) the meaning of unconscionable conduct is well established by judicial interpretation. However, sub-clauses 5 and 6 in this section make it clear that the unconscionable conduct provision is to apply only to dealings relating to a consumer and not dealings relating to businesses even where one business is well-placed to impose `unconscionable' terms on the other.

APADA says that unconscionable conduct should apply to all dealings and not just dealings with a consumer. For example, it cited an instance where a petroleum distributor had been asked by his supplier to take on additional areas of responsibility but at the same time accept a cut in his commission for his whole area. That supplier did not wish to proceed with the arrangement but knew that his commission would be cut if he did not accept. So, to maintain income, he was obliged to agree to the proposal. Had he failed to accept, the supplier would legally have replaced him with another distributor prepared to agree to those terms, draconian as they may have been.

Indeed, while this may on the surface appear to be some sort of competitive conduct in the area of price wars and so on between petrol companies, what in effect is happening is that the company is applying some unfair restrictions on the manner in which the dealer, in this case the distributor, can conduct his business. In doing so we would argue that he is engaging in some fairly unconscionable conduct in that regard. If, as Senator Short said earlier, the Liberal Party is in fact a proponent of the viability of small businesses I would suggest that it give serious thought to supporting this amendment. Earlier today Senator Short launched into one of those diatribes that we have become accustomed to from him from time to time attacking various other senators--

TALK.START.PARA: —Only when strongly provoked.
—I seem to have that effect on Senator Short on an almost daily basis. I assure Senator Short that it is not at all deliberate.
—That makes it even worse.

—I ask Senator Short to wait until I start to try deliberately to provoke him. Notwithstanding whether he believed he was being provoked by me the fact remained that he did launch into a fairly vehement attack on what he saw as our rejection of the needs and interests of small business. I point out, however, that Senator Short's concerns, the issues that in fact he raised during that diatribe, related more specifically, and certainly more effectively, to large rather than small businesses. If he wants to look at conduct in this chamber directed specifically at assisting small businesses he ought to consider the sorts of proposals that have been before this chamber with regard to things such as the 10 per cent sales tax on wine-which was supported in this place by all Liberal and National Party senators; by the changes to the superannuation tax laws, in the course of which debate Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle described as frivolous an amendment attempting to put a ceiling on the amount below which the superannuation tax laws would not be affected, hence helping a great many small businesses; primary industry levies generally across the board and divorcement in service station ownership. I would suggest that perhaps if Senator Short--
—He is against small business. He is a joke.
—I suggest that Senator Chipp is distracting Senator Short from listening to my diatribe. Senator Short can listen to Senator Chipp's diatribe later.
—I am listening to you.

—I wish that Senator Short were more ears than mouth on occasions. Maybe Senator Short will get his score up a little if he supports an amendment which is intended to extend the scope of section 46 so that all dealings, including this sort and additional similar examples-for example, those involving supermarket chains and the smaller supermarket outlets which can be severely disadvantaged by pricing as a result of the practices of the larger wholesale distributors-are included. I ask Senator Short to get his score up by supporting the extension of the effect and effectiveness of section 46, which is our amendment. It will in fact extend effectiveness to pick up the sort of ordinary small business people who we all in this place from time to time express concern for.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: — The amendment moved by Senator Haines is not supported by the Government for a number of reasons. Let me articulate them. Firstly, such a provision would create enormous commercial uncertainty. There is simply no guidance as to the boundaries of the concept of unconscionable conduct that she is proposing, particularly in relation to commercial dealings. For example, could a corporation cease dealing with a distributor who was inefficient or a bad credit risk? This is one reason why section 52A is limited, at least initially, to consumer transactions.

SPEECH.PARA: Secondly, the provision is in no way tied to competition and accordingly is a quite inappropriate provision inserted here in the context of the competition provisions of Part IV. Thirdly, the provision duplicates in an unspecific way what new section 46 covers in a specific and more certain way. It is likely that most unconscionable conduct related in any way to competition would in fact be caught by the proposed strengthened section 46 which we have just adopted. Again, it is the case that the courts may be reluctant to embrace the unconscionable conduct concept in the context of commercial dealings because that context is based on significant disparity, bargaining power and knowledge which are more difficult to demonstrate in dealings between businesses.

Another point to make is that a possible consequence of that reluctance is that the court may narrowly interpret the threshold of substantial market power which is used in both provisions, accordingly rendering the attempted strengthening of new section 46 ineffective. A further point is that there is no evidence that such an extension is necessary particularly in light of the proposed substantial strengthening again of section 46. The amended section 46 will enable small business and the Trade Practices Commission to take action against anti-competitive conduct directed against agents, suppliers or distributors. Finally, the point I make is that in some respects section 46 goes further than the proposed section 46A of Senator Haines by not requiring significant disparity in bargaining power or knowledge to be established. In addition, by explicitly setting out the elements of a contravention and providing evidentiary assistance in section 46 (7) to prove those elements section 46 would in most cases be easier to prove. For that whole variety of reasons we urge the chamber to reject Senator Haines's amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition does not support this amendment by the Australian Democrats. It is introducing a whole new and extremely vague concept into the trade practices legislation. There is some basis for the Government's proposal-although the Opposition does not like it either-to introduce a test of unconscionable conduct in relation to contracts made between the buyer and seller. With this amendment there will be the introduction of this concept of unconscionable conduct between a corporation and various other people such as suppliers, agents and distributors. It will give a much wider extension of this notion of unconscionable conduct. It will be a whole new ball game for the courts to interpret. It will introduce uncertainties into business transactions, a great many of which will be increasingly burdened by this legislation, as the Opposition has been at pains to point out on a number of occasions. This particular proposal will only add to those burdens and will add to them in a vague and most uncertain fashion. For those reasons, we will oppose the Democrats' proposal.

SPEECH.PARA: Question put:
That the proposed new clause be inserted in the Bill.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Haines Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Fresh from that fairly resounding defeat at the hands of an assortment of people who from time to time express cast iron guarantees about their concern and good intentions for small business, I move on--
—To another resounding defeat.
—Probably to another resounding defeat, but one which the honourable senator is going to look considerably more embarrassed about pushing. I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (2) Page 7, after new clause 16, insert the following new clause:
``16a. Section 49 of the Principal Act is amended-
(a) by omitting sub-section (1) and substituting the following sub-section:
`(1) A corporation shall not, in trade or commerce, discriminate between purchasers or proposed purchasers of goods of like grade and quality in relation to-
(a) the prices charged or to be charged for the goods;
(b) any discounts, allowances, rebates or credits given or allowed or to be given or allowed in relation to the supply of the goods;
(c) the provision or proposed provision of services in respect of the goods; or
(d) the making of payments for services provided or to be provided in respect of the goods,

if the discrimination is of such magnitude or is of such a recurring or systematic character that it has or is likely to have the effect of lessening competition in a market for goods, being a market in which the corporation supplies, or those purchasers or proposed purchasers supply, goods.';
(b) by omitting from paragraph (2) (a) `to the purchasers; or' and substituting `or are to be supplied to the purchasers or proposed purchasers;';
(c) by inserting after paragraph (2) (b) the following word and paragraph:

`; or (c) the purchasers or proposed purchasers who do not or would not receive the benefit of the discrimination are or would be able to purchase goods of like grade and quality from a competitor of the supplier on terms in relation to the matters to which the discrimination relates no less favourable than the terms in relation to those matters available to the purchasers or proposed purchasers who receive or would receive the benefit of the discrimination.'; and
(d) by adding at the end thereof the following sub-section:
`(6) In this section, `proposed purchaser', in relation to goods, means a person who has entered into negotiations with respect to the purchase of the goods.'.''.

The Green Paper on the Trade Practices Act entitled `Proposals for change', gave considerable attention to section 49 and expressed some considerable concern about the problems of small business in its attempt to compete on reasonably equal terms with larger corporations while not adversely affecting competition. In its report it quoted some statements from the Council of Small Business Organisations of Australia Ltd. which in its 1979 submission to the Trade Practices Consultative Committee stated:

The discrimination may be of such magnitude in, for instance, a country town, that it seriously jeopardises the existence of a small trader. However, when the discrimination is related to the market place as a whole it becomes insignificant.

We must not lose sight of the fact that while across the wide spectrum of the whole market-place the disappearance of an individual small business may appear insignificant, it is not to the people concerned, nor is it to the general concept of competitiveness in the market-place and the need for that competitiveness in the market-place if not only is the small business sector to survive but also if the consumer is to get a decent deal, so to speak, out of the goods and services that are provided.

Late last year that same Council approached us on the matter having discovered that the Bill amending the Trade Practices Act, as proposed by the Government, did not, in fact, pick up the long and detailed amendment proposed in the Green Paper. It said to us that we, like a number of other political parties in this place, have indicated that we are in favour of providing adequate protection for small business from unfair competition through amendment of the Trade Practices Act. The Council went on to point out what we did, indeed, already know, namely:
. . . the Government has proposed a range of amendments most of which we-
that is COSBOA-
agree with . . .

It conceded that the amendment of section 46 may be of some assistance to small business in some special circumstances. I would have liked Senator Short to be here, but I am sure that with his usual vigilance he will read Hansard tomorrow and discover that no less an organisation than COSBOA believed that, while section 46 went some way down the track to providing assistance to small business in some cases, it certainly did not go as far as it would have liked or groups such as the Australian Petroleum Agents and Distributors Association would have liked, and which, in fact, would have been picked up by our amendment notwithstanding the uncharitable comments that the Minister for Resources and Energy (Senator Gareth Evans) had to make about it. The Council went on to make the following point:
. . . the fundamental need for protection of small business is a strengthening of section 49, Price Discrimination-

Notwithstanding that, as I have already indicated, section 46 does provide some additional assistance to small business and would have provided more if reason had prevailed in this chamber, which it rarely does. Nonetheless, additional changes needed to be made to section 49, specifically because it affects price discrimination. The Council stated:

. . . this is an area which on prima facie evidence is widely exploited by large interests to vary the market situation at the expense of small firms, which are in practice unable to make use of section 49, despite its underlying intent. There has been only one successful case under 49 in the history of the Act and that had special features. The fact that there have been no others indicates just how unusable the present legislation is.

It is unfortunate if there is a piece of legislation which purports to protect small business in some area and the lack of successful court cases under it indicates that in fact it is not as useful as it was apparently intended to be. The letter continues:

Amendments as proposed in the Government's Green Paper would have gone at least some way towards correcting the current bias in favour of big business but as you may be aware the Government reneged on its 1983 election commitment to strengthen section 49 in the face of the anticipated pressure from big interests and in the Bill now before Parliament have left 49 unchanged.

That is the nub of the matter. When it comes to a disagreement between big business in this country and small business, not only does the Australian Labor Government renege on its promises and, indeed, renege on what was a well argued case for amendment to section 49 in the Green Paper, a recommendation that followed some two years of inquiry into the matter, but so do the Opposition parties which, when it comes to the crunch, will take the side of big business against small business every time. I will just read again the paragraph from the letter that is pertinent to this matter. It states:

. . . the fundamental need for protection of small business is a strengthening of section 49, Price Discrimination, as this is an area which on prima facie evidence is widely exploited by large interests to vary the market situation at the expense of small firms.

It is a case of whoever is biggest wins. While as the Council stated in its submission to the Trade Practices Commission it may be only a small trader in a country town, it nevertheless will have a significant economic effect not only on that trader but also on the market-place in a much wider manner. The amendment we have moved, which is currently before the Chair, is an amendment lifted directly from the Green Paper. If Senator Gareth Evans can get to his feet in a minute and with any conscience at all look me or any other person in the eye in this place and come up with a substantial, believable and credible argument for why the Government will not accept this amendment, I will unhesitatingly withdraw some of the uncharitable comments I have made in the past about the honourable senator's sincerity or lack of sincerity.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I agree that the argument in favour of section 49 as expressed in the Green Paper of 1984 was a pretty good argument. I was responsible for circulating it in that form, as Senator Haines points out, but as with so many things in this world one learns from experience and from counter argument and from consultation and discussion and by reading submissions that come in. I have been persuaded, along with the rest of my colleagues in the Government, that I was wrong.
—In other words, you got rolled in Cabinet.

—No, that is not true. Let the record be clear on this. The argument at the end of the day was that section 49 of the Trade Practices Act was almost beyond redemption as an effective working clause on the concept of price discrimination. However much one twisted and stretched the various concepts that made up section 49 and however attractive an exercise it seemed to try to protect small businesses in particular, for which section 49 was originally written, the section was just destined not to work effectively. To the extent it worked effectively, it was likely to have unintended consequences, such as being a deterrence to competition, encouraging price rigidity by suppliers and having a possible backlash effect on at least one category of small businesses, namely, small business manufacturers and suppliers who would have been at risk of actions brought under this.

SPEECH.PARA: I assure Senator Haines that the conclusion to which I came, after discussions with one of her favourite lobbies-although there is a large cast of them these days-the Law Council of Australia, was that small business interests could be better protected by stiffening up and making more effective proposed section 46. That is exactly what we have done, with co-operation, understanding and thoughtfulness on the part of the Australian Democrats, who understood exactly what we are about in proposed section 46 in the way the Opposition did not. I thank them for the understanding and good sense with which they approached that clause.

The view we have reached is that the strengthening of proposed section 46 will better serve those small businesses which are the victims of anti-competitive price discrimination by suppliers possessing substantial market power or by large acquirers who induce price discrimination. The amendment to proposed section 46, as we know, also will provide evidentiary support in proving that a firm has taken advantage of its power for a particular purpose. We know what proposed section 46 is about. We can see now how it can and will operate. The Government and I genuinely believe that is the best way through this, rather than trying to fix up section 49, which regrettably is a labour of Hercules which is unlikely to be brought home successfully.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Haines Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am quite aware that the Law Council of Australia takes a different attitude than we do to section 49 of the Trade Practices Act, as does the Council of Small Business Organisations of Australia. I am aware that the Law Council's comments on the Green Paper indicated that section 49 should be repealed because it believed, as the Minister so correctly said, that proposed section 46 as amended would do the job properly. However, the Law Council of Australia does not represent a wide cross-section of small business people in the community. In fact, it frequently goes to pains to point out that it does not necessarily even represent the views of lawyers in the community. Because the Law Council of Australia-a group for which I have the greatest respect-argues that proposed section 46 helps small business, that is no justification for wiping any suggestion that perhaps small business could be aided in some other way.

SPEECH.PARA: I would have thought that the people to talk to would have been the very people who are subject to some of the measures in the market-place. Those people are represented much more accurately by a group such as COSBOA, rather than by a group such as the Law Council of Australia, however well intended and learned it may be, and I acknowledge that in the main it is both of those things. If an organisation which represents small business says `Yes, we can see that proposed section 46 goes some way to providing protection to small businesses, but does not go as far as we want it to, we need extra support in section 49', I think it should be listened to. When that is backed up by a significant argument in something like the Green Paper, I am sorry, Minister, I cannot accept that.

TALK.START.PARA: —Do you know what the Council of Small Business advised the Government on this issue?
—No, it does not normally send me copies of its letters to you.
—It advised us in favour of proposed section 46 and could not make up its mind on section 49.

—That sounds rather like the Government, in that case. We have made up our minds on this issue. We believe that we are in agreement with the Council's letter to us, which says that as far as it is concerned proposed section 46 goes some way down the track and section 49, if amended in the way suggested by the Green Paper, would go an additional distance down the track and would protect small businesses as they need to be protected increasingly in the market-place from the increasingly predatory behaviour of big business.

SPEECH.PARA: Question put:
That the proposed new clause be inserted in the Bill.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.
