DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Indonesian Refugees-Immigration Procedures-Sri Lanka: Tamil Community-Tasmania: Farmhouse Creek-Human Rights Legislation

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The question is:

INTERJECT.PARA: That the Senate do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kilgariff Sen B.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —Honourable senators will recall that today Senator Susan Ryan, in her capacity as Minister representing the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, answered a question relating to the six Indonesians who have arrived at Melville Island off the coast of the Northern Territory-in fact, just a stone's throw from Darwin. In responding to the question from my colleague Senator Teague, I do not believe that Senator Ryan directly answered the question as to whether the Indonesians were detected by coastal surveillance authorities prior to landing at Melville Island. But from the fact that Senator Ryan made no reference to the detection of these people by coastal surveillance, I suspect that they got through unannounced. I do not make this comment as any criticism of the officers involved in coastal surveillance in the north, for they are fettered. As I have said time and time again, the conditions and limitations under which they are presently operating mean that they have little real hope of detecting intruders into Australian waters or airspace.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not wish to labour the point this evening, but I feel that it must be said that so long as a group of people can turn up on Australian soil undetected we will not be safe from the dangers of drug runners, the introduction of exotic diseases and the smuggling of flora and fauna into and out of Australia. These Indonesians, who are seeking refugee status, came to our shores in a simple single-masted fishing boat. They managed to avoid detection by coast surveillance. Imagine how easy it must be for drug runners who have the advantage of more sophisticated and reliable vessels to avoid detection. Yesterday's Northern Territory News editorial made this point. It stated:
A broken down Indonesian prau can land undetected on Melville Island and disembark six Indonesian refugees who are free to roam at will for two days until discovered by chance.

As I said before, Melville Island is probably only 15 to 20 minutes flying time from Darwin. In fact, it was not so long ago that there were some trawlers hiding behind Melville Island. The editorial continued:
What else is needed to convince the Federal Government of the defencelessness of the north?
Former MHR and Defence Minister Sir Jim Killen once said that Australia could not defend Bondi Beach with a troop of boy scouts on a hot Sunday afternoon.

That statement just about sums up this country's approach to defence which is based upon the possibility that some unspecified enemy could one day attack the south eastern seaboard where most Australians live.
The Northern Territory News quite rightly described that approach as `nonsense'. It continued:

The attack, in one way or the other, if it comes at all will be on the undefended and sparsely populated north. And there is nothing there except a badly undermanned Norforce whose task is one of reconnaissance and not of defence anyway, and a few sightless gunboats.
We are told that the rapid deployment force would be flown north in case of trouble, but the RDF is a joke.
It consists of a couple of infantry battalions and some logistics. It does not have credible artillery support, surface to air missiles or any capacity for sustained action.
It is good enough for a hard day's mortar barrage and little else.

The RDF is all Australia has, in fact. On paper the Australian Army is made up of nine battalions and supporting arms. In reality the country would be flat out fielding four battalions, not enough to dislodge a determined force of paratroopers at Humpty Doo.
Humpty Doo is a security place just outside Darwin. The editorial continued:
The new Tindal RAAF base indicates a shift in Australia's defence priorities, but without ground troops to protect it against sabotage or an air drop it could become a costly liability.
None of this is new, certainly not to the top brass in the Defence Department who have long been aware of the north's pathetic vulnerability.
The Northern Territory News asked: `So why are they not taking remedial action?' The editorial stated that the answer-one that I have so often come up with in this place-was this:
The Federal Government has put the knife into defence spending.
The idea is that when funds are short the armed forces are expendable but the Arts Council, Commission for the Future, Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission and umpteen other useless bodies-
perhaps they have some use, but I would say that defence has a priority-
are not.
The Northern Territory News editorial concluded:
Australia is a rich vast continent on the periphery of Asia, one of the most turbulent and unstable regions in the world.
It will not remain free and sovereign unless Australians show more readiness to defend it.

In conclusion, I can only say that I fully concur with the views expressed in this editorial. Again I urge the Federal Government to get its priorities straight. The defence of Australia seems to be the last of its concerns. Yet this Labor Government ran on a slogan of putting Australia first. It is about time that it honoured that commitment. Northern surveillance is sick, flying time has been cut and our coastal surveillance is so depleted that time and time again we are embarrassed by simple craft or drug runners coming up to and through our front door. I have no doubt that we have the right calibre of personnel to do the job. All they require, of course, are the tools to do the job.

I wish to raise another matter tonight, a rather sad one. I raise a matter with which many honourable senators will undoubtedly be familiar-that is, the problems and delays which occur in relation to requests by constituents for assistance with immigration matters. I, along with many others, have come to expect that immigration matters will often be drawn out. Sometimes no doubt the delays are caused by the persons seeking entry-through actions such as incorrectly completing applications, et cetera and the necessity for investigations to be conducted within a reasonable time period. However, I believe there are occasions when the delays are not the fault of the person seeking to enter Australia and responsibility rests at the feet of the people dealing with the case. There is a tendency, as I say, to take delays for granted and once the matter is resolved to forget about it. But a case which came to my attention in Darwin recently has demonstrated, I believe, the sorry circumstances which can result from these delays and, perhaps, the poor handling of people-little people-by authority.

This case concerned a Mr Allan Nayda, who a number of months ago commenced the process of applying for his sister-in-law, Miss Marlee Thukrua, to come to Australia from Thailand. He obtained papers from the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs for migrant entry under the family reunion category and sent them to Miss Thukrua. According to Mr Nayda, she went on three occasions to the embassy in Bangkok to lodge the completed papers, but was told on each occasion that they could not be accepted. Finally, the papers were accepted on her fourth attempt.

When Mr Nayda was told that the processing of migrant entry would take anything up to six months he then decided to have her apply for a visitors visa. He did this because he was anxious to get her out to Australia as his wife Mala, Miss Thukrua's sister, had been critically ill with heart trouble since December 1984. Mala suffered myocardial infarction-that is, a heart attack-followed by a stroke which left her with dense paralysis down the whole left side of her body. She then suffered a debilitating bowel disease for 7 months, resulting in her becoming exceedingly frail, weak and malnourished. Further illness since December 1985 caused further gross deterioration, profound depression and loss of will to live. Mala had a strong wish to see her sister to keep her company in hospital. It was thought by her family and her doctor that her sister's company might give her more interest in life and help her to recover.

Allan Nayda telephoned the migration officer in Bangkok a number of times trying to get the matter resolved. He was requested to send a return air fare, which he arranged through Qantas Airways Ltd. When Marlee went to collect the ticket she was told by Qantas that she could not have it without a visa. Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, on the other hand, said that no visa would be issued without the ticket being presented. Allan Nayda was then told that Marlee would not be able to emigrate but that a visitor's visa would be considered if he signed a guarantee that she would return to Thailand at the end of six months. He said that he would do this in order to expedite her travel to Australia because by then the situation was getting very urgent.

During another call to Bangkok to ascertain progress, Allan Hayda, apparently in the heat of the moment, insinuated that the delay was being caused by local staff and that language problems were being caused by interpreters. The migration officer got most upset about these claims and indicated that a cable would be sent to the Darwin office explaining the whole situation but that he would be taking no further action in the case. Mr Nayda, not unnaturally, was concerned about this turn of events and my Darwin office made inquiries regarding the contents of the cable and ascertained the following information. Bangkok claimed that they had interviewed Marlee on 3 March; that her first visit was on 20 February to lodge a visitor's visa application; and that her second visit, on 25 February, was to collect a visa. The embassy claimed that she had never applied for migrant entry and had no wish to do so. The embassy claimed that she indicated that she was coming out to cook, clean and help in the house and that payment for this work would be up to Mr Nayda, the brother-in-law. The embassy said that it could not issue a visa because she was coming to work and that they could not consider migrant entry because she did not wish to emigrate. Allan Nayda denies all of this and says that it results from a misunderstanding caused by language difficulties and that the interpreter was putting words into her mouth. He described Marlee as a simple country girl who could not easily understand.

My Darwin office arranged for Mr Nayda to discuss the matter again with Immigration and Ethnic Affairs to try to press for a visitor's visa. He was advised to be totally conciliatory and to indicate that he said things in the heat of the moment because of the stress caused by his frustrations in getting the matter resolved and the stress he was under as a result of his wife's illness. My office also advised him that he should stress that Marlee was coming out only as company for his wife and to aid her recovery. This seemed to work as Immigration and Ethnic Affairs then took the line of supporting the case. With the added support of a letter from Mrs Nayda's doctor indicating how serious was her illness, Darwin Immigration and Ethnic Affairs cabled Bangkok and requested a visitor's visa be issued as soon as possible. Yesterday I was advised that Marlee is to arrive next Tuesday. Sadly, her sister, Mrs Nayda, died on Tuesday night.

As I indicated at the outset, delays are regarded as par for the course where immigration matters are concerned. There are some reasons at times for this. While some are readily accepted and understood, others are a little bit more difficult to take. It is my feeling that this is one of those cases where a little bit more willingness to listen to both Mr Nayda and Marlee Thukrua could have seen the matter resolved much earlier, with the result that Mala might have been able to see her sister before she died. Perhaps she may not even have died.

While I recognised that the officers of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs are dealing with many complex problems, I believe that is all the more reason why every effort should be made to understand what the Department's clients are requesting. It seems here that, because of the language barrier, inordinate delays and misunderstandings allowed this situation to develop unnecessarily. I believe that before officers of any government department dismiss the approaches and requests of people who do not speak English fluently they should give a bit of thought to the potential trauma and injustice which may result. This case is a perfect example of the action or inaction of sometimes insensitive processing and handling, resulting not only in trauma but also in tragedy for one family. I regret that I was unable to help Mala-a little person, an Australian migrant-who died unhappily when perhaps sympathetic treatment may have been a possible remedy.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Missen Sen A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise tonight to discuss a real problem which is affecting many of the people who are applying for migrant arrangements with Australia. In particular I intend to speak on the Tamil members of our community and Tamils who seek to leave Sri Lanka to come to this country. I wish to show that there have been fine words by our Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Hayden) and by members of the Government but they have not been matched by the actions which have been taken, particularly by the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs (Mr Hurford). I also wish to show that Tamils in Sri Lanka and Tamils in Australia who are being threatened with deportation to Sri Lanka are in grave danger because of the failure of the Government to honour its clear understanding of the position in Sri Lanka.

SPEECH.PARA: Many statements were made by the Foreign Minister and others last year and earlier recognising the tremendous communal problem in Sri Lanka-the tremendous hatreds that have been developed, the deaths, violence, torture and so forth. I wish to quote a statement that was made by Mr Hayden before he went to Sri Lanka. It was important that he should go to that country. In fact, the statement that he made almost caused the cancellation of his trip. On 12 June 1985 Mr Hayden is quoted as saying:

There is almost civil war in Sri Lanka between Sinhalese and Tamils. We have a large Sinhalese and Tamil population in Australia and we are concerned about any expressed views on human rights in Sri Lanka.
He went to Sri Lanka and expressed similar views. I think his trip was useful. He did not achieve ultimate results but I think it was very important that he made the trip at the time.

In effect, what I am saying is that what we have done in Australia so far as migration and the people who are here are concerned does not bear out the Government's fine words. I went to Sri Lanka a short time after Mr Hayden in my capacity as the Deputy Chairman of the Sri Lankan Emergency Committee. My report of the very crucial situation that existed is on the record and has been presented to the Parliament. I brought back to this country suggestions which were brought to my attention by the United States Department of State and others that I felt would have been practical and helpful in trying to resolve that dispute. Unfortunately, from that time one has noticed a declining amount of interest on the part of the Australian Government. It took a month for me to receive an indication that the suggestions that I had brought back informally from the State Department needed to be put in writing, that then the Government would consider them but that it did not like them very much.

As I have said, we have had the difficulty that the Government has not stood by the promises that it has made. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard firstly a letter I wrote to the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) on 2 September 1985 in my capacity as Chairman of the parliamentary group of Amnesty International and, secondly, the reply written on his behalf by the Hon. Lionel Bowen, then Acting Prime Minister, on 18 October 1985.
Leave granted.

Approximately ten days ago I had delivered to you, and all Members of the Federal Parliament, the report which the Amnesty Group has presented relating to work done during the recess. In particular it included a report of mine on my mission to Sri Lanka. Regrettably, it was some 3 1/2 weeks before we heard from the Foreign Minister and he has now indicated a lack of enthusiasm for the various suggestions made by officers in the State Department who asked me to refer them informally to him. Apparently he is not prepared to discuss these matters until they are formally brought to his attention by the USA.

My particular reason in writing is that all the information I am receiving indicates that the position is getting worse and worse in Sri Lanka and that ultimately countries of the Commonwealth will no doubt be asked to pick up the bill for a very considerable amount of destruction of lives and property in that sad country. I would hope that at the Commonwealth Heads of Government meeting there will be a very definite effort made to bring the competing parties to generally negotiate for a settlement. It seems that neither the Tamil nor the Government forces at the moment are prepared to disclose their hand and it could lead to a breakdown of the cease-fire, with worse consequences to follow.

I would hope that you will be well briefed on the subject before the Commonwealth Heads of Government meeting and that Australia will play an active role in trying to promote a settlement so that these various groups can live together in harmony on one island.
I will be very happy to discuss this matter with you at any time.
Yours sincerely,
Alan Missen
Senator for Victoria
Chairman
Parliamentary Group
Amnesty International
Acting Prime Minister
Canberra
Senator A. Missen
Parliament House,
Canberra, A.C.T. 2600
Dear Senator Missen
Thank you for your letter of 2 September 1985 to the Prime Minister concerning the situation in Sri Lanka.

As you may be aware, the Government has on numerous occasions made known to the Government of Sri Lanka its concern over the continuing communal violence in that country and has actively encouraged the Sri Lankan Government to seek a political compromise acceptable to all parties in the dispute. Mr Hayden, during his visit in May, held discussions with President Jayewardene, representatives of the Sri Lanka Tamil communities and the Buddhist clergy on the issue.

You will be aware of India's role, particularly since June, in bringing the Sri Lankan Government and Tamil representatives to the negotiating table in an effort to find a political solution to the inter-communal problem. The Government fully supports India's present efforts and welcomes indications that some positive developments may eventuate from these discussions.

The Commonwealth as a whole has not been active on the Sri Lanka problem because the Sri Lankans regard it as being a domestic issue and there have been no indications that either Sri Lanka or India would be prepared to accept a Commonwealth role.
Australia would of course be willing to assist in any appropriate way should India or Sri Lanka seek our (or Commonwealth) assistance to help resolve the conflict.
Yours sincerely,
Lionel Bowen

TALK.START.PARA: —In effect I was suggesting, among other things, that the Government, at the Commonwealth Heads of Government Meeting which was shortly to be held, take action to improve the deteriorating situation in Sri Lanka. Unfortunately, as indicated in the reply, this was not done. Although the Government expressed its continued interest in the problem of Sri Lanka, unfortunately that opportunity was not taken up. This was demonstrated further to me in the answer to a question I asked on 11 November 1985 and which Senator Button answered on behalf of the Prime Minister. I was asking, in effect, whether the situation in Sri Lanka had been raised by Australia or any other nation at CHOGM and what resolutions had come from it. I received a detailed answer from Senator Button in which he said that the President of Sri Lanka had raised the subject of troubles in the north and east of Sri Lanka and apparently reaffirmed his belief in the democratic principle and great ideals of non-violence and that at CHOGM the Sri Lankan Prime Minister raised privately with our Prime Minister remarks by our Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) comparing the situation in Sri Lanka with that in South Africa. He went on to say:

SPEECH.PARA: The Prime Minister dissociated the Australian Government from that position adopted by the Leader of the Opposition.

At CHOGM all we had was not a raising by us of the real problem but a disassociation by the Prime Minister from remarks of the Leader of the Opposition which clearly were rightly made. I had asked whether any proposals had been made at the meeting for resolution of this escalating unrest. Senator Button in his answer to me went on to say:
I am advised that the answer to that question is no.
He further said:

The answer that I have been provided with is that Australia remains deeply concerned by the continuation of the communal conflicts in Sri Lanka and has actively encouraged the Sri Lankan Government to seek a political compromise.

But at the Commonwealth Heads of Government Meeting the Prime Minister and other leaders did not raise this question. Following that chance to raise in an informal way with those leaders of government this problem which worried most of the countries of the Commonwealth, it was disappointing that nothing was done. On 5 December of last year I asked a question of Senator Button, again on behalf of the Prime Minister. In light of this failure, I asked:

Firstly, what is the present position of the Australian Government's policy in respect to Sri Lanka, and has it altered its policy and procedure in regard to the admission and protection of Tamil refugees? Secondly, why is the Government now advising many Tamils who were granted refuge in Australia in the years since 1983 to return to Sri Lanka or they will be deported? Thirdly, does the Government consider that it is now safe for them to return to Sri Lanka and, if so, on what grounds was this judgment made?

I based that question on specific facts given to me by the Tamil organisations, people who have been in Australia for some time. They were being told that they should go back. In fact the Defence of Refugee Status Committee was even questioning them and saying: `There is no real proof that you as a person may be injured or attacked and therefore we cannot treat you as a class'. That is an absurdity to anyone who knows the position in Sri Lanka and who knows the Tamils in that country are in grave danger at present and were at that time. Senator Button, in his reply, gave an answer which has been used and relied upon by the Tamil community in this country and by people who are seeking to stay here. I regard it as of the greatest seriousness that this undertaking given by Senator Button on behalf of the Prime Minister is not being observed at present. He indicated that the Government remained concerned about the communal problems and then he went on to make this important statement:

Following the disturbances, arrangements were made to expedite consideration of Sri Lankan migrant entry cases to Australia and to approve for entry under the special humanitarian program those who were adversely affected by the disturbances-mainly Tamil people. More than 730 persons have been given special visas under the special humanitarian program.
Then, very importantly, he added this statement:
In addition, temporary entrants to Australia who had fears about returning to Sri Lanka have been permitted to extend their entry permits and they will not be threatened by deportation.

That is a very important undertaking. Of course, one would expect it to be observed. It was given by Senator Button on behalf of the Prime Minister. I regret that the intimidation and the attempts to get people out of this country now do not stand four square with that undertaking. There are indeed reasons why people may fear to go back. There are reasons why some 200 members of the Tamil community in Australia came here yesterday. They are concerned with the threat to people-people who will be returned. As I will show, the general result is that those people may be imprisoned and tortured if they go back. Let me give some of the reasons why that fear is quite valid. The Civil Rights Movement of Sri Lanka is a very fine organisation which tries to deal with civil rights matters between the races and since 1971 has been dealing with the cases of people who are ill-treated, put in detention for long periods, tortured and suffer death in custody. These things have gone on and are becoming worse. In a report dated 1 January of this year the Civil Rights Movement of Sri Lanka said:

It is in this context that CRM once again voices its concern about a series of arrests of leftists in the South who are being held either under the emergency regulations or the Prevention of Terrorism Act allegedly for `terrorist activities' and for complicity with armed separatists in the North. These persons are being held in various police stations, often under acutely uncomfortable physical conditions and in general, CRM understands, without the right of access to family or lawyers. CRM is aware of at least one instance where the family was not even informed of the prisoner's whereabouts.

It went on to say that the number was over 100 already and that these are well known people who were engaged in political life. That is one piece of evidence. Further evidence is the statement which Amnesty International, after investigation of this matter, made in a Press release on 30 December 1985. Amnesty had already released a full report of its investigations of the Sir Lankan situation in the years before. In its Press statement Amnesty International said:
Amnesty International today, 30 December 1985, announced that it had called on the Sri Lankan Government to act urgently to stop torture by government forces.
It went on to give details of that and then said:

Amnesty International amassed and checked the evidence of torture in Sri Lanka in line with its usual practice using sworn affidavits, interviewing torture victims, and examining evidence from a range of sources. medical experts experienced in examining torture victims found evidence consistent with torture allegations in three Sri Lankan witnesses they examined outside the country.

Amnesty keeps pressing this fact, which of course the Government denies. The latest information is in a report called Emergency Sri Lanka which I received only today. As Deputy Chairman of the Emergency Committee on Sri Lanka of International Alert, I am pleased that we now have a record which tells us of the worsening situation in that country. The Chairman of that Committee, Dame Judith Hart, was recently in Sri Lanka and India. I quote from the International Alert report:

In a press briefing in Geneva on her return from her mission, Dame Judith announced that she had advised President Jayawardene and members of his cabinet of the intention of the International Emergency Committee to advocate the cessation of government aid to Sri Lanka pending a political settlement acceptable to the peoples of Sri Lanka. It would be recommended that a fund be established to assist in the implementation of a peaceful, political solution and the rehabilitation of the economy and the well-being of the Sri Lankan peoples.

This report, which I urge honourable senators to read, contains remarks which show that in recent times there has been a colossal destruction of civilian life in the community. The Roman Catholic Bishop of Mannar, Thomas Soundaranayagam, is quoted at page 29 of our report as saying:

Sri Lankan forces are conducting a harsh and remorseless campaign among the island's Tamil minority. By means of random murder, indiscriminate trigger-happy soldier keep the Tamils in the north in a state of constant fear. With the vanishing of reason, the fight against Tamil separatist terrorists now has the shrill tones of naked ethnic struggle. The predominantly Sinhalese army seems to have a free hand as it cracks down on the civilian population in the overwhelming Tamil northern province.
Likewise, the Civil Rights Movement of Sri Lanka is quoted as saying in its report:

Mass arrests of Tamil youth are being carried out. Detainees in the custody of the state have been killed. Some members of the security forces have carried out massive reprisals against the civilian population and, in the course of their operations, have killed many people and caused much damage to private property, burning and destroying homes and farms.

I suggest those are reasons why Tamils in this country-some caught here because they were out of their country at the time and others who have come here by one means or another, and who are unable to go back and, as Senator Button has said, will not be forced to go back-are worried about this situation. Indeed, the figures shown to me and the material given to me by the Tamil organisations show that some 376 people have been killed since November alone. Some 6,000 have been killed altogether in the last few years. If one feels that there is some doubt about the situation there is no doubt about it in the eyes of the Department of Foreign Affairs in this country because in the Age of Wednesday, 26 February 1986, the following article headed `Sri Lanka warning' appeared:
The Department of Foreign Affairs has advised people going to Sri Lanka to avoid the northern and eastern regions for safety reasons.

One should say that those who are Tamils should avoid those areas for more than safety reasons alone. I wrote to Mr Hayden on 17 February this year and suggested that we take up this matter with the United Nations Commission on Human Rights of which we are a member to show that our actions are as strong as our previous words. I do not know whether we have already done so. These events are not accidental. It can be seen that they are the result of a deliberate policy on the part of the Sri Lankan Government. I want to quote from an interview with President Jayewardene that appeared in India Today of 15 December of last year in which he indicated the arrogance of his Government and its determination to use military means to achieve the desired result. With regard to Rajiv Gandhi, who has taken a very important interest in this matter, Mr Jayewardene was asked the following question:
Is Rajiv more inclined towards your point of view.
Mr Jayewardene gave the following answer:
There is only one point of view and that is the Sri Lankan's. It is universal.

There is no question of the Tamils having a point of view at all. Later in the interview, Mr Jayewardene went on to say-his statement is a most significant statement because he thought that such an allegation was made by extremists only-that the cease-fire which was arranged last year was for the purpose of enabling the Sri Lankan Government to arm. He was asked the following question:
Is it true that the cease-fire is only an attempt to buy time by both your government and the militants.
President Jayewardene answered:

Yes. We were not ready earlier. Now we are acquiring arms and getting our soldiers trained. We are getting ready for decisive military action if nothing comes out of the negotiations. We will mobilise world opinion and convince others that it is not a racial or ethnic problem but a terrorist problem. Already there is a strong feeling that we should stop all these talks and strike again.
To show the extent to which the Sri Lankan Government is planning further destruction of that country, I quote the following question:
Are you preparing yourself for the worst?
Mr Jayewardene replied:

I am not fully prepared to tackle Jaffna. I want to finish first with the other provinces. It is not difficult to handle Jaffna. We can cut off food and supplies to the peninsula and flush out the terrorists in a month's time. But will India support our action?

I have shown that the staffing of towns, the use of new supplies of arms from the Russians, the Israelis and other sources and the periods of discussion have been used to strengthen the Government's position. Democracy in Sri Lanka does not exist in any real sense. I refer to recent speeches made by the Indians to the United Nations Commission on Human Rights. On 5 March 1986, Dr G. S. Dhillon, leader of the Indian delegation, had this to say about the current situation:

The Commission on Human Rights is meeting at a time when the condition of minorities in Sri Lanka has become very precarious. The Commission has in its deliberations in the past shown its concern for the minorities in Sri Lanka. The very serious escalation in violence in the Northern and Eastern provinces of Sri Lanka, however, poses a challenge now to all those in this Commission who are concerned about the human rights.
It is a shame Australia was not saying this. He went on:

There is very clear evidence now emanating that violence directed against the Tamil minorities is indiscriminate and makes no distinction between those engaged in conflict and innocent civilians . . . For us, and for all the friends of Sri Lanka, these are developments that we view with justified disquiet and unease.

We ought to recognise that that is the fact. The democracy of Sri Lanka has been described in the following terms, terms which are a fair and accurate description of what people who go back there will expect to face:

The reluctance to hold general elections, the banning of the opposition press, the continued reliance on extraordinary powers unknown to a free democracy, arbitrary detention without access to lawyers or relations, torture of detainees on a systematic basis, the intimidation of the judiciary by the executive, disenfranchisement of the opposition, an executive President who holds undated letters of resignation from members of the legislature, an elected President who publicly declares his lack of care for the lives or opinion of a section of his electorate, and the continued subjugation of the Tamil people by a permanent Sinhala majority, within the confines of an unitary constitutional frame, constitute the reality of `democracy', Sri Lankan style.

Is this the type of conditions to which we would send these people back? If the Government wants any evidence that people who may be sent back from Australia would suffer, I have a list, which I will only run through, of people who have been sent back by various countries. I refer to a telex received from the Tamil Information Centre in London, dated 3 March 1986. In 1982 the West German Government deported 93 Tamil youths after negotiations and assurances by the Sri Lankan Government that they would not be arrested, but when these youths arrived on a special flight chartered by the West German Government they were all taken into custody. This was reported by the Press and by the people and by members of the foreign Press and Amnesty International who accompanied the 93 Tamil youths on their trip. In November 1984, 30 Tamil youths were deported from Italy suspected of drug involvement. They have disappeared. The Sri Lankan Government does not know where they are but thinks that they might have turned up in Inida. In December 1984 four Tamil youths deported from Italy were arrested on their arrival at the airport. No news of them is available. Several others are said to have gone on various planes but they have not reached their families and homes. Their fates are unknown. On 5 October 1985 a statement by Mr Lalith Atholathmudali, the Security Minister, was reported in a Tamil newspaper, Virakesari, as follows:
Tamil refugees deported from Switzerland will be arrested if necessary.

There are many other cases where this has happened. What is the situation here in Australia? It is important to realise that these people face considerable danger. Some have been arrested in Melbourne, despite statements by Senator Button. Two youths, Thilagarajah and Gnana-Sivam, are in custody despite Senator Button's statement of 5 December. They are in custody, and have been for many months. They were arrested on 5 December. In February 1986 another visitor, Miss Shan-Mugam, based on Senator Button's statement, asked for her stay to be extended as she was afraid to return to Jaffna as the situation was acute. That request was refused by the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs and the Minister's letter stated that she had said that she would return in her visa application, and that was held against her. Many of the people who are here have been getting letters like the one which went to Mr S. Vettivel, dated 24 January 1986. I seek leave to incorporate that letter in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The letter read as follows-
DEPARTMENT OF IMMIGRATION
AND ETHNIC AFFAIRS
24 January 1986
Mr S Vettivel
3 Plunket Street
HEIDELBERG VIC 3081
Dear Mr Vettivel
I refer to your application for an extension of stay in Australia as a visitor.

When you applied for your visa at the Australian High Commission at Colombo you signed a declaration that, among other things, you would leave Australia at or before the end of your authorized visit period. The issue of a visitor visa constitutes acceptance that this declaration is made in good faith and will be honoured. There is provision for the grant of an extension of stay but only where special or changed circumstances exist.

Your application has been carefully considered but in the absence of circumstances which would warrant an exception to normal visitor policy, I must inform you that it has not been approved. I must also inform you that you do not have the right of appeal to the Immigration Review Panel, which is an independent review body that reports to the Minister.
Consequently you are expected to leave Australia by the date of expiry of your current temporary entry permit, that is 25 February 1986.
Yours sincerely
NINA NIKOLIC-KURZ
for Regional Director

TALK.START.PARA: —In this letter it is said that his visa has expired and that he is expected to leave by the date of expiry of his current temporary entry permit-25 February 1986. Many people are in that position and the Department is trying to get them out. Perhaps it will not deport them; perhaps it is just trying to bluff them into going back to their country, which would be an utter disaster for them. Mr Lewis Kent, a Labor member of the House of Representatives, who has taken a very considerable interest in this matter, wrote to the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs on 10 January giving the names of four important people who have been active in Tamil organisations and who, if they go back to Sri Lanka, will be disastrously treated. The Sri Lankan Government knows of their involvement and, as he said in his letter to the Minister:

SPEECH.PARA: It is obvious from the above that the four would be subject to political persecution in addition to racial persecution that faces all Tamils in Ceylon.
In addition to that I have a letter from Hannah Downie, who is well known in Western Australia for her work in Amnesty International. She says:
The issues Amnesty International is particularly concerned with are:

1. Erratic treatment of would-be refugees or change of status applicants who are Tamils. Some have been served with deportation notices (even if these have subsequently been lifted after protest or legal appeals), despite requests by UNHCR and Amnesty International not to refoule Tamils at this time.

2. Long detention periods for those whose papers are irregular, for example two men recently released from Perth Immigration Detention Centre had been in detention 107 days and their situation is still not clear; a further five have been detained in Sydney since November.

I have considerable information about the further five in Sydney and I just wish to say this: These are people who came out of their country when the worst riots took place. They came here and within a day they had through Amnesty International told the Government that they were here and that they were seeking refugee status. They said that they dare not go back to Sri Lanka because their names were known to the Sri Lankan Government. These four women and one man have been held in custody since October last year and the Tamil community of this country has given guarantees that they will look after the five if they are released from custody and if they can work while their various appeals are being heard. But they are still being kept there in gaol and to make things even worse they are being billed for very substantial sums because the Government claims that it is costing so much money to keep them in detention. One man has been given a bill for 42 days at $37 a day-a total of $1,554 for the `pleasure' of being kept in detention by this Government.

I must say that the Government's attitude, which is exemplified by the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, who will not see me-I have tried to see him for some months but he will not agree to a meeting-is one of complete hypocrisy. This attitude is completely inconsistent with the declarations that the Foreign Minister and the Prime Minister have made in the past. The Government is trying to get these people out of this country by a form of intimidation. I believe it is thought that if we detain them long enough something will change in Sri Lanka. It is clear that nothing will happen in Sri Lanka; I fear that the position there is getting worse. The Sri Lankan Government is mad and does not realise that it is destroying that country in this way. I believe that we in this country should take a strong stand to show that our actions measure up to our words. They have not done so. I expect an answer from the Minister for Education (Senator Ryan), who is at the table tonight. I do not know whether she knows about the matter, but both the Ministers who are concerned have been informed about it and should have provided some answers. I believe this is a disgrace which is besmirching Australia's name.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian people must be wondering what on earth is happening in Tasmania in that area called Farmhouse Creek. Let me tell honourable senators about it. Farmhouse Creek is a small area in the State Forest and it is designated as a timber production area. It is within the concession of Australian Newsprint Mills Ltd and is 7 1/2 kilometres from the wilderness area, from the South West National Park which I am sure, Mr President, you will have heard of on many occasions in relation to the Franklin dam. The conservationists glibly talk about wilderness areas, national park areas and National Estate areas in one voice as though they were all the same thing. They are very far from the same thing. Today Dr Bob Brown said that the Commonwealth has undoubted power to stop the destruction of the forests south of Farmhouse Creek and in our other heritage areas.

SPEECH.PARA: Dr Bob Brown, a member of parliament in Tasmania, is talking about Farmhouse Creek as though it were a heritage area. I can assure honourable senators that it is not a heritage area. Today the Minister for Primary Industry, Mr Kerin, got quite angry about exactly the same thing. I quote a news report which states:
Farmhouse Creek in Tasmania was neither a highly sensitive wilderness area nor ranked for World Heritage listing.
He told parliament that many statements from conservation groups about the region were not factual.
These included claims that it was World Heritage ranked, that it was a wilderness area and that it was a rainforest region.
The National Estate value of Farmhouse Creek was based on old growth forest habitat.

Mr Kerin pointed out very strongly that Dr Brown was not speaking factually, to put it very politely. The World Heritage area and national parks are very different from the National Estate. They are true wilderness areas and are fully protected. The National Estate is quite different. Anyone can nominate an area for the National Estate. Indeed I can nominate your land, Mr President. Whether it would stick is a totally different matter. But once the decision is made to put it on the National Estate Register the only influence the Commonwealth has is under section 30 of the Act which gives power to the Commonwealth Minister to refuse to issue export licences for materials that have come from that area. The Commonwealth has the power to stop any exports, not domestic products, from National Estate areas. Moreover, there is considerable indirect pressure on any company or any individual whose private property has been put on the National Estate Register because once it is listed the conservationists certainly apply pressure, particularly in such areas as I have mentioned, for it to be included as a wilderness area.

We have to bear in mind that 31 per cent of my State is already listed, or has been nominated, for the National Estate. That is nearly a third of my State. How would honourable members like one third of New South Wales to be nominated for the National Estate? It is really quite ridiculous. As I have said, there is a very big difference. According to the report of the Wilderness Society entitled `Wilderness Assessment Management' when all the State forests outside the national parks are logged 4,234 square kilometres of wilderness will still remain in Tasmania. However, that is not enough for the Society; it wants 9,148 square kilometres which is 80 per cent more wilderness than we have at present. These are the Society's figures and are very conservative because they exclude the buffer zones that are around all the wilderness areas. If we let it have its way jobs will certainly be in jeopardy because one in seven Tasmanians who are working have jobs which are tied up with the timber industry.

The areas in dispute are mature eucalypt forests. If they are not harvested now they will be lost forever because they are coming to the end of their life. Other trees will take over and the whole forest will change character. Anyone who argues with that just does not know what forestry is all about. The need for top quality logs by sawmillers is paramount in order for them to keep their business viable. They must have access to top quality logs as well as to lower quality logs.

They must have top quality logs in sufficient numbers, otherwise the balance of their industry is completely destroyed. Is it any wonder, bearing in mind what I have already said, that tempers are running high when so much of Tasmania has already been set aside for wilderness. I believe the forestry workers have been very restrained. When Dr Bob Brown moved in and lay under the wheels of the excavators he was indeed removed for his own safety. He was pulled out from under the wheels of the excavators, I believe, and tossed in the bushes. He was not hurt.

We have a tremendous amount of machinery lying idle down there. For the last week we have had all this heavy machinery lying idle at a cost of $4,500 a day. I ask honourable senators how they would feel if their livelihood were wrapped up in that sort of high cost machinery. It is for that reason that the forestry workers have taken the law into their own hands and moved the conservationists-gently-from under the wheels of their machinery. We had a journalist from the Australian newspaper, Bruce Montgomery, in our area reporting on the situation. As he said, he did not see any punches thrown, although accusations were made later. I am quite sure that all honourable senators would know that if there were any punches thrown journalists would not miss them. They would see them. So I claim that the forestry workers acted in a very restrained manner in the situation.

It is for this reason that the State Government has now declared the area out of bounds. Today 31 arrests have been made. We again have the situation we in Tasmania call `rent-a-cono'. We have the rent-a-conservationists down in that park, being arrested and taken to gaol. If they do not promise not to return to the Farmhouse Creek area they will spend some time locked up.

TALK.START.PARA: —While they are down there they are leaving the Daintree alone.

—That may be very comfortable for Senator Collard but I would rather they went to Queensland. It has got to the stage where it is not funny. We have men wanting to go about their daily work. We have men with a lot of money in the form of overdrafts tied up in heavy machinery who are not able to use it and not able to work. A whole week has gone by without any work because of these conservationists who, with all the best will in the world, as they see it, believe they have the right to overcome the wishes of the majority of Tasmanians. I say that with great authority because it is only a couple of months ago that the Tasmanian Liberal Government was re-elected with a five per cent increase. The people of Tasmania have spoken very clearly about the way they want to have their forests managed. Yet this small group of, I believe, irresponsible people are down there trying to take the law into their own hands. I am absolutely appalled that this is going on once again.

SPEECH.PARA: I know that Mr Kerin is concerned. He has already come out today and said that he is very concerned that the conservationists are taking that action. He has said that under his agreement with Mr Gray the bridge across Farmhouse Creek is to be built and that the road is to go through. As he pointed out, that was all allowed for under the agreement. I sincerely hope that the conservationists accept the fact that an agreement has been made between the Commonwealth and the State. Much and all as they may not like it, an agreement has been reached. They are behaving illegally and they must withdraw from that area.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vanstone Sen A.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight I raise a matter which related to the propriety with which I believe honourable senators should behave towards each other even within the parliamentary system. I have some comments to make with respect to some remarks that have been made by Senator Haines. I have informed Senator Haines, through her office, that I intend to do so this evening to give her the opportunity of attending to listen to my remarks. Should she wish to reply to them that opportunity will obviously be available to her. It is possible that she is in her office at the moment listening to the radio and, in the near future, she will come into the Senate. It is equally possible that she has gone home. I can say only that time will tell what is the case.

SPEECH.PARA: The matter I raise is one of grave concern not only for me as a senator but particularly for me as a senator for South Australia because the remarks that I make obviously relate to another South Australian senator, namely, Senator Haines. I raise this matter this evening apropos of it being raised with me by two of my coalition colleagues. One is Alexander Downer, the honourable member for Mayo-a seat in South Australia-and the other is Peter McGauran, the honourable member for Gippsland. Both of these gentlemen did radio interviews at separate times with Senator Haines on the same subject matter, namely, the package of Bills that are loosely referred to as the human rights Bills. Each of these gentlemen raised with me their concern about remarks made by Senator Haines. I think I can fairly represent their views by saying that they believe that she grossly misrepresented the Opposition's view on the radio.

The first interview undertaken with Senator Haines was by Mr Downer. Mr Downer was making some comments with respect to the proposed Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission and as reported to me, Senator Haines made remarks to the effect that she could not understand why Mr Downer would be making these comments given that the Opposition had allowed the legislation to pass the night before almost without a whimper. Mr Downer, coming from that other place, and this being a radio interview early in the morning, felt somewhat caught out. He could not instantly check up on what had happened the night before and so he let the remark pass but he insisted that he had adequately and appropriately represented the Opposition's view. As I understand it there was no backdown by Senator Haines with respect to the view that she put forward. As luck would have it for the Opposition, Mr Downer pursued this matter and came across Mr MacGauran who was doing an interview with Senator Haines later in the day. Of course, by this time the opportunity had been made available to check exactly what had happened the night before. The same allegation was raised that the Opposition had allowed this legislation to pass without a whimper. I have with me two letters from these gentlemen which are addressed to me. I seek leave to incorporate them in Hansard to save the time of reading them to the chamber.
Leave granted.
The letters read as follows-
13 March 1986
Senator Amanda Vanstone,
Parliament House,
Canberra, A.C.T. 2600
Dear Amanda,
I am writing to you concerning an incident which occurred during a radio debate between me and Senator Janine Haines which is of very real concern to me.

During the debate there was some discussion about the role of the Human Rights and Equal Opportunities Commission and I spelt out the Opposition's concerns about this body. Senator Haines responded that my protestations were empty because of the night of 11 March the Human Rights and Equal Opportunities Bill had been passed by the Senate and the Opposition had not voted against the Bill.
I have subsequently discovered that this statement was totally false. The Bill has not been passed by the Senate.
I should be grateful if you could raise this incident in the Senate as it is a cause of great concern to me that a Senator should make such grossly dishonest statements.
I am sure you will recognise the irony of this falsehood coming from the Deputy Leader of a Party which claims its role is to ``keep the bastards honest''.
Yours sincerely,
Alexander Downer
Member for Mayo
13 March 1986
Senator Amanda Vanstone,
Senator for South Australia
Room 481
Parliament House
Canberra, A.C.T. 2600
Dear Senator Vanstone,

You have asked me to confirm in writing my recollection of a particular aspect of a radio debate on the Bill of Rights with Senator Janine Haines, conducted by Radio 3UL Warragul at 11.15 a.m. on Wednesday 12 March 1986.

The interviewer, Mr Ron Burke, addressed his first question to Senator Haines. He asked her what was her response to the objections raised to the increased powers given to the Human Rights Commission.

During the course of her reply Senator Haines stated that the legislation establishing the Human Rights and Equal Opportunities Commission had been passed by the Senate the previous night and had not been opposed by the Opposition. She then made a comment about how serious the Opposition could be in its concern in regard to the Human Rights and Equal Opportunities Commission when it did not speak or vote against it in the Senate.

When Mr Burke asked me why the Opposition did not oppose the legislation, I replied that the legislation has not been passed by the Senate and that it was in committee stage with the committee reporting progress the previous night. Further more the Opposition had voted against the legislation at the Second Reading stage and would vote against it at the Third Reading stage.
Yours sincerely,
PETER McGauran
Member for Gippsland

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. My complaints are simply these: Given that that is the case-I have no reason to suspect that it is not the case-Senator Haines has either knowingly or, in complete and utter ignorance, grossly misrepresented the position of the Opposition. I remind honourable senators that, on 19 February, this package of Bills was put to the vote on the second reading. While Senator Haines voted with the ayes the Opposition voted with the noes. I would have thought that anyone making a comment about the Opposition's view would have borne that in mind. I would have thought that someone making that sort of comment would have referred to the contribution that the Opposition made in the Committee stage, but I am informed that that is not the case.

SPEECH.PARA: Naturally, when a matter such as this is raised, the first thing that we do-it is the first thing that I do and I assume it is the first thing that a number of other people do-is to ask why. Why would someone do this sort of thing? We are not talking of a new senator caught unawares by a snap radio interview; these were planned interviews. We are not talking about a senator who has made an off the cuff remark and who was not familiar with the passage of the Bills. Senator Haines has involved herself quite solidly with the passage of these Bills. We are not talking about someone who does not have access to Hansard to check what was said. So we ask why. The first thing we might ask is: `Was this deliberate?' We have to say: `Surely not, given that the Australian Democrats have as their slogan ``Let's keep the bastards honest'' '. We surely could not instantly come to the conclusion that this was deliberately done. So we move on to another option and ask: `Was it lack of care?'. We would have to say the same thing again: `Surely not, given the Democrats' purported regard for the parliamentary process and given their purported regard for things being done properly, honestly, openly and above board'. We would have to say that Senator Haines could not walk into a radio interview, so ill-prepared as to grossly misrepresent the Opposition's point of view.

So the next question we come to is: `If it was not out of deliberate motive and it was not a lack of care, was it out of ignorance?' We would have to say the same thing again: `Surely not. Surely an experienced senator, a deputy leader of her own Party, does not make comments on national radio in ignorance of what has happened the night before'. So I cannot offer the answer as to why this has happened, but I raise the matter and indicate that I am not happy that it has happened, that any senator would do this, least of all a senator for South Australia and least of all one from a party which purports to be the party that will keep the rest of us honest. The facts are that the Opposition voted against the second reading of this Bill, that the Bills are being dealt with as a whole in the Committee stage. To say that we let the Bill pass without a whimper is a gross misrepresentation of our position. It is true that on 11 March at the end of the Committee stage of the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission Amendment Bill, no division was called. But you, Mr President, and I, and everyone else know that to say, from that, that the Opposition let it pass without a whimper is to grossly misrepresent the situation.

Lest it be thought that I am being unfair to Senator Haines let me say that I am aware of the fact that she has privately apologised, but it is my view that for such an indiscretion, deliberate, in ignorance or otherwise, a private apology for such a public misrepresentation on two separate radio stations is simply not adequate. I believe Senator Haines should do the right thing. She should acknowledge her error. I will call it that for want of a better description because, as I said, I cannot decide what the motive is, I cannot choose the appropriate word but I think she should acknowledge her error publicly through the Senate and through a Press statement. I would think that that would be the honest thing to do for a deputy leader of a party that purports to be here to keep the rest of us honest.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —A number of matters were raised on the adjournment debate tonight. Senator Kilgariff raised his concerns about the information I gave at Question Time on the six Indonesians who have come into Australia. I gave Senator Kilgariff all the information that was available to me at the time and I will refer his further concerns to the appropriate Minister. Similarly, Senator Missen raised a number of matters concerning immigration and foreign affairs; concerns which I will refer to the appropriate Ministers.
—Is that all you have to say?

—Yes, that is all I have to say. I think the honourable senator raised some very detailed matters and I am not in possession of material by which I could give an adequate response. Senator Walters expressed her views about what is happening on an environmental issue in her State of Tasmania. Senator Vanstone, of course, has raised matters which are directed to the Australian Democrats, and it is for them to respond.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.
Senate adjourned at 11.34 p.m.
